Article 0 — Global Definitions and Rules of Interpretation

Section 1. General Rules
Unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
	•	Terms defined in this Article apply throughout the Constitution. 
	•	Terms defined in specific Articles shall have the meaning given there when used in that Article or in closely related provisions. 
	•	Where a term defined in this Article is reproduced elsewhere, Section 5.5 governs.
	•	Words importing the singular include the plural, and vice versa. 
	•	Words importing the masculine include the feminine and neuter. 
	•	The present tense includes the future tense where context permits. 
	•	“Shall” is mandatory; “may” is permissive. 
	•	“Person” includes natural persons, legal entities, and—where contextually appropriate and consistent with Article XXVI—recognized sentient non-human entities. 
	•	Courts shall construe genuine ambiguities in favor of liberty, accountability, transparency, and the sovereignty of the People, consistent with the text, structure, and express purposes of this Constitution, except where a provision explicitly authorizes restraint of power. 
	•	No interpretation shall give effect to evasive structuring, nominal compliance, or formalism designed to defeat constitutional purpose.
	•	No interpretation shall give effect to collusion, tacit coordination, proxy action, or public-private concerted conduct designed to suppress lawful rights, lawful competition, or constitutional accountability; courts shall treat such conduct as constitutionally void, regardless of nominal legality.
Section 2. Consolidated Defined Terms
	•	Beneficial ownership — Direct or indirect control, equity, coordination, or decision-making power, evaluated by substance over form, including control by contract, debt leverage, proxy voting, board capture, veto rights, or coordinated action (Articles IX, XVII).
	•	Causation (for Evil Designation) — “Causation” means a demonstrated causal connection between the conduct and the Serious Harm, proven by competent evidence.
	•	Civic Citizen — A lawful resident recognized as holding baseline political authority (1× Civic Standing) after satisfying the prerequisites of Article III, including passing the Civic Competence Exam and swearing any required oath; eligible to participate in the franchise as defined in Article III. Article III is lock-protected under Article XV.
	•	Civic Competence Exam — A rigorous, AI-administered test of constitutional knowledge, logic, fallacy detection, and manipulation resistance required for baseline Civic Citizenship (Article III-A).
	•	Civic Standing - The verified civic weight used only for political authority (baseline 1√ó plus earned points), earned prospectively under Article III, non-transferable, and subject to reduction or forfeiture only as expressly provided. "Civic Multiplier" is a legacy synonym and shall be treated as identical to Civic Standing (Article III).
	•	Coercive rituals — “Coercive rituals” means practices that involve: 1. physical injury, 2. sexual exploitation, 3. confinement, 4. forced ingestion, 5. or credible threats of harm, and shall not include voluntary cultural, religious, or symbolic practices. (Cross-reference: Article II.)
	•	Coercion — Physical, psychological, economic, social, spiritual, ideological, or immigration-based pressure that materially impairs free consent or free exercise of constitutional rights. (Cross-references: Articles XXXIII, XXXIV, II §0(e)) 
	•	Collusion — Any knowing or reckless coordination, inducement, or concerted action between any public actor (including any office of public trust, agency, delegate, contractor, or agent) and any private actor that has the purpose or reasonably foreseeable effect of suppressing lawful rights, lawful competition, lawful entry, lawful innovation, or constitutional accountability, including by tacit coordination, proxies, or procedural laundering (Articles X, XI, XXVII, XXX, XLII).
	•	Concerted conduct — Coordinated or mutually reinforcing action by two or more actors, whether express or tacit, formal or informal, direct or by proxy, including parallel conduct where independent justification is lacking.
	•	Constitutional Judicial Commission (CJC) — The independent constitutional body charged with protecting the integrity, independence, continuity, and anti-capture safeguards of the judicial and constitutional system.
	•	Constitutional Review Court (CRC) — The specialized constitutional court with original jurisdiction to adjudicate the constitutionality, validity, and legal effect of laws, executive actions, emergency declarations, and constitutional amendments as assigned herein. Decisions of the Constitutional Review Court shall be final unless accepted for appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic, or unless the Constitutional Review Court certifies that a matter presents complexity, novelty, or institutional consequence requiring full appellate consideration.
	•	Controlled Setting — “Controlled Setting” means a Licensed Medical Facility or a specifically licensed clinical site that provides continuous supervision, controlled access, secure storage, secure disposal, and documented clinical protocols sufficient to prevent diversion and to protect public order. 
	•	Corporation — Any for-profit or nonprofit legal entity recognized by law, existing solely by privilege and not as a natural or moral person (Article XVII). 
	•	CRC–CJC Separation Rule — The Constitutional Review Court and the Constitutional Judicial Commission are distinct and non-substitutable constitutional bodies. No power granted to one may be exercised by the other unless this Constitution expressly so provides. Where ambiguity exists, interpretive authority belongs in the first instance to the CRC, subject to appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic, and institutional-integrity authority belongs to the CJC.
	•	Crime — Conduct expressly prohibited by law enacted in conformity with this Constitution and accompanied by a defined penalty (Article VII). 
	•	Culpable inaction — Knowledge of foreseeable, material harm combined with a failure to act where action was reasonably possible constitutes culpable wrongdoing.
	•	Dangerous ideological indoctrination — “Dangerous ideological indoctrination” means the intentional conditioning of persons, especially minors or dependents, through coercion, isolation, or psychological manipulation, to compel unlawful violence, self-harm, or surrender of autonomy. It shall not include peaceful teaching, advocacy, religious instruction, political belief, or dissent. (Cross-reference: Article II.)
	•	Demographic Engineering — Any deliberate policy, incentive structure, coercive measure, or combination thereof intended to alter the composition, fertility rates, cultural character, or demographic balance of the population for ideological, political, economic, or electoral purposes. (Cross-references: Articles I §7, XXII, XXV, XXVIII)
	•	Disinformation — False information disseminated with intent to defraud, incite violence, corrupt justice, manipulate markets, or endanger safety through direct causation of criminal harm.
	•	Due process — Fair notice, impartial adjudication, meaningful opportunity to be heard, lawful procedure, timely resolution, and availability of effective remedy prior to any deprivation of life, liberty, or property. (Cross-references: Article XXVI; Article II §5)
	•	Due Process and Contestability (for Evil Designation) — “Due Process and Contestability” means any designation or adjudication under the state meaning of “evil” requires timely notice of allegations, disclosure of the evidence relied upon except as strictly necessary to protect narrowly defined sensitive sources subject to judicial review, a meaningful opportunity to contest, and a right to appeal to an independent court.
	•	Evidence-Based — “Evidence-Based” means supported by credible empirical evidence and clinical consensus adequate to justify the intervention under stated conditions, as defined by implementing law.
	•	Evidentiary Standard and Findings (for Evil Designation) — “Evidentiary Standard and Findings” means the state may not designate or adjudicate any person or entity as “evil” for state purposes unless clear and convincing evidence proves the elements and the decision includes written findings of fact and conclusions of law; criminal liability requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
	•	Evil (State Meaning) — “Evil” means culpable conduct that causes Serious Harm and satisfies at least one of the following: (a) Intentional Harm: the actor acted with the purpose to cause harm, deprivation, exploitation, or material injury, or the actor knowingly used persons as means to such harm; (b) Preventable Harm with Culpable Disregard: the actor knew, or a reasonable actor in the same position should have known, that a substantial risk of Serious Harm existed, the actor had practical means and a reasonable opportunity to materially reduce that risk, and the actor nevertheless failed to act or acted in reckless disregard of that risk; (c) System-Protected Incompetence: repeated incompetence, gross negligence, or willful blindness caused serious preventable harm, and an institution, agency, or protected network materially shielded the actor through conflict of interest, captured oversight, falsified reporting, suppression of complaints, retaliation against reporting persons, obstruction, or other deliberate insulation from accountability.
	•	Expressive work embedded in software — Any audiovisual, textual, musical, narrative, interface, or artistic work intentionally incorporated into a software artifact for purposes of operation, interaction, presentation, or narrative function, and which is not reasonably separable without impairing faithful operation, emulation, or preservation.
	•	Federal preemption — Any action that nullifies, displaces, overrides, or renders unenforceable state law (Article XXVIII).
	•	Fiscal coercion — Conditional funding, threats of withdrawal, or program structures designed to create dependency or compel compliance (Article XXVIII).
	•	Good Samaritan Aid — Voluntary, non-commercial humanitarian assistance provided to prevent immediate and serious harm to life or health (such as emergency medical care, basic sustenance, shelter from imminent danger, or rescue), without facilitating, encouraging, or enabling unlawful entry, unlawful residency, or violation of immigration law. (Cross-references: Article I §6)
	•	Government Dispensary Function — “Government Dispensary Function” means the operation, funding, administration, or direct provision by the Republic or a State of a system that distributes, supplies, or otherwise provides substances or Use-Paraphernalia for Non-Therapeutic Consumption, including for Off-Site Use, whether free or subsidized, and whether directly or through contractors or grants. Government Dispensary Function does not include Therapeutic Administration, emergency stabilization, or facility-based clinical care under documented protocols. 
	•	Grave offense / Tier Three offense — Conduct involving violence, predation, corruption of public trust, sexual exploitation, trafficking, or irreparable harm to persons or the Republic; synonymous with heinous crime for purposes of evidentiary admissibility, arms restrictions, and enhanced penalties. Includes but is not limited to murder, rape, molestation, human trafficking, child exploitation, or acts causing widespread or irreparable harm. (Cross-references: Article II §§2, 3; this Article)
	•	Heinous Crime / Heinous Criminal — Synonymous with Grave Offense / Tier Three offense. Conduct involving extreme violence, predation, corruption of public trust, sexual exploitation, trafficking, or irreparable harm to persons or the constitutional order, as expressly listed or reasonably analogous to murder, rape, molestation, human trafficking, child exploitation, or comparable acts of severe moral and physical predation. (Cross-references: Article II §§2, 3; Article VII)
	•	High-stakes decision — Decisions involving significant treasury deployment, identity rules, safety policy, constitutional change, or other matters expressly designated by this Constitution or by statute enacted pursuant to it as high-risk.
	•	High-Quality Evidence — “High-Quality Evidence” means evidence meeting pre-defined methodological standards, such as randomized controlled trials, strong quasi-experimental designs, or systematic reviews of such studies, with outcomes and limitations disclosed, as defined by implementing law.
	•	Horizon (governance chambers, if adopted) — A distinct standpoint of interest and proof, such as Labor, Affected Public, Stewards, Capital, or Commons. Neutrality and Non-Establishment (for Evil Designation) — “Neutrality and Non-Establishment” means the state meaning of “evil” uses secular, measurable criteria and does not require or presume any supernatural claim; the state may not base any designation on viewpoint, party, creed, or identity, and the state may base any designation only on proven conduct and proven harms.
	•	Imminent and Specific Risk / Imminent and Specific Harm — A credible, individualized threat of serious physical, sexual, or lethal harm that is likely to occur within seventy-two (72) hours absent intervention, supported by clear and convincing, particularized evidence rather than generalized or speculative concern. (Cross-references: Article II §§2A, 4A, 5A)
	•	Imminent Threat of Grave Harm (for sentencing, pretrial detention, or temporary protective measures) — A credible, individualized threat of Grave offense-level harm likely to occur within a short timeframe (presumptively 72 hours to 30 days absent intervention), supported by clear and convincing evidence of specific intent, capability, and opportunity. Temporary, judicially ordered measures (e.g., extreme risk protection orders or emergency holds) may be imposed only upon such a finding, with strict time limits, adversarial hearing, and restoration pathway. (Cross-references: Article II §§2A, 3(e), 5A; this Article)
	•	Intoxicating or Dependence-Forming Substance — “Intoxicating or Dependence-Forming Substance” means any substance that materially impairs cognition or function, induces intoxication, or presents substantial risk of dependence, addiction, or compulsive use, as defined by law. For purposes of Drug Policy, the term includes substances classified as Tier II or Tier III under Article XXXIV, and includes any Tier I substance when used for Non-Therapeutic Consumption or when designated by law under objective criteria.
	•	Jubilee — “Jubilee” means a periodic, legally mandated reset or relief mechanism for certain debts, obligations, or concentrated holdings, designed to prevent permanent economic bondage, extreme wealth concentration, or generational dispossession. “Jubilee” does not mean a celebration or holiday for purposes of this Constitution. A jubilee operates as a policy mechanism that may include forgiveness, cancellation, reduction, or restructuring of specified debts; release from long-term or exploitative obligations; or restoration of baseline opportunity or access, as the law defining that jubilee specifies.
	•	Lawful Resident — Any natural person lawfully present within the territory of the Republic, including Civic Citizens and non-civic residents holding valid temporary or permanent lawful status under law. Excludes persons present unlawfully. (Cross-references: Article I §§5–6; Article II §1; Article III.)
	•	Licensed Clinician — “Licensed Clinician” means a physician, advanced practice clinician, or other licensed professional acting within lawful scope of practice and facility protocols.
	•	Licensed Medical Facility — “Licensed Medical Facility” means a hospital, clinic, detoxification facility, inpatient or outpatient treatment center, or other healthcare facility licensed and regulated under law to provide medical care.
	•	Lock-protected provision — A provision designated under Article XV as requiring supermajority and special procedures for amendment, repeal, suspension, or reinterpretation.
	•	Material violation (of plain-language requirements) — A substantial impairment of a reasonable person’s ability to understand the core obligations, prohibitions, exceptions, or consequences of a binding legal rule, such that good-faith compliance is unreasonably difficult.
	•	Medically Supervised Withdrawal — “Medically Supervised Withdrawal” means structured withdrawal management conducted under clinical supervision to reduce risk of death or severe harm, including monitoring, supportive care, and medication when appropriate.
	•	Misinformation — False information lacking malicious intent, distinguished from disinformation.
	•	Non-Therapeutic Consumption — “Non-Therapeutic Consumption” means use, ingestion, inhalation, injection, or other consumption primarily for intoxication, euphoria, recreation, or non-medical effect, or outside the direction of a Licensed Clinician and outside documented clinical protocols. Non-Therapeutic Consumption includes Off-Site Use not issued as medical treatment by prescription or direct clinician order.
	•	Off-Site Use — “Off-Site Use” means consumption or use occurring outside a licensed medical facility or other Controlled Setting authorized by law, including in any Public Space or in a private location not under clinical supervision.
	•	Office of public trust — Any public office, authority, commission, or agency held as a fiduciary duty to the People and the Constitution (Article XI).
	•	Plain language — Language that is clear, concise, and understandable to a reasonable person on first reading, using common words, short sentences, active voice, and logical structure, without unnecessary jargon or complexity.
	•	Pretextual coercion — Any indirect pressure, manufactured or exaggerated emergency, regulatory complexity, conditional benefit/withdrawal scheme, fiscal incentive, procedural barrier, or other mechanism designed to achieve an end that would be unconstitutional if imposed directly, or to impair free consent where consent is constitutionally required. (Cross-references: Article 0-B; Article II §0(e); Articles XXII, XXXIII, XXXVIII)
	•	Public Ministry of Records — The constitutional body responsible for preservation and public accessibility of public records as defined in Article XXXIX.
	•	Public record — Any record, data, document, communication, metadata, or material created, received, held, or controlled by the Republic or its agents (Article XXXIX).
	•	Public Space — “Public Space” means any area held open to the general public or used as a common right-of-way, including streets, sidewalks, parks, trails, transit stations and stops, public parking areas, plazas, public buildings and grounds, and the common areas of publicly funded facilities, whether owned publicly or privately. 
	•	Public stewardship / Stewardship — The fiduciary duty of officials and landholders to act solely in the interest of the People, the Constitution, and future generations, preserving resources and systems for long-term welfare (Articles I, IX, XXXVII).
	•	Public Disorder Metrics — “Public Disorder Metrics” means measurable indicators of public harm or nuisance, including open consumption, needle litter, overdose frequency in Public Space, public intoxication complaints, violent incidents, property crime concentration, and encampment growth, as defined by implementing law.
	•	Punishment — Any deprivation of liberty, property, rights, or status imposed by the State because of crime (Article VII).
	•	Reasonable person — An ordinary individual of average intelligence and education (equivalent to an eighth grade reading level), familiar with everyday English but without specialized legal or technical training.
	•	Religion and Accountability — “Religion and Accountability” means religious bodies remain independent from the state and the state remains independent from religious doctrine, and the state retains a duty to protect the innocent from fraud, coercion, abuse, and violence committed by any person or institution, including religious bodies, under neutral laws of general applicability.
	•	Republic — The sovereign entity established by this Constitution, its institutions, territory, and the People acting in their sovereign capacity.
	•	Research Pilot — “Research Pilot” means a time-limited, evaluated trial program authorized by law with specified metrics, independent evaluation, a sunset date, and termination triggers.
	•	Reserved powers — All powers not expressly delegated to the federal government by this Constitution, retained by the States and the People (Article XXVIII).
	•	Transparency — Timely public access to information sufficient to permit accountability, excluding only narrowly tailored operational secrecy justified by clear and convincing evidence (Articles XI, XXXIX).
	•	Sedation for Stabilization — “Sedation for Stabilization” means clinician-directed sedation used to prevent imminent harm, treat acute agitation or medical complication, or safely stabilize a patient when less restrictive measures would likely fail, and when the clinician documents that sedation is the least harmful available option.
	•	Severe, Dangerous Mental Illness (for purposes of arms restrictions and related liberty deprivations) — A currently active, diagnosed psychiatric condition, substantiated by clear and convincing evidence from two independent licensed medical professionals (neither employed by nor subordinate to the detaining/restricting authority), that renders the individual presently incapable of safely exercising the right in question and poses an imminent and specific risk of serious harm to self or others that cannot be mitigated by less restrictive means. Temporary or mitigated conditions do not qualify. (Cross-references: Article II §§3(b), 4A)
	•	Serious Harm — “Serious Harm” means death, significant bodily injury, severe psychological injury, deprivation of liberty or property without due process, systemic fraud losses, material civil-rights violations, or substantial environmental or public-health injury. 
	•	Software artifact — Any executable or interpretable digital system, including source code, compiled code, firmware, data structures, and integrated components, together with all elements intentionally incorporated for operation, interaction, presentation, or user experience.
	•	Street Enablement Program — “Street Enablement Program” means any publicly funded or administered program whose primary purpose or predictable effect facilitates or sustains non-therapeutic intoxication or drug consumption in Public Space or by Off-Site Use, including distribution of intoxicating or dependence-forming substances for general consumption or distribution of Use-Paraphernalia for Off-Site Use.
	•	Substance Use Disorder — “Substance Use Disorder” means a medically recognized disorder involving clinically significant impairment related to substance use, as defined by generally accepted medical standards adopted by law. 
	•	Supermajority Rule — Unless this Constitution expressly provides otherwise, any requirement for a supermajority vote, approval, or concurrence shall require an affirmative threshold of sixty percent (60%) of the relevant body or electorate.
	•	Therapeutic Administration — “Therapeutic Administration” means the administration, dispensing, or supervised provision of a substance or clinical service by a Licensed Clinician acting within lawful scope of practice, pursuant to documented clinical protocols, for diagnosis, treatment, stabilization, withdrawal management, tapering, detoxification, medication-assisted treatment, Sedation for Stabilization, or other medically recognized therapeutic purpose, within a Controlled Setting or as otherwise authorized by law as medical treatment.
	•	Tier One Disposition — A Tier One (Therapeutic Justice) placement under Article VII, Section 2(b), involving rehabilitation without incarceration through treatment, detoxification, supervised programs, restorative justice, and monitored reintegration, with escalation to Tier Two Disposition for noncompliance as Article VII provides.
	•	Tier-One Offense — A minor offense designated Tier-One under Article VII and implementing law, generally characterized by non-violent, low-harm conduct for which proportionate sanctions may include fines, restitution, community service, short-term restrictions, diversion, or other non-carceral measures. A State may elevate an offense classification from Tier-One Offense to Tier-Two Offense by objective criteria defined by law based on repetition, organization, coordinated schemes, or demonstrated patterns of predation, applied uniformly and subject to appeal.
	•	Tier-I Disposition — A Tier Two (Rehabilitative Incarceration) placement under Article VII, Section 2(f), involving secure and disciplined confinement with labor, education or training, restitution priority, and reform-conditioned privileges and release.
	•	Tier-II Offense — A serious offense designated Tier-Two under Article VII and implementing law, including serious felonies involving corruption, fraud, breach of trust, or comparable severity, and which may trigger Civic Standing reduction where Article III so provides.
	•	Tier-III Disposition — A Tier Three (Punitive Incapacitation) placement under Article VII, Section 2(g), involving harsh but not cruel confinement prioritizing permanent protection of society, denial of non-essential privileges, and exclusion of early release except under extraordinary judicial review.
	•	Tier-III Offense — A Grave offense / Tier Three offense (synonymous with Heinous Crime) as defined herein, which may trigger full forfeiture of Civic Standing where Article III so provides.
	•	Tier I Substance; Tier II Substance; Tier III Substance — “Tier I Substance,” “Tier II Substance,” and “Tier III Substance” have the meanings given in Article XXXIV.
	•	Too Dangerous — “Too Dangerous” means any Tier III substance under Article XXXIV, and any Tier II substance or method of delivery designated by law as “too dangerous” under objective criteria that include overdose risk, diversion risk, lethality, impairment severity, and public-order spillover risk, with criteria and designations published and subject to audit.
	•	Use-Paraphernalia — “Use-Paraphernalia” means items primarily designed or provided to prepare, inject, inhale, smoke, or otherwise consume intoxicating or dependence-forming substances, including needles, syringes, pipes, cookers, filters, tourniquets, and similar implements, excluding medical devices dispensed for legitimate medical treatment by prescription. 

Section 3. In Dubio Pro Libertate: Default-to-Liberty on Delay, Deadlock, or Procedural Hold
	•	Automatic Expiration of Procedural Holds
Any temporary injunction, stay, certification delay, or review process that restrains or blocks the operation of a duly enacted law, lawful executive action, or constitutionally authorized authority shall expire automatically after sixty (60) days, unless the reviewing body issues written findings, supported by clear and convincing evidence, that continuation is necessary to prevent irreparable constitutional harm.
	•	Effect of Expiration
Upon expiration of such restraint, the challenged law or action shall take effect as written, and lawful residents shall regain the full exercise of any right, authority, or liberty previously restrained, pending final adjudication.
	•	Emergency and Defense Contexts
Where the restrained action concerns national defense, emergency response, or existential threat mitigation authorized under this Constitution, any such restraint shall expire automatically after seventy-two (72) hours, absent the findings required in subsection (1).
	•	Deadlock and Failure to Decide
Where the Constitutional Review Court, Constitutional Judicial Commission, Supreme Court, or any reviewing body is evenly divided, fails to reach a required supermajority, or fails to issue a timely decision within constitutionally prescribed limits, the presumption shall resolve in favor of liberty and lawful authority, and against continued restraint, delay, or nullification.
	•	No Implied Extension of Power
Expiration of a restraint under this Section shall not be construed as approval, endorsement, or ratification of the challenged act, but solely as restoration of liberty and lawful operation pending resolution.
	•	Non-Waiver and Lock Protection
The protections of this Section shall not be suspended, waived, or bypassed by emergency declaration, judicial rule, or legislative act, except by constitutional amendment consistent with Article XV.

Section 4. Popular Override of Law and Judicial Doctrine
4.1 Ultimate Popular Authority
Civic Citizens retain the ultimate authority to approve, nullify, override, or restore governmental action taken under this Constitution, including statutes, regulations, and binding judicial holdings or doctrines, subject to the procedural safeguards herein and the lock protections of Article XV.

No court or agency is required to submit any matter to referendum. Referenda occur only upon citizen initiation as provided herein.

4.1A Constitutional Boundary (No Amendment by Override)

No citizen-initiated override under this Section may amend, suspend, repeal, unlock, lock, reinterpret, or otherwise alter the text, structure, or legal effect of this Constitution.

Any petition whose legal effect would directly alter constitutional text, constitutional structure, or lock-protected operation shall be treated as a proposed constitutional amendment or unlocking measure and must proceed exclusively under Article XV, including any heightened thresholds required for unlocking.

4.2 Single-Issue Requirement

Any citizen-initiated override petition shall address one discrete governmental action or legal question only, stated plainly and without aggregation, conditional language, or bundled demands.

A petition that combines multiple actions, policies, or grievances shall be invalid.4.3 Threshold for InitiationA binding popular review may be triggered only upon petition by not less than twenty percent (20%) of Civic Citizens, verified within a fixed statutory period.

4.4 Cooling-Off and Anti-Spam Limitation
No substantially identical petition concerning the same governmental action may be initiated more than once within a defined cooling-off period following a failed referendum or judicial resolution.

The cooling-off period shall be one hundred eighty (180) days, unless the petitioners demonstrate a material change in facts or circumstances occurring after the prior vote or resolution.

A material change includes, but is not limited to:

a. disclosure of previously classified or concealed information;

b. evidence of fraud, misrepresentation, or bad-faith justification by public officials;

c. expansion, prolongation, or material escalation of the challenged action;

d. substantial deviation between stated objectives and actual conduct or outcomes;

e. significant new harm to life, liberty, or national interest not reasonably foreseeable at the time of the prior vote.

The certification authority shall make a threshold determination of material change solely as to form and sufficiency, not political merit.
Mere changes in public opinion, absent new facts or circumstances, shall not constitute material change.

4.5 Amendment-Grade Procedural Safeguards (Form and Disclosure)

All override petitions and referenda under this Section shall satisfy the amendment-grade safeguards of Article XV concerning:
(1) single-subject form;
(2) a plain-language explanation of purpose and effect;
(3) disclosure of all affected provisions, rules, tests, or doctrines; and
(4) public deliberation safeguards.

These safeguards apply regardless of whether the override affects statutory law, regulation, or judicial doctrine, but shall not be construed to impose constitutional amendment thresholds, state-ratification requirements, or unlocking procedures unless the petition triggers the Constitutional Boundary in Section 4.1A.
4.6 Expedited Review Window; Interim Rule
Upon certification of a valid petition, the matter shall proceed to an expedited, binding referendum within a constitutionally prescribed timeframe.

Pending such referendum, the default-to-liberty provisions of this Article shall govern only as to prospective enforcement or expansion of the challenged action, unless a court finds by clear and convincing evidence that continued enforcement is strictly necessary to prevent imminent and specific harm.

4.7 Outcome and Effect
(a) Ordinary Override Threshold

A referendum under this Section shall be required to meet the Supermajority Rule as defined in Article 0.

No higher threshold applies under this Section unless the petition triggers the Constitutional Boundary in Section 4.1A, in which case the matter proceeds under Article XV (including the unlocking threshold where applicable).
(b) Statutory Override Effect
Upon adoption, the challenged statute or regulation is void and unenforceable to the extent overridden.

(c) Judicial Override Effect
Upon adoption, the challenged judicial holding, doctrine, test, standard of review, or precedent shall have no binding or precedential effect and shall not be relied upon by any court or agency.
Affected cases shall be remanded or re-adjudicated under the remaining law and this Constitution, as applicable.

(d) Lock-Protected Limitation
No override may amend, suspend, repeal, weaken, narrow, reinterpret, or render ineffectual any lock-protected provision except by compliance with Article XV, including any heightened approval thresholds required by Article XV for lock-protected change.

4.8 Protection Against Harassment of Review Bodies
No court, commission, or review body shall be required to entertain repetitive, bad-faith, or procedurally defective citizen petitions designed primarily to obstruct governance or exhaust institutional capacity.
Certification authorities may summarily reject petitions that fail to meet the requirements of this Section.
Section 5. Conditional Provisions, Definitions, and Global Interpretive Safeguards

5.1 Conditional and Transitional Clauses

Where this Constitution uses terms such as “during transition,” “phase-in,” “temporary,” “sunset,” “until,” “unless,” or otherwise identifies a provision as time-limited or contingent on a defined condition, such language shall be construed as operative only within the stated scope and duration.

No conditional or transitional clause may be construed to authorize indefinite delay, perpetual “temporary” government, or administrative suspension of constitutional rights.

5.2 Global Principles of Interpretation

Principles of interpretation expressly incorporated by reference from any Article shall apply globally unless expressly overridden.

In cases of genuine ambiguity, delay, deadlock, procedural hold, inaction, or interpretive doubt regarding any provision, power, right, or obligation under this Constitution, interpretation shall favor:
liberty over restraint,
individual rights over administrative convenience,
accountability and transparency over secrecy, and
the sovereignty of the People over the expansion or preservation of governmental authority.

Delay shall not be construed as denial of liberty. No governmental body, officer, or procedure may use inaction, procedural obstruction, or indefinite hold to impair, suspend, or defeat a constitutional right, safeguard, or duly authorized exercise of lawful power.

In cases involving alleged violations of plain-language requirements, ambiguity or complexity shall be construed against the Republic and in favor of liberty and public comprehension, consistent with the In Dubio Pro Libertate principle.

5.3 Definitions, Glossaries, and Supplementation

The Consolidated Defined Terms list in this Article shall be deemed automatically supplemented by any new definitions expressly added to this Article by constitutional amendment.

Statutes may define technical, administrative, or implementing terms for purposes of execution, provided that:
(1) no statutory definition may conflict with this Constitution;
(2) no statutory definition may narrow, expand, manipulate, or redefine any constitutional term in a manner that changes substantive rights, prohibitions, thresholds, caps, floors, or jurisdictional limits;
(3) no statutory definition may introduce “newspeak,” euphemism, or ideological relabeling intended to evade accountability or alter public meaning; and
(4) any statutory definition adopted for general public governance must be written in plain language and recorded by the Public Ministry of Records in a public glossary.

Definitions adopted by statute shall be strictly construed and shall not expand substantive powers, authorities, or limitations beyond those expressly authorized by this Constitution.

5.4 Anti-Paralysis and Anti-Capture Safeguard

No emergency, continuity, necessity, deadlock, or procedural doctrine may suspend, restrict, delay, obstruct, or interfere with the operation of the Constitutional Judicial Commission, or with any constitutional integrity, oversight, anti-capture, or anti-collusion body established by this Constitution.

Any attempt to do so—whether by inaction, pretextual procedural hold, evasion, or indefinite delay—is void ab initio and constitutes grave constitutional malfeasance.

5.5 Duplicate Definitions

Where a definition from this Article is reproduced elsewhere for readability, the reproduced text shall be identical; any conflict is resolved in favor of this Article.
Article 0-A — General Prohibition of Collusion and Coordinated Suppression

Charge

This Article prohibits collusion, coordination, or concerted action between public authority and private power that undermines constitutional rights, lawful competition, civic participation, or the public interest.
It applies to all branches, agencies, officers, contractors, and delegated authorities, without exception.

⸻

Section 1. Prohibited Collusion

No public actor shall knowingly coordinate with any private entity to:
	1.	suppress lawful speech, expression, or communication;
	2.	suppress lawful competition, innovation, or market entry;
	3.	block or delay lawful derivative creation, replication, or repair;
	4.	evade, dilute, or selectively enforce constitutional or statutory obligations;
	5.	manufacture consent, compliance narratives, or procedural barriers that defeat constitutional rights.

Collusion may be express or tacit and need not be formalized to be unlawful.

⸻

Section 2. Participation by Private Power

No private entity may solicit, induce, or participate in collusive arrangements prohibited by this Article.

Private compliance with unconstitutional coordination shall not confer immunity.

⸻

Section 3. Presumptions and Burden of Proof

Collusion shall be presumed where:
	1.	parallel public and private actions produce coordinated suppression;
	2.	communications, incentives, or benefits align public decisions with private advantage;
	3.	enforcement patterns favor specific private actors absent neutral justification.

Upon such a showing, the burden shall shift to the participating parties to demonstrate independent and lawful action.

⸻

Section 4. Remedies and Consequences

Acts of collusion are void.

Remedies and consequences may include:
	1.	injunctive relief;
	2.	invalidation of resulting rules, agreements, or enforcement actions;
	3.	civil and criminal liability;
	4.	loss of public office, licenses, or contracting eligibility.

Standing to challenge violations of this Article shall be broad.

⸻

Section 5. Relationship to Other Provisions

This Article operates in addition to, and not in limitation of:
	•	Article XI (Transparency and Anti-Capture);
	•	Article X (Commons, Technology, and Intellectual Property);
	•	Article XXX (Enforcement Authority);
	•	Article XLII (Communication Freedom).

Where overlap exists, the most restrictive applicable anti-collusion rule shall control.

⸻

Section 6. Construction and Lock Scope

This Article shall be construed broadly against coordinated suppression and narrowly against claims of administrative necessity, efficiency, or partnership.

The prohibition of collusion established by this Article is structural and non-derogable and shall not be suspended, waived, or circumvented by statute, regulation, emergency declaration, or contract.

⸻

Article 0-B — Constitutional Routing of Authority
Charge
This Article establishes the mandatory allocation of constitutional enforcement, integrity protection, and judicial review to ensure that no power center of the Republic may escape oversight through ambiguity, forum shopping, or emergency pretext.  All Articles of this Constitution shall be construed in harmony with this routing.
Section 1. Allocation of Core Functions
The constitutional organs of oversight are assigned exclusive and non-overlapping functions as follows:
Function
Assigned Body
Determination of constitutional meaning, legality, validity, and legal effect
Constitutional Review Court (CRC)
Protection against institutional capture, corruption, coercion, retaliation, concealment, and abuse of process
Constitutional Judicial Commission (CJC)
Final constitutional interpretation, precedent, and resolution of fundamental constitutional conflicts
Supreme Court of the Republic
Fact-finding, audits, and operational investigation
Inspectors, auditors, and specialized oversight bodies
No body may exercise a function assigned to another unless this Constitution expressly so provides.
Section 2. Mandatory Triggering Rules
Whenever any Article of this Constitution provides for:  - judicial authorization, - judicial review, - warrants, - injunctions, - nullification, - suspension of authority, - emergency powers, - secrecy, - dissolution, - loss of rights, or - institutional discipline,  the following routing shall apply unless expressly displaced:
(a) The Constitutional Review Court shall have original jurisdiction to determine constitutional compliance. (b) The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have concurrent authority to certify institutional abuse, capture, or concealment and to petition the Constitutional Review Court for relief. (c) The Supreme Court of the Republic shall have appellate or discretionary review over Constitutional Review Court determinations.
Section 3. Emergency and Secrecy Override Prohibition
No emergency, national security, continuity, or necessity doctrine may suspend, bypass, or reassign the jurisdiction of the Constitutional Review Court or the Constitutional Judicial Commission.  No secret tribunal, special court, or undisclosed adjudicatory body may exercise any function reserved to the Constitutional Review Court, the Constitutional Judicial Commission, or the Supreme Court of the Republic.
Section 4. Anti-Laundering Rule
No statutory court, tribunal, board, agency, or executive process may be used to:  - evade Constitutional Review Court constitutional review; - shield institutional misconduct from Constitutional Judicial Commission investigation; or - substitute administrative process for constitutional adjudication.  Any attempt to do so is void.
Section 5. Construction and Anti-Dilution Rule
This Article shall be construed to preserve:  - rapid constitutional enforcement; - slow and deliberative final review; and - constant protection against institutional capture.  No later Article may impliedly repeal, dilute, or reassign the routing established herein.

Article I — Principles and Nature of the Republic

Charge

The Republic is founded upon the inherent dignity, equal worth, and natural rights of all persons, which exist prior to and above government.

Government is created not to grant rights, but to recognize, protect, and secure them through law, restraint, and accountable power.

This Constitution establishes a Republic of ordered liberty, in which freedom is preserved by law, power is bounded by duty, and public authority exists solely to serve the People.

Civic authority is not inherited, purchased, or seized, but earned through lawful participation, service, and allegiance to constitutional order.

No office, institution, or majority may lawfully override the supremacy of this Constitution, the sovereignty of the People, or the inviolable rights it protects.

This Article sets forth the foundational structure of the Republic: the nature of sovereignty, the limits of power, the distinction between civil and political status, and the duties of stewardship and vigilance that bind all who govern.
Legal Text

Section 1. Nature of the Republic

The Republic is a constitutional, rights-bounded system of ordered liberty grounded in justice, responsibility, and stewardship.

Government exists solely to:
(a) recognize, protect, and secure the natural and civil rights of the People;
(b) uphold equal justice under law;
(c) provide public goods that cannot be effectively supplied by individuals or markets; and
(d) preserve the constitutional order.

Ordered liberty means liberty exercised under law, bounded by the equal rights of others, and constrained by duties of citizenship and public trust — not license, coercion, or arbitrary power.

No authority may redefine “justice,” “evidence,” “morality,” or “public good” to negate, diminish, or subordinate the rights secured by this Constitution.
(cross-reference Article 0; Article II; Article XXVI)

Section 2. Supremacy of the Constitution

This Constitution is the supreme law of the Republic and binds all branches, officers, agencies, courts, subdivisions, and instrumentalities of government.

Any statute, treaty, decree, regulation, ordinance, executive action, judicial doctrine, or administrative practice inconsistent with this Constitution is void and without legal force.

No emergency, necessity, international obligation, or claimed sovereign immunity shall excuse noncompliance.

All public officials owe primary allegiance to this Constitution and are personally accountable for acts taken in violation of it.

Section 3. Separation of Powers

The Legislative, Executive, and Judicial branches are separate, coequal, and bound by this Constitution.

Each branch shall exercise only the powers expressly granted to it, and no branch may exercise, delegate, assume, or conceal the powers of another.

Coequality means no branch is subordinate to another in constitutional authority, but all are subordinate to the Constitution and the People.

No branch may evade accountability through:
• delegation to unaccountable bodies,
• reclassification of powers,
• emergency doctrine,
• judicial or administrative invention, or
• procedural obstruction.

All branches remain continuously accountable to the People and to constitutional review.

Section 4. Moral and Civilizational Foundation

The Republic affirms that liberty cannot be sustained without respect for human dignity, historical continuity, and ethical restraint.

This Constitution is informed by the accumulated moral, legal, and philosophical traditions of human civilization, including principles of justice, mercy, truth, accountability, and stewardship.

Moral principles may guide law, but no moral, religious, cultural, or ideological doctrine shall be imposed by the state as a condition of legal status, civil rights, or political participation.

No religion, creed, philosophy, or belief system shall be established, endorsed, or enforced by government, nor shall belief or conscience be coerced.

No provision of this Section shall be construed to authorize:
(a) establishment of religion;
(b) preference for one faith, culture, or worldview over another;
(c) civil hierarchy based on belief; or
(d) coercion of conscience or identity.

Courts shall construe this Section to preserve moral grounding without permitting theocracy, ideological enforcement, or cultural supremacy.

(cross-reference Article XXXII; Article II §1(a))

Section 5. Civic Status and Non-Civic Citizens

Non-civic citizens include:
(a) persons born within the territory of the Republic;
(b) persons born abroad to citizens of the Republic; and
(c) all persons lawfully admitted for permanent residence.

All non-civic citizens retain the full and equal protection of the Constitution, including all rights enumerated in the Bill of Rights, such as freedom of speech, religion, conscience, movement, enterprise, property, due process, and access to the courts.
(cross-reference Article II; Article 0)

Non-civic citizens may participate fully in civil society, culture, education, labor, association, and public discourse.

Political authority — including the right to vote, hold public office, or exercise control over government institutions — shall be exercised only by Civic Citizens who have satisfied the service, qualification, and loyalty requirements of Article III.

Civic status is a qualification for governance, not a classification of human worth. No civil right, legal protection, or human dignity shall depend upon civic status.

No person shall be deprived of civil rights, property, liberty, or legal standing on the basis of non-civic status, nor may any authority redefine or manipulate civic classifications to evade constitutional protections.

Section 6. Rights of Unlawful Entrants

Persons who enter or reside unlawfully retain the right to:
(a) due process of law;
(b) freedom from violence, coercion, and abuse;
(c) humane treatment; and
(d) Good Samaritan aid necessary to preserve life and dignity.

Unlawful entrants shall not possess political rights, shall not be counted for purposes of representation or apportionment, and shall not acquire lawful status or civic standing through executive, administrative, or political discretion alone.

Any grant, denial, or regularization of status shall occur only through procedures established by law, subject to judicial review and consistent with this Constitution.

Section 7. Mechanisms of Rectification

A lawful and limited pathway of rectification may exist for:
(a) persons brought into the Republic as minors through no fault of their own; or
(b) persons who demonstrate exceptional, verifiable contributions to the public welfare, national security, or civic life of the Republic.

Rectification shall be:
(a) administered by independent, non-partisan bodies;
(b) governed by objective, transparent, and measurable criteria;
(c) subject to judicial review; and
(d) limited in scale so as not to permit demographic engineering, political manipulation, or mass regularization.

No individual, class, or group shall obtain lawful status, residency, or civic standing through discretionary amnesty, executive action, or political bargaining.

Section 8. Condemnation of Corruption and Oathbreaking

Oathbreaking, corruption, fraud, and abuse of public office constitute grave offenses against the Republic and the People.

Public office is a fiduciary trust. Every officer owes a duty of loyalty, honesty, and lawful service to the Constitution and to the People.

Any official who:
(a) knowingly violates the Constitution;
(b) uses office for private gain;
(c) abuses authority;
(d) betrays public trust; or
(e) participates in institutional capture
shall be subject to removal, disqualification, civil liability, and criminal prosecution as provided by law.

No oath, immunity, rank, or position shall shield any person from accountability for betrayal of public trust.

Section 9. Duty of Stewardship

All citizens and all holders of public office owe a constitutional duty of stewardship over land, resources, institutions, and the public trust.

Stewardship means the fiduciary obligation to preserve, maintain, and improve the long-term welfare, resilience, and continuity of the Republic for present and future generations.
(as defined in Article 0)

Neglect, waste, looting, short-term exploitation, or predatory conduct that materially weakens the Republic, degrades its resources, or undermines its institutions constitutes a breach of constitutional duty.

Breach of stewardship is enforceable through civil liability, forfeiture, disqualification from office, and criminal sanction as provided by law.

(cross-reference Articles IX; XXXVII)

Section 10. Eternal Vigilance

(a) Principle

Liberty and constitutional integrity require continuous vigilance. Tyranny, corruption, and decay must be actively opposed and shall not be permitted to arise through silence, fear, or institutional drift.

(b) Right

The People retain the right to peaceably oppose, expose, criticize, investigate, and lawfully resist:
• constitutional violations;
• corruption;
• unlawful authority; and
• abuse of public power.

(c) Protection

No person shall be punished, harassed, censored, surveilled, deprived of rights, or subjected to retaliation for lawful civic protest, whistleblowing, journalism, oversight, or public criticism undertaken in defense of constitutional order.

(d) Civic Duty

All citizens, and especially all holders of public office, have a duty to defend this Constitution, report violations, refuse unlawful orders, and oppose institutional capture, even when such defense is unpopular or dangerous.

Section 11. Lock Designation

Civic vigilance, lawful oversight, and informed engagement by the People are essential to the health and survival of the Republic.

The core principles of this Article — including:
• ordered liberty;
• moral and civilizational grounding;
• the supremacy of the Constitution;
• separation of powers;
• the duty of stewardship; and
• the distinction between Civic and non-civic citizens —
are structural to this Constitution and shall not be repealed, suspended, diluted, or reinterpreted to undermine liberty, accountability, or popular sovereignty.

These principles may be amended only through the lock-protected procedures of Article XV and only in a manner that preserves, and does not diminish, their substantive force.

No statute, regulation, executive action, treaty, or judicial doctrine may evade or weaken this Lock.

Article X — Knowledge, Technology, and the Digital Commons
Charge 

This Article establishes constitutional principles governing knowledge, science, technology, and the digital commons of the Republic. All provisions of this Article shall be construed to promote public access, lawful innovation, transparency, interoperability, and the use of technology in service of individual liberty and democratic self-government. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to authorize technological control, surveillance, restriction of knowledge, or compulsory dependency except as expressly provided by this Constitution and subject to judicial review.

Legal Text
Section 1. Knowledge as a Public Trust (a) Principle of Stewardship Knowledge produced within the Republic, especially through public funding, public labor, or public mandate, is held in trust for the People. No government, corporation, or individual may monopolize, conceal, or weaponize essential knowledge to undermine liberty, public safety, or democratic self-government.
(b) Public Access Scientific research, policy data, regulatory evidence, and technical standards funded by public means shall be publicly accessible, auditable, reproducible where practicable, and archived for posterity. Exceptions may exist only for narrowly defined national security concerns, subject to judicial review and sunset requirements.
(c) Prohibition on Knowledge Suppression It is unlawful for any authority to suppress, distort, or falsify knowledge for political, ideological, or financial advantage. Deliberate suppression of material scientific, medical, economic, or technological facts that causes public harm constitutes a grave offense.

Section 2. The Digital Commons (a) Definition and Scope The Digital Commons consists of public digital infrastructure, publicly accessible networks, government-operated platforms, essential digital utilities, and public data repositories. These systems shall operate for the benefit of the People and may not be privatized in a manner that compromises public access, fairness, or sovereignty.
(b) Neutrality and Access Digital infrastructure operated or regulated by the Republic shall provide equal access without viewpoint discrimination, operate transparently, publish moderation, ranking, and access rules, and prohibit covert manipulation of visibility or reach.
(c) Prohibition on Digital Exclusion No lawful resident may be excluded from essential digital services required for civic participation, education, commerce, or public information, except by due process of law.
(d) For purposes of this Article, “technology” includes autonomous, semi-autonomous, robotic, cyber-physical, and embedded systems, whether stationary or mobile, consumer or industrial.
(e) Safety, liability, or regulatory classification shall not be used to perpetuate vendor control, remote disablement, or restriction of lawful modification after meaningful commercial use has expired.

Section 3. Artificial Intelligence and Automated Systems (a) Permitted Use Artificial intelligence may assist human judgment in data analysis, logistics, research, and administration. AI shall not replace human judgment in matters of rights, liberty, justice, or political power.
(b) Prohibited Uses No AI system may determine guilt or innocence, impose criminal penalties, decide eligibility for rights, manipulate political behavior, conduct psychological operations on the People, engage in deceptive impersonation of humans, or operate without traceability or auditability.
(c) Transparency and Audit All AI systems used by government or critical infrastructure must be documented, auditable, disclose decision logic to authorized oversight bodies, and permit challenge and appeal.
(d) Human Accountability Responsibility for AI-assisted decisions rests with identifiable human officials. All systems shall include a documented mechanism for human override.

Section 4. Information Integrity and Manipulation (a) Prohibition on Information Warfare Against the People It is forbidden for any government agency, intelligence service, corporation, or proxy actor to manipulate search results, algorithmically distort political information, fabricate consensus, or deploy covert influence campaigns against the People.
(b) Separation of Intelligence and Media No intelligence agency, contractor, or former officer within a cooling-off period of not less than five (5) years may own, direct, or covertly influence major media or information platforms.
(c) Platform Accountability Large information platforms shall disclose ownership, funding sources, algorithmic ranking principles, permit independent audits, and refrain from covert manipulation.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall audit platform disclosures and algorithmic behavior for manipulation, political interference, or information warfare and may petition the Constitutional Review Court for corrective orders, sanctions, or platform breakup.

Section 5. Digital Property and Personal Sovereignty (a) Personal Data Ownership Individuals retain ownership of their personal data. Collection or use requires informed, revocable consent.
(b) Limits on Surveillance Mass surveillance without individualized suspicion and judicial warrant is prohibited.
(c) Digital Due Process No person may be digitally deplatformed or denied essential services without notice, explanation, opportunity to respond, and judicial review, except where immediate and demonstrable danger exists.

Section 6. Open Innovation and the Commons of Knowledge
(a) Open Standards The Republic favors open technical standards, interoperability, and transparency over proprietary lock-in.
(b) Intellectual Property Balance Intellectual property exists to encourage creation, not perpetual rent-seeking. IP protections shall be time-limited, proportional, non-predatory, and incapable of extinguishing the commons.
(c) Prohibition on Technological Serfdom No technology may be designed, licensed, or enforced in a manner that creates dependency without exit, disables repair or modification, coerces perpetual payment for basic function, or strips ownership from lawful purchasers.
(d) Right to Repair All citizens and lawful residents possess the unqualified right to repair, modify, or maintain any lawfully acquired device, vehicle, machinery, or equipment. No manufacturer, vendor, or service provider may:
	•	withhold parts, tools, diagnostics, or documentation necessary for repair;
	•	impose contractual restrictions on third-party or self-repair;
	•	use software locks, authentication systems, or firmware restrictions to prevent repair or modification;
	•	void warranties solely due to independent or third-party repair.
This right extends to agricultural, industrial, consumer, and medical equipment. Safety-critical components may be regulated, but such regulation shall not function as a barrier to lawful repair.
(e) Open APIs for Essential Services Essential digital services, including payment systems, messaging platforms, identity verification services, and cloud storage, shall provide open, documented application programming interfaces after maturity as defined by law, to ensure interoperability and prevent technological lock-in.
(f) Platform Neutrality and Open Distribution
No operating system, device manufacturer, or platform may require a single controlled marketplace as the sole means of software distribution.
Alternative stores, sideloading, and third-party distribution shall be permitted without penalty or degradation.

Section 7. Software, Hardware, and Digital Heritage Preservation

(a) Principle of Digital Continuity
Software, hardware designs, artificial intelligence systems, and digital platforms constitute civilizational knowledge. When such systems no longer serve a serious commercial purpose, they shall not be permitted to vanish, decay, or remain locked behind obsolete legal barriers. The Republic affirms a duty to preserve, study, restore, and evolve the technological inheritance of the People.

(b) Abandonment and Sunset Rule
Any proprietary software, hardware platform, artificial intelligence model, or technical system shall be transferred to the Digital Commons under an open-source license when any of the following conditions are met:
	•	forty (40) years have elapsed since initial public release;
	•	the system has entered maintenance-only status for more than ten (10) consecutive years;
	•	the system is no longer commercially distributed or meaningfully supported; or
	•	the original steward has dissolved, abandoned the product, or ceased meaningful development.

Nominal maintenance, artificial licensing, token commercialization, or shell stewardship shall not defeat this transfer.

(c) Scope of Transfer
Upon transfer, the following must be preserved and released where lawfully possible: source code and build systems; documentation and technical manuals; firmware, drivers, and toolchains; hardware schematics and interfaces; and historical version-control and revision history.

(d) Right to Modify, Restore, and Study
The People retain an explicit right to modify abandoned or sunset software, hardware, and artificial intelligence systems; repair, emulate, and modernize legacy platforms; create compatibility layers, ports, and forks; preserve and distribute historical software and digital works; and maintain repositories for archival, educational, hobbyist, or research purposes. Such activities shall not constitute infringement once systems enter the Digital Commons.

(e) Anti-Evasion by Contract or Platform
No lease, subscription, service model, license, or platform control may be used to evade the transfer of control, modification rights, or interoperability guarantees established by this Article once meaningful commercial use has expired. Functional possession and lawful use confer the same post-maintenance rights as ownership.

(f) Prohibition on Destruction or Sabotage
No entity may intentionally destroy, disable, or materially degrade hardware, firmware, or essential components to prevent lawful post-maintenance use, modification, or archival preservation. Such acts constitute spoliation of the Commons and shall result in civil liability, criminal penalty, and compulsory disclosure of all technical materials necessary to restore functionality where practicable.
(g). Anti-Destructive Recycling and Public Reuse Mandate

No electronics recycler, waste contractor, manufacturer, or disposal intermediary may destroy, shred, export, or materially degrade any functional or repairable digital device, computing system, or electronic component for the purpose of market suppression, vendor lock-in, data-control, or artificial scarcity.

All covered entities shall first offer such equipment for:
	•	refurbishment and redistribution to low-income individuals, schools, libraries, and public institutions;
	•	supply to repair cooperatives, right-to-repair programs, and community technology centers;
	•	preservation by museums, archives, and historical computing trusts;
	•	public resale or auction.

Only equipment that is irreparably damaged, unsafe, or beyond reasonable economic repair may be recycled for raw material recovery.

Intentional destruction of usable technology to eliminate competition, suppress secondary markets, or enforce product turnover constitutes spoliation of the Digital Commons and technological sabotage.

(h) Custodianship
Congress shall designate a neutral Digital Heritage Authority responsible for archiving released systems, verifying abandonment or sunset status, maintaining public repositories, and ensuring long-term accessibility. The Authority shall not censor, alter, or suppress released materials nor impose ideological, political, or content-based restrictions.

(i) Judicial Acceleration for Public Necessity
The Constitutional Review Court may order accelerated entry of covered technologies into the Digital Commons upon clear and convincing evidence that continued exclusivity poses:
	•	a substantial risk to public health or safety;
	•	a threat to national resilience or essential infrastructure; or
	•	systemic harm to democratic self-government or access to life-critical knowledge.

Such orders shall be narrowly tailored, subject to appeal, and accompanied by just compensation where constitutionally required. Judicial acceleration is a protective remedy, not punishment.

(j) Software Jubilee
Congress shall establish a recurring Software Jubilee, occurring no less than once every ten (10) years, to identify systems eligible for commons reversion, reconcile legacy licenses, and ensure the timely release of qualifying software, firmware, documentation, and technical knowledge. The Jubilee is ministerial and may not delay or narrow any reversion right.

(k) Jubilee Reciprocity and Conditional Reuse
During any Software Jubilee, any person or entity may lawfully incorporate, adapt, or integrate Digital Commons software into proprietary or mixed systems without immediate disclosure. Such use is conditional upon mandatory return of all derivative improvements to the Digital Commons at the next Jubilee. No contract, license, or technical measure may defeat this obligation. Failure to return derivative code results in forfeiture of exclusive control over all materially dependent systems.

(l) Presumption of Openness
Where ambiguity exists regarding commons reversion, Jubilee release, derivative equity, or disclosure obligations, such ambiguity shall be resolved in favor of:

• public access,
• preservation,
• interoperability, and
• the Digital Commons.

No actor may benefit from uncertainty to withhold or suppress qualifying knowledge.

(m) Anti-Takedown and Anti-Erasure Doctrine
No law, treaty, platform policy, automated system, private contract, or notice-based process may require or permit removal, disabling, blocking, de-indexing, or erasure of any covered material that:
	•	has entered the Digital Commons;
	•	is subject to Jubilee, reversion, or preservation obligations;
	•	constitutes historical, scientific, technical, or cultural record; or
	•	is used for lawful research, interoperability, critique, or archival preservation.

Disputes shall be resolved only by adjudication before the Digital Heritage Authority or a court. Pending adjudication, all materials shall remain accessible in public or escrowed archives. No platform or intermediary incurs liability for preservation. No automated or extrajudicial system may erase public knowledge.

(n) Digital Commons Enforcement Authority (DCEA)
There is established an independent Digital Commons Enforcement Authority charged with protecting the Commons and enforcing this Article. The DCEA shall have subpoena power; authority to compel records and code; power to seize, mirror, and escrow threatened materials; power to issue preservation orders; and standing to bring civil and criminal actions. It shall operate independently and may not be defunded or obstructed.

(o) Preservation-First Rule
When covered materials become the subject of any takedown, copyright, trade-secret, or legal dispute, they shall be immediately mirrored, escrowed, and preserved in full. No removal, de-indexing, or access restriction may occur until adjudication is complete. No party may benefit from erasure or delay.

(p) Anti-DMCA and Anti-Censorship Override
No statute, treaty, regulation, or private enforcement system may override this Article. Where conflict exists, preservation and the Digital Commons control. Automated takedowns and platform censorship of covered materials are void.

(q) Penalties for Erasure and Suppression
Any entity that issues unlawful takedowns, suppresses Commons materials, destroys or hides code, or algorithmically buries qualifying knowledge commits spoliation of the Commons and shall be subject to:
	•	forfeiture of exclusive rights;
	•	compulsory disclosure;
	•	civil liability;
	•	criminal liability where willful or systematic; and
	•	permanent exclusion from government contracts and custodianship.

(r) Anti-Evasion and Corporate Piercing
No corporate structure, DRM system, cloud architecture, platform gate, or contractual web may evade Jubilee or preservation. The DCEA may pierce corporate veils and treat interdependent systems as a single covered work.

(s) Whistleblower Protection and Bounty
Any person who discloses violations of this Section is immune from retaliation, NDA enforcement, trade-secret claims, or liability. Where disclosure leads to enforcement or recovery, the whistleblower shall receive a portion of recovered value, legal protection, and public-service priority.

(t) Jury of the Digital Commons
All major disputes under this Section shall be triable before a jury of the People, empowered to determine suppression, lineage fraud, monopoly, and enforcement remedies. No case may be resolved solely by administrative or private tribunal.

(u) Interpretation
This Section shall be construed to prevent erasure of knowledge, end artificial technological scarcity, and preserve the inheritance of human innovation. Where ambiguity exists, interpretation shall favor openness, preservation, and the People over control. A Republic that forgets how it was built cannot long endure.

Section 8. Mandatory Commons Convergence
 (a) Principle Fragmentation of mature foundational technologies is incompatible with the public good.
(b) Convergence Trigger After fifty (50) years from initial release, all Commons technologies become reciprocally usable.
(c) Effect License barriers to reuse cease; attribution may persist but exclusion may not.
(d) Enforcement Attempts to enforce expired license barriers constitute civil offenses.
(e) Presumption of Openness

Where ambiguity exists regarding the scope, timing, or applicability of commons reversion, release, derivative equity, or disclosure obligations, such ambiguity shall be resolved in favor of:

• public access,
• preservation,
• interoperability, and
• the Digital Commons.

No actor shall benefit from uncertainty to withhold, delay, or suppress software or technical knowledge that would otherwise qualify for public release.

Section 9. Artificial Intelligence Models and Training Data
 (a) Model Sunset AI models enter the Digital Commons upon forty (40) years, ten (10) years of abandonment, or steward dissolution.
(b) Disclosure Architecture, methodologies, and non-sensitive weights shall be disclosed; raw data may remain private subject to transparency of sources and bias.
(c) Convergence After convergence, interoperability and cross-model research may not be obstructed.

Section 10. Education and Technological Literacy
 The Republic shall ensure citizens can understand technology, recognize manipulation, and participate meaningfully in digital society.

Section 11. Enforcement and High Crimes
 (a) Grave Offenses Weaponization of technology against the People, mass digital manipulation, and suppression of essential knowledge may constitute grave or third-tier crimes.
(b) Proof Standards Civil remedies require clear and convincing evidence; criminal liability requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt, consistent with Article VII.

Section 12. Search, Indexing, and Information Neutrality Search and recommendation systems shall not manipulate visibility for ideological or political advantage and must disclose ranking principles.

Section 13. Artificial Intelligence Oversight in Government No person may be governed by opaque systems. Oversight shall be independent and subject to judicial review.

Section 14. Prohibition on Digital Destabilization The Republic shall not employ algorithmic manipulation or AI-driven conditioning to coerce domestic or foreign populations.

Section 15. Biological Knowledge and Genetic Stewardship Life-critical medicines, seeds, and genetic knowledge shall enter the Commons after defined sunsets. Monopoly over life is prohibited.

Section 16. Prohibition on Knowledge Suppression Lawfully commons-held knowledge shall not be concealed or algorithmically buried. Control of visibility is control of thought.

Section 17. Search and Epistemic Integrity Discovery systems are cognitive infrastructure and shall remain neutral and auditable.

Section 18. Harmonization and Anti-Fragmentation This Article shall be read in harmony with Articles VII, IX, XVII, and XIX. Courts shall evaluate substance over form.

Section 19. Prohibition on Social Credit and Ideological Scoring No system may condition access to rights, services, or markets on ideological, political, or behavioral scoring, including ESG-style frameworks. Neutral compliance with safety, environmental, or labor law is permitted.

Section 20. Interpretation This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that technology remains subordinate to human dignity, democratic self-rule, and truth. Where ambiguity exists, interpretation shall favor liberty over control, transparency over secrecy, accountability over convenience, and the People over systems.
For knowledge is light, and light must never be hidden.


Section 21. Open Technical Education and Workforce Access

(a) Knowledge Without Gatekeepers
No person shall be denied access to learning, practicing, or contributing to software, artificial intelligence, digital systems, or technical fields on the basis of proprietary tools, closed platforms, corporate credentialing, or platform-controlled ecosystems.

The Digital Commons shall serve as a universal technical learning environment.

(b) Commons-Based Education

Congress shall ensure that the Digital Commons includes:
	•	full repositories of open software, source code, tools, and build systems;
	•	public documentation, manuals, and engineering references;
	•	historical systems and modern platforms for study, emulation, and training;
	•	open development environments accessible without proprietary licenses.

No corporation, platform, or vendor may monopolize the pathways by which engineers, developers, or technologists are trained.

(c) Open Credentialing

The Republic shall recognize Commons-Based Credentials, including:

• publicly verifiable code contributions;
• peer-reviewed open-source work;
• technical challenges and audits;
• and demonstrated system mastery.

No employer, government agency, or licensing body may require exclusive reliance on corporate, proprietary, or platform-issued certifications where equivalent Commons credentials exist.

(d) Right to Practice and Publish

Every person has the right to:

• write, run, test, and distribute lawful software;
• contribute to open projects;
• operate servers, platforms, and services;
• publish tools, models, and code;
• and participate in the Digital Commons

without platform discrimination, app-store gatekeeping, or vendor lock-in.

(e) Anti-Platform Gatekeeping

No operating system, device, cloud provider, marketplace, or platform may:

• restrict access to development tools;
• require proprietary SDKs or approval to write or deploy software;
• impose fees, licenses, or identity controls to participate in programming;
• or block lawful educational or development use.

(f) Workforce Mobility and Non-Extortion

No firm may require:

• proprietary toolchains;
• closed certifications;
• non-compete clauses;
• code ownership over personal or Commons-based work;
• or platform dependency

as a condition of employment, contracting, or professional participation.

Knowledge belongs to the People, not the employer.

(g) Apprenticeship and Commons Service

Congress shall establish:

• open apprenticeships;
• Commons-based technical service;
• and public digital infrastructure projects

as recognized civic and professional pathways under Article III and Article XX.

Service to the Digital Commons shall qualify as civic contribution.

(h) Enforcement

Violations of this Section constitute technological capture and are enforceable by:

• the Digital Commons Enforcement Authority;
• juries of the People;
• inspectors general;
• and any affected citizen.

Remedies include nullification of abusive contracts, restitution, platform access orders, and disqualification of gatekeeping firms from public contracts.


Article X-A — Digital Commons, Preservation, and Technological Continuity

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Additive Effect

This Article supplements Article X — Knowledge, Technology, and the Digital Commons.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to repeal, narrow, suspend, rebalance, condition, or reinterpret any provision, prohibition, right, or safeguard contained in Article X.

Silence in this Article shall not be construed as authorization to weaken, privatize, destroy, or withhold access to the digital commons protected under Article X.

⸻

Section 2. Digital Heritage and Civilizational Memory

Digital works, systems, formats, and infrastructures of enduring cultural, scientific, educational, or technical significance constitute part of the digital heritage of the People.

Digital heritage is held in trust for present and future generations and shall not be deliberately destroyed, rendered inaccessible, or allowed to decay through neglect where preservation is reasonably practicable.

The preservation of digital heritage is a constitutional interest, not a discretionary policy preference.

⸻

Section 3. Technological Abandonment and Reversion to the Commons

A digital work, system, or platform shall be deemed abandoned where:
	1.	it is no longer supported, maintained, or meaningfully accessible by its steward;
	2.	it is commercially sunset without provision for continuity or access;
	3.	its continued enclosure serves no legitimate public or productive purpose.
