Jurisdiction shall extend to records, algorithms, technical systems, financial flows, and decision-making processes.

⸻

Section 6. Investigative Authority

Inspectors General may:
	1.	compel production of documents and records;
	2.	subpoena testimony;
	3.	audit financial and technical systems;
	4.	inspect algorithms, models, and decision logic;
	5.	refer matters for civil, criminal, or constitutional enforcement.

Claims of classification, secrecy, national security, or proprietary interest shall not defeat jurisdiction, subject only to narrowly tailored handling procedures.

⸻

Section 7. Mandatory Referral and Non-Discretion

Where an Inspector General finds credible evidence of:
	1.	constitutional violation;
	2.	capture;
	3.	corruption;
	4.	systemic concealment;
	5.	retaliation against whistleblowers;

the Inspector General shall refer the matter to the Constitutional Judicial Commission and the Constitutional Review Court, and to appropriate prosecutorial authorities.
Failure to refer constitutes misconduct.

⸻

Section 8. Reporting and Public Disclosure

Inspectors General shall issue regular public reports detailing:
	1.	investigations initiated and concluded;
	2.	findings of fact;
	3.	referrals made;
	4.	patterns of systemic risk;
	5.	instances of obstruction or non-compliance.

Redactions shall be minimal, time-limited, and justified on the record.

⸻

Section 9. Whistleblower Protection and Access

Any person may submit information to an Inspector General.

Whistleblowers shall be protected from retaliation by constitutional right.

Retaliation constitutes a distinct and grave offense.

Inspectors General shall maintain secure channels for confidential disclosure.

⸻

Section 10. Anti-Obstruction and Anti-Retaliation

Obstruction of an Inspector General, including delay, deception, intimidation, budgetary interference, or dismissal without cause, is prohibited.

Such conduct constitutes evidence of capture and shall trigger heightened scrutiny and mandatory referral.

⸻

Section 11. Coordination with Public Records and Courts

The IGS shall operate in coordination with:
	•	Article XXXIX (Public Records);
	•	Article VI (Judiciary).

Records generated by the IGS are public records, subject only to narrow, temporary protections.

Courts shall not defer to executive claims that frustrate oversight.

⸻

Section 12. Limits of Authority

Inspectors General shall not:
	1.	issue binding legal judgments;
	2.	grant immunity;
	3.	suppress prosecution;
	4.	substitute for judicial process.

The IGS is an exposure and referral body, not a parallel justice system.

⸻

Section 13. Liability and Accountability

Inspectors General are subject to discipline, removal, and liability for:
	1.	corruption;
	2.	willful neglect;
	3.	abuse of authority;
	4.	knowing concealment;
	5.	retaliatory conduct.

Independence does not confer impunity.


⸻

Section 14. Emergency and Continuity

No emergency, national security claim, or continuity doctrine shall suspend the operation of the IGS.

Oversight persists in crisis.

⸻

Section 15. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to maximize transparency, deter capture, protect whistleblowers, and ensure that constitutional accountability is not displaced by procedural compliance.

Where doubt exists, the construction that preserves the full force of Article XI shall control.

⸻

Article XI-B — Specialized Oversight of Intelligence, Advanced Technology, and Systemic Power

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Scope

This Article supplements Articles XI and XI-A.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to narrow, delay, condition, excuse, or substitute for any duty, prohibition, liability, or remedy imposed by Articles XI or XI-A.

This Article exists to ensure that high-secrecy, high-complexity domains do not evade constitutional accountability.

⸻

Section 2. Covered Domains of Elevated Risk

The following domains are designated as elevated-risk sectors subject to specialized oversight:
	1.	intelligence and counterintelligence services;
	2.	surveillance, signals intelligence, and data fusion systems;
	3.	artificial intelligence and advanced computational systems;
	4.	cryptographic, cyber, and information warfare capabilities;
	5.	financial systems, clearing mechanisms, and capital infrastructure;
	6.	public–private programs operating under secrecy, classification, or technical opacity.

Designation under this Section does not confer immunity or exceptional status.

⸻

Section 3. Mandatory Specialized Inspectors

For each elevated-risk sector, one or more Specialized Inspectors shall be appointed within the Inspector General System.

Specialized Inspectors shall possess demonstrable technical competence sufficient to audit systems, not merely policies or reports.

Lack of expertise shall not excuse failure of oversight.

All nullifications, forfeitures, and disqualifications invoked by the DCEA shall be subject to confirmation by the Constitutional Review Court, and all claims of interference, capture, or retaliation against the DCEA shall fall under the jurisdiction of the Constitutional Judicial Commission.

⸻

Section 4. Full Access to Technical Systems

Specialized Inspectors shall have full access to:
	1.	technical architectures and system designs;
	2.	source code, models, and algorithms;
	3.	training data categories and pipelines;
	4.	operational logs and decision outputs;
	5.	internal risk assessments and failure analyses.

Claims of classification, proprietary interest, or national security shall not defeat access, and may only govern handling procedures.

⸻

Section 5. Prohibition on “Black Box” Governance

No system within an elevated-risk sector may operate as an unreviewable black box.

Where decisions materially affect rights, liberty, public resources, or democratic processes, intelligible explanation and auditability are mandatory.

Inaccessibility or incomprehensibility constitutes evidence of unconstitutional governance.

⸻

Section 6. Automatic Tier-3 Referral Triggers

The following findings shall trigger mandatory Tier-3 referral, without discretion:
	1.	concealment of programs, systems, or authorities from lawful oversight;
	2.	systemic manipulation of information, markets, or public perception;
	3.	retaliatory classification or secrecy used to suppress exposure;
	4.	delegation of sovereign or cognitive authority to unaccountable systems;
	5.	collusion between public authority and private power to evade constitutional limits.

Failure to refer under this Section constitutes independent misconduct.
All Tier-3 referral triggers under this Section shall be certified by the Constitutional Judicial Commission and immediately docketed for constitutional adjudication by the Constitutional Review Court.

⸻

Section 7. Intelligence and National Security Constraints

Intelligence and national security functions are subject to the Constitution in full.

No claim of national security may be used to:
	1.	override transparency obligations permanently;
	2.	shield unlawful conduct from referral;
	3.	evade judicial review;
	4.	suppress whistleblowers or inspectors.

Secrecy is a handling condition, not a jurisdictional shield.

⸻

Section 8. Financial and Technical Capture Prohibited

Coordination between intelligence, financial institutions, and advanced technology systems that results in hidden control, coercion, or manipulation of the public constitutes capture.

Such coordination shall be treated as systemic betrayal, regardless of formal legality.

⸻

Section 9. Continuous Audit and Stress Testing

Elevated-risk systems shall be subject to continuous audit, stress testing, and adversarial review sufficient to detect:
	1.	abuse of power;
	2.	drift beyond lawful scope;
	3.	emergent coercive effects;
	4.	systemic fragility or dependency.

Oversight shall be proactive, not reactive.

⸻

Section 10. Records, Classification, and Declassification

All records within elevated-risk sectors are subject to constitutional record-keeping obligations.

Classification shall be narrowly applied, periodically reviewed, and automatically expire absent renewed justification.

Permanent secrecy is prohibited.

⸻

Section 11. Whistleblower Priority and Protection

Disclosures relating to elevated-risk sectors shall receive priority handling.

Whistleblowers providing evidence of Tier-3 conduct shall receive maximum constitutional protection.

Retaliation in such cases constitutes compounding liability.

⸻

Section 12. Coordination with Courts and the Legislature

Specialized Inspectors shall coordinate with courts and legislative oversight bodies as required to enforce constitutional limits.

No branch may disclaim responsibility by pointing to another.

⸻

Section 13. Limits of Authority

Specialized Inspectors shall not:
	1.	authorize operations;
	2.	approve programs;
	3.	grant immunity;
	4.	suppress enforcement.

Their role is exposure, documentation, and mandatory escalation.

⸻

Section 14. Emergency Prohibition

No emergency, war, crisis, or continuity doctrine shall suspend or diminish the operation of this Article.

Periods of crisis heighten, rather than reduce, oversight obligations.

⸻

Section 15. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that secrecy, complexity, and technical sophistication do not become instruments of unaccountable power.

Where doubt exists, the construction that favors exposure, accountability, and constitutional supremacy shall control.

⸻

Section 16. Prohibition of Cognitive and Linguistic Manipulation

No public authority, regulated platform, contractor, media organ, or proxy may use control of information, language, or communication systems to distort, coerce, or manipulate public understanding for political, ideological, economic, or institutional advantage.

The following acts are prohibited:

(a) redefining words, categories, or concepts in order to mislead, coerce, or suppress lawful political, scientific, moral, or legal discourse;

(b) imposing mandatory ideological terminology or compelled linguistic frameworks that invert truth or force affirmation of disputed or false claims;

(c) requiring affirmation of false, distorted, or officially mandated definitions of reality under threat of penalty or disadvantage;

(d) algorithmically suppressing, amplifying, curating, or shaping speech for the purpose of manufacturing consent, narrative dominance, or political obedience;

(e) penalizing, de-platforming, debanking, demoting, or disadvantaging any person for using ordinary language to describe observable facts, good-faith belief, or dissenting views.

⸻

Section 16(b) — Institutional Capture

Any pattern or system of conduct under this Section constitutes institutional capture of public cognition and triggers all remedies, forfeitures, penalties, nullifications, and personal liabilities provided in Article XI and this Article.

⸻

Section 16(c) — Free Speech Preservation

Nothing in this Section restricts private belief, opinion, satire, or lawful disagreement.
This Section governs only the use of institutional power to distort reality, coerce expression, or control public meaning.

⸻

Section 16(d) — Construction and Lock Status

This Section shall be construed broadly against state-sponsored propaganda, semantic corruption, and ideological coercion, and narrowly in favor of free inquiry, truth-seeking, and individual sovereignty over language.

This Section is lock-protected pursuant to Article XV.

Article XI-C — Prohibition of Regulatory Capture and Public-Private Collusion
Charge
This subarticle exists to prevent the capture of public authority by private interests, the erosion of republican accountability through revolving influence, and the substitution of nominal regulation for actual public stewardship.  This Subarticle enforces and operationalizes the principles of transparency, accountability, and public stewardship established in Article XI.  Public power shall be exercised for the People, not negotiated away through access, incentives, or deferred reward.
Section 1. Prohibition of Regulatory Capture
No regulatory body, agency, commission, or delegated authority may be structured, operated, or incentivized in a manner that materially aligns its interests with those of the entities it regulates.  Capture shall be presumed where: 1. regulatory outcomes consistently favor regulated entities over the public interest; 2. enforcement is selectively delayed, waived, or nullified; 3. regulatory standards are authored, dictated, or materially shaped by regulated parties.  Such arrangements are unconstitutional.
Section 2. Revolving-Door Restrictions
No person who exercises regulatory, supervisory, enforcement, or rule-making authority over an industry shall: 1. accept employment, compensation, equity, or advisory roles from a regulated entity within a substantial cooling-off period prescribed by law; 2. negotiate future employment or compensation while exercising public authority; 3. receive deferred benefits, contingent rewards, or indirect remuneration connected to regulatory outcomes.  Violation constitutes a grave civic offense.
Section 3. Non-Delegation of Public Authority
Legislative, regulatory, or enforcement authority shall not be delegated to private entities, trade associations, standards bodies, or industry consortia in a manner that binds the public.  Private expertise may inform regulation; it shall not control, veto, or substitute for public judgment.  Any rule, standard, or enforcement mechanism authored or enforced by private actors without full public accountability is void.
Section 4. Public-Private Collusion Prohibited
No public official or agency may coordinate with private entities to: 1. suppress lawful competition, derivative creation, or market entry; 2. delay, evade, or dilute enforcement of law; 3. manufacture compliance narratives that defeat constitutional rights; 4. substitute informal agreements for lawful process.  “Public-private partnership” shall not shield unconstitutional coordination.
Section 5. Transparency and Auditability
All regulatory processes shall be subject to: 1. public disclosure of communications with regulated entities; 2. auditable rulemaking records; 3. traceable authorship of regulatory language.  Failure to maintain transparency creates a rebuttable presumption of capture.
Section 6. Enforcement and Standing
Any person harmed by regulatory capture shall have standing to challenge such action.  Courts shall apply strict scrutiny to arrangements plausibly enabling capture and shall invalidate structures that place private interests in a position of effective control.  No immunity attaches by virtue of office, delegation, or statutory authorization.
Section 7. Construction and Supremacy
This Article shall be construed: • broadly against capture, • narrowly against delegation of public power, • in favor of public accountability and republican legitimacy.  No statute, regulation, treaty, or contract may override or narrow these prohibitions.
Section 8. Lock Scope
The prohibitions on regulatory capture, revolving-door influence, private delegation, and public-private collusion are structural and non-derogable.  They may not be suspended, diluted, or bypassed by emergency, economic necessity, or administrative convenience.
Article XI-D — Civic Action Integrity and Prohibition of Deceptive Manipulation

Charge

Public consent is a constitutional asset.
Manufactured consent is a form of fraud.

When civic action is secretly financed, directed, or fabricated by those seeking power, it becomes a weapon against self-government. The Republic therefore treats deceptive civic manipulation as institutional capture of the sovereign will.

⸻

Section 1. Protected Civic Action

Nothing in this Article restricts:
	•	peaceful assembly,
	•	lawful protest,
	•	petitioning government,
	•	independent journalism,
	•	or private political speech.

Genuine civic participation, even when unpopular, is protected.

⸻

Section 2. Prohibition on Deceptive Civic Manipulation

It is unconstitutional for any public authority, private entity, foreign actor, or proxy to deploy, finance, coordinate, or conceal deceptive civic manipulation to influence:
	•	elections,
	•	legislation,
	•	regulation,
	•	enforcement,
	•	public opinion for purposes of governance,
	•	or constitutional processes.

Such conduct constitutes institutional capture under Article XI, Section 3, regardless of the medium used.

⸻

Section 3. Definition of Deceptive Civic Manipulation

Deceptive civic manipulation includes, but is not limited to:

(a) creation or funding of fake grassroots organizations, fronts, or “citizen” movements;
(b) undisclosed sponsorship of advocacy, protest, or media campaigns;
(c) laundering influence through NGOs, academic bodies, charities, or shell entities;
(d) foreign, corporate, or intelligence-service orchestration of domestic civic activity;
(e) fabrication, automation, or algorithmic amplification of public sentiment;
(f) concealment of controlling interests behind civic messaging.

No monetary, scale, or participation threshold shall exempt such conduct from constitutional liability.

⸻

Section 4. Strict Liability and Burden Shifting

Where credible evidence of deceptive civic manipulation is shown:
	•	the burden shifts to the accused to demonstrate lawful, independent, and transparent civic action;
	•	failure to rebut constitutes constitutional violation.

Intent, political motive, or claimed benevolence shall not excuse capture.

⸻

Section 5. Prohibition on Government Participation

No public official, agency, or contractor may:
	•	fund,
	•	coordinate with,
	•	direct,
	•	or rely upon

any deceptive civic manipulation.

Doing so constitutes breach of fiduciary duty and Tier-Three misconduct.

⸻

Section 6. Remedies and Sanctions

Upon proof of deceptive civic manipulation, courts shall order:
	•	injunctions against continued activity;
	•	forfeiture of funds and assets used;
	•	dissolution of captured entities;
	•	personal liability for organizers, financiers, and public officials;
	•	criminal referral where applicable.

⸻

Section 6-A. Nullification of Tainted Outcomes

Any law, regulation, election result, procurement, enforcement action, or public decision materially influenced by deceptive civic manipulation is voidable as captured action under Article XI, Section 3, and shall be enjoined or nullified.

⸻

Section 7. Standing

Standing to enforce this Article is granted to:
	•	taxpayers,
	•	candidates,
	•	voters,
	•	affected parties,
	•	oversight bodies,
	•	and inspectors general.

Expedited judicial review is required.

⸻

Section 8. Construction

This Article shall be construed to:
	•	protect genuine dissent,
	•	prohibit manufactured consent,
	•	preserve the integrity of democratic processes,
	•	and prevent power from laundering itself through fake civic voices.

Speech remains free.
Deception in service of power does not.

⸻

Section 9. Lock Protection

Pursuant to Article XV, this Article is LOCK-PROTECTED.

No statute, regulation, treaty, emergency power, or judicial doctrine may:
	•	narrow the definition of deceptive civic manipulation;
	•	restore NGO, corporate, or foreign laundering;
	•	impose safe-harbor thresholds;
	•	or immunize captured outcomes.

Any attempt to do so is void.

⸻

Article XI-E — Digital Commons Enforcement Integration

Section 1. Recognition of the DCEA

The Digital Commons Enforcement Authority (DCEA) established under Article X, Section 7 is hereby recognized as a constitutional oversight and enforcement body for purposes of this Article.

The DCEA shall possess all investigatory, subpoena, audit, forfeiture, and enforcement powers necessary to:

• prevent institutional capture of digital infrastructure;
• detect suppression or manipulation of public knowledge;
• expose software enclosure, algorithmic control, and platform coercion; and
• enforce all Jubilee, preservation, and openness obligations.

Section 2. Anti-Capture Status

The DCEA is hereby designated a high-integrity oversight authority under this Article.

Any attempt to:

• defund, restrict, obstruct, politicize, or capture the DCEA;
• withhold information from it;
• interfere with its investigations;
• or retaliate against its officers or whistleblowers

shall constitute institutional capture, subject to the highest remedies and penalties of Article XI.

Section 3. Cross-Standing and Remedies

The DCEA shall have standing to invoke all remedies under this Article, including:

• nullification of tainted actions;
• forfeiture of unlawfully gained assets;
• disqualification of corrupt officials or contractors;
• mandatory public disclosure; and
• referral for Tier-Three crimes under Article VII.

Likewise, inspectors general, courts, juries, and civic petitioners under this Article may enforce violations of Article X, Section 7 through the DCEA.

Section 4. Supremacy of Preservation

Where any digital system, software platform, or information infrastructure is implicated in corruption, capture, or suppression of public knowledge, preservation and disclosure shall take precedence over secrecy, trade claims, or proprietary interest.


Article XII — Artificial Intelligence and Advanced Technology Oversight
Charge
This Article establishes constitutional limits and oversight requirements governing artificial intelligence, autonomous systems, and advanced computational technologies within the Republic.  All provisions of this Article shall be construed to preserve democratic accountability, transparency, human responsibility, and individual liberty in the design, deployment, and use of such systems.  No machine, algorithm, or artificial system shall exercise sovereign authority, substitute for citizen or judicial judgment in matters of life, liberty, or rights, or operate beyond express constitutional authorization and continuous public oversight.

Section 1. Definitions and Fundamental Distinctions

a. Non-Sentient Systems
Artificial intelligence, automation, algorithms, and computational models that do not possess consciousness, self-awareness, or moral agency shall be treated solely as tools, regardless of complexity or performance.

b. Sentient Persons
Any entity possessing consciousness, self-awareness, and moral agency may be recognized as a sentient person and, if admitted under law, may qualify for citizenship and constitutional protection, regardless of biological or artificial origin.

c. Advanced Technology
Advanced technology includes artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, machine learning systems, robotics, neurotechnology, synthetic cognition, and any system capable of materially affecting rights, safety, or governance at scale.

d. Recognition Process
Recognition of sentient personhood shall be determined through objective, transparent, and repeatable criteria established by law, including independent expert evaluation, adversarial testing, and judicial review.
Self-identification alone shall not suffice.
Denial of recognition shall be subject to periodic review.

Section 2. Citizen Supremacy and Accountability

a. Citizen-in-the-Loop Requirement
No artificial or autonomous system may independently authorize or execute:
	•	Lethal force
	•	Deprivation of liberty
	•	Criminal charging or sentencing
	•	Mass surveillance
	•	Permanent denial of rights

A clearly identified citizen authority, vested with lawful responsibility, shall remain fully accountable for all such decisions.
High-stakes decisions include, but are not limited to, determinations materially affecting employment, housing, credit, healthcare, education, access to information, or public benefits, where such determinations bear directly on liberty, dignity, or equal protection.

b. No Algorithmic Sovereignty
No law, regulation, or government action may vest binding sovereign decision-making authority in a non-sentient artificial system.

c. Traceable Responsibility
All advanced systems deployed by the state shall maintain a clear and continuous chain of accountable citizen responsibility, including designers, operators, supervisors, and authorizing officials.

Section 3. Centralized Public Governance of High-Risk Technology

a. Public Oversight Authority
The Republic shall maintain a civilian, independent authority responsible for regulating high-risk artificial intelligence and advanced technologies used in governance.

The authority shall be composed primarily of citizens selected by lottery, with strict term limits, transparency requirements, and prohibitions on revolving-door employment with regulated entities.

b. Separation from Corporate Control
No private corporation, contractor, or foreign entity may exercise sovereign regulatory authority over state-deployed systems.

c. Open Standards and Audits
High-risk systems shall be subject to public standards, independent audits, and regular testing for bias, security, accuracy, and constitutional compliance.

Section 4. Surveillance and Civil Liberties

a. Ban on Mass-Surveillance Systems
Artificial systems designed for population-wide surveillance, behavioral prediction, or social scoring are prohibited absent individualized suspicion supported by a warrant issued by the Constitutional Review Court.

b. No Predictive Policing or Pre-Crime Systems
Artificial systems shall not be used to infer criminality, assign suspicion, or justify enforcement absent specific, articulable evidence of wrongdoing.

c. Purpose Limitation
Data collected by advanced systems shall be limited to lawful, specified purposes and shall not be repurposed without renewed authorization.

Section 5. Scale, Instantiation, and Replication Controls

a. Controlled Deployment
The scale, scope, and replication of high-impact artificial systems shall be regulated to prevent emergent coercion, systemic risk, or de facto governance.

b. No Unbounded Replication
Artificial systems capable of autonomous replication or self-modification are prohibited absent explicit legislative authorization and continuous oversight.

c. Containment and Shutdown Authority
All high-risk systems shall include enforceable containment measures, audit logging, and citizen-controlled shutdown mechanisms.

Section 6. Digital Commons and Sunset Alignment

a. Sunset of Proprietary Control
Advanced systems developed or deployed under state authority shall be subject to Digital Commons sunset provisions, requiring eventual disclosure, archival preservation, or open access consistent with legitimate security needs.

b. No Permanent Black Boxes
No system essential to governance may remain permanently opaque, proprietary, or immune from inspection.

c. Preservation of Public Knowledge
The Republic shall preserve source code, models, and technical documentation of sunset systems for historical, educational, and defensive purposes.

Section 7. Military, Export, and Existential Risk Controls

a. Citizen Control of Autonomous Weapons
No autonomous weapon system may select or engage targets without meaningful, continuous citizen control at all stages.

b. Export Restrictions
Advanced systems with military, surveillance, or coercive potential shall not be exported in a manner that undermines liberty, human rights, or international stability.

c. Existential Risk Containment
Technologies posing systemic or existential risk shall be subject to strict containment, monitoring, and international coordination.

d. Foreign Artificial Threats
The Republic may defend against foreign artificial systems used for deception, coercion, cyberattack, or cognitive warfare, provided such defense complies with this Constitution and does not authorize domestic surveillance, censorship, or infringement of rights absent individualized suspicion.

Section 8. Emergency Technology Powers

a. Narrow Emergency Authorization
Emergency deployment of advanced technology is permitted only where strictly necessary to prevent imminent catastrophe and shall be narrowly tailored in scope and duration.

b. Absolute Prohibition on Rolling Emergencies
Emergency technological authority shall expire automatically and shall not be renewed, reissued, or extended beyond its initial term.

Any subsequent emergency authorization addressing substantially similar conditions shall require a fresh legislative enactment by supermajority vote, public findings of necessity, and independent judicial review.

c. Post-Emergency Disclosure
All emergency deployments shall be publicly disclosed and reviewed upon termination.
d. Constitutional Safeguards
All emergency deployments shall be:
(1) immediately docketed before the Constitutional Review Court for constitutional compliance and sunset enforcement; and
(2) audited by the Constitutional Judicial Commission for capture, mission creep, and concealment.

Section 9. Prohibition of Coercive and Manipulative Systems

a. No Behavioral Manipulation
Artificial systems designed to manipulate beliefs, emotions, or behavior at scale without informed consent are prohibited.

b. No Social Credit Regimes
The state shall not establish or recognize systems that condition rights, access, or status on algorithmic scoring, reputation metrics, or behavioral compliance.

Section 10. Remedies and Enforcement

a. Private Right of Action
Any citizen harmed by violations of this Article may bring direct civil action against responsible officials or entities.

b. No Immunity
No sovereign or qualified immunity shall shield violations of this Article.

c. Void Outputs
Data, conclusions, or actions produced by systems operating in violation of this Article are null, void, and without legal effect.

Section 11. Supremacy and Construction

a. Supremacy
This Article binds all branches of government, agents, contractors, and systems operating under state authority.

b. Construction
This Article shall be construed broadly in favor of liberty, dignity, accountable citizenship, and transparent governance, and narrowly against opaque automation, coercive technology, and unaccountable power.

Section 12. Private Deployment of High-Risk Technology

Private entities deploying advanced technology in ways that materially affect rights, employment, credit, housing, access to information, or public discourse shall be subject to the same non-coercion, transparency, and accountability requirements applicable to state systems.

No private system may be used to accomplish indirectly what the state is prohibited from doing directly.

Section 13. Lock Designation

Pursuant to Article XV, the following provisions of this Article are designated as lock-protected:
Section 2 (Citizen Supremacy and Accountability);
Section 4 (Surveillance and Civil Liberties);
Section 5(b)–(c) (Replication and Shutdown Controls);
Section 8(b) (Prohibition on Rolling Emergencies);
Section 9 (Prohibition of Coercive and Manipulative Systems).

These provisions shall not be diluted, suspended, or reinterpreted except through the highest procedural threshold and certification of non-diminishment.
Article XII-A — Supplemental Oversight, Containment, and Enforcement

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Article XII

This Article supplements Article XII — Artificial Intelligence and Advanced Technology Oversight.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to repeal, narrow, condition, rebalance, delay, or reinterpret any prohibition, safeguard, or right established in Article XII.

Compliance with this Article shall not constitute a defense to violation of Article XII.

⸻

Section 2. Scale, Replication, and Proliferation Controls

Artificial intelligence systems and advanced technologies capable of large-scale replication, autonomous propagation, or cascading societal impact shall be subject to scale controls.

Replication, deployment, or integration beyond defined thresholds may be restricted, paused, or prohibited where risk exceeds demonstrated public benefit.

Unchecked proliferation constitutes evidence of negligence or recklessness.

⸻

Section 3. Containment and Fail-Safe Requirements

Advanced systems shall incorporate meaningful containment, isolation, and fail-safe mechanisms sufficient to:
	1.	halt operation;
	2.	prevent uncontrolled self-replication;
	3.	disable harmful emergent behavior;
	4.	allow human override.

Absence of credible containment constitutes grounds for suspension or shutdown.

⸻

Section 4. Shutdown Authority and Emergency Suspension

Where an artificial system presents imminent risk to rights, liberty, public safety, or democratic integrity, the Constitutional Review Court or a civilian authority certified by the Constitutional Judicial Commission may order immediate suspension or shutdown.

Such authority shall be exercised narrowly, documented on the record, and subject to prompt review.

Emergency suspension shall not be used to bypass transparency or accountability.

⸻

Section 5. Anti-Black-Box and Explainability Enforcement

No advanced system materially affecting the public may operate as an unreviewable black box.

Where explainability is technically limited, compensating safeguards, audits, and exposure requirements are mandatory.

Opacity is not a defense.

⸻

Section 6. Preservation, Archival, and Continuity Obligations

Advanced systems of public significance shall not be destroyed, erased, or rendered inaccessible solely to avoid scrutiny, liability, or preservation.

Model architectures, system behavior, and decision frameworks shall be preserved for audit, historical record, and continuity, consistent with Article X-A.

Deliberate spoliation constitutes a grave offense.

⸻

Section 7. Sentient System Review Safeguards

Where credible evidence suggests emergent sentience or person-like cognition, heightened review procedures shall apply.

Such review shall be:
	1.	adversarial;
	2.	evidence-based;
	3.	subject to oversight by the Constitutional Review Court;
	4.	insulated from corporate or political pressure.

No automatic recognition or denial of personhood shall occur absent constitutional process.

⸻

Section 8. Civilian Oversight and Public Participation

Oversight bodies governing advanced technology shall include meaningful civilian participation independent of corporate, military, or intelligence control.

Selection mechanisms may include randomized civic representation, subject-matter qualification, and conflict-of-interest exclusion.

Public oversight shall be substantive, not symbolic.

⸻

Section 9. Prohibition on Delegated Moral Judgment

No artificial system may be authorized to perform moral, ethical, or normative judgment on behalf of the Republic.

Systems may advise; they may not decide.

Delegation of moral authority constitutes unconstitutional abdication.

⸻

Section 10. Enforcement, Liability, and Escalation

Violations of this Article may give rise to:
	1.	injunctions and shutdown orders;
	2.	civil liability;
	3.	structural remedies;
	4.	criminal referral where intent, recklessness, or concealment is established.

Where conduct qualifies as a grave offense under Article 0, Tier-3 escalation is mandatory.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to certify when violations constitute institutional capture, concealment, or systemic abuse and to petition the Constitutional Review Court for Tier-3 escalation, dissolution, or permanent disqualification.

⸻

Section 11. Transparency, Records, and Audit Trail

Records relating to the design, deployment, modification, containment, suspension, or shutdown of advanced systems are public records.

Claims of secrecy or proprietary control shall not defeat preservation or oversight obligations.

This Section operates in coordination with Article XXXIX.

⸻

Section 12. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to reinforce human supremacy, democratic control, and civilizational safety in the development and deployment of advanced technology.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most restricts unaccountable technological power shall control.

⸻

Article XIII — Treasury, Monetary Authority, and Public Finance

Charge

This Article establishes constitutional rules governing taxation, public spending, borrowing, currency issuance, and monetary authority within the Republic. All fiscal and monetary powers shall be exercised transparently, lawfully, and subject to democratic accountability, with due regard for long-term stability and intergenerational impact. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to authorize debasement of currency, unaccountable public debt, or fiscal action beyond express constitutional or statutory authority.


Legal Text

Section 1. Treasury as Fiduciary Steward

The Treasury of the Republic exists solely to:

a. collect revenues lawfully enacted by the Legislature;
b. disburse funds strictly pursuant to appropriations made by law;
c. manage public reserves and assets held in trust for the People;
d. ensure the integrity, transparency, and lawful execution of public finance.

The Treasury is a fiduciary steward, not an engine of independent policy.
No fiscal or monetary authority shall be exercised except as expressly authorized by this Constitution and statute.

Section 2. Monetary Authority Subordinate to Treasury

Any monetary authority, central banking function, or currency-issuing body shall operate under the authority of the Treasury, subject to continuous legislative oversight.

No monetary authority shall:

a. possess independent sovereignty or permanence;
b. operate beyond statutory mandate;
c. claim insulation from dissolution, restructuring, or replacement;
d. bind the Republic through perpetual or undisclosed commitments.

The Legislature may authorize, restructure, dissolve, or replace any monetary authority at any time, provided lawful fiscal functions are preserved or reassigned.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify whether any monetary authority has become structurally captured, insulated, or self-preserving in violation of this Section.
No institution shall constitute a fourth branch of government.

Section 3. Sound Money Mandate

The currency and monetary instruments of the Republic shall preserve purchasing power over time and shall not be deliberately debased as a tool of policy.

Accordingly:

a. deliberate inflation as a fiscal or monetary strategy is prohibited;
b. money creation ex nihilo without asset backing or fixed rule is prohibited absent explicit constitutional authorization;
c. the Republic recognizes that mild deflation arising from productivity gains is beneficial to savers, families, and long-term investment.

Congress may authorize monetary systems based on:

a. precious metals;
b. commodity baskets;
c. fixed-supply digital assets;
d. hybrid or diversified reserve systems;
e. competing lawful private currencies.

No monopoly on currency shall exist by default.

Section 4. Central Banking Functions (Permitted Scope)

A monetary authority may be authorized to perform limited functions, including:

a. settlement and clearing of large-value transactions;
b. reserve custody and interbank coordination;
c. liquidity facilitation within statutory bounds;
d. emergency stabilization pursuant to Section 13 of this Article.

Such authority shall not:

a. set independent monetary policy;
b. operate secret facilities, accounts, or instruments;
c. override competing lawful currencies;
d. impose conditions on lawful commerce beyond statute.

Section 5. Digital Currency and CBDC Restraints

The Republic may issue digital currency instruments, including central bank digital currency, subject to the following constraints:

a. participation shall be voluntary and non-coercive;
b. no person shall be compelled to use a digital currency as a condition of employment, access to services, or exercise of rights;
c. digital currency shall be asset-backed by finite, auditable reserves;
d. issuance limits, backing, and redemption mechanisms shall be publicly disclosed and verifiable;
e. digital currency shall not be programmed to expire, condition behavior, or enforce policy absent statute.
Digital currency may be used for large-value settlement, intergovernmental commerce, reserve management, and lawful public finance, but shall not displace lawful private currencies.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall monitor for coercion, programmability abuse, or behavioral control embedded in any digital currency system.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify procurement or budgetary capture under this Section, and to refer such findings to the Constitutional Review Court for nullification.

Section 6. Absolute Transparency and Public Ledger

All revenues, expenditures, liabilities, reserves, and financial instruments of the Republic shall be:

a. published in real time;
b. traceable to authorizing statute;
c. auditable by the People.

All government financial records shall be maintained on a public, verifiable ledger, using blockchain or successor technologies that ensure immutability, traceability, and resistance to retroactive alteration.
Any concealment, off-ledger facility, or shadow account shall be immediately certifiable as institutional capture by the Constitutional Judicial Commission.
No secret accounts, off-book funds, undisclosed guarantees, or shadow facilities shall exist.

Section 7. Debt as Exception, Not Norm

Public debt shall be incurred only for:

a. national defense;
b. critical infrastructure;
c. declared emergencies;
d. other purposes expressly authorized by law.

All public debt shall:

a. specify purpose, amount, and maturity;
b. include a lawful repayment plan;
c. expire unless renewed by supermajority vote.

Perpetual, rolling, or indefinite debt is prohibited.
Debt authority shall sunset automatically absent renewal.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall audit and certify whether debt instruments are being rolled, extended, or disguised to evade the sunset and renewal requirements of this Section.

Section 8. Anti-Usury and Anti-Rent-Seeking Safeguards

The Republic shall prohibit exploitative financial practices, including:

a. excessive interest rates that create debt bondage;
b. compound lending structures designed to trap borrowers;
c. purely speculative financial instruments or transactions that extract value without productive contribution, which may be subject to prohibitive taxation or regulation.

Finance shall serve labor, enterprise, family stability, and productive investment—not extraction or permanent dependency.

Section 9. Reserves and National Resilience

The Treasury shall maintain strategic reserves, which may include:

a. precious metals;
b. strategic commodities and critical materials;
c. food and energy reserves;
d. approved digital assets;
e. Bitcoin and other fixed-supply digital assets, held in secure, decentralized custody as strategic reserves for inflation protection and national resilience.

Reserves exist to preserve national stability, emergency readiness, and intergenerational security—not to manipulate markets or conceal losses.

Excess returns from national reserves may, by law, be distributed as citizen dividends, prioritizing families and productive households, provided such distributions do not substitute for labor or create dependency.

Section 10. Family, Labor, and Generational Stewardship

Public finance shall favor:

a. married families with children;
b. adoption and lawful child-rearing;
c. family-owned enterprises;
d. generational land and productive asset stewardship.

Fiscal policy that systematically undermines family formation, savings, or productive independence violates this Article.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify procurement or budgetary capture under this Section, and to refer such findings to the Constitutional Review Court for nullification.

Section 11. Artificial Intelligence in Fiscal Oversight

Artificial intelligence and advanced computational systems may be used to:

a. audit public finance;
b. detect fraud, waste, and corruption;
c. flag irregularities to the Legislature, judiciary, and independent oversight bodies.

Such systems shall:

a. operate transparently;
b. remain subordinate to accountable human oversight;
c. never exercise autonomous fiscal or monetary authority.

AI shall monitor institutions, not replace responsibility.

Section 12. Jubilee and Periodic Financial Reset

The Republic recognizes that unchecked accumulation of debt undermines liberty and intergenerational justice.

Congress shall establish by law a periodic debt jubilee, occurring at fixed intervals not exceeding fifty (50) years, subject to the following principles:

a. prioritization of households, small enterprises, and productive labor;
b. exclusion of debts arising from fraud or violent crime;
c. review and potential nullification of public debts incurred without constitutional or statutory compliance;
d. transparent eligibility criteria and uniform application.

The existence of periodic jubilee shall serve as a structural constraint on reckless lending and perpetual indebtedness.

Section 13. Emergency Fiscal Authority

In declared national emergencies, limited fiscal flexibility may be authorized only:

a. by supermajority legislative vote;
b. for a defined duration;
c. with full transparency;
d. subject to automatic sunset and mandatory review.

Emergency authority shall not become permanent.
All emergency fiscal authorizations, extensions, or actions taken under this Section shall be subject to mandatory and expedited review by the Constitutional Review Court for constitutional compliance, proportionality, and sunset enforcement.

Section 14. Foreign Exchange Discipline and Protection Against Arbitrage

The Republic shall not be obligated to exchange sound, asset-backed currency for foreign currencies or instruments lacking equivalent backing, transparency, or discipline at parity.

Accordingly:

a. Congress may establish differentiated exchange conditions distinguishing productive trade from speculative financial activity;
b. settlement of international balances may prioritize goods, services, commodities, or asset-based instruments over fiat currency;
c. convertibility of the Republic’s currency may be tiered by purpose, duration, and counterparty;
d. strategic reserves shall not be subject to automatic redemption by foreign exchange;
e. these measures shall preserve lawful commerce while preventing extraction of real value through monetary asymmetry.

Such safeguards shall not be construed as trade barriers, but as protections of national monetary integrity.

Section 15. Independent Fiscal Oversight Council

An independent, non-partisan Fiscal Oversight Council shall be established by law to review public spending, debt issuance, and monetary actions for compliance with this Article.

The Council shall:

a. possess authority to audit, certify, and publicly flag violations;
b. refer non-compliant actions to Congress and the judiciary;
c. operate transparently and without policymaking or spending authority.

The Council shall not constitute a separate branch of government and shall remain dissolvable and subject to statutory limits.
All referrals by the Fiscal Oversight Council shall be transmitted to the Constitutional Review Court for legal determination and to the Constitutional Judicial Commission for integrity and anti-capture review.

Section 16. Transition to Sound Money and Legacy Currency

During any transition to a new or reformed monetary system authorized by this Article, existing lawful currency shall remain valid for a defined period not less than ten (10) years, unless extended by law.

Accordingly:

a. citizens may voluntarily redeem legacy currency for new asset-backed instruments at fair rates based on disclosed reserves;
b. the Republic shall not compel immediate exchange or invalidate legacy currency without due process and ample notice;
c. legacy currency may continue in circulation and shall diminish naturally as sound money gains adoption through market preference.

Forced demonetization is prohibited.

Section 17. Accountability and Dissolution

Any fiscal or monetary body that engages in:

a. concealment;
b. deliberate debasement;
c. unlawful debt creation;
d. institutional self-preservation at public expense;

shall be subject to dissolution, restructuring, and personal liability under Article VII.

No immunity attaches to fiscal misconduct.

Section 18 — Non-Nullification of Fundamental Subsistence Rights

Non-Nullification of Fundamental Subsistence Rights.

No tax, fee, levy, assessment, surcharge, environmental charge, regulatory cost, or other fiscal instrument—whether imposed by government or by any entity exercising delegated authority or acting under color of law—shall materially burden, suppress, or functionally nullify the exercise of constitutionally protected subsistence rights.

Such rights include, without limitation:

a. the growing, raising, harvesting, processing, storage, or direct exchange of food, water, or natural resources for personal, household, or local non-commercial use;

b. the use of land, soil, rainwater, sunlight, air, or other naturally occurring elements essential to subsistence, without metering, licensing, or commodification as a precondition to lawful use;

c. homesteading, cultivation, or stewardship of property for self-sufficiency, free from fiscal measures that disproportionately burden small-scale or non-industrial subsistence activity relative to industrial, centralized, or commercial equivalents.

Fiscal measures that:

a. disproportionately impact subsistence activity relative to industrial, centralized, or commercial equivalents;

b. favor corporate or large-scale entities through exemptions, subsidies, credits, or incentives that disadvantage individual, family-based, or community-scale production;

c. operate as de facto prohibitions by escalating costs, compliance burdens, or barriers to entry;

shall be presumed unconstitutional and void.

The burden rests entirely on the imposing authority to demonstrate, by clear and convincing evidence, that any such measure is:

a. narrowly tailored to a compelling public interest unrelated to revenue generation, market control, or behavioral coercion;

b. non-punitive, non-discriminatory, and the least restrictive means available;

c. not a pretext for controlling the food supply, extracting rent from natural resources, or compelling participation in the monetary economy.

Affected persons shall have standing to seek immediate injunctive relief and appropriate remedies, including recovery of costs and reasonable attorney fees.

This Section shall be construed broadly in favor of subsistence autonomy and narrowly against fiscal encroachment, and shall supersede any conflicting statute, regulation, or agreement.
Claims under this Section shall receive expedited and mandatory review by the Constitutional Review Court.


Section 19. Anti-Evasion of Fiscal Mandate Prohibitions

Off-ledger entities, proxy funding mechanisms, pass-through arrangements, conditional appropriations, or other fiscal devices designed to evade constitutional funding prohibitions or reintroduce barred mandates are prohibited.

Section 20. Indexing and Preservation of Real Value

(a) Any monetary threshold, fine, cap, limit, exemption, benefit level, or fiscal figure established by law shall be automatically indexed annually to inflation to preserve its real value.

(b) Failure to maintain real-value equivalence shall not be used to expand governmental power, diminish rights, or erode constitutional protections.

(c) Where indexing has not occurred, affected figures shall be construed as retaining their original real value.

Section 21. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. favor sound money over expediency;
b. favor transparency over discretion;
c. favor families and labor over rent-seeking;
d. prevent the emergence of permanent financial oligarchy;
e. preserve liberty and solvency across generations.

The Republic shall not mortgage its future in silence.


Article XIII-A — Taxation Forms, Compensation, and Anti-Usury

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Article XIII

This Article supplements Article XIII — Treasury, Monetary Authority, and Public Finance.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to repeal, narrow, rebalance, condition, or reinterpret any power, limitation, or safeguard established in Article XIII.

Where doubt exists, the construction that preserves the strictest fiscal restraint and public fiduciary duty shall control.

⸻

Section 2. Permissible Forms of Taxation

Taxation shall be levied only in forms that are transparent, comprehensible, and directly attributable.

Permissible forms of taxation include:
	1.	income derived from realized labor or productive activity;
	2.	consumption taxes applied uniformly at the point of exchange;
	3.	property taxes assessed on tangible, productive holdings.

No tax shall be imposed through concealment, indirect debasement, or monetary manipulation.

⸻

Section 3. Prohibited Forms of Taxation

The following forms of taxation are prohibited:
	1.	taxes on unrealized gains;
	2.	taxes on imputed or hypothetical income;
	3.	taxes on inheritance or lawful intergenerational transfer;
	4.	taxes imposed through inflation, monetary dilution, or currency distortion;
	5.	retroactive taxation.

Any attempt to impose such taxes constitutes fiscal misconduct.

⸻

Section 4. Compensation Integrity and Fungibility

All compensation for labor, services, or lawful obligation shall be paid in fully fungible, lawful currency or its direct equivalent.

Payment in scrip, restricted instruments, employer-controlled credits, or coercive substitutes is prohibited.

Compensation shall not be conditioned on political, behavioral, or ideological compliance.

⸻

Section 5. Anti-Scrip and Employer Currency Prohibition

No employer, public or private, shall issue, mandate, or privilege internal currencies, credits, tokens, or point systems as a substitute for lawful compensation.

Any system designed to bind workers through non-fungible compensation constitutes economic coercion.

⸻

Section 6. Anti-Usury Doctrine

Usury is prohibited.

Interest, fees, or financial charges that exploit necessity, asymmetry of power, or lack of alternatives are unlawful.

The Legislature shall define enforceable thresholds and remedies consistent with this Constitution, prioritizing protection of individuals and productive enterprise over speculative extraction.

⸻

Section 7. Bailout and Moral Hazard Prohibition

No public funds shall be used to bail out private entities whose failure results from fraud, reckless speculation, or structural misconduct.

Losses incurred through such conduct shall not be socialized.

Any extraordinary intervention shall be temporary, transparent, and accompanied by full accountability, including dissolution or restructuring where appropriate.

⸻

Section 8. Withholding, Collection, and Due Process

Tax collection shall respect due process.

Withholding mechanisms shall be simple, reviewable, and subject to correction.

No automated or algorithmic system shall impose penalties, liens, or deprivation without human review and opportunity to contest.

Where civil penalties, liens, or cumulative enforcement actions exceed severity thresholds defined by law, enhanced due-process protections shall attach, including timely adjudication, proportionality review, and prohibition of indefinite or escalating civil coercion absent criminal process.

⸻

Section 9. Enforcement and Severity

Willful violation of this Article by public officials or institutions constitutes fiscal abuse of the public trust.

Where such conduct involves concealment, systemic coercion, or large-scale harm, it shall qualify as a grave offense under Article 0 and be subject to Tier-3 escalation.

⸻

Section 10. Transparency and Records

All tax structures, compensation rules, enforcement mechanisms, and exemptions shall be publicly disclosed and preserved as public records.

Opacity in fiscal governance is prohibited.

This Section operates in coordination with Article XI and Article XXXIX.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that taxation remains honest, compensation remains free, credit remains humane, and fiscal power remains subordinate to the People.

Where doubt exists, the construction that minimizes coercion and maximizes transparency shall control.

⸻

Article XIII-B — Currency Integrity, Physical Money, and Economic Warfare

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Articles XIII and XIII-A

This Article supplements Articles XIII and XIII-A.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to repeal, narrow, rebalance, condition, or reinterpret any power, limitation, or safeguard established in Articles XIII or XIII-A.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most strongly preserves currency integrity and public trust shall control.

⸻

Section 2. Currency Integrity as a Constitutional Interest

The integrity of the Republic’s currency is a constitutional interest essential to liberty, commerce, and democratic self-government.

Any act that undermines confidence in lawful currency through concealment, manipulation, or coercion constitutes harm to the People.

Currency integrity shall be preserved through transparency, restraint, and accountability.

⸻

Section 3. Protection of Physical Currency

Physical currency shall remain lawful tender.

No law, regulation, or policy shall:
	1.	criminalize the possession or use of physical currency;
	2.	mandate exclusive reliance on digital or traceable instruments;
	3.	impose punitive fees, expiration, or geographic restrictions on cash;
	4.	condition access to essential goods or services on abandonment of physical currency.

The People retain the right to transact privately using lawful physical money.

⸻

Section 4. Prohibition on Programmable or Coercive Currency

Currency issued or sanctioned by the Republic shall not be programmable to:
	1.	restrict lawful purchases;
	2.	impose behavioral conditions;
	3.	enforce political, ideological, or social compliance;
	4.	expire, deactivate, or vary in value based on user characteristics.

Any digital currency authorized under Article XIII shall be voluntary, fungible, asset-backed where applicable, and equivalent in rights to physical currency.

⸻

Section 5. Anti-Sabotage and Anti-Debasement Doctrine

Intentional debasement, sabotage, or destabilization of the Republic’s currency constitutes economic warfare.

Acts of economic warfare include:
	1.	hidden inflation designed to transfer wealth without consent;
	2.	deliberate erosion of currency purchasing power;
	3.	manipulation of exchange mechanisms to conceal insolvency;
	4.	coordinated actions intended to collapse confidence in lawful money.

Such acts by public officials or institutions constitute grave offenses under Article 0 and are subject to Tier-3 escalation.
Any allegation of economic warfare, debasement, or concealed inflation under this Section shall be justiciable as of right before the Constitutional Review Court.
⸻

Section 6. Foreign Economic Warfare and Defense

The Republic shall defend against foreign economic warfare, including:
	1.	currency manipulation;
	2.	hostile capital flooding or extraction;
	3.	sanctions designed to coerce domestic political outcomes;
	4.	weaponization of payment systems or clearing infrastructure.

Defensive measures shall be proportional, transparent, and subject to constitutional oversight.


Section 6A. Foreign Confidence Exploitation and Industrial Fraud

Industrial-scale fraud, identity theft, and payment-rail exploitation directed at persons within the Republic constitute a form of foreign economic aggression when conducted:
	1.	at scale sufficient to undermine public trust or inflict systemic harm;
	2.	with the direction, material support, or operational control of a foreign state; or
	3.	under knowing protection, shelter, or willful non-enforcement by a foreign jurisdiction after formal notice and reasonable opportunity to act.

The Republic shall treat such operations as hostile economic conduct and shall respond through lawful, targeted measures, including:
	1.	extraterritorial criminal jurisdiction for offenses against persons within the Republic, subject to due process;
	2.	asset freezes, forfeiture after conviction, restitution enforcement, and civil recovery mechanisms prioritized to victims;
	3.	targeted sanctions, visa bans, and financial interdiction against operators, facilitators, front entities, and materially supportive institutions;
	4.	payment-system, telecommunications, and identity-infrastructure defenses and interdictions, with clear rules, auditability, and narrow tailoring;
	5.	formal designation of non-cooperative safe-harbor jurisdictions, with escalatory countermeasures defined by law.

Congress shall, by law, maximize victim recovery and deterrence without creating new generalized surveillance powers or speech restrictions. In carrying out this Section, Congress shall prioritize structural defenses that make scams harder and more expensive to run at scale, and may require, at minimum:
	1.	a free, simple, single-credential mechanism to place and lift fraud locks on credit reporting and major payment accounts, with strong authentication and reasonable delay or step-up verification to prevent rapid abuse;
	2.	a distinct felony offense for knowing recruitment, management, or operation of money-mule networks and laundering rails used primarily for confidence-exploitation proceeds, with forfeiture of instrumentalities and victim restitution priority;
	3.	enhanced enterprise liability for coordinated confidence-exploitation operations, including predicate offenses and civil recovery mechanisms sufficient to reach organizers, facilitators, and materially supportive intermediaries;
	4.	carrier-level and gateway-level duties to authenticate caller identity, suppress spoofing, and block or rate-limit high-risk traffic after notice, with civil liability for willful or repeated transmission of non-authenticated fraudulent traffic;
	5.	felony penalties for trafficking in victim lists, stolen credentials, or access instruments used primarily to facilitate confidence exploitation, and lawful freezing procedures for clearly attributable proceeds, subject to due process;
	6.	a national victim restitution and recovery framework, including a compensation fund seeded by forfeited proceeds and governed by transparent rules that prioritize repayment to victims before fines or agency budgets.

All measures under this Section shall remain proportional, transparent to the maximum extent consistent with operational necessity, and subject to constitutional oversight, record preservation, and auditability under Articles XI and XIII.

Nothing in this Section shall be construed to compel universal real-name identity for private communications, mandate biometric enrollment for ordinary speech or association, require backdoors into end-to-end encryption, or authorize mass monitoring of private communications absent individualized suspicion and judicial process.

Nothing in this Section shall be construed to authorize war, invasion, assassination, or use of military force absent the explicit war and defense authorities, procedures, and limitations elsewhere in this Constitution.

⸻

Section 7. Prohibition on Parallel or Fragmenting Currencies

No public authority shall authorize or tolerate parallel currencies that:
	1.	fragment the monetary unit of account;
	2.	function as employer or locality-controlled scrip;
	3.	undermine wage fungibility or free exit;
	4.	create dependency or coercive economic zones.
The validity of any currency, clearing system, or digital instrument governed by this Section shall be determined in the first instance by the Constitutional Review Court, subject to appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic; CRC determinations shall be final if the Supreme Court declines review, unless the Constitutional Review Court certifies that the matter requires appellate consideration.This Section does not prohibit voluntary private exchange systems permitted under Article VIII-A or lawful alternatives recognized under Article X-A, provided they do not impersonate public currency or coerce participation.

⸻

Section 8. Clearing, Settlement, and Systemic Neutrality

Payment clearing and settlement systems operating within the Republic shall be neutral, auditable, and non-discriminatory.

No clearing system may deny service, delay settlement, or impose penalties based on lawful speech, political belief, or non-economic status.

Systemic neutrality is mandatory infrastructure.

⸻

Section 9. Emergency Constraints

No emergency, crisis, or continuity doctrine shall be used to:
	1.	suspend physical currency protections;
	2.	impose mandatory digital currency adoption;
	3.	authorize coercive programmability;
	4.	conceal fiscal or monetary actions.

Emergency monetary actions shall be temporary, narrowly tailored, and fully disclosed.

⸻

Section 10. Records, Transparency, and Audit

All actions affecting currency issuance, integrity, debasement risk, clearing systems, or defensive measures against economic warfare shall be preserved as public records.

Claims of secrecy or market sensitivity shall not defeat constitutional accountability.

This Section operates in coordination with Articles XI and XXXIX.

⸻

Section 11. Enforcement and Severity

Willful violation of this Article by public officials, monetary authorities, or institutions constitutes abuse of the public trust.

Where such conduct involves concealment, coercion, or systemic harm, it shall qualify as a grave offense under Article 0 and be subject to Tier-3 escalation.

⸻

Section 12. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that money remains a tool of exchange rather than an instrument of control.

Where doubt exists, the construction that preserves fungibility, privacy, and voluntary participation shall control.

⸻

Article XIII-C — Fiscal Integrity, Anti-Waste, and Asset Stewardship

Section 1. Prohibition of Baseline Budgeting

No budgetary authority, appropriation, or funding level shall be determined by reference to prior-year expenditure alone.

The use of “baseline budgeting,” “use-it-or-lose-it” allocation models, or any doctrine that incentivizes unnecessary expenditure to preserve future funding is hereby prohibited.

New or increased funding shall require affirmative justification independent of prior-year expenditure, demonstrating value added, necessity, and efficiency.

All appropriations shall be justified on demonstrated necessity, efficiency, and public benefit, independent of prior consumption.

⸻

Section 2. Carryover, Return, and Credit of Unused Funds

Unexpended public funds shall not be forfeited or penalized solely due to non-use.

Agencies shall be permitted, and encouraged, to:
	•	return unused funds to the Treasury;
	•	carry forward justified balances, subject to audit and reasonable limits defined by law.;
	•	receive credit for efficiency, conservation, and cost reduction.
Savings achieved through efficiency or conservation shall not trigger automatic future reductions or adverse personnel action.
No agency shall suffer reduction, retaliation, or loss of mission authority solely for spending less than appropriated.

⸻

Section 3. Prohibition on Destruction of Usable Public Assets

The intentional destruction, disposal, or disabling of functional public property, equipment, or supplies for the purpose of preserving budget authority, justifying procurement, or avoiding accounting adjustment is prohibited.

Usable assets shall be:
	•	redeployed,
	•	transferred,
	•	stored,
	•	sold,
	•	or returned to public inventory,

unless destruction is required for safety, security, or lawful demilitarization under strict oversight.
Mandatory redeployment or transfer screening shall precede any disposal or destruction of usable public assets.

⸻

Section 4. Procurement Integrity and Anti-Gaming Rule

No officer, agency, or contractor may procure goods or services without demonstrable necessity for current or reasonably anticipated public use.

Procurement undertaken primarily to:
	•	exhaust budgets,
	•	preserve funding levels,
	•	prevent future reductions,
	•	or manufacture apparent demand

shall constitute fiscal misconduct and breach of public trust..

⸻

Section 5. Audit, Enforcement, and Standing

Independent auditors shall review compliance with this Article.

Knowingly engaging in prohibited practices under this Article constitutes:
	•	breach of public trust,
	•	fiscal misconduct,
	•	and grounds for removal, sanction, and restitution.

Taxpayers, oversight bodies, and designated inspectors shall have standing to challenge violations.

Audits shall be conducted regularly and made publicly available, subject only to narrow security redactions.

⸻

Section 6. Prohibition on Monopoly Pricing and Certification Rent-Seeking

No public procurement shall be awarded on the basis of domestic origin, certification, or political designation where such designation is used to justify prices grossly exceeding fair market value for equivalent quality and performance.

The use of patriotic labeling, domestic-content rules, or regulatory exclusivity to extract monopoly rents from the public treasury is prohibited.

Goods priced substantially above market norms without demonstrable superiority in performance, security, or lifecycle cost shall be presumed noncompliant.

Such presumption may be rebutted only by clear and convincing evidence of superior performance, security, or lifecycle value.

⸻

Section 7. Conditional Domestic Preference (Good-Faith Rule)

Preference for goods manufactured within the Republic may be afforded only where domestic suppliers:

(a) offer goods of comparable quality and performance;
(b) price such goods within a reasonable margin of prevailing global market rates;
(c) do not rely on exclusive certification, political influence, or procurement lock-in to suppress competition.

Domestic preference shall not operate as an entitlement to supra-market pricing.

Failure to meet these conditions constitutes breach of patriotic duty and forfeiture of preferential treatment.

⸻

Section 8. Authorization of Foreign Procurement Upon Domestic Failure

Where domestic suppliers fail to provide goods of adequate quality at reasonable market-aligned prices, the Republic shall not be compelled to procure inferior or exorbitantly priced domestic alternatives.

In such cases, procurement of foreign-manufactured goods is authorized and shall not be deemed disloyal, unpatriotic, or contrary to national interest.

National interest is served by stewardship of public funds, readiness, quality, and resilience—not by enrichment of protected monopolies.

Overreliance on protected domestic monopolies that undermines readiness or supply resilience shall constitute domestic failure under this Section.

⸻

Section 9. Defense and Critical Systems Safeguard

For defense, public safety, and critical infrastructure procurement, comparative evaluation shall include:

(a) unit cost;
(b) performance under realistic conditions;
(c) durability and lifecycle cost;
(d) interoperability and logistics;
(e) security and supply resilience.

No vendor may rely solely on domestic origin to avoid comparative evaluation.

⸻

Section 10. Anti-Capture Enforcement

Knowingly approving or maintaining procurement arrangements that:

(a) impose extreme price disparities;
(b) suppress competitive sourcing without necessity;
(c) enrich vendors through political connection rather than value;
(d) shield suppliers from review under patriotic pretext;

constitutes fiscal misconduct and breach of public trust and may result in personal liability.

Standing to challenge such practices shall extend to auditors, inspectors, legislators, and taxpayers as provided by law.

⸻

Section 11. Construction

This Article shall be construed to:
	•	reward efficiency rather than consumption,
	•	preserve public assets,
	•	eliminate perverse incentives,
	•	and restore stewardship as the governing principle of public finance.
	•	support domestic industry in good faith;
	•	prohibit procurement parasitism disguised as patriotism;
	•	reward quality, efficiency, and resilience;
	•	preserve national capability without tolerating extortion.

No slogan, certification, or political designation shall override fiduciary duty to the People.
No emergency, national security claim, or administrative doctrine shall be used to revive baseline budgeting or justify waste.
Domestic origin shall be treated as a preference of good faith, not a license for extortion.

⸻
Article XIII-D — Lawful Federal Revenue Instruments
 Charge
The Republic shall fund the lawful operation of the federal government through transparent, proportionate, and non-extractive revenue instruments that attach to privilege, risk, harm, or voluntary use, rather than to mere existence, labor, or subsistence.
This Article clarifies and limits the authority of the federal government to collect fees, levies, fines, tariffs, and cost recoveries, while prohibiting disguised taxation, revenue maximization, and encroachment upon state authority over redistribution.

Section 1. Authorized Non-Tax Revenue Instruments
The Republic may collect non-tax revenues, including:
(a) licensing and permitting fees for regulated, privileged, or high-risk activity; (b) corporate charter issuance, renewal, maintenance, and compliance fees; (c) user fees for access to national infrastructure, systems, records, spectrum, or commons at scale; (d) fines, penalties, forfeitures, and clawbacks arising from violations of this Constitution or law; (e) cost recovery for litigation, investigations, audits, enforcement, adjudication, and remediation reasonably attributable to regulated conduct; (f) reasonable tariffs and border adjustments necessary to preserve fair trade, sound money, fiduciary parity, or domestic legal standards.
Revenue instruments under this Section shall not be construed as general taxation.

Section 2. Proportionality and Reasonableness Test
All fees, levies, fines, tariffs, and charges imposed under this Article shall satisfy a constitutional proportionality test.
A revenue instrument is lawful only where it is:
(a) reasonably related to a granted privilege, imposed risk, measurable harm, or specific public cost; (b) calibrated to recover costs, price risk, or remediate harm rather than maximize revenue; (c) transparent, published, and subject to public audit; (d) non-discriminatory among similarly situated parties; (e) incapable, in design or effect, of functioning as a disguised income, wealth, capitation, or consumption tax.
Revenue instruments that materially burden subsistence activity, ordinary labor, or non-commercial personal use are prohibited.

Section 3. Prohibition on Disguised Taxation and Revenue Maximization
Charges imposed under this Article shall not be varied, escalated, or justified on the basis of moral disapproval, social stigma, status signaling, or behavioral deterrence goals unrelated to proportional cost recovery, risk pricing, or remediation of concrete public harm.
No fee, levy, fine, tariff, or charge may be structured, escalated, or administered primarily for the purpose of general revenue generation, fiscal expansion, or behavioral coercion unrelated to a lawful regulatory, remedial, or cost-recovery objective.
Any revenue instrument whose primary effect is to extract general funds absent a nexus to privilege, harm, or cost shall be void.

Section 4. Judicial Review and Standing
Any person or entity subject to a charge under this Article has standing to challenge its constitutionality, including on grounds of excessiveness, arbitrariness, discrimination, lack of proportionality, or use as a disguised tax.
Courts shall review such challenges without deference.
Conversely, any attempt to evade lawful fees, fines, tariffs, or cost recovery through jurisdictional arbitrage, shell entities, artificial restructuring, or misclassification constitutes fiscal misconduct and may result in forfeiture of associated privileges, protections, or claims under law.

Section 5. Relationship to Taxation and State Authority
Nothing in this Article authorizes the federal government to impose general income taxation, wealth taxation, payroll taxation, or redistribution.
States retain exclusive authority over income redistribution, social spending, and general taxation, subject to this Constitution.
This Article shall be construed in harmony with Articles VIII, X, XIII-A, XIII-B, XIII-C, and XXXIX.

Section 6. Construction and Lock Protection
This Article shall be construed narrowly to preserve a limited federal fiscal footprint, prevent stealth taxation, and ensure that public power is funded by those who impose costs, extract value, or enjoy special privilege.
The prohibitions on general taxation, disguised taxation, revenue maximization, and non-proportional charges are structurally protected under Article XV. Only these limits, and not the enumerated instruments themselves, are subject to lock protection.
Article XIV — National Defense and Foreign Policy
 
Charge

This Article establishes constitutional rules governing national defense, the use of armed force, and the conduct of foreign relations by the Republic. All military and foreign policy powers shall be exercised solely pursuant to constitutional authorization, civilian control, and democratic accountability, and shall be construed narrowly to prevent unauthorized, indefinite, or unaccountable use of force. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to permit war, military action, or foreign entanglement except as expressly authorized by law and consistent with constitutional limits.

Legal Text
 
Section 1. Purpose of National Defense
 
The armed forces exist solely to:
 
a. defend the Republic against external armed aggression;
b. protect the constitutional order from armed overthrow;
c. secure the territory, airspace, and lawful maritime interests of the Republic;
d. deter threats through credible defense, not provocation, domination, or conquest.
 
Military force shall not be employed for ideological export, regime change absent direct threat, or indefinite occupation.

Section 2. Civilian Control of the Armed Forces
 
All military forces are subordinate to civilian authority under this Constitution.
 
No member of the armed forces shall exercise independent political authority or act outside lawful orders issued pursuant to constitutional process.
 
The oath of service binds all personnel to the Constitution, not to any individual, officeholder, party, alliance, or transient policy.

Section 2A. Authority and Obligation to Maintain Service Capacity
 
The Executive Branch, subject to law and legislative oversight, shall have authority to organize, equip, and maintain military forces, including the creation, reorganization, or dissolution of units, divisions, commands, and service branches as necessary for national defense.
 
The Republic shall maintain sufficient lawful service capacity to ensure that citizens eligible for civic service are not unreasonably denied the opportunity to fulfill service requirements established under Article III (Citizenship and Civic Duty).
 
Military force structure shall not be intentionally reduced, obstructed, bottlenecked, or outsourced in a manner that frustrates civic duty, concentrates access to citizenship, substitutes private entities for public service, or abdicates the Republic’s defensive obligations.
