Nothing in this Section authorizes conscription, emergency expansion absent legislative approval, or the circumvention of constitutional limits on the use of force.

Section 3. Declaration of War, Authorization, and Use of Force
 
No war shall be declared, nor hostilities initiated or sustained, except by:
 
a. a formal declaration of war approved by a two-thirds (⅔) vote of both legislative houses; or
b. an immediate defensive response to an armed attack, limited strictly in scope and duration.
 
Any action initiated under subsection (b) shall:
	1.	be reported to the Legislature within seventy-two (72) hours;
	2.	expire automatically after sixty (60) days unless authorized by recorded legislative vote;
	3.	allow an additional thirty (30) days solely for safe and orderly withdrawal if authorization is denied.

Section 3A. Prohibition on Open-Ended Authorizations (AUMF Restrictions)
 
No Authorization for Use of Military Force, joint resolution, or statutory authorization shall be:
 
a. open-ended in time, geography, enemy designation, or mission scope;
b. interpreted to permit perpetual, rolling, or successor hostilities;
c. extended to new theaters, actors, or conflicts absent explicit reauthorization.
 
All authorizations shall specify:
	1.	defined objectives;
	2.	geographic scope;
	3.	named adversaries or targets;
	4.	legal basis;
	5.	maximum initial duration not exceeding one (1) year.
 
Reauthorization shall be required for continuation.

For purposes of this Article, an armed attack shall mean a kinetic or cyber action causing actual or imminent loss of life, territorial violation, or destruction of critical civilian or military infrastructure. Intelligence assessments, proxy actions, or speculative threats alone shall not suffice.

Section 4. Definition of War and Hostilities
 
For purposes of this Constitution, “war” and “hostilities” include, but are not limited to:
 
a. sustained or repeated airstrikes, drone strikes, missile strikes, naval actions, or cyber operations causing physical destruction or loss of life;
b. cumulative military actions that, taken together, constitute ongoing armed engagement;
c. blockades, kinetic interdictions, or coercive military actions framed as non-war measures.
 
No executive characterization shall exempt such actions from constitutional requirements.
 
Ambiguities shall be resolved against unilateral executive authority and in favor of legislative deliberation.

Section 5. Duration, Sunset, and Review of Armed Engagements
 
All authorized uses of military force shall include:
 
a. defined objectives;
b. geographic scope;
c. legal authority;
d. anticipated duration;
e. clear conditions for termination.
 
No authorization may exceed one (1) year without reauthorization.
 
Cumulative or recurring military actions related to the same conflict or adversary shall be treated as a single engagement for purposes of duration limits.
 
Failure to reauthorize shall mandate withdrawal, except where withdrawal would imminently endanger forces in the field.

Section 6. Limits on Emergency Military Authority
 
No declaration of emergency, national security threat, or foreign crisis shall:
 
a. suspend constitutional rights;
b. alter amendment procedures;
c. permit indefinite military engagement without legislative authorization;
d. justify secrecy beyond strict operational necessity.
 
All emergency military authority is subject to Article XV and judicial review without deference.
Nothing in this Article shall be construed to authorize economic warfare, monetary coercion, or financial sabotage except as expressly permitted and constrained under Article XIII-B.

Section 7. Foreign Treaties, Alliances, and International Obligations
 
Treaties and international agreements shall require:
 
a. disclosure of all material obligations;
b. approval by two-thirds (⅔) of the Legislature;
c. consistency with this Constitution.
 
No treaty, alliance, security pact, or international commitment may:
 
a. supersede constitutional rights;
b. compel domestic lawmaking absent legislative approval;
c. create binding military obligations without legislative authorization for each use;
d. impose perpetual or indefinite defense commitments;
e. override state sovereignty in violation of Article XXVIII.
 
No entangling alliance shall bind the Republic to automatic war.

Section 8. Military Transparency and Accountability
 
The Legislature shall maintain continuous oversight of defense expenditures, operations, intelligence activity, and procurement.
 
Secret law, undisclosed military commitments, and unaccountable intelligence operations are prohibited.
 
Classification shall be limited to operational necessity and subject to periodic review, sunset, and declassification.
 
Grave violations shall be subject to penalties under Article VII.

Section 9. Prohibition of Mercenary and Proxy Forces
 
The Republic shall not outsource the use of force to mercenary entities, private armies, or unaccountable proxies.
 
Any private contractor performing security or military-adjacent functions in contingency operations shall:
 
a. be subject to United States jurisdiction, including UCMJ and MEJA where applicable;
b. operate under full transparency and civilian oversight;
c. be prohibited from offensive combat absent explicit legislative authorization;
d. be individually accountable for unlawful acts.
 
No private force shall be used to evade constitutional war powers.

Section 10. Treatment of Service Members
 
Service members are citizens in uniform, not instruments.
 
They retain constitutional protections except where narrowly limited by necessity of service and due process.
 
No service member shall be compelled to obey unlawful orders. Obedience to unlawful orders shall not be a defense.

Section 11. Foreign Policy Restraint and Diplomacy
 
Foreign policy shall favor diplomacy, lawful trade, cultural exchange, and peaceful cooperation over coercion and force.
 
The Republic shall pursue a predisposition toward restraint and non-intervention, intervening only where constitutionally authorized and demonstrably necessary for defense.
 
Selective or undeclared interventions are prohibited.

Section 12. Judicial Review, Standing, and Remedies
 
Any Civic Citizen, service member, or state with standing may challenge violations of this Article, including ongoing unauthorized operations.
 
Courts may issue injunctive relief, withdrawal orders, and other remedies necessary to enforce constitutional limits.
 
Claims of military necessity or national security shall receive no deference where constitutional structure or rights are implicated.

Section 13. Prohibition on Perpetual Military Commitments
 
No military basing agreement, security pact, or foreign deployment arrangement shall create indefinite obligations.
 
All such commitments require periodic legislative reauthorization and are subject to sunset.

Section 14. Enforcement and Penalties
 
Officials who knowingly authorize, conceal, or sustain unconstitutional military action, unlawful secrecy, or evasion of legislative authority shall be subject to penalties under Article VII, including mandatory Tier Three liability where grave harm results.
 
No immunity shall attach to constitutional violation.

Section 15. Interpretation
 
This Article shall be interpreted to:
 
a. favor defense over domination;
b. favor restraint over intervention;
c. resolve ambiguity against unilateral executive action;
d. preserve civilian supremacy;
e. protect those who serve;
f. prevent normalization of perpetual war.
 
The sword shall defend the Republic—
never rule it.

 
Article XIV-A — Defense Governance and Accountability

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Article XIV

This Article supplements Article XIV — National Defense and Foreign Policy.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to expand war powers, diminish civilian supremacy, or weaken the constraints imposed by Article XIV.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most restricts unaccountable force shall control.

⸻

Section 2. Civilian Supremacy and Unified Command

All military and defense institutions remain subordinate to civilian authority.

No military, intelligence, or security body may exercise independent political authority, initiate hostilities, or define national policy.

Fragmentation of command to evade accountability is prohibited.

⸻

Section 3. Defense Procurement and Anti-Capture Doctrine

Defense procurement shall be transparent, competitive, and subject to continuous audit.

Prohibited practices include:
	1.	revolving-door inducements;
	2.	cost-plus structures without strict justification;
	3.	concealed subcontracting;
	4.	classified procurement used to suppress oversight.

Systemic procurement abuse constitutes capture of the war power.

⸻

Section 4. Intelligence Boundaries and Military Separation

Intelligence services shall support, not direct, military operations.

No intelligence body may:
	1.	initiate force;
	2.	conduct lethal operations absent lawful authorization;
	3.	substitute covert action for declared hostilities.

Intelligence is informational, not sovereign.

⸻

Section 5. Prohibition on Permanent or Private Militaries

Standing armed forces shall exist only under constitutional authorization.

Private military forces, mercenary organizations, or deniable proxy forces acting on behalf of the Republic are prohibited.

Delegation of violence to evade constitutional limits constitutes grave misconduct.

⸻

Section 6. Treatment of Service Members

Members of the armed forces remain citizens under law.

They retain:
	•	the duty to refuse unlawful orders;
	•	access to independent judicial review;
	•	protection from retaliation for lawful refusal.

No oath may bind service members to unconstitutional action.

⸻

Section 7. Veterans’ Obligations and Care

The Republic owes lifelong duty of care to those injured, disabled, or traumatized in its service.

Failure to provide adequate medical, psychological, and social support constitutes breach of public trust.

Veterans shall not be abandoned after lawful service.

⸻

Section 8. Transparency, Records, and Historical Accountability

Defense actions, procurement decisions, and intelligence-military coordination shall be preserved as public records, subject only to narrow and temporary classification.

Permanent secrecy regarding acts of force is prohibited.

This Section operates in coordination with Articles XI and XXXIX.

⸻

Section 9. Enforcement and Severity

Willful violation of this Article by public officials, commanders, or institutions constitutes abuse of constitutional authority.

Where such conduct involves concealment, unauthorized force, or systemic harm, it qualifies as a grave offense under Article 0 and is subject to Tier-3 escalation.

⸻

Section 10. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that force remains accountable, intelligence remains bounded, service remains honored, and war remains the exception rather than the norm.

⸻

Article XIV-B — Military Justice and Constitutional Subordination

Section 1. Establishment of Military Justice

The Republic may maintain a system of military justice to enforce discipline, readiness, lawful orders, and the laws of war within the Armed Forces.

Military justice exists to preserve lawful command — not to insulate the military from constitutional law.

Section 2. Jurisdiction

Military courts shall have jurisdiction only over:

(a) service members on active duty;
(b) offenses arising directly from military service;
(c) violations of the laws of war;
(d) conduct affecting readiness, security, or lawful command.

Military courts shall have no jurisdiction over:

(a) civilians;
(b) constitutional interpretation;
(c) the legality of war, surveillance, or detention;
(d) political, speech, or belief-based offenses.

Section 3. Due Process and Rights

Service members retain all constitutional rights except where narrowly limited by the necessities of service and due process.

No military tribunal may:
	•	deny counsel,
	•	suppress exculpatory evidence,
	•	use secret law, or
	•	impose punishment absent a public, recorded proceeding.

Section 4. Subordination to the Constitutional Review Court

All military justice proceedings, including courts-martial and disciplinary actions, shall be subject to constitutional review by the Constitutional Review Court for:

(a) jurisdiction;
(b) legality of orders;
(c) constitutional compliance;
(d) proportionality of punishment.

The CRC shall have authority to:
	•	stay proceedings;
	•	suppress unlawfully obtained evidence;
	•	vacate unlawful convictions;
	•	enjoin unconstitutional prosecutions.

Decisions of the CRC are subject to appellate review by the Supreme Court of the Republic.

Section 5. Protection Against Command Influence

No commander or chain of command may:

(a) direct the outcome of any military judicial proceeding;
(b) retaliate against a service member for lawful defense or refusal of unlawful orders;
(c) interfere with counsel, evidence, or review.

Violations constitute grave offenses.

Section 6. Institutional Integrity and the CJC

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have authority to:

(a) audit military courts, JAG offices, and disciplinary systems;
(b) investigate retaliation, command coercion, or secret tribunals;
(c) certify institutional capture or abuse;
(d) petition the CRC for emergency relief, suspension of proceedings, or structural remedies.

No military justice system may operate beyond civilian constitutional oversight.

Section 7. No Emergency or War Exception

No state of war, emergency, or national security claim may suspend:

(a) CRC review;
(b) CJC oversight;
(c) service member due process; or
(d) the prohibition on secret tribunals.

Military necessity does not override constitutional law.

Section 8. Construction

This Article shall be construed to ensure:
	•	discipline without tyranny,
	•	obedience without blind loyalty,
	•	readiness without lawlessness, and
	•	a military that serves the Republic, not itself.


Article XV — Amendments, Lock Clauses, and Anti-Emergency Drift

Charge

This Article establishes the exclusive procedures and requirements by which this Constitution may be amended, corrected, or clarified. All amendment powers shall be exercised openly, deliberately, and in strict conformity with the processes set forth herein, and shall not be expanded or bypassed by emergency, necessity, or convenience. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to permit suspension, alteration, or informal modification of constitutional provisions outside the amendment process expressly authorized by this Constitution.


Legal Text

Section 1. Supremacy of This Article

This Article governs all constitutional amendment, suspension, modification, interpretation, emergency authority, and claims of necessity.

No statute, treaty, executive action, judicial doctrine, regulation, administrative interpretation, or emergency declaration may alter, bypass, suspend, reinterpret, or override this Article.
Any attempt to do so is null and void.
For purposes of this Article, “interpretation” includes judicial doctrine, tests, standards of review, balancing frameworks, and deference regimes.

Section 2. Classes of Constitutional Provisions

The Constitution is composed of three classes of provisions:

a. Unamendable Core Principles
b. Structurally Locked Provisions
c. Generally Amendable Provisions

No provision may be reclassified except through amendment procedures applicable to the higher class.

Section 2A. Recognition of Article-Level Locks
Lock declarations contained within individual Articles of this Constitution are fully valid, self-executing, and of equal force to locks designated by appendix, index, or global classification.

Where an Article declares itself locked or subject to heightened amendment or interpretive constraints, that declaration shall govern the amendment, interpretation, and enforcement of that Article according to its own terms and in harmony with this Article.

No court, authority, or officer may deny effect to an Article-level lock on grounds of placement, form, or location.


Section 3. Unamendable Core Principles (Eternity Clauses)

The following principles are permanent and unamendable and shall not be repealed, suspended, modified, reinterpreted, or overridden by any authority, at any time, for any reason:

a. the supremacy of this Constitution over all other law;
b. the sovereignty of the People as the sole source of political authority;
c. the separation of powers among Legislative, Executive, and Judicial branches;
d. the prohibition of hereditary, purchased, corporate, algorithmic, or non-human political authority;
e. the requirement of civic citizenship, earned through service and duty, as a prerequisite for voting and holding public office;
f. the prohibition on suspension of constitutional rights by emergency, decree, necessity, or reinterpretation;
g. the guarantee of due process and equal protection under law;
h. the prohibition of perpetual or rolling emergency powers;
i. the right of lawful resistance to constitutional violations as defined elsewhere in this Constitution;
j. the prohibition on federal coercion of state sovereignty through fiscal dependency, conditional funding, or economic pressure;
k. the prohibition on federal preemption of state law by regulation absent express legislative authorization and constitutional necessity;
l. the right of states to decline participation in non-mandatory federal programs without retaliation or deprivation of unrelated funds;
m. the right of citizens to challenge federal encroachment upon state sovereignty through judicial process;
n. the prohibition on sovereign immunity where the federal government unlawfully intrudes upon powers reserved to the states.
Any act purporting to amend, suspend, or circumvent these principles is void ab initio and constitutes oathbreaking.

o. no private contract, covenant, oath, or obligation may bind any natural person beyond the lifetime of the consenting party, except where expressly authorized by this Constitution. All such obligations expire at death. No contract purporting to bind an individual beyond their natural lifetime shall be enforceable, except where expressly permitted by this Constitution.


Section 4. Structurally Locked Provisions

Structurally locked provisions include, but are not limited to:

a. amendment procedures and thresholds;
b. electoral integrity mechanisms;
c. legislative transparency and integrity requirements;
d. federalism and reserved powers;
e. judicial independence and limits;
f. anti-capture, anti-corruption, and public stewardship requirements;
g. sunset, reauthorization, and outcome-based governance mandates;
h. limitations on federal funding conditions and fiscal coercion of states;
i. limitations on regulatory preemption of state law;
j. program sunset, outcome review, automatic devolution, and state opt-out rights.

These provisions may be amended only through the procedures in Section 6 and may not be altered, suspended, or bypassed during declared emergencies.

Section 5. Generally Amendable Provisions

All constitutional provisions not listed in Sections 3 or 4 are generally amendable, subject to the procedures and safeguards of this Article.

No amendment may contradict, undermine, or indirectly erode unamendable or structurally locked provisions.

Section 6. Amendment Procedures

An amendment, repeal, suspension, correction, clarification, or material reinterpretation of this Constitution may be proposed and adopted only by one of the exclusive methods set forth in Section 20.

Without limiting Section 20, a popular proposal by national civic petition shall meet thresholds defined by law and consistent with Article XXVII.
Such thresholds shall be no lower than ten percent (10%) of Civic Citizens, unless this Constitution expressly provides otherwise.

All proposed amendments shall:
be single-subject;
include a plain-language explanation of purpose and effect;
disclose all affected provisions;
state anticipated risks, tradeoffs, and consequences.

Amendment Thresholds:
Unless this Constitution expressly provides otherwise, any amendment, repeal, suspension, or material reinterpretation of a provision shall require adoption by one of the three methods in Section 20, and shall additionally require:

(a) certification by the Supreme Court that the change does not diminish substantive rights or enforcement mechanisms protected under lock clauses;
(b) independent review by the Constitutional Judicial Commission affirming absence of institutional capture, coercion, or pretextual motivation.

Section 18 governs unlocking lock-protected provisions, including the applicable supermajority threshold and safeguards for unlocking.

Section 7. Temporal Safeguards

No amendment may be:

a. introduced, voted upon, or ratified during a declared national emergency;
b. fast-tracked, bundled, or exempted from public review;
c. applied retroactively to immunize wrongdoing or shield prior violations.

A minimum public deliberation period of ninety (90) days shall apply to all amendments.
No temporary, provisional, pilot, sunset-based, or experimental measure may bypass or suspend constitutional requirements.

Section 8. Prohibition on Emergency Constitutional Alteration

No emergency, war, disaster, economic crisis, public health threat, or security concern shall justify:

a. suspension of constitutional rights;
b. alteration of amendment procedures;
c. concentration of power beyond constitutional limits;
d. reinterpretation of this Constitution to expand authority.

Emergency powers may coordinate action, not rewrite law.

Section 8A. Emergency Coordination Without Constitutional Displacement

In cases of declared national emergency, including invasion, insurrection, or catastrophic disaster, the federal government may exercise temporary coordinating authority solely for the purpose of resource alignment and intergovernmental cooperation.

Such authority is permitted only where:

a. approval by a sixty percent (60%) vote of both legislative houses;
b. limited to coordination, not command or displacement of state law;
c. does not suspend constitutional rights or alter constitutional structure;
d. expires automatically after ninety (90) days unless renewed by identical vote;
e. is subject to immediate and non-deferential judicial review.

Emergency authority shall not create precedent, implied power, or interpretive expansion.

Section 9. Automatic Rollback of Emergency Authority

All emergency powers shall:

a. be expressly enumerated by statute;
b. be narrowly tailored;
c. expire automatically without renewal.

Upon expiration, all actions taken under emergency authority shall revert to constitutional baseline.

No emergency power may create precedent.

Section 10. Judicial Review and Burden of Proof

All claims of emergency necessity, constitutional reinterpretation, implied authority, or federal preemption shall be subject to immediate CRC judicial review without deference.

The burden of proof rests entirely on the authority asserting necessity or supremacy.

Citizens may challenge federal actions that unlawfully undermine legitimate state law or state sovereignty, independent of state participation or consent.

Silence, ambiguity, historical practice, or administrative convenience shall not suffice. Constitutional silence shall not be construed as permission to alter, amend, or reallocate power.

Section 11. Personal Accountability for Abuse

Any official who knowingly:

a. exceeds emergency authority;
b. enforces unconstitutional orders;
c. attempts constitutional alteration outside this Article;
d. conceals, misrepresents, or fabricates emergency justification;

shall be personally liable under law, in addition to removal from office.

No immunity attaches to constitutional violation.

Section 12. Treaty and International Constraint Clause

No treaty, international agreement, compact, or foreign obligation may:

a. amend this Constitution;
b. supersede constitutional rights;
c. bind the Republic beyond the powers granted herein;
d. require coercion of state participation in federal programs;
e. impose regulatory preemption absent constitutional authorization.

Treaties inconsistent with this Constitution are void.

Section 13. Federal–State Program Sunset and Devolution

All federal programs materially affecting state governance, regulatory authority, or fiscal structure shall expire after ten (10) years unless affirmatively reauthorized through the full legislative process.

Each such program shall state explicit, measurable objectives.

Failure to meet stated objectives shall trigger automatic review and presumptive devolution of authority to the states.

No emergency declaration may suspend this requirement.

Section 14. State Exit Rights and Fiscal Rebalancing

States may opt out of participation in federal programs not constitutionally mandatory.

Upon opt-out, the state shall receive a proportional tax rebate or fiscal credit reflecting its contribution, adjusted for shared national obligations.

No opt-out shall result in punitive withholding of unrelated funds, services, or protections.

This right shall not be suspended by statute, regulation, emergency, or treaty.

Section 15. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. preserve constitutional continuity;
b. prevent erosion by exception;
c. deny legitimacy to fear-based governance;
d. favor liberty, accountability, and restraint over expedience.

The Constitution shall not die quietly.

Section 16. Prohibition on Emergency Circumvention

No declaration of emergency, national security crisis, public health order, economic emergency, invasion, rebellion, martial law, or any other exigency may suspend, waive, limit, or circumvent any provision of this Constitution, including lock-protected rights, due process guarantees, or definitions in Article 0.
Temporary protective measures (e.g., extreme risk protection orders, judicially supervised civil holds) are permissible only when strictly necessary, time-limited, individualized, supported by clear and convincing evidence of an Imminent and Specific Risk (as defined in Article 0), and subject to immediate adversarial review and restoration. Such measures are civil in nature and do not constitute suspension or derogation of constitutional rights.
Any attempt to use emergency authority for permanent structural change, rights erosion, or pretextual coercion (as defined in Article 0) is void ab initio and constitutes a grave offense.

Section 17. Lock-Protected Provisions

Provisions designated as lock-protected (including but not limited to Article II in its entirety, Article III earned civic citizenship, Article XXVI Charter of Inviolable Rights, and all cross-references to definitions in Article 0 that support these Articles) may not be repealed, suspended, weakened, narrowed, reinterpreted, or rendered ineffectual except by the highest procedural threshold above and only for the purpose of clarifying consistency or expanding protections.
New lock designations may be added by constitutional amendment meeting the above requirements, or by legislative act ratified by a seventy-five percent (75%) supermajority of both chambers and signed by the Executive, provided the addition strengthens liberty, accountability, or sovereignty rather than restricting it.
Lock-protected provisions include, but are not limited to, Article XXX (Federal Enforcement Authority, Accountability, and Civic Restraint) in its entirety; Article XXIV (Federal Law Enforcement and the Use of State Force) in its entirety; the separation of intelligence and law enforcement; prohibitions on entrapment and manufactured radicalization; safeguards governing automated integrity monitoring; and the affirmative duty to dissolve corrupt enforcement bodies.
For purposes of this Article, ‘highest procedural threshold’ means: (i) the Section 6 Amendment Thresholds for structurally locked provisions; and (ii) where Section 18 applies, the Section 18 unlocking threshold plus all Section 18 procedural safeguards.
While a provision remains lock-protected, amendments may only clarify consistency or expand protections; any other change requires unlocking under Section 18.

Section 18. Unlocking Lock-Protected Provisions

(a) Purpose and Narrow Construction
Lock-protected provisions exist to prevent short-term passions, capture, or emergency opportunism from weakening core rights, caps, floors, prohibitions, and structural safeguards. Unlocking is permitted, but shall occur only through a heightened process that is insulated from bundling, deception, and procedural laundering.

(b) Methods and No Bypass
Unlocking may be accomplished only by one of the exclusive methods in Section 20, and only upon satisfaction of this Section.
No statute, court, commission, or officer may treat a lock-protected provision as unlocked by interpretation, necessity, “balancing,” implied power, emergency, or administrative convenience.

(c) Single-Subject and Explicit Targeting
An unlocking measure must identify, by citation, the exact lock-protected provision(s) to be unlocked and shall address no other subject. Any measure that bundles unlocking with unrelated policy change, appropriations, or institutional re-structuring is void.

(d) Plain-Language and Disclosure Requirements
Any unlocking measure must satisfy amendment-grade safeguards, including:
(1) a plain-language explanation of purpose and legal effect;
(2) a redline-style disclosure of the exact textual change(s) to the lock status and any intended amendment text if paired under subsection (i);
(3) a disclosure of all provisions whose operation would be altered directly or by necessary implication; and
(4) a public posting period sufficient for review, as specified by law consistent with this Constitution.

(e) Petition Gate
Where unlocking proceeds by national referendum, no unlocking measure may be placed on the ballot absent a petition threshold of not less than twenty percent (20%) of Civic Citizens, verified within a fixed statutory period.

(f) Cooling-Off and Anti-Spam
No substantially similar unlocking measure concerning the same lock-protected provision(s) may be initiated more than once within one hundred eighty (180) days following a failed vote, absent material change as defined in Article 0, Section 4.4.

(g) Approval Threshold
Unlocking a lock-protected provision requires approval by not less than seventy percent (70%) of the deciding body under the chosen method in Section 20, and no lesser threshold shall suffice.

(h) Turnout Floor (Anti-Low-Turnout Capture)
No unlocking referendum shall be valid unless participation meets a minimum turnout floor established by this Constitution or by national law enacted pursuant to it, which shall be set high enough to prevent factional capture through low-participation elections.

(i) Unlock-and-Amend, or Unlock-Only
An unlocking measure may be presented as:
(1) Unlock-only: removing lock protection while leaving the text otherwise unchanged; or
(2) Unlock-and-amend: unlocking and adopting a specific amendment text simultaneously.
Where presented as unlock-and-amend, both the unlocking and the amendment text must satisfy all requirements of this Section, including the single-subject rule and the seventy percent (70%) threshold.

(j) Certification for Form and Honesty (Not Merit)
Prior to ballot placement (or, where applicable, prior to final adoption), the CJC and the CRC shall certify only:
(1) single-subject compliance;
(2) plain-language sufficiency and accurate disclosure of legal effect; and
(3) absence of procedural laundering, deception, or hidden alteration of caps, floors, prohibitions, or jurisdictional limits.
Neither body may veto an unlocking measure based on policy disagreement.

(k) Timing Restrictions
No unlocking referendum may be conducted during a declared emergency or within a constitutionally defined cooling period after an emergency, as specified by law consistent with this Constitution.

(l) Effect of Successful Unlock
Upon successful unlock, the provision remains fully operative but becomes amendable under the ordinary amendment rules of this Constitution, except as otherwise restricted herein. Any subsequent amendment must still comply with all applicable rights protections, due process constraints, and anti-capture safeguards.
Unlocking measures and any paired amendments are subject to the Decennial Reaffirmation and Automatic Reversion requirements of this Article.

Section 19. Decennial Reaffirmation of Amendments; Automatic Reversion

(a) Provisional Adoption; Required Reaffirmation; Reaffirmation Window
Every constitutional amendment adopted under this Article shall remain subject to a mandatory reaffirmation referendum conducted during the tenth (10th) year after the amendment’s effective date, within a fixed window defined by law.

If the reaffirmation referendum is not conducted within that window, the amendment automatically reverts at the close of the window as though it failed reaffirmation.

(b) Reaffirmation Threshold
An amendment shall become permanent only if reaffirmed by a simple majority (50% + 1) of participating Civic Citizens in the reaffirmation referendum.

(c) Automatic Reversion Upon Failure
If an amendment fails reaffirmation, the Constitution shall automatically revert to the text and legal effect that existed immediately prior to that amendment, effective upon certification of the referendum result.
No further legislative or judicial act shall be required to restore the prior text.

(d) Ballot Clarity
The reaffirmation ballot shall present the amendment as adopted and shall ask, in plain language, whether the People reaffirm it to remain in force.
No reaffirmation ballot may bundle multiple amendments.

(e) Single Reaffirmation
An amendment reaffirmed under this Section shall thereafter remain in force unless amended or repealed pursuant to this Article. No further periodic reaffirmation is required.

(f) Savings and Stability
Reversion under this Section shall not:
(1) void final judgments entered while the amendment was in force, absent independent constitutional defect or fraud;
(2) impair vested private rights lawfully accrued in reliance on the amendment, where such impairment would violate due process; or
(3) invalidate completed governmental acts that were lawful when performed;
provided that all ongoing enforcement, future legal standards, and prospective governmental actions shall conform to the restored constitutional text upon reversion.

(g) Application to Unlocking
An unlocking measure, whether unlock-only or unlock-and-amend, constitutes a constitutional alteration for purposes of this Section and shall be subject to reaffirmation and potential reversion on the same terms.

Section 20. Methods of Constitutional Amendment, Repeal, Locking, and Unlocking

(a) Exclusive Methods
This Constitution may be amended, repealed, locked, or unlocked only by one of the following three methods:

(1) Legislative Supermajority Method.
Approval by a supermajority vote of both legislative houses as defined by the Supermajority Rule, together with all certifications and procedural safeguards required by this Constitution for the category of change sought.

(2) Convention of the States Method.
Approval by a Convention of the States conducted under this Constitution, requiring concurrence of not less than seventy-five percent (75%) of the States, together with all certifications and procedural safeguards required by this Constitution for the category of change sought.

(3) Popular Supermajority Method.
Approval by national referendum of Civic Citizens, requiring a supermajority vote as defined by the Supermajority Rule; provided that any measure whose purpose includes Unlocking under Section 18 shall require the unlocking threshold of Section 18(g).

(b) Equal Validity
Any method listed in subsection (a) is sufficient to enact constitutional change without requiring approval by the other methods, except where this Constitution expressly provides otherwise for unamendable provisions.

(c) Single-Subject and Plain-Language Safeguards
All measures under any method shall comply with single-subject form, plain-language requirements, and disclosure of legal effect, and shall be void if adopted through bundling, deception, or procedural laundering.

Section 21. Lock Designation
This Article (including all lock designation procedures, anti-emergency rules, and supermajority thresholds) is itself lock-protected and may not be amended except by the highest procedural threshold and certification of non-diminishment.
Article XV-A — Emergency Powers Harmonization

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Article XV

This Article supplements Article XV.

No declaration of emergency, necessity, crisis, or exigency shall suspend, override, condition, delay, or evade any provision of this Constitution unless such suspension is expressly authorized by this Constitution and explicitly names the affected Article and Section.

No emergency authority exercised under this Article shall suspend, override, delay, or condition the operation of Article XXVIII-A — State Nullification and Federalism Safeguards.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most preserves rights and limits power shall control.

⸻

Section 2. Single-Emergency Rule

At any given time, all asserted emergency powers exercised by the Republic shall be treated as part of a single constitutional emergency, regardless of label, agency, or domain.

No authority may segment, stack, or relabel emergencies to evade constitutional limits.

⸻

Section 3. Duration  Harmonization

All emergency authorities expire after ninety (90) days unless renewed pursuant to this Article, and no emergency authority may be renewed more than once absent materially new facts.

Where multiple emergency authorities prescribe different durations, the shortest duration shall control.

Extensions may occur only through the strictest renewal process applicable among the invoked authorities.

Rolling or serial emergencies are prohibited.

⸻

Section 4. Scope Harmonization

Where multiple emergency provisions authorize differing scopes of action, the narrowest scope shall control.

Emergency authority shall be limited to actions strictly necessary to address the precipitating condition.

Generalized, anticipatory, or speculative measures are prohibited.

⸻

Section 5. Rights-Preserving Tie-Breaker

Where emergency authorities conflict, the interpretation that most preserves individual rights, due process, and civilian supremacy shall prevail.

No emergency interpretation may diminish non-derogable rights or locked provisions.

⸻

Section 6. Cross-Article Emergency Claims

No authority may invoke emergency language from one Article to bypass constraints imposed by another.

Emergency provisions shall be read in coordination, not isolation.

⸻

Section 7. Judicial Acceleration

All emergency actions shall be subject to accelerated judicial review.

Courts shall not defer to emergency declarations and shall independently assess necessity, scope, and duration.

Delay shall not be justified by crisis.

⸻

Section 8. Automatic Reversion and Cleanup

Upon expiration or termination of an emergency:
	1.	all extraordinary powers immediately cease;
	2.	all emergency rules automatically sunset;
	3.	all records are preserved as public records;
	4.	all actions taken are subject to retrospective review.

Failure to revert constitutes a continuing constitutional violation.

⸻

Section 9. Anti-Precedent Rule

No emergency action, interpretation, or practice may be cited as precedent for future authority.

Emergency governance is inherently non-precedential.

⸻

Section 10. Enforcement and Severity

Willful violation of this Article by public officials or institutions constitutes abuse of constitutional authority.

Where such violation involves concealment, persistence beyond authorization, or systemic harm, it qualifies as a grave offense under Article 0 and is subject to Tier-3 escalation.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that emergencies do not become mechanisms of constitutional erosion.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most rapidly restores normal constitutional order shall control.

⸻

Article XVI — Elections and Democratic Legitimacy

Charge

This Article establishes constitutional requirements governing elections and the democratic legitimacy of public authority within the Republic. All electoral processes shall be conducted transparently, securely, and verifiably, and shall be designed to ensure accurate expression of voter intent, equal participation, and public confidence in electoral outcomes. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to authorize electoral manipulation, unreviewable procedures, or the exercise of governmental authority absent lawful and credible elections.
Legal Text

Section 1. Authority Over Elections

a. Source of Authority

The authority to conduct elections arises from the People and is exercised through the States, subject to this Constitution. Elections are a public trust, not a partisan instrument.

b. Hybrid Administration Model

Elections shall be administered by the States within a uniform constitutional framework established by the Republic to ensure fairness, security, and equal protection.
States retain operational control; the Republic retains oversight authority to guarantee constitutional compliance.

c. Federal Standards

Congress shall establish national minimum standards governing:
	•	voter eligibility verification;
	•	ballot integrity and chain of custody;
	•	auditability and recount procedures;
	•	election security against fraud, coercion, and foreign interference;
	•	transparency and public observability.

No State may fall below these standards.

d. Prohibition on Federal Control of Outcomes

Neither Congress nor the Executive may dictate election outcomes, manipulate vote counting, interfere with lawful State administration, or delay elections except as constitutionally authorized.

e. Election Oversight Tribunal

A permanent, independent Election Oversight Tribunal shall:
	•	audit compliance with this Article;
	•	hear procedural challenges;
	•	certify national election integrity;
	•	refer violations for prosecution.

The Tribunal shall consist of nine members, appointed through the Constitutional Judicial Commission (CJC) process defined in Article VI, serving staggered nine-year terms, and shall be subject to institutional-integrity supervision by the CJC and constitutional-compliance review by the Constitutional Review Court (CRC).
f. Transparency Requirement

All election procedures, software specifications, chain-of-custody rules, audit methods, and certification standards shall be public by default.

g. Interpretation

This Section preserves State administration, national legitimacy, voter confidence, and the sovereignty of the People.

Section 2. The Right to Vote

a. Citizenship Requirement

The right to vote is reserved exclusively to Civic Citizens. No legal resident or non-civic person may vote in any election.

b. Condition of Capacity

Voting requires reasoned judgment. No person may vote while intoxicated, impaired, or cognitively incapacitated.
No proxy or caretaker voting is permitted.

c. Primary Voting Method

Voting shall occur in person at supervised polling locations using physical paper ballots as the controlling legal record, with identity and biometric verification via transparent, publicly auditable systems.

Biometric data shall be:
	•	minimized;
	•	stored locally;
	•	deleted immediately after verification.

d. Secure Digital Voting in Special Circumstances

Secure digital machine voting (via phone or computer) is permitted only for:
	•	active-duty military personnel deployed overseas;
	•	diplomatic personnel stationed abroad;
	•	verified medically incapacitated Civic Citizens unable to travel.

Such voting must use end-to-end verifiable, publicly auditable systems with biometric pre-registration and supervised transmission.

e. Prohibited Practices

Mail-in ballots, ballot harvesting, drop boxes, unsupervised remote voting, and internet voting outside the above exceptions are prohibited.

f. National Election Day

A national Election Day shall be a federal holiday.
Employers are strongly encouraged to grant paid leave.
Employees denied time off for voting due to ideological or partisan motive may sue for damages.

g. Uniformity

These standards apply to all elections at every level.

h. Interpretation

The ballot is a responsibility exercised with sobriety and presence.

Section 3. Voter Eligibility and Voter Rolls

a. National Civic Voter Roll

A single National Civic Voter Roll shall contain only eligible Civic Citizens.

b. Eligibility Criteria

Enrollment requires:
	•	verified Civic Citizenship;
	•	completed service obligations;
	•	lawful age;
	•	capacity;
	•	biometric uniqueness.

No excessive documentation may disproportionately burden eligible citizens.

c. Automatic Enrollment and Maintenance

Enrollment is automatic upon certification of Civic Citizenship.
Rolls shall be continuously maintained to remove deceased, ineligible, or duplicate entries.

d. Prohibition on Arbitrary Purges

No mass or algorithmic purges are permitted without individualized cause and due process.
Removal requires notice, evidence, and opportunity to contest.

e. Annual Public Audit

The voter roll shall undergo an annual public audit.

f. Criminal Penalties

Manipulation of voter rolls constitutes a Tier III offense.

g. Interpretation

The integrity of the roll is the integrity of the Republic.

Section 4. Ballots and Voting Methods

a. Authorized Ballots

Only uniform, publicly issued paper ballots (or secure digital equivalents in approved special circumstances) may be used.

b. Polling Places and Observers

Voting occurs only at supervised polling locations with non-partisan citizen observers.

c. Order and Sobriety

Intoxicated or disruptive individuals shall be denied voting, subject to provisional review.

d. Chain of Custody

Every ballot shall be tracked, sealed, logged, and transported under dual custody.

e. Counting

Counting shall occur publicly, transparently, and promptly, with livestreaming where practicable.
Paper ballots (or verified digital records) govern.

f. Prohibited Practices

Ballot harvesting, unsupervised vote curing, drop boxes, and post-hoc reinterpretation are forbidden.

g. Interpretation

Convenience shall never outweigh legitimacy.

Section 5. Election Administration and Oversight

a. State Administration

States administer elections as fiduciaries of the People.

b. Federal Oversight

The Republic audits compliance but does not control outcomes.

c. Mandatory Audits

All elections undergo post-election audits prior to certification.

d. Certification

No officeholder may assume office prior to lawful certification.

e. Prohibition on Interference

Political interference with administration or audits is a Tier III offense.

Section 6. Political Parties and Coalitions

a. Permitted Scope

Political parties may organize at the county, parish, or State level.

b. Temporary National Coalitions

Temporary, election-specific national coalitions are permitted and must dissolve immediately upon certification.

c. Prohibition on Permanent National Parties

Permanent national or multi-jurisdictional super-parties are forbidden.

d. Funding and Transparency

Political funding shall:
	•	be limited to individual Civic Citizen contributions;
	•	remain local or State-based;
	•	be disclosed in real time.

Corporate, foreign, union, and anonymous donations are prohibited.

e. Interpretation

Factions may compete and coordinate temporarily. They may not entrench permanent dominance.

Section 7. Election Security and Integrity

a. Foreign Interference

Foreign involvement in elections constitutes an attack on sovereignty.

b. Cybersecurity

Election infrastructure must be domestically owned, auditable, and hardened.

c. Intelligence Neutrality

Intelligence agencies may not influence domestic political outcomes.

d. Interpretation

The Republic protects debate; it does not tolerate manipulation.

Section 8. Counting, Certification, and Audit

a. Public Counting

Counting shall be observable, documented, and prompt.

b. Audits and Recounts

Mandatory audits precede certification.
Full recounts occur when statutory thresholds are met.

c. Finality

Once certified and remedies exhausted, results are binding.

Section 9. Disputed Elections and Remedies

a. Right to Challenge

Challenges require credible, material evidence.

b. Exclusive Forums

Disputes shall be adjudicated only by the Election Oversight Tribunal or the Constitutional Review Court, with the Constitutional Review Court possessing mandatory jurisdiction over claims alleging constitutional violation, systemic manipulation, or loss of democratic legitimacy.

c. Remedies

Remedies must be proportional and narrowly tailored.

d. Nullification

Nullification is permitted only where legitimacy is irreparably compromised, upon:
(1) a two-thirds finding by the Election Oversight Tribunal and confirmation by the Constitutional Review Court; or
(2) a Supreme Court finding of irreparable constitutional destruction.

e. Scope and Targeting of Electoral Remedies

Any nullification, invalidation, recall, forced re-election, or removal exercised pursuant to this Article shall be specific to the office, contest, or electoral body directly affected.
No single petition, tribunal finding, judicial order, or popular act may dissolve, purge, or invalidate an entire branch of government in aggregate.
Executive officers shall be removable individually by office.
Legislative bodies may be subject to re-election by chamber, not jointly.
Judicial officers may be removed individually, including a chief justice, but the judiciary as an institution shall not be dissolved by collective action.

Remedies shall preserve constitutional continuity while restoring legitimacy.
f. Interpretation

Disputes must end, or the Republic cannot endure.

Section 10. Election Crimes and Penalties

a. Election Crimes

Fraud, coercion, manipulation, obstruction, or certification of false results are Tier II or Tier III offenses.

b. Aggravated Offenses

Foreign collaboration and systemic fraud carry enhanced penalties.

c. No Statute of Limitations

There is no statute of limitations for crimes against democratic legitimacy.

Section 11. Media, Technology, and Intelligence Separation

a. Absolute Separation

Intelligence agencies may not partner with or embed in media or technology platforms.

b. Revolving Door Ban

A minimum seven-year separation applies between intelligence service and platform authority.

c. Algorithmic Neutrality

Search engines, feeds, and AI systems may not manipulate political visibility or outcomes.

d. AI Constraints

AI may present facts and labeled opinion aggregates only; it may not persuade.

e. Transparency

All government–platform contacts must be disclosed.

f. Interpretation

Debate is protected. Manipulation is forbidden.

Section 12. Civic Trust and Democratic Legitimacy

a. Legitimate Authority

All authority derives from informed, sober, voluntary consent expressed through lawful elections.

b. Manufactured Consent Forbidden

Legitimacy may not be claimed through deception, coercion, or manipulation.

c. Finality and Transfer

Certified elections require peaceful transfer of power.

d. Right of Resistance

When a government systematically subverts elections, suppresses lawful remedies, and rules without genuine consent—upon a two-thirds declaration by State legislatures convened in constitutional convention or a Supreme Court finding of irreparable constitutional destruction—the People retain the inherent right of resistance, including insurrection, as a last resort.

This right arises only when constitutional order has been destroyed, not merely when outcomes are disputed.

e. Enduring Covenant

Where elections are honest, the Republic endures. Where elections are corrupted, liberty collapses.

f. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to preserve trust between the People and their institutions, recognizing that without trust, law decays into force, and authority into tyranny.

Article XVI-A — Election Integrity and Auditability

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Article XVI

This Article supplements Article XVI — Elections and Democratic Legitimacy.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to modify, narrow, relax, or reinterpret any requirement, prohibition, or safeguard established in Article XVI.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most preserves electoral legitimacy and public trust shall control.

⸻

Section 2. Chain-of-Custody as a Constitutional Requirement

All ballots, records, and election materials shall be subject to continuous, documented chain-of-custody from issuance through final certification.

Any break, ambiguity, or undocumented transfer in custody creates a rebuttable presumption of compromise.

Chain-of-custody records shall be public records.

⸻

Section 3. Auditability and Public Verification

All elections shall be auditable by independent observers using methods that are:
	1.	publicly observable,
	2.	repeatable,
	3.	comprehensible to a reasonable citizen,
	4.	independent of proprietary claims.

No election outcome may rely exclusively on processes that cannot be meaningfully audited by human review.

⸻

Section 4. Technology Neutrality and Burden of Proof

No voting or tabulation technology is presumed valid by default.

The burden of proof rests on the authority employing any technology to demonstrate:
	1.	transparency,
	2.	resistance to tampering,
	3.	verifiability independent of vendor assertions,
	4.	absence of remote or covert alteration capability.

Failure to meet this burden prohibits use.

⸻

Section 5. Software and Vendor Restrictions

Election software, firmware, and tabulation systems shall be:
	1.	open to inspection,
	2.	version-controlled,
	3.	publicly documented,
	4.	reproducible from source where applicable.

Proprietary secrecy shall not defeat audit, review, or challenge.

Vendor indemnification clauses shall not shield liability for failure, fraud, or concealment.

⸻

Section 6. Escalation Triggers and Automatic Review

The following conditions automatically trigger mandatory review, recount, or escalation:
	1.	material chain-of-custody defects;
	2.	statistically anomalous results inconsistent with observable conditions;
	3.	equipment malfunction affecting outcome margins;
	4.	documented interference or suppression.

Discretionary refusal to review under such conditions is prohibited.
Where escalation is triggered under this Section, the Constitutional Review Court shall have mandatory and expedited jurisdiction to order audits, recounts, preservation of evidence, and injunctions against certification.

⸻

Section 7. Failure Resolution and Election Invalidation

Where integrity defects cannot be cured through audit or recount, the affected election or contest shall be invalidated.

Certification shall not occur where legitimacy cannot be affirmatively demonstrated.

No authority may certify an election solely to preserve continuity or convenience.

⸻

Section 8. Remedies and Temporary Governance

In the event of invalidation:
	1.	lawful interim governance shall proceed under existing constitutional succession rules;
	2.	prompt re-election shall occur under corrected conditions;
	3.	emergency powers shall not be invoked to bypass re-election.

Continuity does not justify legitimacy failure.

⸻

Section 9. Accountability and Severity

Willful interference with election integrity, auditability, or review constitutes abuse of democratic authority.

Where such conduct is systemic, coordinated, or outcome-determinative, it qualifies as a grave offense under Article 0 and is subject to Tier-3 escalation.

⸻

Section 10. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that electoral outcomes are provable, not presumed.

Where doubt exists, the construction that favors verification over finality shall control.

⸻

Article XVI-B — Popular Recall, Removal, and Institutional Dissolution

Section 1 — Affirmation of Popular Authority

The People retain the sovereign authority to recall, remove, expel, or otherwise terminate the service of any public official, officer, or appointee, and to dissolve governmental agencies or administrative bodies that are corrupt, hostile to constitutional order, or persistently fail in their lawful duties.

This authority is fundamental and shall not be construed narrowly.

⸻

Section 2 — Scope Limitation and Targeting Requirement

The exercise of popular recall, expulsion, or dissolution under this Constitution shall be specific and targeted.

No single popular petition, vote, or action may:
	•	dissolve an entire constitutional branch of government in aggregate;
	•	vacate all offices within a branch simultaneously; or
	•	extinguish a constitutionally required governmental function.

Popular remedies shall operate against persons, offices, agencies, or discrete institutional components, not against constitutional structures as a whole.

⸻

Section 3 — Personnel Removal Distinguished from Functional Abolition

The removal of officials, officers, or employees shall not be construed as the abolition of the constitutional powers or duties attached to their offices.

Where an office or agency is dissolved by popular action:
	•	the function it performed shall remain constitutionally required unless expressly eliminated by constitutional amendment;
	•	the temporary absence of an office shall not excuse nonperformance of constitutional duties.

⸻

Section 4 — Mandatory Reconstitution of Essential Functions

Upon the dissolution or vacancy of an agency, department, or office charged with executing a constitutional or statutory function:
	1.	The Executive shall be affirmatively obligated to:
	•	reconstitute the function in a lawful form;
	•	appoint new leadership and personnel, as required;
	•	restore operational capacity without undue delay.
	2.	Reconstitution may include:
	•	restructuring or renaming the agency;
	•	replacement of personnel in whole or in part;
	•	alteration of internal organization;
but shall not include permanent abdication of the function.

Failure to reconstitute a required function constitutes a constitutional violation.

⸻

Section 5 — Legislative and Judicial Symmetry

Popular recall and removal powers shall apply with equal force to:
	•	executive officers;
	•	individual legislators;
	•	legislative chambers (one chamber at a time);
	•	individual judicial officers, including a chief justice.

The judiciary and legislature as institutions shall not be dissolved in their entirety by a single popular act.

⸻

Section 6 — Anti-Abuse and Continuity Safeguard

All exercises of popular recall or dissolution shall:
	•	preserve constitutional continuity;
	•	avoid the creation of institutional vacuums;
	•	be executed in a manner consistent with public order and lawful transition.

The People’s sovereign authority to correct government abuse shall not be construed to authorize constitutional self-destruction.

⸻

Section 7 — Construction and Precedence

This Article governs the scope and effect of popular recall, expulsion, and institutional dissolution throughout this Constitution.

In the event of conflict or ambiguity, this Article shall control.

⸻Article XVII — Corporate Legitimacy and Accountability

Charge

This Article establishes constitutional requirements governing the formation, recognition, regulation, and accountability of corporations and similar artificial entities within the Republic. Corporate status shall confer no sovereign authority and shall remain subordinate to law, public oversight, and the rights of natural persons. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to grant corporate privileges, immunities, or legal standing beyond those expressly authorized by law and consistent with constitutional limits.


Legal Text

Section 1. Nature of Corporate Existence

(a) No Natural Right
Corporations possess no natural, inherent, or inalienable rights. They exist solely by charter, license, or recognition granted by the Republic for defined productive purposes. Corporate existence is a privilege, not a right.

(b) Instrumental Character
A corporation is a legal instrument through which natural persons act. It shall not be treated as a moral person, citizen, or sovereign entity. Rights extended to corporations exist only insofar as they are necessary to enable lawful productive activity and accountability.

(c) Subordination to the Republic
All corporations are subordinate to the Constitution, the sovereignty of the Republic, the welfare of the People, and the rule of law. No corporate interest may supersede these obligations.

Section 2. Legitimate Purposes

(a) Productive Purpose Requirement
Corporations may be formed only for legitimate productive purposes, including creation of goods or services, employment of labor, innovation and research, infrastructure development, lawful trade and commerce, and charitable or educational activity conducted in good faith. Formation for predatory, manipulative, extractive, or purely rent-seeking purposes is prohibited.

(b) Prohibited Corporate Purposes
It is unlawful to form or operate a corporation primarily for hostile takeovers intended to destroy productive capacity, concealment of assets, ownership, or intent, evasion of legal or moral accountability, laundering of foreign or illicit influence, manipulation of markets, elections, or public institutions, destabilization of communities, food systems, or governance, or coordinated harm to the Republic or its People. Such purposes render a corporation illegitimate ab initio. A finding of illegitimacy ab initio shall require determination by the Constitutional Review Court based on evidence of primary purpose, intent, and material conduct.

Section 3. Transparency and Accountability

(a) Beneficial Ownership
All corporations shall disclose their true beneficial owners and controlling interests. Layered entities, nominees, shell structures, trusts, and artificial partitions shall not obscure accountability. For constitutional purposes, ownership, control, coordination, and common management shall be aggregated regardless of legal form. The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to audit, investigate, and certify whether beneficial ownership, shell structures, or artificial partitions are being used to evade accountability under this Article.

(b) Substance Over Form
Courts shall evaluate corporate conduct by material outcomes and intent, not by nominal compliance or formal structure. Legal form shall not shield substantive wrongdoing.

(c) Piercing of the Corporate Veil
Where a corporation is used to commit wrongdoing, evade law, sabotage public systems, or cause grave harm, courts shall pierce the corporate veil without limitation. Veil piercing shall occur through process before the Constitutional Review Court, with personal liability attaching only to natural persons found culpable by evidence of control, intent, or knowing participation.

Section 4. Grave Corporate Offenses

(a) Definition
A corporation commits a grave offense when it knowingly or recklessly engages in conduct that undermines the sovereignty of the Republic, corrupts public institutions, poisons land, food, water, or people, enables trafficking, slavery, or systemic exploitation, engineers dependency or artificial scarcity, manipulates law, science, information, or technology with knowing falsehood or reckless disregard for truth to cause public harm, or obstructs or sabotages the public commons after lawful sunset or convergence. For purposes of this Section, ‘knowingly or recklessly’ requires actual knowledge, willful blindness, or conscious disregard of a substantial and unjustifiable risk of public harm.

(b) Third-Tier Classification
Grave corporate offenses may be classified as third-tier crimes where scale, intent, or impact warrants. ‘Third-tier crimes’ shall have the meaning, evidentiary standards, and penalties set forth in Article VII. Corporate form shall not mitigate severity.
(c) Constitutional Judicial Commission
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify whether conduct under this Section constitutes institutional capture, foreign influence, or coordinated economic warfare, and may petition the Constitutional Review Court for Tier-Three classification.


Section 5. Remedies and Sanctions

(a) Dissolution
Upon Constitutional Review Court finding of grave offense, a corporation may be dissolved, stripped of charter, or barred permanently from reconstitution under any form.

(b) Forfeiture
Assets used to commit or conceal wrongdoing may be seized and repurposed for restitution or public benefit, with priority given to non-culpable parties such as employees (wages and pensions) and small shareholders before public use.

(c) Criminal Prosecution
Natural persons responsible shall be prosecuted to the full extent of the law. No fine shall substitute for accountability.

(d) Enemy of the Republic
Where a corporate entity acts maliciously, systematically, and evidentially against the Republic, it may be designated an Enemy of the Republic following rigorous evidentiary review, scientific and factual assessment of harm and intent, and judicial determination by seven-ninths vote of the Supreme Court with public findings, following an evidentiary record developed by the Constitutional Review Court. Designation as an Enemy of the Republic shall require clear and convincing evidence of malicious intent, systematic conduct, and grave harm, with findings addressing necessity, proportionality, and exhaustion of lesser remedies. Such designation shall apply only to the offending entity and responsible natural persons, and shall not impose collective punishment on non-culpable employees, customers, or shareholders.

Section 6. Digital Commons Compliance

(a) Constitutional Obligation
Any corporation that develops, maintains, controls, or licenses software, hardware, data systems, or technical infrastructure subject to Article X shall comply with abandonment, sunset, and convergence requirements; preserve and disclose all code and design iterations upon trigger; and cooperate with lawful archival and public access. Terms including ‘abandonment,’ ‘sunset,’ and ‘convergence’ shall have the meanings set forth in Article X.

(b) License Warfare Prohibited
The use of licensing schemes, shell entities, legal fragmentation, or ideological barriers to prevent lawful reuse of mature knowledge after lawful convergence trigger constitutes hostile conduct against the Republic. Findings of hostile conduct under this Section shall require determination by the Constitutional Review Court based on technical evidence and material obstruction of lawful convergence.

Section 7. Periodic Charter Review and Mission Lock

(a) Periodic Charter Review
Corporations exceeding thresholds defined by law shall undergo periodic charter review every twenty-five (25) years to demonstrate ongoing productive purpose and public benefit. Charter review shall be evidence-based, non-ideological, and limited to evaluation of stated productive purpose, public harm, and material compliance, and shall not be used to punish lawful dissent or unpopular speech.

(b) Founder Mission Lock
Founders may embed an irrevocable productive mission statement in the corporate charter. Courts shall consider this mission in veil-piercing, dissolution, or grave offense proceedings.

(c) Anti-Crony Certification
Corporations receiving federal contracts, subsidies, bailouts, or emergency aid must certify no political donations or lobbying in the prior five (5) years. 
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall audit and certify compliance with this subsection and may refer violations to the Constitutional Review Court for remedies under Section 5.

(d) Open-Source After Subsidy
Technology developed with public funds or tax privileges must open-source non-core intellectual property after fifteen (15) years or patent expiration, whichever comes first.

(e) Innovation Monopoly Carve-Out
Temporary protection from certain anti-monopoly rules may be granted to corporations that create entirely new markets through genuine innovation. ‘Genuine innovation’ requires demonstrable creation of new productive capacity, not merely financial engineering, regulatory arbitrage, or control of existing markets.

Section 8. Prohibition on Reconstruction and Conquest Profiteering

(a) No Profit from War or Collapse
No corporation, consortium, financial instrument, or private actor may profit from military conquest, post-war reconstruction, regime collapse, sanctions-induced scarcity, or humanitarian crises caused or exacerbated by state action.

(b) Ban on Preferential Contracting
No corporation may receive preferential contracts or exclusive rights in territories subject to military intervention or post-conflict rebuilding arising from prior lobbying or political coordination.

(c) Public-Interest Reconstruction Only
All reconstruction efforts shall prioritize civilian welfare, essential infrastructure, and transparent contracting.

(d) Criminal Liability
Any corporation or natural person who advocates for war for private gain, engineers instability for profit, or exploits conquest to extract wealth commits a grave offense against the Republic. Liability requires material advocacy, coordination, or action that foreseeably contributed to conflict or exploitation, not mere expression of opinion absent causal nexus.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate coordination, lobbying, or financial engineering intended to provoke or exploit conflict and to refer such findings to the Constitutional Review Court.

Section 9. Limits and Protections

(a) Protection of Legitimate Enterprise
This Article shall not be interpreted to punish lawful success, discourage productive enterprise, prohibit scale achieved through value creation, interfere with honest competition, or suppress lawful dissent or innovation.

(b) Due Process
All actions under this Article require notice, evidence, judicial review, and proportional remedies. No corporation shall be condemned by accusation alone.

Section 10. Interpretation
This Article shall be interpreted to ensure that economic power remains the servant of human dignity, national sovereignty, and truth. When private power becomes unaccountable, liberty dies. Therefore, the Republic reserves the right to revoke the privileges it grants.

Article XVII — Definitions and Construction
	•	Corporation includes any for-profit or nonprofit legal entity recognized by law.
	•	Beneficial ownership means direct or indirect control, equity, or decision-making power.
	•	Grave offense means conduct defined in Section 4 meeting the mens rea requirements herein.
	•	Enemy of the Republic means designation under Section 5(d).
	•	Crime tiers, evidentiary standards, and penalties are governed by Article VII.
	•	Digital commons terms are governed by Article X.
	•	Rules of constitutional interpretation are governed by Article XIX.
	•	Courts shall evaluate substance over form and require notice, evidence, judicial findings, and proportionality before sanctions.

As it is written: “You cannot serve both God and Mammon.”

Article XVIII — Civic Formation, Education, and the Preservation of the Republic

Charge

This Article establishes constitutional principles governing civic formation and education within the Republic for the purpose of sustaining democratic self-government. All educational and civic institutions operating under public authority shall be construed to promote independent reasoning, historical understanding, lawful civic participation, and respect for constitutional order. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to authorize ideological compulsion, partisan indoctrination, or the use of education as an instrument of political conformity or administrative control.

Section 1. Purpose of Civic Education

Education within the Republic shall serve the formation of persons capable of:

a. rational thought and evidence-based judgment;
b. ethical reasoning and moral responsibility;
c. understanding the structure, history, and limits of government;
d. detecting deception, propaganda, and bad-faith argument;
e. peaceful debate, lawful dissent, and civic participation;
f. lawful self-defense and defense of the innocent.

No educational system shall be oriented toward ideological conformity, partisan allegiance, or administrative obedience.

Section 2. Methods of Instruction

Instruction shall emphasize:

a. inquiry over indoctrination;
b. dialogue, debate, and cross-examination over rote memorization;
c. mentorship, apprenticeship, and mastery over credential accumulation;
d. primary sources over interpretive orthodoxy;
e. practical application alongside theory.

No institution receiving public funds may substitute political doctrine, identity-based dogma, or compelled belief for critical reasoning and open inquiry.

Section 3. Historical and Constitutional Literacy

Education shall include rigorous instruction in:

a. the history of the Republic and its founding principles;
b. comparative political systems and their failures;
c. the causes of tyranny, collapse, and corruption in past civilizations;
d. the structure, powers, and limits of each branch of government;
e. the rights and duties of citizens and residents.

Historical instruction shall neither whitewash nor demonize, but present facts, context, tradeoffs, and consequences honestly.

Section 4. Debate, Rhetoric, and Truth-Seeking

Education shall cultivate the ability to:

a. argue from evidence rather than authority;
b. recognize logical fallacies, emotional manipulation, and rhetorical coercion;
c. engage opposing views in good faith;
d. distinguish disagreement from enmity;
e. revise beliefs when confronted with superior evidence.

The Republic affirms that truth withstands challenge and that censorship is the refuge of weak arguments.

Section 5. Physical Competence and Defensive Readiness
 
(patched)

Education shall include physical training sufficient to promote:

a. health, discipline, and self-control;
b. confidence without aggression;
c. lawful self-defense and defense of others;
d. situational awareness and de-escalation skills.

Instruction in martial arts, defensive techniques, first aid, and the safe handling of tools and arms may be offered in an age-appropriate manner, voluntarily, and with parental or guardian consent.

Such training shall emphasize responsibility, restraint, and proportionality.

Section 6. Civic Responsibility and Service

Education shall prepare individuals for the responsibilities of citizenship, including:

a. jury service;
b. public deliberation;
c. emergency response and civil defense;
d. lawful resistance to tyranny.

Nothing in this Section shall compel ideological conformity or mandatory service, but the Republic may incentivize civic education and preparedness consistent with liberty.

Section 7. Protection Against Educational Capture

No educational institution receiving public funds may:

a. operate as a vehicle for partisan political advocacy;
b. condition advancement on ideological affirmation;
c. suppress lawful speech or inquiry;
d. impose collective guilt or privilege based on immutable characteristics;
e. subordinate competence to political criteria.

Violations of this Section are subject to judicial review and loss of public funding.
Section 7-A. Curricular Transparency and Provenance

All curricular standards, instructional frameworks, approved materials lists, textbook adoption decisions, educator training guidance issued or funded under public authority, and assessment rubrics that materially influence public instruction shall be treated as public records.

Such materials shall be proactively published in accessible, searchable form, including authorship or sponsoring bodies, dates of issuance and revision, stated objectives, and a public change-log sufficient to identify substantive edits across versions.

No public educational authority may rely upon opacity, outsourcing, or contractor status to evade disclosure, provenance, or accountability for materials used in publicly funded instruction.
Section 7-B. No Ideological Tests by Accreditation, Framework, or Proxy

No educational institution receiving public funds, and no accreditor or standards body exercising public authority or determining eligibility for public funds, shall condition admission, grading, credentialing, employment, or advancement on ideological affirmation, compelled belief, compelled political speech, or viewpoint conformity.

No institution shall launder prohibited compulsion or suppression through “standards,” “best practices,” “equity frameworks,” “professional norms,” or similar instruments where the practical effect is ideological enforcement rather than competence-based evaluation.
Section 7-C. Enforcement, Standing, and Remedy

Violations of Sections 7, 7-A, or 7-B are subject to expedited judicial review. Standing shall be afforded to students, parents or guardians, educators, and taxpayers as provided by law.

Courts may order disclosure, enjoin enforcement of unlawful requirements, and impose proportionate funding consequences for institutions that persist in prohibited practices after notice and opportunity to cure.

Section 8. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to favor:

a. intellectual independence over conformity;
b. competence over credentials;
c. courage over compliance;
d. truth over narrative;
e. civic strength over passive dependence.

The Republic entrusts its future not to managed populations, but to educated, capable, and free persons.

Section 9. Mentorship, Aptitude, and Developmental Pluralism
 
(patched)

The Republic recognizes that human excellence arises through diverse paths of development and that individuals possess varied aptitudes, temperaments, and talents.

Education and civic formation shall therefore:

a. encourage mentorship, apprenticeship, and guided mastery to cultivate natural gifts in science, engineering, medicine, craftsmanship, art, philosophy, and other fields essential to civilization;
b. support intensive, structured educational paths for those who benefit from high expectation, discipline, and close guidance;
c. protect exploratory, self-directed, and experiential learning for those who mature through autonomy, play, and discovery.

Parents and guardians retain primary authority to guide the upbringing and educational path of their children, consistent with the safety, dignity, and rights of the child.

No single model of childhood, parenting, or development shall be imposed by the state. The Republic shall neither penalize ambition nor suppress independence where both are exercised lawfully and without harm.

Public institutions shall accommodate varied developmental approaches, provided that core civic competencies, literacy, numeracy, physical health, and constitutional understanding are achieved.

The Republic shall provide targeted, non-coercive support—including grants, scholarships, and digital resources—to ensure equitable access to mentorship, apprenticeships, and alternative educational paths for families of limited means.
