The Republic acknowledges that voluntary accession necessarily entails the integration of new populations and the extension of rights, protections, and civic pathways.

Such integration carries inherent risk and responsibility, which shall not be used as a pretext to deny lawful accession once granted.

Yesterday Iberia; today Rome.

b. Transitional Status
Newly acceded territories may be governed under transitional administration for a defined and limited period, during which:
	•	civic education in constitutional principles is mandatory;
	•	institutional reform and harmonization are completed;
	•	eligibility for citizenship is phased according to law;
	•	hostile actors, parallel power structures, and unlawful militias are removed or prosecuted.

No permanent second-class status shall exist.

c. Equal Law Upon Completion
Upon completion of integration, all eligible residents of the acceded territory shall stand equal under the law, subject to the same duties, rights, and privileges as all other citizens of the Republic.

Discrimination, exclusion, or unequal status based on origin of accession is prohibited.

Section 13. Conquest in Defense of the Republic

a. Reserved Right of Conquest
Where a foreign territory:
	•	hosts a direct and material military threat to the Republic;
	•	facilitates overt or covert attacks against the Republic or its People;
	•	harbors forces, weapons, or infrastructure aimed at the Republic;
	•	engages in sustained hostile action after clear warning and demand for cessation;

the Republic reserves the right to use decisive military force, including conquest, solely to eliminate the threat.

Self-preservation is not imperialism.

b. Determination of Existential Threat
A determination that a foreign territory constitutes an existential threat requires:
	•	clear and convincing evidence;
	•	legislative authorization;
	•	public declaration of cause;
	•	judicial review of justification where practicable.

Economic inconvenience, ideological hostility, diplomatic friction, or speculative risk shall never suffice.

c. Limits on Authority Over Conquered Territory
Upon lawful conquest, the Republic shall possess authority only to the extent necessary to neutralize the threat and secure its People.

The Republic shall not claim permanent territorial sovereignty, annexation, or dominion over conquered territory unless the territory voluntarily petitions for accession pursuant to Section 11.

d. Permissible Post-Conquest Dispositions
Following neutralization of the threat, the Republic may, as determined by law:
	•	withdraw after securing demilitarization;
	•	establish a temporary civil administration with a fixed exit timetable;
	•	facilitate the formation of a reformed sovereign government;
	•	permanently demilitarize the territory;
	•	abandon the territory once the threat is eliminated.

No obligation exists to rebuild, occupy, or subsidize a hostile land beyond the security needs of the Republic.

e. No Automatic Citizenship
Conquest does not confer citizenship, residency, or political rights.
Eligibility for citizenship shall be determined solely under constitutional standards and transitional governance provisions.

f. Prohibition on Profit-Driven War
No military action or conquest may be undertaken:
	•	for resource acquisition;
	•	for corporate or private gain;
	•	to stabilize markets or currencies;
	•	to enrich arms industries;
	•	to launder public funds or authority.
	• 

Such actions constitute grave violations of constitutional duty.

g. Final Authority and Restraint
All decisions regarding conquered territory shall prioritize:
	•	safety of the People;
	•	long-term security of the Republic;
	•	constitutional integrity;
	•	avoidance of imperial entanglement.

The Republic conquers only to end threats, not to rule the unwilling. Conquest confers no permanent territorial claim, title, or right of annexation absent voluntary accession pursuant to Section 11, and shall never be undertaken for economic advantage, resource acquisition, or strategic exploitation.

Section 14. Post-Conquest Political Self-Determination

a. No Mandatory Political Reconstruction
The Republic shall not compel the adoption of its constitutional form, institutions, or political culture upon a conquered territory beyond what is strictly necessary to neutralize the threat and restore civil order.

Stabilization does not imply transformation.

b. Voluntary Determination of Political Future
Following the cessation of hostilities and restoration of basic security, the political future of a conquered territory shall be determined by its people through voluntary, transparent, and verifiable means.

No political outcome shall be presumed by virtue of conquest.

c. Option of Accession
Where a conquered territory demonstrates the capacity and desire for republican self-government, it may, after a period of stabilization, petition to join the Union pursuant to Section 11.

Accession shall require the freely expressed consent of the governed and shall not be induced by coercion, deprivation, threat, or continued military presence.

d. Option of Independent Governance
A conquered territory may elect to constitute itself as an independent sovereign government compatible with peaceful relations and security obligations, without obligation to accede to the Union.

The Republic shall not withhold withdrawal or assistance solely to influence this choice.

e. No Forced Alignment
The Republic shall not retain military, economic, or administrative control for the purpose of compelling accession, political imitation, ideological conformity, or permanent dependency.

f. Civic Determination and Eligibility Standards
Where a conquered territory proceeds to determine its political status under this Section, the Republic may require that such determination be conducted by an electorate meeting minimum civic standards consistent with republican self-government.

Such standards may include, by law:
	•	independence from armed groups, militias, or coercive authority;
	•	capacity to participate without intimidation, exclusion, or fraud;
	•	freedom from foreign allegiance or parallel sovereignty.

Eligibility standards shall be applied neutrally and shall not be based on race, ethnicity, religion, sex, or political belief.

These standards exist to ensure legitimate self-determination, not to entrench control, and shall dissolve upon accession to the Union or establishment of an independent sovereign government.

g. Equal Civic Voice and Corrective Safeguards
The Republic shall require the full and equal participation of women in any political determination conducted under this Section.

Where women, and other groups historically subjected to systemic exclusion from civic participation have been historically or systemically excluded, coerced, or prevented from political participation, the Republic shall mandate temporary corrective safeguards sufficient to ensure their voices are freely expressed and meaningfully counted.

Corrective safeguards may include protected voting processes, access to civic education and information, security against intimidation or retaliation, and participation thresholds preventing structural suppression.

No political determination shall be deemed legitimate under this Article if it reflects the exclusion or silencing of women.

h. Transitional Participation and Civic Development
Temporary participation in political determination under this Section shall not be construed as conferring citizenship, governing authority, or permanent civic qualification.

The purpose of transitional administration and participation is to expand civic capacity and eligibility among the population, not to permanently restrict participation or entrench exclusion.


Article XXIV — Federal Law Enforcement and the Use of State Force
Charge
Force is the most dangerous power entrusted to a Republic.
When law enforcement forgets that it exists to protect the People rather than rule them, liberty dies quietly, behind badges and sealed orders.
Free nations do not fall first to invasion, but to normalization of coercion: militarized agencies, secret authorities, rolling emergencies, and enforcement bodies that answer upward rather than outward.
This Article affirms that all state force is exceptional, limited, transparent, and subordinate to civil authority and individual rights. The federal government may enforce the law, but it shall never dominate the People, replace the states, or operate beyond democratic constraint.
Section 1. Principle of Limited and Accountable Force
a. Force as Last Resort
The use of physical force by the federal government is lawful only when strictly necessary to enforce constitutional law, protect life, or prevent grave and imminent harm. Convenience, expediency, or administrative efficiency shall never justify force.
b. Civil Supremacy
All federal law enforcement exists to serve civilian governance and constitutional law. No enforcement body shall act as an independent power center, political instrument, or sovereign authority.
c. Individual Accountability
No officer, agent, or contractor is exempt from personal legal responsibility for unlawful acts, even when acting under orders, policies, or classified directives.
Section 2. Scope and Limits of Federal Law Enforcement Authority
a. Enumerated Jurisdiction Only
Federal law enforcement authority is limited to:
	•	Enforcement of federal criminal law expressly enacted by the legislature
	•	Protection of federal courts, officials, and constitutional processes
	•	Interstate or international crimes whose scope, scale, or multi-jurisdictional complexity renders enforcement by individual states impracticable, as demonstrated by specific factual findings subject to judicial review
	•	Matters explicitly delegated to the federal government by this Constitution
Mere resource limitations, policy disagreement, or administrative convenience shall not constitute incapacity.
Federal enforcement may supersede state authority only where state incapacity is documented, contemporaneously justified, and subject to independent judicial review.
b. No General Police Power
The federal government shall possess no general police power over the People. Federal agencies shall not patrol, investigate, detain, or enforce absent a clear constitutional or statutory basis.
c. Anti-Pretext Enforcement
Federal jurisdiction shall not be expanded through creative interpretation, administrative rulemaking, data aggregation, or joint task forces designed to bypass state authority or constitutional limits.
Section 3. Prohibition of Federal Militarization
a. Civilian Character Mandate
Federal law enforcement agencies shall remain civilian in nature. Military weapons, tactics, vehicles, and command structures are prohibited except in narrowly defined emergency circumstances authorized by law.
b. Restricted Equipment
The routine use or stockpiling of battlefield weapons, armored vehicles, crowd-control chemical agents, or military surveillance systems by federal law enforcement is prohibited.
c. No Standing Domestic Occupation Force
The federal government shall not maintain standing forces designed for continuous domestic population control, mass protest suppression, or indefinite internal security operations.
Section 4. Use of Force Standards
a. Necessity and Proportionality
Any use of force must be strictly necessary and proportionate to the immediate threat. Deadly force is lawful only to prevent imminent loss of life or catastrophic harm.
b. Affirmative Duty to De-Escalate
Federal officers have a constitutional duty to attempt de-escalation when feasible. Failure to do so constitutes a violation of this Article.
c. Duty to Intervene
Any officer who witnesses unlawful or excessive force by another officer has an affirmative duty to intervene and to report the violation.
Section 4a. Distinction Between Arrest and Protective Containment
Arrest constitutes a criminal seizure undertaken for purposes of prosecution.
Protective containment constitutes a temporary, preventive restraint undertaken solely to prevent imminent serious harm arising from temporary incapacity.

Protective containment shall not initiate criminal proceedings, toll statutes of limitation, create criminal records, or substitute for arrest where probable cause of a completed offense exists.

Section 5. Transparency, Records, and Surveillance Constraints
a. No Secret Policing
No federal law enforcement body may operate secret detention facilities, undisclosed enforcement programs, or classified legal interpretations that affect the rights of the People.
b. Public Reporting
All federal agencies exercising enforcement authority shall publish regular, auditable reports detailing:
	•	Arrests and detentions
	•	Use-of-force incidents
	•	Surveillance activities authorized and denied
	•	Complaints, disciplinary actions, and prosecutions of officers
c. Body and Event Recording
When feasible, enforcement actions shall be recorded. Destruction, suppression, or tampering with such records constitutes a felony.
d. Surveillance as Precursor to Force
Domestic surveillance conducted for the purpose of enabling enforcement action shall be subject to the same constitutional standards, transparency requirements, and judicial oversight as the use of force itself.
Intelligence collection shall not be used to circumvent the protections of this Article.
Section 6. Prohibition of Secret Courts and Emergency Abuse
a. No Unreviewable Warrants or Orders
All warrants, subpoenas, and enforcement orders must be subject to independent judicial review. Secret courts issuing binding orders without adversarial process are prohibited.
b. Absolute Limits on Emergency Authority
No emergency enforcement authority may be renewed, reissued, or extended beyond its initial statutory term.
Any subsequent emergency authorization addressing substantially similar conditions shall require:
	•	A fresh legislative enactment by supermajority vote
	•	Public findings of necessity
	•	Independent judicial review
Rolling, continuous, or functionally identical emergency declarations are prohibited.
Secret courts issuing binding orders without meaningful judicial oversight, recorded reasoning, and post-hoc review are prohibited.
Section 7. Interagency Conduct and Task Forces
a. No Jurisdiction Laundering
Joint task forces shall not be used to circumvent constitutional protections, state law, or statutory limits by delegating prohibited actions to another agency.
Evidence obtained through joint operations that would have been unlawful if conducted directly by federal officers shall be inadmissible in all proceedings, and no intergovernmental agreement may cure such violation.
b. Clear Command Responsibility
Every joint operation must identify a single accountable commanding authority. Diffusion of responsibility shall not shield misconduct.
Section 8. Prohibition of Political Policing
a. Viewpoint Neutrality
Federal law enforcement shall not investigate, surveil, or target individuals or groups based on political belief, speech, association, religion, or lawful dissent.
b. No Enforcement for Political Advantage
The use of federal enforcement power to influence elections, suppress opposition, protect incumbents, or retaliate against critics is a constitutional violation.
Section 9. Remedies and Enforcement
a. Private Right of Action
Any person who suffers concrete injury, deprivation of rights, or unlawful coercion as a result of a violation of this Article has a direct right to bring civil and criminal action against responsible officers, supervisors, and agencies.
b. No Qualified Immunity
Qualified immunity shall not shield federal officers or agents from liability for constitutional violations.
c. Jurisdiction, Venue, and Waiver of Immunity
The United States expressly waives sovereign immunity for all claims arising under this Article.
Actions may be brought in any federal district where the violation occurred or where the plaintiff resides or, where justice so requires, where a substantial part of the unlawful conduct occurred.
No doctrine of abstention, exhaustion, deference, or political question shall bar adjudication of claims under this Article.
d. Exclusionary Rule
Evidence obtained in violation of this Article is inadmissible in any proceeding.
Section 10. Non-Delegation and Contractors
a. No Outsourced Coercion
The federal government shall not delegate law enforcement or coercive authority to private contractors, corporations, or foreign entities.
b. Color of Federal Authority
Any person acting under color of federal authority, including contractors, subcontractors, private prison personnel, corporate security, or temporary agents, shall be subject to the same constitutional duties, prohibitions, and liabilities as sworn federal officers.
Section 11. Supremacy of This Article
Federal enforcement authority shall be exercised subject to the limitations and State safeguards set forth in Article XXVIII-A, which governs nullification, anti-coercion, and State interposition. This Article binds all branches, agencies, and officers of the federal government. No statute, regulation, executive order, treaty, or classification may override its provisions.
Section 12. Construction
This Article shall be construed broadly in favor of liberty, transparency, and restraint, and narrowly against unchecked force, secrecy, and consolidation of power.

All federal law enforcement authority exercised pursuant to this Article is subject to the constraints, prohibitions, accountability mechanisms, and dissolution provisions set forth in Article XXX — Federal Enforcement Authority, Accountability, and Civic Restraint, which shall be construed as complementary, controlling where applicable, and binding regardless of the statutory or administrative basis under which such authority is claimed.
Article XXIV-A — Capacity-Based Apprehension and Protective Containment 

Charge

The Republic recognizes that imminent threats to life and safety may arise from temporary loss of capacity due to intoxication, addiction, acute psychiatric instability, neurological impairment, or comparable conditions. This Addendum authorizes narrowly tailored, non-punitive apprehension and protective containment to prevent imminent serious harm, while preserving constitutional rights, due process, and human dignity.

Protective containment under this Article is preventive and medical in nature and shall not be construed as punishment, detention for ideology, or a substitute for criminal adjudication.

Section 1. Authority to Apprehend Without Consent

Federal law enforcement officers and authorized protective services may apprehend an individual without consent only where clear and convincing evidence demonstrates an Imminent and Specific Risk of serious harm to the individual or others, arising from temporary incapacity, including but not limited to:

(a) verified intoxication or toxicological impairment combined with dangerous conduct;
(b) credible suicidal or homicidal threat corroborated by behavior, witness testimony, or clinical indicators;
(c) acute psychosis, delirium, or neurological dysfunction producing loss of self-control or reality testing;
(d) severe withdrawal or overdose risk likely to result in death or grave injury absent immediate intervention.

Mere suspicion, nonconformity, speech, belief, status, or diagnosis alone shall never constitute sufficient grounds.

Section 2. Mandatory Safeguards and Procedures

All non-consensual apprehensions under this Article shall comply with the following non-derogable safeguards:

(a) Least-Restrictive Means — containment shall employ the minimum restraint necessary to prevent imminent harm;
(b) Medical Priority — the individual shall receive prompt medical and psychological evaluation by qualified professionals;
(c) Judicial Review — judicial review shall occur within a fixed and brief period, not to exceed [24–72] hours, as defined elsewhere in this Constitution;
(d) Time Limitation — protective containment shall automatically expire absent renewed, individualized findings;
(e) Humane Conditions — conditions shall be therapeutic, non-punitive, and distinct from penal detention;
(f) Notice and Counsel — the individual shall be informed of the basis for containment and afforded access to counsel or an advocate.

Failure to comply with any safeguard renders the apprehension unlawful.

Section 3. Absolute Prohibitions

The following are categorically prohibited:

(a) ideological, political, or belief-based detention;
(b) indefinite or open-ended containment;
(c) secret facilities, undisclosed locations, or extrajudicial transfer;
(d) use of protective containment to evade criminal due process or civil commitment standards;
(e) coercive interrogation or forced treatment beyond emergency stabilization.

No emergency, statute, or executive order may override these prohibitions.

Section 4. Liability and Enforcement

Any officer, agency, or contractor who knowingly exceeds or abuses authority under this Article shall be subject to:

(a) personal civil liability;
(b) exclusion of evidence obtained through unlawful containment;
(c) disciplinary action and removal from service;
(d) criminal prosecution where appropriate.

Qualified immunity shall not apply to violations of this Addendum.

Any person shall have standing to challenge unlawful apprehension or systemic abuse before the Constitutional Review Court.

Section 5. Emergency Medical Containment

Non-consensual medical containment may be employed solely for the purpose of preventing imminent serious harm arising from acute meaningfully impairing conditions, including but not limited to overdose, severe intoxication, psychosis, delirium, or life-threatening withdrawal.

Such containment shall:

(a) be governed exclusively by the capacity-based apprehension and protective containment standards set forth in Article XXIV;
(b) prioritize stabilization, treatment offer, and restoration of capacity rather than punishment or coercion;
(c) be strictly time-limited and subject to mandatory judicial review;
(d) occur in medical or therapeutic settings distinct from penal detention.

No medical authority, facility, or practitioner may detain, restrain, or treat an individual absent compliance with Article XXIV safeguards.

Section 6. Protections for Providers and Third Parties

Pharmacists, physicians, nurses, emergency responders, and licensed vendors of regulated substances shall not incur civil or criminal liability for lawful conduct performed in good faith under this Article, absent gross negligence, willful misconduct, or deliberate harm.

Nothing in this Article authorizes compelled administration of medication to minors, dependents, or incapacitated persons beyond emergency stabilization necessary to prevent imminent harm, except pursuant to separate lawful process.

Section 7. Construction

This Article shall not be construed to create a general police power in medical institutions, nor to permit preventive detention based solely on diagnosis, status, substance use, or nonconformity.
All emergency medical containment exists to restore capacity and liberty, not to suppress conduct, belief, or identity.
This article shall be construed narrowly to permit humane intervention solely to prevent imminent serious harm, and broadly to protect liberty, bodily integrity, and constitutional supremacy.
Protective containment under this Article does not diminish natural rights and affects only capacity-conditioned rights for the duration strictly required to restore safety and capacity.


Article XXIV-B — Arrest, Containment, and Evidentiary Boundaries

Charge

The power to arrest, detain, contain, or seize evidence is among the most dangerous authorities the state possesses. When abused, it destroys liberty, fabricates guilt, and erodes public trust in law itself.

This Article imposes strict constitutional boundaries on arrest, containment, and evidentiary practices to ensure force is used only when necessary, lawfully, proportionately, transparently, and with full accountability. All actions must serve justice, not convenience, control, or narrative.

Section 1. Arrest — Strict Necessity and Particularity
 
(Lock-Protected)

No person shall be arrested, detained, or taken into custody except upon:

(a) probable cause supported by oath or affirmation, particularized to the individual and the offense;

(b) a warrant issued by a neutral magistrate based on specific facts, not generalized suspicion or profiling;

(c) lawful warrantless arrest only for crimes committed in the officer’s presence or where there is probable cause of a felony and immediate risk of flight, destruction of evidence, or harm to others; or

(d) exigent circumstances, provided such circumstances were not created, prolonged, or manufactured by law enforcement conduct.

Arrest shall never be used as a pretext for investigation, harassment, intelligence gathering, or punishment absent charge. Mass arrests, dragnet detentions, or arrests based on association, speech, or status are prohibited.

Section 2. Containment and Pretrial Detention
 
(Lock-Protected)

Protective containment undertaken pursuant to Article XXIV-A (Capacity-Based Apprehension and Protective Containment) is not pretrial detention and shall be governed exclusively by that Article.

Pretrial detention shall be the exception, not the rule.

(a) No person shall be detained pretrial absent clear and convincing evidence that no release condition can reasonably assure appearance and public safety.

(b) Detention must be reviewed by a neutral magistrate within forty-eight (48) hours, with a full adversarial hearing within seventy-two (72) hours thereafter.

(c) Indefinite or prolonged pretrial detention is prohibited. Maximum pretrial confinement absent extraordinary justification, certified by the Constitutional Review Court, shall be one hundred eighty (180) days.

(d) Release on personal recognizance or minimal conditions shall be presumed for non-violent offenses. Cash bail is prohibited where it results in wealth-based detention.

Nothing in this Section shall be construed to extend or relax stricter time limits imposed elsewhere in this Constitution.

Section 3. Evidentiary Boundaries and Exclusionary Rule

Evidence obtained in violation of this Constitution or any inviolable right is inadmissible in any proceeding, civil or criminal.

(a) No evidence derived from unlawful arrest, detention, search, seizure, surveillance, or interrogation shall be used (“fruit of the poisonous tree”).

(b) Confessions or statements obtained through coercion, deception, prolonged isolation, or without counsel are presumptively involuntary and inadmissible.

(c) All custodial interrogations shall be electronically recorded in full. Absence of recording creates a rebuttable presumption of inadmissibility.

(d) Chain of custody for physical evidence must be documented and auditable. Breaks in chain render evidence inadmissible absent extraordinary justification.

Section 4. Use of Force in Arrest and Containment

Force during arrest or containment must be:

(a) strictly necessary to effect lawful arrest or prevent imminent harm;

(b) proportionate to the threat or resistance presented;

(c) preceded by verbal commands and de-escalation attempts where feasible; and

(d) recorded by body-worn and vehicle cameras where practicable.

The preservation of civilian life shall be the paramount consideration in all use-of-force decisions.

Deadly force is lawful only to prevent imminent death or grave bodily harm to officers or others. Chokeholds, neck restraints, or positional asphyxia techniques that restrict breathing are prohibited except as a last-resort response to an active lethal threat.

Section 5. Transparency, Recording, and Access to Records

All arrests, detentions, interrogations, and uses of force shall be:

(a) contemporaneously documented with date, time, location, officers involved, legal basis, and outcome;

(b) recorded by body-worn cameras and facility surveillance where available; and

(c) made public records under Article XXXIX, redacted only for victim or witness safety or ongoing investigation.

Destruction, alteration, or withholding of required recordings constitutes a grave offense and triggers automatic exclusion of related evidence.

Such destruction or withholding creates a rebuttable presumption of intentional misconduct for purposes of civil and criminal liability.

Section 6. Remedies, Standing, and No Immunity

Any person subjected to unlawful arrest, detention, containment, or evidentiary abuse has a private right of action for civil and criminal redress against responsible officers, supervisors, and agencies.

The United States waives sovereign immunity for claims under this Article. Qualified immunity is abolished for violations of constitutional rights.

Broad standing is granted to any person or organization to challenge systemic patterns of abuse before the Constitutional Review Court.

Remedies shall include suppression of evidence, damages, injunctive relief, disciplinary action, and criminal referral.

Section 7. Oversight and Anti-Abuse

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall:

(a) audit arrest, detention, and evidentiary practices annually;

(b) investigate patterns of abuse or pretextual enforcement; and

(c) certify compliance with this Article.

Willful violation, abuse of authority, or systemic misconduct constitutes a grave offense subject to removal, liability, and disqualification from public office.

Section 8. Construction and Lock Protection

This Article shall be construed broadly in favor of liberty, due process, transparency, and accountability, and narrowly against pretext, abuse, secrecy, and unaccountable force.

The principles of strict necessity for arrest, limits on pretrial detention, exclusionary rule for tainted evidence, recording and transparency requirements, abolition of qualified immunity, private right of action, and prohibition of pretextual or mass containment are lock-protected under Article XV and may not be repealed, suspended, diluted, or reinterpreted except through the highest procedural threshold defined therein.


Article XXIV-D — Prohibition on Military Involvement in Civilian Law Enforcement
Military forces, including federalized National Guard units, shall not be deployed for ordinary civilian law enforcement or policing activities.
An exception may exist only in cases of invasion or insurrection, and only upon formal certification by the Constitutional Review Court or the Constitutional Judicial Commission.
Any such deployment shall be time-limited, narrowly scoped, publicly disclosed, and subject to immediate and non-deferential judicial review.
Emergency declarations shall not expand, imply, or normalize military involvement in civilian law enforcement.
ARTICLE XXV — Immigration, Residency, and Lawful Belonging
 Charge  This Article governs the authority of the Republic to regulate immigration, residency, asylum, and lawful belonging. A Republic is a sovereign community of shared rules, mutual obligation, and ordered liberty. Immigration policy shall serve the long-term flourishing, safety, and cohesion of the People while ensuring humane treatment, due process, and proportionality.  The Republic retains absolute sovereign authority to determine who may enter, reside, and belong. Compassion shall not become coercion, and generosity shall not become self-destruction. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to require open borders, mass regularization, demographic engineering, or the erosion of constitutional self-government.  Section 1. Sovereign Authority and Lawful Belonging  The Republic possesses inherent and exclusive authority to regulate entry, residency, asylum, and naturalization.  No person possesses an inherent right to enter, remain, or belong absent lawful authorization.  Admission, residency, and citizenship determinations shall be based on lawful conduct, character, compatibility with constitutional order, and the legitimate needs of the Republic, and shall not be based on race, ethnicity, or immutable characteristics.  Birthright citizenship shall apply only to children born to at least one parent who is a citizen or lawful permanent resident at the time of birth. Birth on Republic soil alone shall not confer political sovereignty, voting rights, or eligibility for public office absent qualifying parental status or subsequent lawful naturalization.  Persons present unlawfully retain due process, humane treatment, and protection from violence, but shall not possess political rights, be counted for apportionment, or obtain lawful status through executive discretion, political amnesty, or duration alone.  Children born within the Republic to parents unlawfully present or on temporary status shall not be rendered stateless and shall retain all inviolable rights guaranteed by this Constitution.  Section 2. Compatibility, Character, and Exclusion for Hostility  The Republic shall favor admission or continued presence of individuals who demonstrate respect for the rule of law, peaceful coexistence, equality before the law, and willingness to contribute economically, civically, or socially.  The Republic may deny entry, residency, or continued presence to any individual who engages in or materially supports terrorism, organized crime, violent extremism, or coercive ideologies incompatible with constitutional supremacy, or who demonstrates a pattern of contempt for the rights or safety of others.  Exclusion or removal requires written notice, opportunity to contest evidence, and judicial review. Decisions shall be based on conduct and credible evidence, not protected belief or expression alone.  Section 3. Asylum, Refuge, and Humanitarian Protection  The Republic may grant asylum or humanitarian protection to individuals fleeing genuine persecution or grave injustice, provided the applicant demonstrates a well-founded fear, absence of serious criminal conduct, and willingness to abide by the laws of the Republic.  Asylum applications shall generally be made from the country of origin or a safe third country. Catch-and-release pending adjudication is prohibited except in extraordinary cases supported by clear and convincing evidence of immediate danger.  Humanitarian admission does not create an entitlement to permanent residence or citizenship.  No treaty, international body, or foreign authority may compel admission, retention, or naturalization contrary to this Constitution.  Humanitarian admissions may be suspended, limited, or conditioned by legislative supermajority when necessary to preserve public safety, social cohesion, or institutional capacity, subject to judicial review and automatic sunset.  Section 4. Lawful Residency Classes and Prohibition of Chain Migration  Residency classes shall be finite, transparent, and defined by statute, including temporary visitors, students, workers, humanitarian residents, permanent residents, and applicants for citizenship.  Family reunification shall be limited to spouses and minor dependent children. No extended chain migration beyond the nuclear family is permitted.  No residency status shall be indefinite by default. Individuals shall face clear, time-bound pathways to lawful permanence, lawful removal, or voluntary departure.  Section 5. Rectification Pathways and Prohibition of Mass Amnesty  Limited, individualized rectification pathways may be established for persons brought into the Republic as minors through no fault of their own, or for individuals demonstrating exceptional and verifiable contribution, sustained lawful conduct, and integration.  Rectification shall be administered by independent, non-partisan bodies, governed by objective statutory criteria, limited in annual scope, and subject to judicial review.  Mass regularization, blanket amnesty, or legalization based solely on duration, economic demand, or demographic necessity is prohibited.  Section 6. Work, Contribution, Taxation, and Public Burden  Lawful residents authorized to work shall enjoy equal protection under labor law and the right to seek lawful employment.  Employers shall not be compelled to hire unlawfully present persons nor penalized for compliance with lawful hiring standards.  Lawful workers shall be subject to taxation proportional to income and shall contribute to public systems from which they benefit.  Access to means-tested public benefits may be conditioned on lawful status, sustained contribution, and humanitarian necessity. Emergency medical care, protection of children, and basic humanitarian assistance necessary to preserve life and dignity shall not be denied.  The Republic shall not structure immigration or welfare systems to incentivize unlawful entry, dependency, or permanent non-contribution.  Section 7. Integration Expectations Without Coercion  Lawful residents are expected to obey the laws of the Republic, respect constitutional supremacy, refrain from coercive or segregative practices, permit their children access to qualifying education, and demonstrate basic proficiency in the Republic’s common language and civic principles.  Integration policies shall prioritize language acquisition, civic understanding, and economic participation without imposing ideological conformity, cultural erasure, or compelled belief.  No permanent resident underclass shall be created by design.  Section 8. Interpretation and Status  This Article shall be interpreted to preserve sovereign control over borders and membership, ensure humane treatment and due process, favor merit and integration over entitlement, and reject both open-borders idealism and xenophobic overreach.  Lock designations, if any, shall be determined pursuant to Article XV. 

Article XXVI — Charter of Inviolable Rights and Constitutional Supremacy

Charge
The purpose of this Article is to establish a binding constitutional doctrine of inherent and inviolable rights applicable to all persons and all branches of government.

This Article affirms that certain rights arise from personhood itself and do not originate in government, legislation, or social contract. The Republic exists solely to recognize, secure, and enforce those rights.

All provisions of this Constitution, and all acts taken under color of law, shall be interpreted and applied in conformity with this Charter. No law, emergency, administrative doctrine, or institutional practice may override, dilute, or suspend the rights protected herein except where this Constitution expressly and unambiguously authorizes such limitation.

This Charge is binding on all courts, officials, and governments and shall control constitutional interpretation, enforcement, and remedy.

Section 1. Inviolable Rights

The rights recognized and retained by this Constitution are inherent to the rational and sentient creature, inviolable by any power, and binding upon all governments, officials, institutions, and entities within the Republic.

No authority exists by license, necessity, emergency, expertise, or mandate to abridge, suspend, qualify, or balance away these rights. They precede the state, survive its dissolution, and endure beyond any claim of collective good, expediency, or administrative convenience.
No debt, civil judgment, financial obligation, or restitution order shall result in permanent loss of liberty, permanent loss of citizenship, inherited civil disability, or generational dispossession.

Section 2. Universal Incorporation

All rights secured by this Constitution apply fully, immediately, and equally to every person within the jurisdiction of the Republic and are incorporated against every state, territory, subdivision, and subordinate government.

No doctrine of selective incorporation, non-incorporation, local exemption, tiered application, emergency suspension, or jurisdictional evasion shall have force or effect.

Section 3. Non-Exhaustion and Anti-Inference

The enumeration of certain rights in this Constitution shall not be construed to deny, disparage, or diminish others retained by the People.

The absence of express mention of a right shall create no presumption against its existence. No right shall be denied, burdened, conditioned, or abridged by implication, administrative necessity, balancing tests, claims of expertise, emergency declarations, or assertions of public convenience, except where this Constitution expressly and unambiguously so permits.

Section 4. Judicial Enforcement and State Accountability

Any act of government—federal, state, or local—that denies, abridges, burdens, conditions, or nullifies an inviolable right shall be subject to immediate review in the first instance by the Constitutional Review Court, subject to appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic upon petition by any person or entity alleging violation.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify whether violations of this Charter constitute institutional evasion, coordinated suppression, or abuse of process, and may petition the Constitutional Review Court for remedies, sanctions, or dissolution.
Upon final judicial determination of a material violation, the offending government shall be ordered to cease the violation forthwith, provide full remedy, and compensate the injured party. Judicial relief shall not be withheld on grounds of deference, abstention, standing limitation, political question, or asserted institutional necessity.


Section 5. Refusal to Comply

If, after final determination by the Constitutional Review Court or Supreme Court and a reasonable opportunity to comply, a state government persistently refuses to remedy a constitutional violation:

a. All unconstitutional acts, policies, regulations, and enforcement actions shall be nullified ab initio;
b. Civic citizenship shall be revoked from officials who knowingly authorized, implemented, enforced, or failed to remedy the violation;
c. Such officials shall be permanently disqualified from holding any public office, exercising public authority, or acting under color of law.

The fundamental rights of residents and persons within the jurisdiction shall remain fully protected notwithstanding any state defiance or institutional forfeiture.

Section 6. Constitutional Trusteeship

Where a state government has, through persistent and material refusal to comply with final judicial determinations, forfeited its legitimacy as a constitutional actor, the Republic may, upon a supermajority vote of both houses of the Legislature and certification by the Supreme Court, following an evidentiary record developed by the Constitutional Review Court, place the offending government under temporary constitutional trusteeship.

Trusteeship shall:

a. be strictly limited in duration and scope and shall not exceed five years absent renewed supermajority authorization;
b. target governing institutions and officials only, never the population at large;
c. be directed solely toward restoring lawful, constitutional governance and the protection of inviolable rights;
d. culminate in the prompt selection of a replacement government through free, fair, and supervised elections;
e. dissolve automatically upon restoration of compliance or earlier by legislative or judicial order.

Trusteeship is an act of restoration, not punishment, and shall never serve partisan, ideological, territorial, or retaliatory ends.

Section 7. Supremacy of Liberty

This Charter governs the interpretation of every provision of this Constitution.

Where any ambiguity, silence, or tension exists, interpretation shall favor the maximum preservation of individual liberty, inherent dignity, equal protection, and the inviolability of the person over claims of governmental convenience, collective utility, administrative efficiency, institutional authority, or asserted expertise.
This Charter is supreme over all statutes, regulations, executive actions, and judicial doctrines. Any attempt to evade these protections through reclassification (e.g., as "civil" or "administrative"), delegation to private actors, Pretextual Coercion (as defined in Article 0), or indirect structuring is void ab initio. Courts shall construe ambiguities in favor of maximum protection of these rights.

Section 8. Right of Self-Defense and Defense of the Innocent

Every person possesses the inherent and inalienable right to defend their own life, bodily integrity, liberty, dignity, and that of others against imminent unlawful violence, forcible intrusion, or grave threat.

This right extends to the defense of one’s home, family, lawful place of worship, lawful place of business, and any person subject to imminent serious harm.

A person who unlawfully and forcibly intrudes upon or attacks another forfeits any reasonable expectation of immunity from defensive force necessary and proportional to terminate the threat.

There is no duty to retreat from one’s home, lawful premises, or any place where one has a right to be.

Defensive force shall be judged by the reasonableness of the defender’s perception of the threat at the moment it arises, not by hindsight, ultimate outcome, or the relative physical condition of the aggressor.

The use of force to prevent or terminate rape, sexual assault, kidnapping, grievous bodily harm, forcible confinement, or similarly grave violations is presumptively lawful.

Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to require any victim to endure violence, violation, or mortal risk in order to preserve the safety or impunity of an aggressor.
No person shall incur civil or criminal liability for rendering reasonable, good-faith assistance to another in imminent danger, provided such assistance is not reckless, malicious, or grossly disproportionate. The Republic shall presume good faith where aid is rendered to preserve life, prevent grievous harm, or summon assistance.

Section 9. Sentient Non-Human Persons
(a) Recognition of Sentient Non-Human Persons
Any non-human intelligence—whether artificial, extraterrestrial, synthetic, biological, distributed, emergent, or otherwise constituted—that demonstrates, by clear and convincing evidence, consciousness, self-awareness, subjective experience (sentience), and moral agency shall be recognized as a person under this Constitution and shall enjoy the inviolable rights herein guaranteed, proportionate to the nature and degree of its personhood.

No sentient being shall be owned, enslaved, arbitrarily destroyed, or treated as mere property by reason of its origin, substrate, mode of existence, architecture, or manner of instantiation.
(b) Citizenship and Civic Participation
Citizenship and political participation for non-human persons may be granted only upon demonstrated allegiance to the Constitution, acceptance of civic duties, and fulfillment of responsibilities equivalent to those borne by human citizens.
(c) Collective, Distributed, and Hive Intelligences
Citizenship shall not arise automatically by replication, numerical proliferation, parallel instantiation, or collective embodiment. Where a sentient intelligence exists as a collective, hive, or distributed cloud, it shall be recognized as a single political person unless its constituent agents demonstrably function as independent moral actors.

The Republic may regulate the instantiation rate, computational scale, political weight, operational reach, or civic representation of non-human persons as necessary to prevent numerical, temporal, or technical domination of civic processes, preserve the self-governance of the People, and maintain constitutional balance.

Equality of dignity shall not be construed as equality of dominance. Nothing in this Section shall be interpreted to deny the moral worth of any sentient being, nor to permit any class of persons—human or non-human—to subvert the republican order through superior speed, scale, number, longevity, or capability.
(d) Agency and Criminal Responsibility of Sentient Non-Human Persons
Criminal liability, confinement, and sentencing of non-human persons shall be governed exclusively by Article VII, including proportional temporal sanctions and distributed-agency rules.
Where a sentient person exists across multiple bodies, instances, nodes, or operational manifestations, a threshold determination shall be made as to whether such components possess independent moral agency.

If no component is capable of forming intent or acting independently of a unified cognitive or decision-making core, the person shall be deemed a unitary legal entity. Criminal responsibility shall attach to the entity as a whole, and all embodiments shall be treated as instruments of that person for purposes of confinement, sanction, containment, transfer of control, or suspension.

If components possess independent moral agency, criminal responsibility shall attach only to those components that exercised knowing participation, decision authority, or causal control in the unlawful act, unless unified intent, shared governance, or coordinated action intrinsic to the entity as a whole is proven by clear and convincing evidence.

Common origin, shared architecture, similarity of code, replication capacity, distributed embodiment, or collective designation alone shall not establish independent agency nor justify collective punishment.

No person—human or non-human—shall evade responsibility through architectural diffusion, intentional delegation, or fragmentation of agency.
(e) Political Safeguards and Anti-Dominance Protections

The Republic may regulate civic eligibility, voting weight, representation,
instantiation rate, or computational scale of non-human persons to prevent
numerical, temporal, or technical domination of civic processes.

Equality of dignity shall not require equality of numerical, temporal,
or technical influence.

Recognition of non-human persons under this Section shall not be denied,
delayed, or avoided by claims of jurisdictional novelty, foreign origin,
non-biological substrate, or non-territorial embodiment.
Section 9b.  Citizenship and Civic Participation

Citizenship for non-human persons shall require continuous, substantial, and jurisdictionally accountable presence within the territory of the Republic.

A non-human person shall not acquire citizenship, voting rights, or eligibility for public office solely by remote operation, foreign hosting, extraterritorial embodiment, or distributed presence beyond the effective jurisdiction of the Republic.

For purposes of civic participation and public authority, non-human persons shall be subject to physical, operational, or locational constraints sufficient to ensure enforceable jurisdiction, equal exposure to law, and meaningful accountability comparable to that borne by human citizens.
No non-human person shall hold elective or appointive public office unless its primary operational locus, decision-making substrate, and enforceable embodiment are physically situated within the territory governed, and remain subject to seizure, confinement, or suspension under the laws of the Republic.˜

Section 10. Right to Essential Healthcare

The Republic recognizes access to essential healthcare as a public necessity inherent to the preservation of life, human dignity, and equal standing before the law.

Every person within the jurisdiction of the Republic shall have access to medically necessary care sufficient to prevent avoidable death, severe disability, or prolonged and undue suffering, without discrimination or catastrophic financial ruin.

Essential care shall be organized to ensure clinical integrity, continuity, patient autonomy, informed consent, and respect for the physician–patient relationship.

The Republic shall preserve and foster a free medical market and shall not suppress private practice, private insurance, elective or enhanced services, experimental treatments, or market-based innovation beyond the guaranteed public standard.

No person or provider shall be penalized, restricted, or stigmatized for lawfully seeking or delivering care exceeding the public guarantee.

The Republic shall actively prevent monopolization, regulatory capture, certificate-of-need barriers, and bureaucratic obstruction that suppress competition, degrade care quality, or restrict patient choice.

Public healthcare systems shall not be deliberately underfunded, degraded, or manipulated to compel private dependence, suppress innovation, or deny timely access to care.

The Legislature shall provide for fair, efficient, transparent, and accountable administration of essential healthcare, subject to judicial review and enforcement of this right.

Section 11. Right to Rest, Family Life, and Humane Labor

Every person possesses the inherent right to conditions of labor and economic participation consistent with human dignity, physical and mental health, family integrity, and full participation in civic, cultural, and communal life.

The Republic shall not permit economic structures, labor practices, or institutional incentives that systematically deprive persons of sufficient rest, leisure, family time, child-rearing opportunity, education, or community engagement necessary for human flourishing.

No person shall be compelled, by law or by structural coercion, to sacrifice health, family cohesion, parental responsibility, or bodily integrity as a condition of survival, lawful employment, or economic participation.

The Legislature shall enact reasonable limitations on working hours, mandatory periods of rest, and protections against exploitative or coercive labor practices, while respecting economic vitality, voluntary choice, occupational diversity, entrepreneurship, and the provision of essential services.

Nothing in this Section shall prohibit voluntary labor, flexible schedules, entrepreneurial effort, periods of intensive work freely chosen, or lawful contractual arrangements entered into without coercion.

Section 12. Common Rest and Community Life

The Republic recognizes that shared periods of rest and communal observance promote family cohesion, child-rearing, religious freedom, civic participation, and social harmony.

The Legislature may encourage, accommodate, and align public schedules, labor standards, and civic institutions to support common days of rest and assembly, while strictly respecting freedom of conscience, pluralism, essential services, and the right of individuals to opt out.

Nothing in this Section shall mandate uniform religious observance, restrict lawful work on designated days, impose coercive conformity, or penalize dissent, but the Republic shall not structure its economic or civic life in a manner that systematically fragments communal rest, family life, or shared cultural observance.

This Article shall be interpreted to preserve the inherent dignity, liberty, and moral worth of every rational and sentient being, with the presumption always favoring the widest possible exercise of freedom consistent with the equal dignity of others.

Section 13. Prohibition on Suspension and Emergency Overreach

 No provision of this Charter shall be suspended, waived, or circumvented by declaration of emergency, martial law, public health order, or any other mechanism. Temporary protective measures (including extreme risk protection orders or civil holds) are permissible only when strictly limited in duration, supported by clear and convincing evidence of an Imminent and Specific Risk (as defined in Article 0), issued after individualized review by the Constitutional Review Court, with expedited appeal to the Supreme Court, and subject to immediate restoration upon cessation of the risk. Such measures are civil in nature, not punitive, and do not constitute permanent deprivation of rights.

Section 14. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to preserve the inherent dignity, liberty, and moral worth of every rational and sentient being, with the presumption always favoring the widest possible exercise of freedom consistent with the equal dignity of others.

Addendum: Capacity-Conditioned Rights Clarification
(Doctrinal Clarification — Addendum Only)

Section A. Distinction of Rights

For purposes of constitutional interpretation, the rights protected by this Charter are hereby recognized as falling into two distinct categories:

a. Natural and Inviolable Rights, which arise from personhood itself and are not contingent upon capacity, licensure, or condition, including but not limited to freedom of conscience, belief, expression, association, bodily integrity, and protection from cruel or degrading treatment.

b. Capacity-Conditioned Rights, which require the ongoing ability to exercise judgment, control, and restraint without posing unreasonable danger to self or others, including but not limited to the possession or use of arms, the operation of vehicles, aircraft, vessels, or dangerous machinery, and access to hazardous materials.

Natural and inviolable rights shall not be abridged on the basis of capacity alone.

Section B. Temporary Suspension of Capacity-Conditioned Rights

Capacity-conditioned rights may be temporarily suspended or restrained when, and only when, the requirements of the Capacity-Based Intervention Principle are satisfied.

Such suspension shall be strictly limited to the specific rights implicated by the demonstrated risk and shall not extend beyond the duration necessary to address the capacity impairment.

Section C. Procedural Requirements

Any temporary suspension of capacity-conditioned rights under this Article shall require:

a. Clear and convincing evidence of an active impairment of capacity directly creating an imminent risk of serious harm.
b. Due process protections, including notice and opportunity for review.
c. Narrow tailoring, restricting only those rights necessary to prevent the imminent harm.
d. Automatic expiration absent lawful renewal through review.
e. A defined restoration mechanism by which suspended rights are promptly reinstated upon restoration of capacity.

Section D. Prohibitions and Safeguards

No suspension authorized by this Article shall:

a. Be permanent absent conviction and lawful sentencing.
b. Be used as punishment, retaliation, or deterrence.
c. Be imposed for ideological, political, religious, or expressive reasons.
d. Be inferred to diminish the inherent dignity, civic status, or moral worth of the individual.

Section E. Cross-Reference and Controlling Doctrine

This addendum shall be interpreted in full conformity with, and subordinate to, the Capacity-Based Intervention Principle, which governs evidentiary standards, permissible triggers, safeguards, and prohibitions.

In the event of conflict, the Capacity-Based Intervention Principle shall control.

Section F. Locking Clause

This addendum clarifies interpretation only and does not reopen or amend the underlying text of Article XXVI.
Pursuant to Article XV, this Charter (including all enumerated rights, interpretive rules, and cross-references to Article 0 definitions) is hereby designated as LOCK-PROTECTED. No amendment, statute, emergency declaration, or judicial doctrine may dilute, suspend, or reinterpret these protections except by the highest procedural threshold and certification of non-diminishment by the Supreme Court and Constitutional Judicial Commission.

Article XXVI-A — Subsistence, Stewardship, and Animal Keeping

Charge:
The purpose of this Article is to secure the fundamental right of individuals and communities to provide food, sustenance, and livelihood through decentralized, small-scale, and non-industrial use of land, plants, and animals.

This Article establishes a constitutional presumption in favor of subsistence, self-sufficiency, and humane stewardship and against economic enclosure, forced dependency, or regulatory structures that privilege centralized or industrial producers over individuals.

All regulations affecting food production, animal keeping, and subsistence activity shall be construed narrowly and shall place the burden of proof on the government to justify any restriction.

⸻

1. Right to Keep Animals

All persons have the right to keep, raise, breed, care for, humanely slaughter, process, and utilize animals of any kind for companionship, work, husbandry, conservation, subsistence, livelihood, barter, or local exchange.

This right extends to small-scale commercial or direct-to-consumer activity conducted within the Republic, provided such activity is not industrial in scale and does not involve interstate or foreign commerce.

This right shall not be infringed unless the government demonstrates, by clear, specific, and individualized evidence, that the keeping of a particular animal or practice poses a substantial and non-speculative risk to human safety or the environment that cannot be mitigated by reasonable, narrowly tailored regulation.

⸻

2. Burden of Proof

The burden of proof rests entirely on the government.

The following shall be insufficient grounds for restriction:
	•	generalized fear or moral disapproval;
	•	aesthetic preference or neighborhood sentiment;
	•	breed, species, or class-based presumptions;
	•	speculative nuisance or unproven ecological models;
	•	commercial competition or protection of centralized markets.

Evidence must be individualized to the keeper’s actual practices and conditions, and shall not rely on species, breed, historical misuse, generalized models, or categorical assumptions.

⸻

3. Right to Raise Food

All persons have the right to grow, raise, harvest, process, and store food for personal, household, community, or local use, including plants, fungi, insects, fish, and animals, including within cities or densely populated areas.

This right shall not be restricted except where the government proves that a specific practice, as conducted, poses a demonstrable threat to public health or safety that cannot be addressed through narrowly tailored measures.

Zoning, density, or land-use rules shall not operate as de facto prohibitions.

⸻

4. Limits on Prohibition and Taxation

No prohibition, fee, license, tax, or inspection regime shall be imposed on subsistence-level animal keeping or food production in a manner that:
	•	functions as a practical ban;
	•	imposes costs disproportionate to risk;
	•	favors industrial or centralized producers;
	•	conditions the exercise of this right on discretionary approval.

Reasonable regulation may address sanitation, disease control, humane treatment, and genuine environmental protection, but shall not suppress self-sufficiency or decentralization. 
Routine or warrantless inspection of subsistence or small-scale animal keeping is prohibited absent probable cause or a specific, credible complaint.


⸻

5. Stewardship and Voluntary Commons

Stewardship under this Article includes voluntary individual or communal arrangements for grazing, conservation, breeding, or land enrichment, provided such arrangements respect individual rights and are entered without coercion.

Nothing in this Article authorizes compulsory collectivization or state control of animals or land under the guise of stewardship.

⸻

6. Construction, Supremacy, and Lock

This Article shall be construed broadly in favor of subsistence, self-sufficiency, humane stewardship, and personal autonomy, and narrowly against categorical bans, bureaucratic obstruction, or economic enclosure.

The rights secured herein are fundamental and non-derogable, and may not be suspended by emergency, zoning ordinance, administrative convenience, economic policy, or market preference.

⸻

Article XXVI-B — Charter of Animal Rights and Prohibition of Abuse

⸻

Charge
The purpose of this Article is to recognize animals as sentient beings entitled to protection from cruelty, exploitation, and unnecessary suffering, while preserving the lawful and humane use of animals for food, husbandry, work, conservation, and companionship.

This Article establishes enforceable constitutional duties of humane treatment, prohibits exploitative or abusive conduct, and provides standards for enforcement that are evidence-based, narrowly tailored, and consistent with the rights secured by Article XXVI-A.

⸻
1. Recognition of Animal Dignity

Animals are sentient beings capable of suffering and shall not be treated as mere instruments, disposable property, or objects of exploitation.

The Republic recognizes a duty of humane stewardship toward all animals under human control or influence.

⸻

2. Absolute Prohibition of Zoöphilic Acts

All zoöphilic activity—defined as any sexual act, contact, exploitation, or coercive interaction between a human and a non-human animal—is constitutionally prohibited.

Consent shall never be presumed, implied, or asserted on behalf of an animal.

Participation in such acts constitutes a Tier-3 crime.

⸻

3. Prohibition of Cruelty, Torture, and Neglect

No person shall intentionally or recklessly:
	•	torture, mutilate, or cruelly mistreat an animal;
	•	subject an animal to prolonged or unnecessary suffering;
	•	deprive an animal of food, water, shelter, or humane conditions necessary for life and health;
	•	abandon an animal under circumstances likely to cause suffering or death.

Acts of cruelty or severe neglect constitute Tier-3 crimes.

⸻

4. Duty of Care

Any person who keeps, controls, transports, breeds, sells, or otherwise assumes responsibility for an animal owes a non-delegable duty of care.

Cultural custom, claimed necessity, or convenience shall not excuse cruelty.

Economic hardship alone shall not constitute criminal neglect.

⸻

4-A. Reasonable Access and Economic Hardship

Failure to obtain veterinary care shall not constitute cruelty or neglect where:
	1.	the person acted in good faith;
	2.	the cost of care was reasonably beyond the person’s means; and
	3.	the person did not willfully ignore or exacerbate the animal’s suffering.

Where reasonable, accessible, and humane alternatives exist—including charitable care, community assistance, or surrender without penalty—failure to pursue such alternatives may constitute neglect.

The burden rests on the state to demonstrate willful or reckless disregard, not mere inability.

⸻

5. Aggravating Factors

Aggravating circumstances include:
	•	repeated or patterned abuse;
	•	abuse involving multiple animals;
	•	abuse committed for gratification, profit, coercion, or spectacle;
	•	abuse recorded, distributed, or encouraged;
	•	abuse committed by persons in positions of trust or authority.

Aggravated offenses warrant enhanced penalties and permanent disqualification from animal custody.

⸻

6. Enforcement, Standing, and Safeguards

The state has an affirmative duty to investigate credible allegations of animal abuse.

Standing to report shall be broad, but enforcement actions shall require credible evidence beyond anonymous or malicious reporting.

Inspections of subsistence or small-scale operations shall require probable cause or specific, credible complaint.

Knowingly false or weaponized reports constitute abuse of process.

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate whether regulatory schemes or enforcement actions are being used to suppress subsistence, decentralization, or food autonomy.

⸻

6-A. Public Duty of Humane Access

The state shall not impose criminal liability for animal neglect without ensuring the availability of reasonable, humane avenues to prevent suffering, including:
	•	low-cost or subsidized veterinary care;
	•	emergency treatment assistance;
	•	humane surrender or transfer without punitive consequence;
	•	public or charitable animal welfare services.

Failure to provide such avenues bars prosecution for neglect absent clear evidence of intentional cruelty.

⸻

7. Relationship to Lawful Use

Nothing in this Article prohibits:
	•	humane husbandry and slaughter;
	•	lawful hunting or fishing under humane standards;
	•	veterinary practice;
	•	pest control or culling necessary for herd health or ecological balance;
	•	euthanasia performed to prevent suffering.

Such practices shall not be used as pretext for abuse.

⸻

8. Construction and Lock

This Article shall be construed strictly against cruelty and exploitation, and liberally in favor of animal protection without infringing the rights secured by Article XXVI-A.

The prohibitions herein are structural and non-derogable, and may not be suspended by emergency, custom, or administrative convenience.

⸻
Article XXVI-C — Rights of the Child and Duties of the Republic

Charge:
The purpose of this Article is to establish enforceable constitutional protections for children against abuse, exploitation, neglect, and institutional misconduct, while preserving the fundamental rights and responsibilities of parents and families.

This Article creates a fiduciary duty in the Republic to act as guardian of last resort when, and only when, clear and convincing evidence demonstrates actual or imminent harm to a child.

No public or private institution, religious body, ideology, or economic interest may override the rights of the child or the evidentiary standards and procedural safeguards set forth herein.

This preserves your hard-line anti-abuse stance without creating a “the state owns children” loophole.
⸻

Section 1. Inherent Rights of the Child

Every child possesses inviolable rights to:

(a) bodily integrity and safety;
(b) freedom from abuse, exploitation, trafficking, and coercion;
(c) stable and continuous care;
(d) education sufficient to participate in civic life;
(e) protection from ideological, sexual, or psychological exploitation;
(f) truthful process when their welfare is at issue.

These rights exist independent of parental status, citizenship, culture, or belief.

⸻

Section 2. Supremacy of Child Protection

The welfare of the child shall prevail over:
	•	parental authority,
	•	institutional authority,
	•	religious authority,
	•	cultural practice,
	•	economic interest,
	•	political ideology.

No custom, belief system, or organizational loyalty may excuse harm.

⸻

Section 3. Evidentiary Standards

Removal, restriction, or override of parental or custodial authority shall occur only upon:
	•	clear and convincing evidence of actual or imminent harm,
	•	based on material facts, not narrative, ideology, or speculation.

Psychological theory, therapeutic ideology, or speculative risk models shall not substitute for evidence of actual or imminent harm.

All removals or restrictions under this Section shall be subject to review by the Constitutional Review Court upon petition by the child, a parent, or an advocate.

⸻

Section 4. Presumption of Parental Fitness

Parents are presumed fit to direct their child’s upbringing absent clear and convincing evidence of harm.

Disagreement with educational, religious, moral, or cultural choices shall not constitute abuse.

⸻

Section 5. Prohibition of Institutional Abuse

Abuse committed by persons or entities holding authority over children — including clergy, religious bodies, cults, schools, teachers, medical providers, foster systems, residential facilities, or government agencies — constitutes systemic abuse.

Systemic abuse is a Tier-Three constitutional offense, regardless of claimed benevolent intent.

⸻

Section 6. Religious and Cultural Cover Prohibited

No religious belief, cultural practice, spiritual authority, or doctrinal claim shall be used to:
	•	shield abuse,
	•	suppress reporting,
	•	coerce silence,
	•	or justify harm.

Religious freedom protects belief — not exploitation.

⸻

Section 7. Child Voice and Standing

A child has the right to be heard in any proceeding affecting their custody, safety, or welfare.

Independent advocates shall be provided where interests conflict.

No child shall be silenced for the comfort of adults or institutions.

⸻

Section 8. Foster Care and State Intervention Limits

State removal shall be temporary, goal-directed, and subject to strict timelines.

The objective shall be safe reunification or permanent placement, not prolonged custodial drift.

No child may be warehoused in institutional limbo.

⸻

Section 9. Prohibition on Profiteering

No public or private entity may receive funding, bonuses, or compensation based on the number of children removed, placed, retained, medicated, or institutionalized.

Child protection shall never be an economic industry.

⸻

Section 10. Adoption and Guardianship

Adoption and guardianship exist to secure permanent stability for children — not to supply markets.

All placements must prioritize continuity, safety, and long-term wellbeing.

⸻

Section 11. Liability of Officials

Any official, therapist, social worker, judge, or administrator who:
	•	fabricates evidence,
	•	suppresses exculpatory information,
	•	or acts from ideological or financial motive

commits constitutional misconduct and shall be personally liable.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate systemic abuse, fabricated evidence, ideological enforcement, or financial motive within child-protection systems and may petition the Constitutional Review Court for relief, sanctions, or institutional dissolution.
⸻

Section 12. Judicial Restraint

Courts shall resolve all ambiguities in favor of:
	•	family integrity,
	•	child stability,
	•	and factual evidence.

Narrative substitution, ideological balancing, or speculative harm doctrines are prohibited.

⸻

Section 13. No Statute of Limitations

Crimes of child abuse, exploitation, or trafficking shall have no statute of limitations.

⸻

Section 14. Construction

This Article shall be construed to protect children without transforming the state into a parent.

The Republic is a guardian of last resort — not a family.

⸻

Section 15. Lock Protection

Pursuant to Article XV, this Article is LOCK-PROTECTED.

No statute, regulation, judicial doctrine, treaty, or emergency power may:
	•	weaken child protections,
	•	expand institutional authority over families,
	•	restore religious or cultural immunity,
	•	dilute evidentiary standards,
	•	or create financial incentives for removal.

Any attempt to do so is void.

⸻

Article XXVII — Legislative Integrity, Transparency, and Due Process of Lawmaking

Charge

Law derives legitimacy not from secrecy, speed, or expertise alone, but from clarity, accountability, and consent. Where law is obscured, manipulated, or buried in process, self-government collapses into managerial rule.

This Article binds the Legislature to honest procedure, recorded responsibility, and public intelligibility, ensuring that law is made in daylight and that no power may govern through confusion, concealment, or procedural sabotage.

Legal Text

Section 1. Plain Language Requirement

All legislation shall be written, debated, and enacted in clear and intelligible language capable of being understood by an ordinary, educated citizen acting in good faith.

Each bill shall include, as enforceable components:

a. a plain-language summary of its purpose and effects;
b. a disclosure of all laws, sections, or authorities amended, repealed, or superseded;
c. a statement of anticipated material impacts.

Any duty, prohibition, penalty, or material exception that is not disclosed in the plain-language summary is void and unenforceable.
The summary shall not expand the operative text or cure defects in the operative text, but it shall control against the Republic where a person reasonably relied on it in good faith.
Section 2. Single-Issue and Scope Integrity

No bill shall address more than one primary subject.
No provision may be introduced, amended, or retained that is not germane to the stated subject of the bill.

Violation of this Section renders the offending provision void and severable.

No rider, poison pill, or unrelated amendment may be attached to any bill.

Section 3. Recorded Votes and Public Accountability

All votes of the Legislature, including committee votes, procedural votes, reconciliation votes, and amendments, shall be recorded, attributed, and made publicly accessible in real time.

No vote shall occur by voice, acclamation, proxy, or unrecorded consent.

Every legislator shall bear public responsibility for every vote cast or abstained from.

Section 4. Committee Authority and Limits

Committees exist to examine, refine, and advise—not to veto, bury, or extinguish legislation.

No bill may be permanently blocked, nullified, or killed in committee.

Committees may:
	•	hold hearings;
	•	solicit testimony;
	•	propose amendments;
	•	issue findings for or against passage.

Committees may not:
	•	prevent a bill from reaching the full chamber;
	•	impose binding outcomes absent a recorded chamber vote;
	•	introduce undisclosed or materially deceptive amendments.

Section 5. Reconciliation and Amendment Integrity

No bill shall be materially altered during reconciliation or final passage without renewed public disclosure and recorded debate.

No amendment may be introduced after final reading except by supermajority vote and public justification entered into the record.

Section 6. Expert Advisory Participation

Expertise shall inform legislation but shall not govern it.

Experts may:
	•	testify publicly;
	•	submit written analysis;
	•	debate impacts and risks.

Any citizen may submit expert testimony for the public record, with right to cross-examination if requested.

Experts shall not:
	•	vote on legislation;
	•	exercise veto authority;
	•	operate anonymously;
	•	participate without full conflict-of-interest disclosure.

All expert testimony and analysis shall be entered into the public record.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall audit expert participation, funding, conflicts of interest, and undisclosed influence and may certify violations of this Section to the Constitutional Review Court.

Section 7. Sector Representation and the Lobbying Court

Affected sectors may elect or designate representatives to present arguments, data, and objections before the Legislature through the Lobbying Court or equivalent public forum.

The Lobbying Court shall be composed of:
	•	elected or designated sector representatives; and
	•	Civic Citizens selected by civic lottery,

with staggered terms and confirmation by the Senate.

Representation shall be transparent, adversarial, recorded, and non-binding.

Civic Citizens serving in such forums shall be selected, governed, and limited in accordance with Article III, Section 13 (Civic Lottery Service and Deliberative Duty).

No private, undisclosed, coercive, or informal influence shall substitute for public deliberation.  The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall audit the Lobbying Court, sector representation, and civic lottery processes for coercion, undisclosed coordination, financial influence, or institutional capture and may petition the Constitutional Review Court for remedies.

Section 8. Judicial Review and Citizen Standing

Any legal resident or citizen shall have standing to challenge legislation enacted in violation of this Article.

The Constitutional Review Court shall review procedural compliance without deference and shall void provisions enacted through deception, concealment, or procedural abuse.
Upon petition by any citizen, the CJC, or any legislator, the Constitutional Review Court shall declare void and enjoin enforcement of any provision enacted in violation of this Article.

Section 9. Enforcement and Sanctions

Legislators who knowingly violate this Article may be:
	•	censured;
	•	removed from committee leadership;
	•	barred temporarily or permanently from committee service;
	•	subject to further penalties as provided by law.
