No immunity shall attach to procedural deception. 
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify violations of this Article and to petition the Constitutional Review Court for enforcement of sanctions.

Section 10. State-by-State Rollout for Non-Supermajority Legislation

Legislation that fails to achieve a supermajority (two-thirds) of both legislative houses shall, if passed by simple majority, be implemented on a state-by-state basis where feasible and consistent with the subject matter.

This requirement shall not apply only where immediate uniformity is constitutionally indispensable, the burden of proof resting on the Legislature.

Implementation shall proceed sequentially:

a. Phase One — Sponsoring States
Implementation shall begin exclusively in states whose representatives voted in favor of the legislation.
This phase shall last no fewer than two (2) years unless otherwise specified.

b. Phase Two — Neutral States
Upon documented evaluation of outcomes, implementation may expand to states selected by public lottery from among those whose delegations abstained or were internally divided.
States may decline participation without penalty.

c. Phase Three — Opposing States
States whose delegations voted against the legislation shall not be subject to implementation unless:
	•	prior phases demonstrate material success against stated metrics; and
	•	the Legislature affirms continuation by renewed recorded vote.

This rollout shall mitigate harm, permit empirical testing, and restrain the growth of unpopular or unproven laws.
No federal funding, emergency relief, or baseline services may be withheld as retaliation against lawful non-participation.
All rollout data, evaluations, and dissenting analyses shall be published in real time.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall audit all rollout data, metrics, and evaluations for manipulation or suppression and may refer violations to the Constitutional Review Court.

Section 11. Sunset and Reauthorization

All legislation, except constitutional amendments, shall expire after ten (10) years unless explicitly reauthorized by a new act of the Legislature.

Reauthorization requires the same procedural integrity as initial enactment, including:
	•	plain-language summary;
	•	single-subject compliance;
	•	recorded votes.

Laws not reauthorized shall sunset automatically, with orderly transition provisions where necessary.

Section 12. Measurable Outcomes and Repeal Review

Every bill shall state explicit, measurable outcomes and success criteria.

Upon expiration or five (5) years after enactment, whichever occurs first, the Legislature shall review whether the law achieved its stated objectives.

Failure to meet criteria shall trigger mandatory repeal consideration.
Any such law may be challenged by any citizen or lawful resident before the Constitutional Review Court, which shall have original and mandatory jurisdiction to determine validity under this Section.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall certify whether outcome metrics have been satisfied and may petition the Constitutional Review Court to compel repeal consideration where criteria are not met.

Section 13. General Laws and Prohibition of Favoritism

(a) Laws shall be general in application wherever reasonably possible.

(b) Special, local, targeted, or carve-out legislation conferring advantage, immunity, exemption, subsidy, or burden upon specific persons, entities, industries, or classes is prohibited absent compelling necessity demonstrated by clear and convincing evidence.

(c) Favoritism, selective exemptions, donor-based privileges, political carve-outs, or regulatory advantages designed to benefit or burden particular interests are inconsistent with republican legitimacy and void where general law suffices.

(d) No law shall favor or burden persons or entities on the basis of political affiliation, donor status, corporate form, or lobbying influence.

(e) Market-distorting subsidies, tax preferences, or regulatory exemptions that create rent-seeking or undermine equal competition are prohibited unless strictly necessary and narrowly tailored.

Section 14. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to favor transparency, intelligibility, accountability, and public trust over efficiency, expediency, or institutional convenience.

Law shall not govern by ambush.


Article XXVII-A — Plain-Language Law and Public Comprehension
Charge
A free People must be able to read the law and know what it requires, what it forbids, and what it allows.
This Republic shall not govern by obscurity, technical maze, or elite language.
Section 1. Right to Understand the Law
The People have the fundamental right to understand the laws that govern them.
The Republic shall not use unnecessary complexity, elite language, technical obscurity, or procedural barriers to evade public understanding, accountability, or the sovereignty of the People.
(cross-reference: Article I §1; Article 0 §4.2; Article XI)
Section 2. Plain-Language Requirement
All laws, regulations, executive orders, judicial rules, and other binding legal instruments shall be drafted in clear, plain language.
A reasonable person with an eighth-grade education shall be able, on first reading and without specialized assistance, to understand from the operative text:
	•	what the law requires;
	•	what the law forbids;
	•	who is subject to it; and
	•	the consequences of violation.

The drafting and intelligibility standards of Article XXVII-A apply to all binding instruments under this Section.

Section 3. Structure and Drafting Duties
Every person or body authorized to draft binding legal text has an affirmative fiduciary duty to:
	•	prefer common words over jargon;
	•	eliminate unnecessary legal or technical terms;
	•	define any required technical term clearly and immediately upon first use;
	•	employ short sections, descriptive headings, numbered or bulleted lists, and tables where appropriate;
	•	collocate each duty, prohibition, deadline, exception, and penalty with the rule that triggers it; and
	•	express every rule in direct, active voice that identifies the actor and the precise conduct required or forbidden (e.g., “A person shall…” or “No entity may…”).
Section 4. Limited Use of Complexity
Complexity may be used only when strictly necessary to achieve a legitimate legal purpose that cannot be accomplished through plain language.
Where complexity is used, the drafter shall:
	•	state the necessity in plain language within the text itself; and
	•	immediately provide a plain-language restatement that a reasonable person can follow in good faith. Necessity shall be proven by clear and convincing evidence if challenged under this Article.
Section 5. No Excuse of Expertise
No official, agency, court, or other public actor may defend, enforce, interpret, or uphold a binding legal rule on the ground that the public cannot reasonably understand it.
Expert assistance in drafting is permitted, but expertise shall never substitute for or override the People’s right to comprehend the law.
Section 6. Official Plain-Language Summary
Every enacted law or binding regulation shall include an official plain-language summary that accurately reflects its legal effect.
The summary shall, at minimum, identify:
	•	the persons and entities covered;
	•	the duties imposed and acts prohibited;
	•	the key deadlines, thresholds, exceptions, and conditions; and
	•	the civil, criminal, administrative, or other consequences of violation. The summary is not binding law and shall not replace the operative text, but it shall guide good-faith compliance and may be relied upon in defenses against penalties for non-willful violations.

The summary is not binding law and shall not expand the operative text or create new obligations, penalties, or exceptions.

A person may reasonably rely on the official summary as evidence of good-faith understanding, and such reliance shall bar penalties for non-willful violations unless the Republic proves actual notice and intentional evasion.

Section 7. Construction Against Unnecessary Complexity
In cases of genuine ambiguity arising from unnecessary complexity or failure to comply with this Article, courts shall construe the provision:
	•	against the drafter and the Republic; and
	•	in favor of individual liberty, public understanding, and the sovereignty of the People. (cross-reference: Article 0 §2 — In Dubio Pro Libertate; Article 0 §4.2)
When the Republic seeks to impose punishment, civil penalty, or other deprivation under a rule alleged to violate this Article, the Republic bears the burden to prove—by clear and convincing evidence—that the rule is sufficiently clear to permit reasonable understanding and fair notice.
Section 8. Remedy for Material Violation
A court may suspend enforcement of any law, regulation, or binding rule that materially violates this Article until the Republic rewrites it in conformity with plain-language requirements.
Material violation exists when unnecessary complexity or non-compliance substantially impairs a reasonable person’s ability to understand core obligations, prohibitions, or consequences.
Upon suspension, the court shall issue written findings identifying:
	•	the specific passages or features that violate this Article; and
	•	the minimum corrections required to cure the violation. Suspension shall not apply to emergency enforcement necessary to prevent imminent and specific harm to life or physical safety, but the Republic shall rewrite the rule at the earliest practicable time. The Constitutional Review Court shall have original jurisdiction over challenges alleging violations of this Article, subject to appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic. (cross-reference: Article 0-B §2 — Mandatory Triggering Rules)
Section 9. Lock Protection (Optional – if you want supermajority safeguards)
This Article is lock-protected under Article XV. Any amendment, repeal, suspension, or reinterpretation requires the supermajority procedures specified therein.
Article XXVIII — Federalization of Sovereign Authority

Charge

A Republic that centralizes all authority becomes brittle, unresponsive, and tyrannical.
A Republic that fragments without order dissolves into paralysis and factional decay.

Federalism exists to preserve liberty by dividing power, disciplining ambition, and allowing lawful diversity of governance within a unified constitutional order. Power shall be delegated upward only where necessary, retained locally wherever possible, and exercised always as a trust held for the People.

This Article affirms that sovereignty originates with the People, is exercised through layered institutions, and must never be consolidated beyond constitutional necessity.

Legal Text

Section 1. Source of Sovereign Authority

All sovereign authority derives from the People.

The People delegate defined powers to local, state, and federal institutions through this Constitution. No level of government possesses inherent authority beyond that which is expressly granted or necessarily implied.

Section 2. Reserved Powers

All powers not expressly delegated to the federal government by this Constitution are reserved to the States and to the People.

Federal authority shall be construed narrowly where ambiguity exists. Silence shall not be interpreted as permission for expansion.

Section 3. Enumerated Federal Responsibilities

The federal government shall exercise exclusive authority only over matters that are inherently national in scope, including:

a. national defense and the lawful use of force;
b. foreign relations, treaties, and diplomacy;
c. protection of constitutional rights against state infringement;
d. regulation of interstate and international commerce where uniformity is indispensable;
e. maintenance of national currency, weights, measures, and standards;
f. constitutional adjudication and enforcement.

No additional powers shall be implied absent clear constitutional authorization.

Section 4. Concurrent Authority, Preemption, and Regulatory Limits

Where federal and state authority overlap, federal law shall prevail only when:

a. the subject matter is inherently national in scope; and
b. uniformity is demonstrably necessary to preserve constitutional rights, national security, or the structural integrity of the Republic.

Preemption shall not be presumed. The burden of justification rests with the federal authority.

Federal regulations shall not preempt state law unless Congress has expressly authorized such preemption by statute, and only where the regulation independently satisfies the criteria of this Section.

No agency may create preemption by interpretation, guidance, rulemaking, or enforcement practice absent explicit legislative authorization.

Section 5. Experimental Governance and Policy Diversity

States may enact policies, programs, and regulatory frameworks that exceed federal minimum standards or diverge from federal practice, provided such measures do not violate constitutional rights.

The federal government shall not penalize, coerce, or financially sabotage states for lawful policy divergence.

Innovation through lawful experimentation is a protected feature of the Republic.

Section 6. Anti-Commandeering and Anti-Coercion

The federal government shall not compel states, state officials, or state resources to enforce federal law absent explicit constitutional authorization.

Coercive funding conditions, administrative mandates, or indirect enforcement mechanisms shall not substitute for lawful authority.

No federal funding program may be structured, conditioned, or administered in a manner that creates fiscal dependency or economic pressure so severe as to effectively coerce state compliance with federal policy.
The mechanisms, procedures, and remedies for State interposition and nullification are governed exclusively by Article XXVIII-A.
Voluntary participation shall be genuine, reversible, and free from punitive consequence.

Section 7. Transparency of Federal–State Interaction

All federal conditions attached to funding, regulatory cooperation, or program participation shall be disclosed in plain language and approved through recorded legislative votes.

No undisclosed obligation, informal pressure, or conditional dependency shall bind a state.

Section 8. State Participation in Federal Processes

States shall retain meaningful participation in federal governance through:

a. representation in the Legislature as defined elsewhere in this Constitution;
b. participation in advisory, review, or deliberative bodies where constitutionally authorized;
c. the right to challenge federal overreach through the courts.

States shall not be reduced to administrative subdivisions of the federal government.

Section 9. Civic Participation and Deliberative Federalism

The Republic may employ deliberative mechanisms incorporating Civic Citizens to review, advise upon, or evaluate federal policy affecting state sovereignty.

Any Civic Citizens so engaged shall be selected and governed in accordance with Article III, Section 13 (Civic Lottery Service and Deliberative Duty).

Such bodies shall be advisory only and shall not displace elected authority.

Section 10. Harmonization with Legislative Integrity

Federal legislation subject to phased or state-by-state rollout under Article XXVII shall respect state autonomy in implementation methods, enforcement priorities, and administrative design, unless uniformity is constitutionally indispensable.

States shall not be compelled to implement federal law beyond the scope authorized by this Constitution.

Section 11. Emergency Powers and Temporary Federal Coordination

In cases of declared national emergency, including invasion, insurrection, pandemic, or catastrophic natural disaster, the federal government may temporarily assume expanded coordinating authority solely for the purpose of harmonization and resource allocation, not displacement of lawful state authority.

Such authority requires:

a. a declared emergency;
b. approval by a two-thirds (⅔) vote of both legislative houses;
c. a narrowly tailored scope limited to the emergency;
d. automatic sunset not exceeding one (1) year unless renewed by identical vote.

Emergency authority shall not permanently preempt state law, suspend constitutional rights, or create enduring federal jurisdiction.
Nothing in this Article shall be construed to exempt any state law from the supremacy of this Constitution or the inviolable rights it secures.

Section 12. Program Sunset, Metrics, and Devolution

All federal programs materially affecting state governance shall expire after ten (10) years unless affirmatively reauthorized by Congress.

Each such program shall state explicit, measurable objectives.

Failure to meet stated objectives shall trigger automatic review and presumptive devolution of authority to the states.

Section 13. Exit Rights and Fiscal Rebalancing

States may opt out of federal programs not constitutionally mandatory, subject to reasonable notice.

Where opt-out occurs, the state shall receive a proportional tax rebate or fiscal credit reflecting its contribution, adjusted for shared national obligations.

No opt-out shall result in punitive withholding of unrelated funds or services.

Section 14. Prohibition of Secession and Unilateral Nullification

No state, subdivision, or authority may unilaterally secede from the Republic or nullify federal law duly enacted in compliance with this Constitution.
Redress of grievances shall occur through constitutional processes, including judicial review, legislative challenge, amendment, or lawful withdrawal of delegated authority by the People.  This prohibition does not bar lawful nullification under Article XXVIII-A or lawful secession or partition under Articles 28-B and 28-C.

Section 15. Standing, Sovereign Immunity, and Judicial Review

Any state, civic citizen, or lawful resident with standing may challenge violations of this Article.

Citizens may challenge federal actions that unlawfully undermine legitimate state law or state sovereignty.

No claim of sovereign immunity shall bar suit where the federal government or its agents exceed constitutional authority or encroach upon reserved state powers.

The Constitutional Review Court shall review such claims without deference and shall enjoin unconstitutional actions.

Section 16. Ceremonial Offices and Cultural Continuity
	•	State Cultural Autonomy
A State may, consistent with this Constitution, retain or establish ceremonial, cultural, or historical offices—including monarchs, traditional leaders, or symbolic heads of state—provided that such offices exercise no sovereign authority, no coercive power, and no lawmaking or veto authority under this Constitution.
	•	No Sovereignty or Legal Authority
Ceremonial offices shall confer no authority over legislation, adjudication, enforcement, taxation, defense, or administration, and shall not supersede or dilute the supremacy of constitutional governance.
	•	No Citizenship by Title or Office
Holding a ceremonial or hereditary office shall not confer civic citizenship, political rights, voting privileges, office-holding eligibility, or exemption from any civic duty.
Any individual occupying such an office shall be subject to the same requirements for citizenship, service, taxation, and accountability as any other person.
	•	Equal Civic Obligation
Individuals holding ceremonial offices shall, if seeking civic citizenship, satisfy the same conditions of service, contribution, and allegiance required of all applicants, without exception or preferential treatment.
	•	Security Without Privilege
A State may provide reasonable protection to ceremonial officeholders against credible threats or opportunistic harm, provided such protection does not create immunity from law, special legal status, or exemption from investigation, prosecution, or judgment.
	•	Selection and Succession
The method of designation, succession, or removal of ceremonial offices is a matter of state cultural law and shall have no legal effect beyond symbolic representation.
Such methods shall not bind other States, the Republic, or future governments.
	•	Judicial Non-Interference
No court shall construe the presence of ceremonial or cultural offices as incompatible with republican governance, provided that all sovereign authority remains derived from and constrained by this Constitution.

Section 17. Prohibition of Unfunded Mandates

(a) No level of government may impose duties, mandates, regulatory requirements, or administrative obligations upon subordinate governments, private entities, or individuals without providing full funding sufficient to cover the costs of compliance.

(b) Unfunded mandates are presumptively void. The burden rests upon the imposing authority to demonstrate full funding or de minimis cost.

(c) Conditional grants, coercive funding mechanisms, or threats of withdrawal of unrelated funds shall not be used to compel compliance with mandates prohibited by this Section.

(d) This prohibition shall be construed broadly to prevent indirect coercion and evasion of sovereign authority.

Section 18. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to preserve liberty through division of power, prevent consolidation of authority, and favor local governance where national necessity is not proven.

Efficiency, convenience, and administrative uniformity shall not override constitutional structure.

Article Article XXVIII-A — State Nullification and Federalism Safeguards

Section 1 — Right of State Interposition

(a) Each State reserves the sovereign right to interpose and nullify any federal or national law, regulation, mandate, or executive action that exceeds the enumerated powers expressly delegated to the federal government by this Constitution, or that is not strictly necessary and proper for their execution.

(b) State interposition is a constitutional safeguard of federalism and shall operate as a lawful defense against overreach, consolidation, or abuse of centralized authority.

⸻

Section 2 — Criteria for Nullification

Nullification may be invoked where a federal action:

(a) burdens State sovereignty, individual liberties, or local economies without clear constitutional authorization;

(b) imposes speculative, novel, or disproportionate requirements lacking demonstrated, non-speculative harm, including but not limited to mandates premised upon conjectural environmental, economic, or public-welfare claims;

(c) results from interstate imbalance, including policies driven primarily by populous or economically dominant States that coerce, externalize costs upon, or structurally disadvantage less-populous States through federal mechanisms.

⸻

Section 3 — Process and Thresholds

(a) Nullification may be initiated by:
	1.	a majority vote of the State legislature; or
	2.	a citizen petition bearing verified digital signatures from not less than ten percent (10%) of registered voters of the State, utilizing secure, auditable systems sufficient to prevent fraud and ensure integrity.

(b) Upon initiation, nullification shall require approval by a sixty percent (60%) supermajority in a statewide popular referendum, conducted within one hundred eighty (180) days of initiation.

(c) Upon approval, the challenged federal action shall be null and unenforceable within the State pending judicial resolution.

(d) The federal government bears the burden to prove, by clear and convincing evidence in the Constitutional Review Court, that the challenged action is constitutionally required, narrowly tailored, and not pretextual. Generalized invocations of interstate commerce, environmental necessity, or public welfare shall not suffice absent individualized, non-speculative harm.

(e) Nullifications shall sunset after ten (10) years unless renewed through the same process. Upon renewal, the nullification shall become permanent within that State and shall not require a constitutional amendment.

⸻

Section 4 — Anti-Coercion and Anti-Bullying Protections

(a) No federal funding, grant, subsidy, incentive, or assistance shall be conditioned upon compliance with a nullified action, nor withheld or reduced as retaliation for lawful nullification.

(b) States may form compacts for mutual defense against federal overreach, provided such compacts respect equal State sovereignty and do not infringe powers expressly reserved to the federal government, including treaty-making and national defense.

(c) Federal actions that disproportionately benefit or burden States based upon population size, economic dominance, or political influence are presumptively invalid unless justified by demonstrable, direct, cross-border necessity.

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate and certify whether federal agencies, courts, or political actors are engaging in financial coercion, regulatory retaliation, or institutional pressure to defeat lawful nullification, and may petition the Constitutional Review Court for injunctive or structural relief.

⸻

Section 5 — Limits and Construction

(a) Nullification shall not apply to federal powers expressly enumerated in this Constitution where genuine, direct, and material cross-border effects are proven.

(b) No State may nullify the same federal action more than once within a ten-year period absent materially new evidence of harm.

(c) This Article shall be construed broadly in favor of State sovereignty and federalism, narrowly against centralization, and to prevent the federal government from becoming an instrument of interstate domination, administrative coercion, or arbitrary mandate.

(d) Knowing violations of this Article by federal officials constitute breaches of public trust and are impeachable offenses.Article XXVIII-B — Lawful Secession and Peaceful Territorial Reconstitution

Charge

The Republic is founded on consent, not force.
No political union remains legitimate when maintained only by coercion.

At the same time, no community may shatter the Republic by impulse, faction, or fraud.

This Article provides the sole lawful path by which a State or defined territory may withdraw from the Republic — not as rebellion, but as an act of peaceful self-determination, conducted with restraint, protection of minorities, and preservation of human dignity.

⸻

Section 1. Prohibition on Unilateral Secession

No State, territory, or subdivision may unilaterally secede from the Republic.

No declaration, referendum, legislative act, or executive order shall have legal force unless conducted strictly in accordance with this Article.

Any attempt to secede outside this framework constitutes insurrection and is void.

⸻

Section 2. Threshold for Secession Petition

A State may initiate the secession process only upon:

(a) a petition approved by at least sixty percent (60%) of registered voters in a statewide referendum;
(b) certification that the referendum was conducted under free, fair, and transparent conditions;
(c) judicial confirmation that no coercion, suppression, or foreign interference tainted the vote.

The question submitted shall explicitly state that secession entails full loss of representation, federal protection, and constitutional entitlements.

⸻

Section 3. Cooling-Off and Reconfirmation Period

Upon initial approval, a mandatory cooling-off period of five (5) years shall begin.

During this period:
	•	the State shall remain fully subject to the Constitution,
	•	negotiations may occur,
	•	grievances shall be formally documented and addressed.

At the conclusion of this period, a second referendum shall be held requiring the same 60% threshold.

Failure to reconfirm terminates the secession process.

⸻

Section 4. Federal Negotiation Duty

Upon successful reconfirmation, the Federal Government shall enter good-faith negotiations to determine:
	•	division of public property and debt;
	•	citizenship status of residents;
	•	pensions, benefits, and military obligations;
	•	borders and infrastructure;
	•	continuation or termination of treaties and compacts.

Negotiations shall prioritize:
	•	continuity of daily life,
	•	economic stability,
	•	and protection of human rights.

⸻

Section 5. Protection of Minorities and Dissenters

Any region, county, or contiguous population within the seceding State that votes against secession by a 60% supermajority shall have the right to:
	•	remain in the Republic;
	•	form a new State;
	•	or join an adjacent State.

No person shall be forced into secession against their will.

Borders shall be drawn to minimize displacement and protect community integrity.

⸻

Section 6. Individual Citizenship Choice

Every resident of the seceding territory shall retain the right to:
	•	remain a citizen of the Republic,
	•	acquire citizenship of the new polity,
	•	or hold dual status if agreed by treaty.

No person shall become stateless.

No person shall be punished for their choice.

⸻

Section 7. Continuity of Rights

All persons within the seceding territory shall retain:
	•	their property rights,
	•	contracts,
	•	pensions,
	•	and accrued legal claims.

No collective forfeiture or confiscation is permitted.

⸻

Section 8. Prohibition on Armed Secession

No armed force, militia, or security apparatus may:
	•	compel participation,
	•	suppress dissent,
	•	or enforce secession.

Any use of force to effect or resist lawful secession outside constitutional authority constitutes a Tier-Three offense.

⸻

Section 9. International Status

A seceding State shall not be recognized as independent until this Article is fully satisfied and a final treaty of separation is ratified by both governments.

Foreign recognition prior to lawful completion is void.

⸻

Section 10. Relationship to Nullification and Partition

Secession under this Article is distinct from:
	•	lawful nullification under Article XXVIII-A;
	•	internal partition under Article XXVIII-C.

Nullification addresses unconstitutional acts.
Partition addresses internal State breakdown.
Secession addresses irreconcilable sovereign divergence.

No process may be used to bypass another.

⸻

Section 11. Judicial Review

All stages of the secession process shall be subject to continuous judicial review by the Constitutional Review Court, with appellate review by the Supreme Court of the Republic.

Such review shall ensure, at all times, that:

(a) the consent of the affected population is free, informed, and uncoerced;
(b) the rights and protections of political, ethnic, religious, and regional minorities are preserved; and
(c) all actions taken remain in full compliance with this Constitution.

⸻

Section 12. Lock Protection

This Article is LOCK-PROTECTED pursuant to Article XV.

No emergency, statute, treaty, or judicial doctrine may:
	•	weaken its thresholds,
	•	shorten its timelines,
	•	remove minority exit rights,
	•	or authorize unilateral separation.

The Republic shall not be dissolved by haste, nor preserved by force.

⸻

Article X-C — Lawful Replication of Historic Artifacts and Works
Charge
This Article enshrines the right of the People to reproduce, revive, and continue the use of historic artifacts and works for which lawful exclusivity has expired and for which original manufacturers or rights holders no longer provide meaningful access.  Its intent is to: 1. preserve material culture, technical capability, and craftsmanship; 2. prevent artificial scarcity created through abandonment or neglect; 3. enable lawful replication of goods for which public demand exists but original supply does not; 4. protect honest makers and consumers from coercive or bad-faith intellectual property enforcement; 5. counteract “vaulting,” suppression, or deliberate non-distribution of expired works through destruction, refusal to supply, or intimidation, ensuring that expiration restores actual use rather than a de facto perpetual monopoly.  This Article shall be construed liberally in favor of continuity, revival, and honest reuse, and narrowly against monopoly by neglect.
Section 1. Entry into the Functional Commons
Upon expiration of lawful design, patent, copyright, recipe, or equivalent exclusivity, historic artifacts and works enter the functional commons.  Any person or entity may manufacture, prepare, or produce faithful reproductions of such works, including but not limited to: • vehicles and machines; • computers, electronics, and embedded systems; • software, video games, and digital media; • tools, household goods, footwear, and apparel; • food items, recipes, and preparation methods.  Reproductions may include adaptations strictly necessary for compatibility with contemporary technology, such as software porting or component substitution, provided the core form, function, and behavior remain faithful.
Section 2. Scope of Faithful Reproduction
Lawful reproductions may replicate form, function, materials, dimensions, composition, operation, taste, and preparation, without alteration, where fidelity is the objective.  Mere copies, scans, photographs, recordings, format shifts, or minor modifications of works in the functional commons shall not qualify as original creations eligible for new exclusivity protections absent substantial, original transformation.
Section 3. Prohibited Representations
Reproductions shall not: • use protected trademarks, logos, or trade names as branding; • falsely claim to be original manufacture; • misrepresent endorsement, affiliation, or authorization.  Nothing in this Article permits consumer deception.
Section 4. Required Disclosures
Reproductions must clearly disclose: • that they are reproductions, revivals, or faithful replicas; • the original creator, brand, or manufacturer that inspired the work; • the historical period, year, or model referenced.  Truthful statements of inspiration, lineage, or historical origin shall not be deemed infringement.
Section 5. Trademark and Trade Dress Limits
Trademark law governs identity and branding, not use or replication.  Accordingly: 1. active trademarks remain protected against consumer confusion; 2. trade dress protection shall not prohibit faithful replication of functional form, geometry, materials, recipes, or operation where no deception is intended; 3. expired or abandoned trademarks may not be revived solely to suppress lawful replication; 4. intimidation, litigation, or contractual coercion intended to block lawful replication absent deception is prohibited.
Section 6. Regulatory Parity
Safety, health, environmental, and operational regulations apply equally to original works and lawful reproductions.  No heightened burden may be imposed solely because a work is a replica.
Section 7. Anti-Extinction and Anti-Suppression Rule
No entity may prohibit or suppress lawful replication solely by: • discontinuing production; • withholding tooling, formulas, code, or documentation no longer under protection; • refusing to license expired rights; • asserting new exclusivity through trivial derivatives or re-registrations.  Upon verifiable abandonment—defined as non-supply for five (5) years without reasonable justification—entities shall make available, upon request and at reasonable cost, any non-proprietary know-how necessary for faithful replication.  Abandonment shall not function as perpetual control.
Section 8. Irrevocability of Commons Entry
Entry into the functional commons is permanent and irrevocable. No retroactive claim, penalty, or reclassification shall attach to prior or ongoing lawful use.
Section 9. Construction
This Article shall be construed: • in favor of honest revival and public access; • against monopoly by neglect, intimidation, or vaulting; • in harmony with the continuity and commons doctrines of Article X.  Where doubt exists, interpretation shall resolve for use, not erasure.
Section 10. Lock Scope
The principles of: • functional commons entry, • lawful replication, • anti-extinction, • anti-vaulting, • truthful attribution, and • irrevocability of public-domain restoration  are structural and non-derogable.  Implementation mechanisms remain subject to law consistent with this Constitution.
Article XXIX — Infrastructure, Mobility, and the Right to Travel

Charge

A free people must be able to move, build, repair, explore, and depart without asking permission of bureaucracy or surrendering dignity to control systems.

When movement is restricted through cost, complexity, surveillance, artificial scarcity, or revenue-driven enforcement, liberty becomes theoretical rather than lived. Efficient cities and shared infrastructure are compatible with freedom; coerced immobility and administrative enclosure are not.

This Article affirms mobility as a civil liberty, not a managed privilege, and binds transportation and infrastructure policy to liberty, safety, competence, and accountability.

Section 1. Right to Travel and Freedom of Movement

a. Free Internal Movement
Every citizen and every person lawfully within the Republic possesses the right to travel freely within its territory without internal passports, routine checkpoints, or compulsory identification absent reasonable, articulable suspicion of specific unlawful conduct, supported by objective facts and subject to immediate judicial review upon challenge.

b. No Enclosure by Design
No system of urban design, zoning, transportation planning, or infrastructure policy shall operate as a de facto enclosure, confinement, or mobility rationing regime.

c. Prohibition of Movement Conditioning
The exercise of the right to travel shall not be conditioned upon social behavior, economic status, health compliance, energy quotas, congestion pricing schemes, or algorithmic scoring.

Section 2. Right to Own, Operate, and Repair Personal Conveyances

a. Core Mobility Rights
The right to travel includes the right to own, operate, modify, maintain, and repair personal vehicles and conveyances.

b. Mechanical Simplicity and Durability
The Republic shall not prohibit or disfavor mechanically simple, durable, repairable, or long-lived vehicle designs absent a compelling and demonstrable safety necessity.

c. Right to Repair (Affirmative Duty)
Manufacturers and distributors shall provide parts, tools, diagnostics, firmware access where applicable, and repair documentation at reasonable cost, without proprietary, contractual, or technological restrictions designed to prevent independent repair.

d. Warranty Fairness Rule
Manufacturers are not required to warrant damage or failure caused by modifications that exceed design limits or materially degrade safety, reliability, or drivetrain integrity.
Manufacturers may not void or deny warranty coverage solely because a vehicle was repaired, maintained, or serviced by an independent party or by the owner using reasonable methods.

e. Comparative Access Standard
Citizens shall retain access to affordable, reliable, and mechanically intelligible vehicles comparable to those lawfully available to ordinary persons in other advanced nations.

Section 3. Prohibition of Artificial Cost Inflation and Regulatory Capture

a. No Price Engineering by Regulation
No government entity may use safety, environmental, efficiency, or administrative authority as a pretext to:
	•	artificially inflate vehicle or conveyance cost;
	•	mandate luxury, proprietary, or surveillance-dependent technologies where simpler alternatives suffice;
	•	force premature obsolescence; or
	•	concentrate mobility access among elites, corporations, or favored partners.

b. Burden of Justification
All mobility-related regulation must satisfy necessity, proportionality, and a demonstrable public safety benefit supported by evidence.

c. Anti-Capture Safeguard
Regulations that substantially increase cost or complexity shall be subject to periodic review for regulatory capture and shall sunset automatically absent affirmative renewal.

Section 4. Personal Flight and Advanced Conveyance

a. Right to Personal Flight
The right to travel includes the right to develop, own, and operate personal aircraft, aerial vehicles, and emergent conveyances not yet fully contemplated.

b. Safety-Based Limitations Only
Limitations on personal flight or advanced conveyance shall be performance-based and risk-proportionate. Safety standards shall not be used to prohibit entire classes of conveyance or innovation absent a clear showing of unavoidable and substantial danger.

c. No Protection of Legacy Systems
The Republic shall not prohibit personal flight or advanced conveyance to preserve legacy infrastructure, incumbent industries, or bureaucratic convenience.
d. Administrative Burden Clause
No licensing, certification, insurance, or safety requirement shall be imposed under this Section where the cumulative administrative burden, cost, delay, or procedural complexity has the effect of prohibiting lawful use by an ordinarily competent individual.

In assessing proportionality, courts shall compare such requirements to those imposed on functionally analogous activities already permitted within the Republic.

Section 5. Infrastructure, Access, and Competence

a. Essential Mobility Infrastructure
Essential mobility infrastructure includes roads, bridges, rail corridors, ports, airspace coordination systems, and facilities necessary to ensure safe, nondiscriminatory travel throughout the Republic, including rural and non-metropolitan regions.

b. Public or Delegated Operation
Infrastructure may be publicly operated or lawfully delegated to private entities, provided that access remains nondiscriminatory, fees are transparent and proportionate, monopolies are time-limited, and long-term capture is prohibited.

c. Competence and Value Requirement
Transportation and infrastructure systems shall not function as de facto employment or patronage programs. Compensation, staffing, and contracting shall reflect market value, demonstrated competence, and performance.

d. Automation and Innovation Permitted
Automation, robotics, and advanced systems may be employed to improve safety, efficiency, and maintenance quality and shall not be prohibited to preserve inefficient labor structures.

e. Duty of Maintenance
Persistent neglect of essential mobility infrastructure constitutes a justiciable violation of this Article.
f. Failure Metrics Clause
Persistent neglect shall be evidenced by measurable service degradation, safety failures, maintenance backlogs, or repeated noncompliance with published performance standards over a sustained period.

Demonstrated chronic failure shall constitute standing for judicial intervention regardless of whether catastrophic harm has yet occurred.
g. Foreign Ownership Prohibition
Critical mobility infrastructure shall not be owned or controlled by foreign governments, entities, or nationals absent an explicit national security waiver enacted by the legislature.

Section 6. Prohibition of Confinement Schemes

a. No De Facto Mobility Rationing
The Republic shall not implement policies whose practical effect is to confine citizens to prescribed geographic zones or penalize travel beyond arbitrary boundaries.

b. Voluntary Density Only
Urban density and walkability may be encouraged but shall remain voluntary and shall not operate through coercion, penalties, or withdrawal of services.

Section 7. No Surveillance-by-Mobility

a. Mobility Is Not a Control Channel
Transportation systems shall not be used as instruments of mass surveillance, behavioral control, or social scoring.

b. Strict Data Limits
Any mobility-related data collection must be minimal, purpose-limited, non-retentive, and subject to judicial oversight.

c. Void Illicit Data Use (Tier 3 Exception)
Except in cases involving Tier 3 heinous crimes as defined by this Constitution, data obtained in violation of this Section is inadmissible and without legal effect.
In Tier 3 cases, all truthful, probative information may be considered, provided that unlawful conduct by government actors remains subject to civil and criminal liability.

d. Tier 3 Vehicle Enforcement Authority
Upon issuance of a judicial warrant supported by reasonable, articulable suspicion that a specific vehicle has been used, is being used, or is imminently intended to be used in the commission of a Tier 3 crime, including:
	•	heinous crimes, including murder, rape, child sexual exploitation, trafficking, or acts of extreme violence;
	•	repeat violent offenders demonstrating incorrigibility or a pattern of predatory conduct; or
	•	demonstrably unrepentant, predatory, or irreversibly dangerous individuals, including those reasonably identified as engaged in ongoing human trafficking, child exploitation networks, or professional people-smuggling operations;

law enforcement may temporarily designate such vehicle as an instrument of enforcement for the limited purpose of apprehension, interdiction, or prevention of harm.

Such authority shall be narrowly tailored to the identified vehicle, individual, and offense, and may include disabling, tracking, remote intervention, or seizure where necessary to protect life, prevent escape, or disrupt ongoing exploitation of vulnerable persons.

Execution shall be decisive and proportionate, provided that:

(a) the warrant specifies the vehicle, scope, and duration;
(b) authority expires immediately upon resolution or apprehension;
(c) collateral use against uninvolved persons or vehicles is prohibited; and
(d) post-action judicial review is mandatory within forty-eight (48) hours.

Nothing in this Section authorizes generalized vehicle surveillance, standing vehicle control powers, or routine enforcement use.
e. Data Retention and Secondary Use Ban
Any mobility-related data collected under a lawful authorization shall be automatically deleted upon fulfillment of the specific, articulated purpose for which it was obtained, absent renewed judicial authorization.

Such data shall not be repurposed, aggregated, sold, transferred, or combined with other datasets for secondary analysis, profiling, or intelligence use.


Section 8. Remedies and Enforcement

a. Standing
Any person denied mobility rights, subjected to unlawful restriction, excessive citation, surveillance-by-mobility, or artificial cost inflation has standing.

b. Remedies
Remedies include injunctive relief, declaratory judgment, damages (including punitive damages where malice is shown), and reasonable attorney fees.

c. No Immunity
No sovereign, qualified, or administrative immunity shall shield violations of this Article.

Section 9. Prohibition of Revenue-Driven Mobility Enforcement

a. No Ticket Traps
Traffic controls and signage shall be reasonably visible, consistently applied, and designed to promote safety rather than revenue. Concealed or manipulative enforcement schemes are prohibited.

b. No Quotas or Revenue Targets
No jurisdiction may impose citation quotas, revenue targets, or budgetary dependence on mobility-related fines or fees.
c. Indirect Incentive Prohibition
No agency, officer, contractor, or jurisdiction shall receive funding, bonuses, budget increases, or performance evaluations tied directly or indirectly to citation volume, fee generation, asset forfeiture, or enforcement yield.

d. Due Process and Contestability
All citations shall include a clear mechanism for contest. Persons residing outside the issuing jurisdiction shall be permitted remote appearance using secure technology.

e. Purpose Limitation
Mobility enforcement shall exist solely to improve safety and encourage responsible operation.

Section 10. Transition and Regulatory Sunset

All regulations, licensing regimes, and administrative practices inconsistent with this Article shall sunset within five (5) years of ratification unless reenacted by legislative supermajority with written justification demonstrating necessity and proportionality.
Immediate Conflict Rule
Any newly enacted regulation, policy, or administrative action that conflicts with this Article shall be void ab initio and may not rely on the transition period for validity.

Section 11. Right to Non-Motorized and Low-Regulation Mobility

The right to travel includes the right to move by foot, bicycle, animal, human-powered craft, or minimally complex conveyance without unnecessary licensing, tracking, or regulatory burden. Public space shall not be designed or regulated to exclude or penalize non-motorized travel.

Section 12. Protection Against Energy or Fuel Rationing

No law, regulation, or fee structure shall ration, quota, or discriminatorily price fuel, energy, or propulsion for personal mobility absent a declared emergency certified by the Constitutional Review Court and limited to the duration of the emergency.

Section 13. Private Infrastructure and Public Access

Private ownership or operation of essential mobility corridors (highways, ports, airports, rail) shall not create de facto enclosure or discriminatory access. Reasonable public easement or access rights may be required, with just compensation.

Section 14. Right to Depart the Republic

The right to travel includes the right to depart the Republic absent conviction for a grave offense or active judicial process. No exit controls, exit taxes, or capital controls shall be imposed except as necessary to prevent flight from lawful criminal prosecution.

Section 15. Construction

This Article shall be construed to favor freedom over convenience, access over control, competence over patronage, innovation over stagnation, and liberty over administrative tidiness.
Anti-Fragmentation Rule
No jurisdiction within the Republic may impose mobility, licensing, or access requirements that functionally reintroduce internal borders, checkpoints, or movement barriers under another name.
Where doubt exists as to whether a regulation burdens the right to travel or lawful mobility, such doubt shall be resolved in favor of the individual and against the enforcing authority.

Article III — Civic Participation and Weighted Sovereignty

Charge

Political sovereignty is a privilege scaled by demonstrated responsibility to the Republic.
All lawful residents retain equal civil rights and human dignity.
Civic Standing (1× base plus earned weights) may be recognized only among Civic Citizens. No Civic Standing exists for non-civic residents, who possess no franchise unless and until Civic Citizenship is earned under this Article.
This Article defines the conditions under which political authority, suffrage, and eligibility for public office are granted within the Republic. It establishes Civic Citizenship as a constitutional office of trust, earned through lawful service, competence, and allegiance to the constitutional order, and it distinguishes political authority from personhood, dignity, and civil rights.
The purpose is to ensure that those who govern have demonstrated sacrifice, responsibility, and accountability to the People, while guaranteeing equal civil rights and human dignity to all lawful residents.
(Cross-references: Article I §1; Article II §0; Article 0-A; Article 0-B; Article XV; Article III-A)

Section 1. Definitions, Age of Majority, and Service Eligibility

(a) Age of Adulthood.
The age of adulthood shall be twenty-one (21).

(b) Minimum Age to Begin Service.
No qualifying service toward Civic Citizenship or Civic Standing may begin before eighteen (18) years of age.

(c) Practical Minimum Age for Completion.
Because qualifying service may not begin before eighteen (18), and the shortest qualifying term is two (2) years, completion before twenty-one (21) shall be rare or impracticable except where specifically authorized by law without undermining the purpose of this Article.

(d) Classes of Persons.
This Constitution recognizes: lawful residents, non-civic residents, civic citizens, and unlawful entrants.
Political authority attaches only to civic citizens except as expressly authorized by this Constitution.

(e) Exclusivity of Status.
No person shall be assigned to any legal or political status other than those listed in subsection (d).
No agency, court, or statute may create intermediate, hybrid, provisional, or alternative classes of political personhood.

(f) Protection of Minors.
No labor, training, volunteer work, apprenticeship, military program, or institutional participation undertaken before eighteen (18) years of age may be credited toward Civic Citizenship, Civic Standing, political eligibility, or officeholding thresholds.

(g) Civic Standing / Civic Multiplier.
“Civic Standing” (also referred to in prior drafts as a “Civic Multiplier”) means a verified civic weight used only for political authority as defined in this Article.
Civic Standing does not determine personhood, dignity, civil rights, or human worth.

(h) Political Authority Reserved.
No voting right, office-holding right, initiative power, or binding political authority may be exercised by any person who is not a Civic Citizen, unless expressly authorized by this Constitution.
Administrative, consultative, or advisory participation shall not be construed as political power.

Section 2. Civil Rights for All Lawful Residents

All persons lawfully residing within the Republic shall enjoy inalienable rights as expressed in this Constitution, regardless of civic status, including:
freedom of speech, thought, conscience, religion, and assembly;
protection from arbitrary search, seizure, or deprivation of life, liberty, or property without due process;
the right to fair trial, legal representation, and equal protection under law;
freedom of movement, occupation, contract, and private property ownership; and
access to emergency medical care, basic education for minors, and public safety services.

These rights shall not be abridged except where necessary to protect the rights of others, or as otherwise authorized under strict due process.

Civic Standing constitutes a political trust and office of governance, not a classification of personhood, civil worth, or human dignity.

(a) Standard of Restriction.
No right listed in this Section may be limited or burdened except by:
(1) individualized judicial order;
(2) based on clear and convincing evidence;
(3) of imminent and specific harm; and
(4) using the least restrictive means.
Generalized public safety, administrative convenience, or group status shall not suffice.

(b) Prohibition on Collective or Status-Based Deprivation.
No lawful resident shall lose or have diminished civil rights on the basis of citizenship status, immigration category, economic condition, race, belief, or political view.
Only individualized criminal conviction or judicial incapacity may justify restriction.

(c) Determination of Dangerousness.
Any finding of persistent criminality or irredeemable danger shall comply fully with Article II, including due process, evidence standards, right to counsel, and periodic review.

Section 3. Non-Civic Residents and Base Participation

(a) Non-Civic Status.
Non-civic residents retain all civil rights but possess no Civic Standing, no franchise, and no eligibility for public office.

(b) Participation in Civil Society.
Non-civic residents may participate in civil society, lawful associations, public discourse, petitioning, and other protected civic action, and may pursue lawful pathways toward Civic Citizenship as defined herein.

(c) No Exercise of Binding Governmental Power.
No non-civic resident may exercise or control binding governmental power, including through regulatory bodies, public–private partnerships, advisory boards with decision authority, state-funded NGOs, or contractual delegation of governmental functions.

(d) Access to Pathways.
No lawful non-civic resident shall be barred, delayed, or obstructed from pursuing lawful pathways toward Civic Citizenship except by individualized judicial finding of disqualification consistent with due process.
Section 4. Status at Birth and Prevention of Statelessness

(a) Personhood and Protection.
A person born within the jurisdiction of the Republic shall possess legal personhood and full protection of law.

(b) No Civic Citizenship by Birth.
No person shall acquire Civic Citizenship by birth, descent, or place of birth alone. Political authority must be earned pursuant to this Article.

(c) Childhood Presence and Access to Pathways.
Any person lawfully present in the Republic from childhood shall have full access to the lawful pathways toward Civic Citizenship upon reaching adulthood. No person raised within the Republic may be permanently barred from earning Civic Citizenship absent disqualifying conduct under this Constitution.

(d) No Statelessness.
No child shall be rendered stateless by operation of law.
No classification of birth status shall affect legal personhood, human dignity, civil rights, or equal protection of the laws.
Section 5. Promotion to Civic Citizen by Civic Competence Exam

(a) Gateway to the Franchise.
The Civic Competence Exam is the gateway to the franchise.

Every lawful resident who satisfies the lawful prerequisites for Civic Citizenship established by this Article, and who passes the Civic Competence Exam, shall be recognized as a Civic Citizen for purposes of voting and shall receive a base 1× Civic Standing.

(b) Exam Effects Limited.
Passage of the exam shall not, by itself, grant eligibility for public office unless this Article expressly provides otherwise.

(c) Administration, Security, and Anti-Capture.
Administration, security, transparency, appeals, and anti-capture safeguards for the exam are are governed by Article III-A and Article 0-B, and shall be construed to prevent factional manipulation, credential laundering, or administrative expansion of the electorate.
(d) Minimum Residency Prerequisite.
An applicant must have maintained continuous lawful residency within the Republic for no less than five (5) years immediately preceding application.
Law may provide narrowly tailored modifications only where required by military necessity or for persons born within the Republic to Civic Citizen parents, provided no such modification creates elite exemption or unequal civic standing.

(e) Civic Education and Oath Requirement.
An applicant must complete civic education covering the Constitution, the history of the Republic, the structure and limits of government, and the duties of citizenship, and must swear a public oath of allegiance affirming loyalty to the Republic and its constitutional order.
The oath shall be binding and enforceable as a condition of Civic Citizenship.

(f) Retesting.
Retests shall occur every twenty (20) years unless otherwise specified by this Constitution.
Retakes shall be unlimited.
Any fee shall be limited to cost and waived for indigent applicants.
(g) Mandatory Grant Upon Qualification; No Added Requirements.
Where an applicant has met all constitutional requirements, the administering authority shall recognize Civic Citizenship and the baseline 1× Civic Standing.
No administering authority may impose requirements beyond those expressly enumerated in this Article, and any such attempt is void.
Failure or refusal to grant recognition upon qualification constitutes a constitutional violation subject to judicial compulsion and damages.

Section 6. The Franchise and the Baseline Weight

(a) Franchise Reserved.
The right to vote in public elections is reserved to Civic Citizens.

(b) Baseline Voting Authority.
A Civic Citizen with 1× Civic Standing possesses baseline voting authority as defined by this Constitution and implementing election law consistent with Article XVI.

(c) No Below-1× Voting.
No person may vote with Civic Standing below 1×.

(d) No Civic Standing Outside Civic Citizenship.
No Civic Standing exists for non-civic residents, and no person may claim or exercise a multiplier, weight, or proxy vote unless and until Civic Citizenship is earned under this Article.

Section 7. Earning Civic Standing Above 1×

(a) General Rule.
Civic Standing above 1× may be earned only prospectively through verified contribution categories defined by this Article and implemented by statute consistent with it.

(b) Non-Transferability.
A higher Civic Standing shall never be purchased, inherited, transferred, delegated, or obtained by proxy.
(c) Prohibition on Purchase or Preferment.
No money, donation, investment, inheritance, sponsorship, political affiliation, or personal relationship shall confer, accelerate, or substitute for any requirement of Civic Citizenship or Civic Standing.

(d) Prohibition on Credential Substitution.
No academic degree, license, certification, wealth, or professional status shall substitute for qualifying service, hardship, or other earned requirements of this Article.

(e) Neutrality of Evaluation.
No person shall be judged, favored, or disqualified based on religion, political belief, ideology, speech, or lawful association.
Only conduct, verified contribution, competence (as expressly defined), and constitutional loyalty may be evaluated.
(f) Verifiable, Sustained, Non-Trivial.
The Republic shall award additional Civic Standing credit only for contributions that are verifiable, sustained, and non-trivial.

(g) Anti-Gaming Rules.
No nominal participation, shell service, purchased certifications, proxy-crediting, or coordinated fraud may generate Civic Standing.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission (CJC) shall audit claims.
Intentional falsification, proxy-crediting, or bribery to obtain Civic Standing constitutes a disqualifying offense, triggers revocation, and constitutes at minimum a Tier-II offense where so classified by Article II and implementing law.
(Cross-reference: Article 0-A for anti-collusion.)

Section 8. Point Schedule and Qualifying Contribution Categories

(a) Structure and Cap.
Additional Civic Standing shall be calculated as a point schedule, where 1 point = +1× Civic Standing above the base 1×.
Maximum additional points: nine (9).
Maximum total Civic Standing: ten (10)×.

Categories shall be non-overlapping. A single act or period of conduct may not be double-counted across categories.

(b) Service (up to 5 points).
(1) Verified military service, emergency services, disaster response, hazardous public works, or comparable hardship-based service, credited by duration and risk under neutral standards.
(2) Verified civic volunteering: one (1) point per four hundred (400) hours of verified service, capped at three (3) points within this Service category.
(3) Hardship / Exposure Requirement.
Qualifying service credited under this subsection must be arduous, public-facing, and oriented toward danger, hardship, trauma exposure, sustained labor, or material sacrifice for the protection of the innocent or the common good.
Service shall not include administrative, clerical, advisory, managerial, academic, symbolic, leisurely, or elite-protective assignments absent direct, sustained exposure to risk or hardship.

(4) Non-Delegation; No Dilution.
Neither the Legislature nor any administrative body may redefine, dilute, bureaucratize, credential-substitute, or otherwise weaken qualifying service standards so as to reduce the hardship, danger, sacrifice, or public exposure required by this subsection.
(c) Competence & Contribution (up to 3 points).
(1) Passing CJC-administered examinations in civics, constitutional law, technical security, or other domains expressly authorized by law consistent with this Article: +1 per exam, maximum two (2) points.
(2) Significant Digital Commons contributions (including open-source, archival, preservation, restoration, or other verified contributions consistent with Article X and Article X-A): +1 per verified contribution, maximum two (2) points.
No person may receive more than three (3) points total in this subsection (c), and no person may exceed the overall Article cap.

(d) Stewardship & Sacrifice (up to 1 point).
(1) Ten (10) or more years of land stewardship as defined by law consistent with Article IX: +1 point.
(2) Validated whistleblowing under neutral standards, where the disclosure materially protects the Republic and is confirmed through due process: +1 point (one-time).
No person may receive more than one (1) point under this subsection (d).

(e) Raising Children (up to 2 points total).
Verified primary caregiving for a continuous five (5) year period per child, credited under neutral criteria, capped at two (2) points total for this subsection.
Anti-abuse safeguards shall apply, including safeguards against coercion, fraud, trafficking, and forced reproduction, and shall require judicially auditable verification standards.

(f) Enterprise Stewardship and Civic Achievement (integration rule).
Where statute recognizes “Enterprise Stewardship” (operating a lawful business over a sustained period with auditable compliance, non-capture conduct, and productive value) or other “Civic Achievement” (verified contributions strengthening resilience, infrastructure, scientific capacity, public health, or local prosperity) as qualifying conduct, such recognition shall:
(1) apply neutral, viewpoint-blind criteria;
(2) exclude fraud, corruption, predatory crime, trafficking, severe labor abuses, or deliberate public deception; and
(3) be credited only within the existing caps of subsections (b) through (e), as specified by statute, without increasing the overall maximum points unless this Constitution is amended under Article XV.

Section 9. Point Reductions, Forfeiture, and Restoration

(a) Tier-II Offenses.
Upon lawful conviction for Tier-II offenses (including serious felonies and corruption), Civic Standing shall be reduced by two (2) to five (5) points as determined by the court under neutral standards proportional to severity.

(b) Tier-III Offenses.
Upon lawful conviction for Tier-III offenses (grave crimes), Civic Standing shall be permanently reduced to 0× (with loss of political authority).
Any restoration shall require:
(1) at least twenty (20) years;
(2) restitution and completion of all judicially ordered obligations;
(3) CJC certification of rehabilitation and non-danger.
(c) Retroactive Application to Credits.
Reductions and forfeitures may apply to grandfathered credits where the disqualifying offense occurred pre-ratification, subject to due process and proof.

(d) Appeals.
Appeals shall be available through the Constitutional Review Court (CRC) or the routing specified by Article 0-B.
The burden shall rest upon the State by clear and convincing evidence where the State seeks deprivation or reduction beyond baseline.
(e) Finality of Lawful Grant; Non-Retroactivity.
Once Civic Citizenship or Civic Standing is lawfully granted, it shall not be revoked, impaired, or reduced except as expressly authorized by this Article upon final judicial judgment.
No retroactive rule, reinterpretation, or change in standards may be applied to create grounds for loss, suspension, or reduction.
(f) Good-Faith Interpretation.
No person shall be punished under this Article for disagreement, legal interpretation, advocacy, or scholarly opinion, even if later determined to be incorrect, unless deliberate and knowing intent to subvert the constitutional order is proven.

Section 10. Application, Scope, and Election Effects

(a) Scope Rule: Ordinary Elections.
Ordinary elections remain one-person-one-vote among Civic Citizens unless this Constitution expressly provides otherwise.

(b) Scope Rule: Defined High-Stakes Referenda.
Civic Standing may affect only:
(i) eligibility thresholds for office, and/or
(ii) defined high-stakes referenda categories expressly enumerated by this Constitution.

(c) Weighted Referenda Default Rule.
Where high-stakes referenda are enumerated and authorized for weighted tally, outcomes shall require:
(1) a weighted-majority threshold as specified by this Constitution (default 55% unless otherwise provided); and
(2) compliance with Article XVI auditability and election integrity standards.

(d) Office-Holding Threshold.
Eligibility for public office may require Civic Standing above 1× as set by this Constitution or by statute consistent with it.
Unless otherwise specified by this Constitution, candidacy for federal office shall require at least five (5)× Civic Standing at the time of candidacy.

(e) No Factional Engineering.
No statute may set office thresholds or weighting rules in a manner designed for factional exclusion, demographic engineering, incumbent entrenchment, or administrative expansion of the electorate.

Section 11. Transition and Grandfathering

(a) Grandfathered Credits (Transition Provision).
Service rendered to prior sovereign entities during the transition shall count toward additional points under this Article, subject to verification and the caps herein, including:
(1) military service (active/reserves/veterans): up to five (5) points;
(2) public education: high school = +1; associate’s = +1.5; bachelor’s or higher = +2;
(3) government employment: five (5) years = +1, capped at +3; and
(4) other recognized service (including Peace Corps or jury duty) as recognized by law consistent with neutral standards.

(b) Claim Window and Process.
A ten (10) year window post-ratification shall exist for filing grandfathering claims through CJC-administered procedures, subject to appeal routing under Article 0-B.
(Cross-reference: Article L §8 for grandfathering, if applicable.)

(c) Transition Phase-In.
A ten (10) year phase-in period may be used for administrative normalization, provided that:
(1) no person is stripped retroactively of a lawfully obtained baseline 1× Civic Standing without due process;
(2) fraud and disqualifying offenses remain subject to revocation under this Article; and
(3) election integrity remains governed by Article XVI.

Section 12. Administration, Records, and Public Ledger

(a) Oversight.
Implementation and enforcement of this Article shall be overseen by the CJC pursuant to Article 0-B.

(b) Records and Public Ledger.
Civic Citizenship status and Civic Standing credits shall be recorded in a public ledger consistent with Article XI and Article XXXIX, with narrowly tailored protections for sensitive personal data as expressly authorized by law and subject to judicial review.

Section 13. Anti-Expansion by Implication; Construction

(a) Narrow Construction of Political Authority.
Political authority and Civic Standing rules shall be construed narrowly against expansion by implication and broadly in favor of accountability, clarity, and verifiable contribution.

(b) No Administrative Expansion of the Electorate.
No administrative expansion of the electorate is allowed.
Only the pathways expressly authorized by this Constitution and laws consistent with it may confer Civic Citizenship or Civic Standing.
(c) Universal Incorporation; Preemption.
The standards for Civic Citizenship, Civic Standing, suffrage, political authority, and eligibility for public office established by this Article apply uniformly and bind the federal government, all states, territories, municipalities, and political subdivisions.
Any state or local law, policy, charter, or regulation inconsistent with this Article is void.
No jurisdiction may supplement, narrow, evade, or redefine these standards.
(d) Prohibition on State Vote-Buying.
No government may offer, condition, expand, or withhold any public benefit, tax status, subsidy, service, or regulatory privilege in exchange for voting, registration, turnout, or political support.


Section 14. Refugees and Extraordinary Regularization

(a) Applications for Lawful Residency.
Refugees, asylees, and unlawfully present persons may apply for lawful residency under conditions set by law.

(b) Narrow Extraordinary Status.
In extraordinary circumstances, a person may be granted a non-franchise lawful status solely to prevent statelessness, enable lawful employment, or permit travel documentation.
Such status shall confer no political rights and shall not substitute for Civic Citizenship.

(c) Individualized Determination; No Mass Regularization.
All grants under this Section shall be based on individualized findings. No blanket, class-based, or mass regularization program is permitted.

(d) Fraud Voidance.
Any status obtained through fraud, identity manipulation, or concealment of criminal history is void and revocable.

Section 15. Lock Designation

This Article is lock-protected under Article XV.
Amendments require the supermajority thresholds required by Article XV, CRC/CJC certification as required by Article 0-B and Article XV, and popular ratification as required by this Constitution.
(a) Prohibited Alterations.
The following are prohibited: reclassification of Civic Citizenship as personhood/caste; dilution or credential-substitution of service; creation of elite exemptions or proxy pathways; state or local deviation; circumvention through emergency powers or administrative discretion; judicial reinterpretation expanding political authority absent earned requirements.

(b) Permitted Amendments (Narrow Exception).
Amendment may occur only to clarify internal consistency, strengthen enforcement/anti-capture, address unforeseen evasion, or expand pathways only where equal or greater hardship, risk, and sacrifice is imposed.
No amendment may reduce standards, relax thresholds, or introduce inherited, purchased, or proxy political authority.

(c) Construction Duty.
All courts, agencies, boards, and officers shall enforce this Article as written, resolve ambiguities against expansion of political power without earned requirements, and treat Civic Citizenship as a constitutional office of trust.
Article III-A — Civic Competence Exam and Administration

Charge

The Civic Competence Exam is the gateway to baseline Civic Citizenship (1×).
It exists to ensure that the franchise rests on demonstrated comprehension of the Constitution, core civic mechanics, and basic reasoning competence sufficient for informed participation, while remaining accessible, viewpoint-neutral, non-capturable, and resistant to manipulation.

The Exam shall be administered in a manner that prevents elitism, credential laundering, ideological gatekeeping, covert discrimination, administrative expansion of the electorate, and covert dilution of standards.

(Cross-references: Article III §5; Article II; Article 0-B; Article XV; Article XVI; Article XXXIX.)

Section 1. Exam Effect and Limits

(a) Gateway to Civic Citizenship.
Passing the Exam entitles an applicant who otherwise meets Article III prerequisites to recognition as a Civic Citizen at baseline 1×.

(b) No Office Eligibility by Exam Alone.
Passing the Exam does not grant eligibility for public office unless otherwise authorized by this Constitution.

(c) No Discretionary Denial.
No authority may deny Civic Citizenship to an otherwise qualified applicant who passes the Exam, nor impose additional requirements beyond Article III and this Article.

Section 2. Exam Blueprint and Content Limits

(a) Permitted Content Domains.
The Exam may test only:
(1) constitutional text comprehension and structure;
(2) separation of powers, due process, and basic civic mechanics (elections, representation, lawful limits of state power);
(3) basic reasoning competence, including identification of common logical fallacies and manipulation techniques;
(4) basic historical and institutional literacy necessary to understand constitutional governance and civic duties.

(b) Prohibited Content Domains.
The Exam shall not test:
(1) partisan affiliation, ideology, or policy preferences;
(2) religious doctrine or anti-religious doctrine;
(3) cultural conformity, compelled speech, or compelled assent to contested narratives;
(4) advanced academic specialization, obscure trivia, or professional credential content unrelated to the permitted domains.

(c) Plain Language Requirement.
Exam language shall be written in plain language suitable for competent adult readers, and shall be designed to test comprehension and reasoning rather than vocabulary gamesmanship.

Section 3. Standard-Setting, Difficulty Control, and Fairness

(a) Minimum Competence Standard.
The passing standard shall reflect the minimum competence needed for informed civic participation, and shall not exceed what is reasonably necessary to achieve the purpose of this Article.

(b) Calibration and Drift Control.
The Exam shall be calibrated against defined competencies and reviewed at regular intervals to prevent covert drift in difficulty.
Any increase in difficulty, scope, or passing threshold requires:
(1) public notice;
(2) written justification tied to the permitted domains; and
(3) certification under Article 0-B.

(c) No Demographic or Faction Engineering.
No scoring rule, item selection rule, language rule, or administrative practice may be designed to exclude or include persons on demographic, factional, or viewpoint grounds.

Section 4. Access, Accommodations, and Language

(a) Universal Access.
The Republic shall provide adequate, geographically reasonable access to testing locations and schedules, including remote proctoring where feasible without compromising integrity.

(b) Disability Accommodations.
Reasonable accommodations shall be provided for disabilities, including extended time, assistive technology, or alternative formats, without reducing the substantive competencies tested.

(c) Language Availability.
The default Exam language shall be the official public language(s) defined by law.
Translations may be provided, but the constitutional text comprehension component must remain tied to the official constitutional text and its publicly ratified meaning.
No translation policy may be used to covertly expand or restrict the electorate.

Section 5. Retesting, Validity Period, and Fees

(a) Retakes.
Retakes shall be unlimited.

(b) Periodic Retesting.
Retesting shall occur every twenty (20) years for continued recognition as a Civic Citizen unless otherwise specified by this Constitution, consistent with Article III.

(c) Fees.
Any fee shall be limited to the cost of administration.
Fees shall be waived for indigent applicants under procedures that are simple, fast, and reviewable.
No fee structure may function as a poll tax.

Section 6. Integrity, Security, and Anti-Cheating

(a) Identity and Security Controls.
The Republic shall use reasonable identity verification and security controls to prevent impersonation, answer trafficking, and systemic cheating.

(b) Minimal Intrusion.
Security controls shall use the least intrusive means consistent with maintaining exam integrity, and shall not become a pretext for surveillance or intimidation.

(c) Consequences for Fraud.
Intentional impersonation, organized cheating, bribery, or trafficking in exam answers constitutes a disqualifying offense, triggers invalidation of results, and shall be punishable under Tier-II offense classifications where provided by Article II and implementing law.

Section 7. AI Use, Open Auditability, and Non-Capture

(a) Open Specifications.
Where AI is used to generate, assemble, proctor, or score the Exam, the technical specifications, evaluation criteria, and governance processes shall be public, auditable, and reproducible, subject only to narrowly tailored withholding of live item-bank contents.

(b) Model Rotation; No Single Controller.
No single vendor, agency, party, university, or private actor may control the Exam system.
AI models and scoring systems shall be rotated and independently auditable under procedures certified by the CJC pursuant to Article 0-B.

(c) Item Bank Confidentiality With Verifiable Governance.
The live question bank may remain confidential to prevent answer memorization, but:
(1) the blueprint, competency definitions, and scoring rubric must be public;
