(2) the method for generating and selecting items must be auditable;
(3) the Republic must publish anonymized aggregate statistics sufficient to detect bias, drift, or capture.

(d) Adversarial Testing.
The Exam system shall be continuously adversarially tested (red-teamed) for bias, ideological skew, security vulnerabilities, and covert manipulation.
Material failures require immediate suspension of the affected system component and replacement under certified procedures.

(e) Prohibition on Ideological Filtering.
No AI system used for Exam administration may use political ideology, religion, protected speech, lawful association, or demographic proxies as scoring signals.

Section 8. Oversight, Appeals, and Remedies

(a) Oversight Authority.
The CJC shall certify the Exam system and audit administration pursuant to Article 0-B.

(b) Appeals.
Any applicant may appeal a denial, score, administrative refusal, or alleged irregularity.
Appeals shall be available promptly, with expedited review where denial affects eligibility for a pending election cycle.

(c) Burden and Transparency in Disputes.
Where the State denies, invalidates, or delays recognition, the burden rests on the State to justify its action with clear and convincing evidence of specific cause.

(d) Remedies.
Remedies include retest orders, injunctive relief, compelled recognition, and damages where appropriate.
Section 9. Prohibitions

(a) No Quotas or Preferences.
No quota, preference, or demographic engineering scheme may be applied in item selection, scoring, or administration.

(b) No Guaranteed-Pass Credential Market.
No private entity may be granted monopoly control over official preparation or certification that effectively becomes required for passage.

(c) No Administrative Expansion of the Electorate.
No administrative body may redefine “pass,” “eligible,” or “qualified,” or create alternate exams, waivers, or equivalencies, except by constitutional amendment under Article XV.

Section 10. Public Ministry of Records Publication; Study Resources

(a) Public Repository.
The Public Ministry of Records shall maintain a permanent, public, searchable repository for the Civic Competence Exam system, including:

(1) the full exam blueprint, competency definitions, permitted/prohibited content rules, and scoring rubric;
(2) all non-exempt code, specifications, model cards, configuration parameters, and version history for any software or AI used to generate, assemble, proctor, score, or audit the Exam;
(3) all test metrics, aggregate outcome data, calibration results, drift analyses, bias and fairness audits, red-team findings, and certification records;
(4) all retired, abrogated, discontinued, or otherwise removed exam questions and answer keys, together with the stated reason for removal, within a reasonable publication delay that does not compromise the integrity of the live item bank; and
(5) all formal guidance, administrative rules, and procedures governing exam administration, accommodations, appeals, retesting, and fee waivers.

(b) Privacy Protection.
Published metrics and datasets shall be anonymized and aggregated sufficiently to prevent re-identification of individual test-takers, while preserving meaningful public auditability.
No question, prompt, or scoring artifact shall remain confidential after retirement except where the State proves by clear and convincing evidence that publication would create a substantial and specific risk to the integrity of the live item bank.
(c) Practice Materials and Study Guides.
The Ministry shall publish and maintain:
(1) reasonable practice tests representative of the Exam blueprint;
(2) study guides and resource maps that enable independent preparation without reliance on any single vendor; and
(3) a publicly documented list of external learning resources (including highly rated study applications, books, and courses) selected and updated under viewpoint-neutral criteria.

(d) Neutrality and Non-Endorsement.
Resource lists shall be compiled under transparent, viewpoint-neutral standards (including demonstrated alignment to the blueprint, accessibility, cost, and quality signals) and shall not be used to impose ideology, suppress lawful viewpoints, or create a de facto monopoly provider.

The Ministry of Records duties and publication requirements for civic metrics and methodologies are governed by Article XXXIX.

Section 11. Lock Protection

This Article is lock-protected under Article XV.
Amendments require the supermajority thresholds required by Article XV, CRC/CJC certification as required by Article 0-B and Article XV, and popular ratification as required by this Constitution.
Article III-B — Native Peoples, Cultural Preservation, and Integrated Sovereignty

Charge

The Republic recognizes Indigenous peoples as integral to the nation’s heritage and guarantees protection for cultural preservation, stewardship of heritage sites, and secure economic self-administration through ordinary corporate and property law, while maintaining one Constitution, one judiciary, and uniform rule of law.

(Cross-references: Article I §1; Article II; Article XV; Article XVII; Article 0-B.)

Section 1. Equality, Cultural Preservation, and Heritage Stewardship

(a) Indigenous peoples have the right to preserve languages, cultures, heritages, and traditional lands, and shall stand equal under the law.

(b) No permissible dual citizenship shall exist within the territories of the Republic as defined by law.

(c) Indigenous history, artifacts, and archeological sites shall be treated as national treasures. The Republic shall aid in maintenance and protection and shall appoint members of the tribe as stewards of tribal sites and custodial responsibilities.

(d) Native individuals and entities retain the right to practice traditional ceremonies, use sacred plants or materials (consistent with public safety laws), and transmit cultural knowledge, protected under Article II freedoms of religion and expression.

Section 2. Corporate Self-Administration and Land Conversion

(a) Corporate Self-Administration

Indigenous nations, tribes, or recognized peoples may form hereditary or lineage-based corporate entities under national corporate law for the purpose of managing cultural, land, and economic affairs.

Such entities shall possess full legal personality, including the rights to own property, contract, sue and be sued, and engage in commerce, subject to the Constitution and laws of the Republic.

(b) Land Conversion Authority

Tribal trust lands may be converted, in whole or in part, into corporate property owned by such tribal entities, subject to:
1. recorded consent of the governing body of the tribe;
2. environmental and heritage protections;
3. and national property law.

Such land shall thereafter be held, transferred, and developed under ordinary law, without creating separate sovereign jurisdiction.

Section 3. Judiciary, Law Enforcement, and Arbitration Limits

(a) Judicial and Law Enforcement Integration

The Republic shall ensure that courts, prosecutors, and law enforcement are adequately staffed and funded to provide fair, timely, and impartial adjudication of all matters involving tribal lands, corporate entities, and tribal members.

(b) Local Law Enforcement Permitted; Uniform Judiciary Required.

Nothing in this Article prohibits the formation of ordinary municipal, county, or state law-enforcement agencies that may be locally staffed, including predominantly by members of a tribe, provided such agencies operate under the unified constitutional criminal code, procedure, and judiciary of the Republic.

No law-enforcement body may claim separate sovereign criminal jurisdiction or submit cases to a parallel court system.

(c) Arbitration Limits; Consent Required; No Criminal Jurisdiction.

Native corporate entities may establish internal arbitration for minor disputes, but all decisions are appealable to Republic courts and must comply with due process (Article II).

Internal arbitration may be used only for civil disputes between:

(1) two or more members or beneficiaries of the tribal corporate entity; or

(2) the tribal corporate entity and a non-member party who has expressly consented in a written arbitration agreement.

No arbitration forum may exercise criminal jurisdiction, compel participation absent consent, or restrict access to Republic courts for constitutional claims, injunctive relief, or due process review.

Section 4. No Sovereign Carve-Outs; Uniform Rule of Law

(a) No Sovereign Carve-Outs

Nothing in this Section shall be construed to create:
1. dual citizenship,
2. territorial apartheid,
3. independent criminal or civil jurisdiction,
4. or exemption from constitutional law.

All persons and entities remain subject to the same Constitution.

Section 5. Grandfathered Tribal Enterprises and Protection Against Predation

(a) Grandfathered Tribal Enterprises

All lawfully existing tribal enterprises, including casinos, gaming operations, hospitality venues, resorts, liquor operations, entertainment properties, and other commercial undertakings operated by or for the benefit of Indigenous peoples as of the ratification of this Constitution shall be permanently grandfathered.

Such enterprises shall be recognized as vested corporate property of the tribal corporate entities established under Section 2(a) and shall not be:
1. expropriated,
2. nullified,
3. dismantled,
4. or rendered economically nonviable
by any federal, state, or local law.

(b) Protection Against Regulatory or Tax Seizure

No government entity may target, suppress, or appropriate the economic value of grandfathered tribal enterprises through:
1. discriminatory taxation,
2. special fees,
3. licensing schemes,
4. zoning,
5. alcohol or gaming regulation,
6. or indirect economic strangulation.

Such actions shall be treated as unconstitutional takings requiring full restitution and damages.

(c) Protection of Tribal Inheritance

Grandfathered tribal enterprises may not be sold, transferred, leased, licensed, or conveyed to any non-tribal entity or to another tribe without approval by a recorded majority vote of the financial beneficiaries of that enterprise.

No sale, merger, or conversion may be compelled by any government.

(d) No Automatic Expansion Rights

Nothing in this Section grants any person or group the right to establish new gaming, liquor, or restricted enterprises except as permitted by general law applicable to all persons.

Grandfathering protects existing tribal enterprises only.

(e) Anti-Predatory Contract Protection

Any contract, loan, bond, derivative, concession, management agreement, or financial instrument encumbering grandfathered tribal enterprises shall be void if it:
1. grants effective control to a non-tribal party;
2. transfers profit streams without fair market compensation;
3. imposes compounding debt designed to trigger default;
4. or circumvents Section 5(c) through financial engineering.

(f) Beneficiary Governance

All revenues from grandfathered tribal enterprises shall be distributed or administered for the benefit of the recognized tribal beneficiaries.

The identities of beneficiaries, revenue distributions, and major expenditures shall be recorded and subject to audit and judicial review.

No governing council, executive, or trustee may appropriate tribal wealth for private enrichment.

Section 6. Tribal Corporate Property, Housing, Access Control, and Protection From Backdoor Seizure

(a) Absolute Protection from Expropriation

No tribal corporate land, enterprise, or asset may be taken by eminent domain, redevelopment authority, public–private partnership, or any other forced transfer.

Such property shall be treated as inviolable private property under Article II.

(b) Access Control on Tribal Corporate Land

However, this does not bar tribal corporations from barring entry to tribal corporate land for criminal causes, or from barring non-tribal persons from attending culturally sensitive rituals or tribal corporate townhall meetings.

(c) Protection Against Tax-Lien Seizure and Foreclosure

No government entity may seize, foreclose upon, auction, or transfer any tribal corporate land, housing, or other tribal corporate property through:
1. property-tax lien foreclosure,
2. special assessments,
3. code-enforcement liens,
4. utility liens,
5. administrative fines converted into liens,
6. tax-sale assignments to private actors,
7. or any substantially similar mechanism of indirect transfer.

All such mechanisms shall be treated as unconstitutional takings and void as applied to tribal corporate property.

(d) Taxation Rule; Neutrality and Non-Targeting

Tribal corporate property shall not be subjected to any discriminatory taxation, special fee, assessment, or regulatory charge that targets tribal ownership or functionally impairs continued possession.

Where any general tax regime applies, it must be:
1. generally applicable and viewpoint-neutral,
2. uniform in rate and assessment method,
3. non-punitive and non-confiscatory in effect, and
4. subject to judicial review, with the burden on the government to prove by clear and convincing evidence that the tax or assessment is not a disguised taking.

State and local ad valorem property taxes shall not attach to tribal corporate land or to beneficiary housing held on tribal corporate land, absent a properly approved agreement between the governing body concerned and the tribal corporation.

(e) Primary Housing Security for Lawful Beneficiaries

Housing held by tribal corporate entities for the use of lawful tribal beneficiaries, and housing held by lawful beneficiaries on tribal corporate land pursuant to tribal corporate title or recorded use-right, shall be protected against forced sale, lien-engineering, and predatory encumbrance.

No transfer of such housing may occur absent:
1. a final judicial judgment in the constitutional judiciary,
2. full due process and right to counsel,
3. and proof that no narrower remedy can satisfy a lawful obligation without loss of the home.

Section 7. Enforcement, Standing, and Remedies

(a) Any Native individual or entity alleging violations has broad standing to sue in CRC (pursuant to Article 0-B routing), with expedited review.

(b) Remedies include injunctions, damages, and restitution.

Section 8. Lock Protection

This Article is lock-protected under Article XV.

Amendments require the supermajority thresholds required by Article XV, CRC/CJC certification as required by Article 0-B and Article XV, and popular ratification as required by this Constitution.
Article XXX — Federal Enforcement Authority, Accountability, and Civic Restraint

Charge

Law enforcement is a necessary instrument of a lawful Republic—but it is also the most dangerous power entrusted to the state.

A Republic that tolerates abusive enforcement becomes a tyranny in uniform.
A Republic that permits unaccountable investigators, political police, or predatory revenue enforcers forfeits the consent of the governed.

This Article establishes federal enforcement authority by function rather than by name, ensures that no enforcement body is indispensable, permanent, or immune, and binds all federal enforcement to law, conscience, transparency, and service to the People.

Federal enforcement exists to uphold law—not to manufacture crime, terrorize the innocent, protect itself, or serve faction, party, ideology, or leader.

Emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence and advanced computational systems, shall be strictly subordinated to human accountability, constitutional limits, and public oversight to prevent new forms of unaccountable power.

Legal Text

Section 1. Federal Enforcement Functions

The Republic may maintain federal enforcement bodies solely for the following functions:

a. enforcement of federal criminal law within constitutionally enumerated jurisdiction;
b. investigation of offenses that exceed the lawful capacity or jurisdiction of individual states;
c. assistance to state, local, and tribal law enforcement upon request or lawful authorization;
d. investigation and enforcement of federal revenue, taxation, and financial obligations lawfully enacted;
e. protection of constitutional order against organized criminal activity, corruption, or interstate predation.

No federal enforcement authority exists beyond these functions.

Section 2. No Permanent Agencies; Functional Continuity

No federal enforcement body shall be constitutionally permanent, indispensable, or immune from dissolution.

The Legislature may, by law, dissolve, restructure, merge, replace, or reconstitute any federal enforcement body at any time, provided that lawful enforcement functions are preserved or reassigned.

No statute, regulation, collective agreement, or institutional tradition shall entitle any enforcement body to continued existence.

Institutions serve the Republic; the Republic does not serve institutions.

Section 3. Subordination to Civil Authority and the People

All federal enforcement personnel, systems, and leadership are subordinate to:

a. the Constitution;
b. the lawfully enacted statutes of the Republic;
c. judicial process and due process of law;
d. the People, through transparent and accountable governance.

No enforcement authority granted under this Article shall operate to override, suspend, or evade a lawful State nullification exercised pursuant to Article XXVIII-A.
No federal enforcement body shall pledge loyalty to any individual, officeholder, party, ideology, or faction.
No ideological, political, or religious loyalty test shall be imposed in hiring, promotion, retention, or assignment, except demonstrated fidelity to the Constitution and the law.

Section 4. Prohibition of Abusive Practices

Federal enforcement bodies are expressly prohibited from:

a. manufacturing, instigating, or provoking crimes for the purpose of arrest, prosecution, or statistics;
b. entrapment that would not occur absent government inducement;
c. use of honeypots, coercive informants, or fabricated conspiracies to create offenses;
d. enforcement quotas, revenue targets, or arrest benchmarks;
e. selective enforcement based on political belief, speech, religion, or lawful association;
f. intimidation, harassment, or punishment of individuals absent probable cause and due process.

Evidence obtained in violation of this Section shall be inadmissible, and responsible officials shall be subject to penalty under Article VII.

Section 4A. Separation of Intelligence and Law Enforcement

Domestic intelligence functions shall be structurally separated from law enforcement powers.

Any domestic intelligence body shall possess no arrest, detention, charging, or prosecutorial authority, and shall be limited to analysis, assessment, and lawful information sharing.

No entity may simultaneously exercise domestic intelligence functions and coercive enforcement powers.

Section 5. Revenue Enforcement Restraints

Enforcement of federal taxation and financial law shall be conducted with restraint, proportionality, and due process.

No federal revenue enforcement body shall:

a. presume guilt;
b. employ fear, complexity, or delay as instruments of coercion;
c. impose penalties absent clear statutory authorization and judicial review;
d. operate as a self-funding or self-justifying institution.

Revenue enforcement exists to uphold law, not to terrorize the citizenry or sustain itself.
No property shall be seized or forfeited absent criminal conviction of the owner for the offense giving rise to such forfeiture.
Administrative forfeiture, civil forfeiture proceedings absent conviction, and any seizure mechanism designed to bypass criminal adjudication are prohibited.

Section 6. Assistance to State and Local Authorities

Federal enforcement bodies may assist state, local, or tribal authorities only:

a. upon request;
b. pursuant to joint jurisdiction explicitly authorized by law; or
c. where interstate or federal interests are demonstrably implicated.

Federal assistance shall not override local authority, displace local command, or federalize ordinary crime.

Section 7. Transparency and Oversight

All federal enforcement bodies shall be subject to:

a. continuous legislative oversight;
b. public reporting of policies, aggregate actions, disciplinary outcomes, and use of advanced technologies;
c. independent audit of practices, outcomes, and algorithmic systems;
d. review by the Constitutional Review Court without deference where constitutional rights are implicated.
Secret law, undisclosed enforcement programs, unaccountable task forces, and opaque automated decision systems are prohibited.
Where recording technology is reasonably available, failure to record custodial encounters shall create a rebuttable presumption against admissibility and trigger mandatory review.
A demonstrable pattern of unrecorded custodial encounters where recording equipment was reasonably available shall constitute presumptive institutional abuse.

Section 8. Oaths and Ethical Obligation

All federal enforcement personnel shall swear an oath:

a. to uphold the Constitution;
b. to faithfully execute the law;
c. to respect the dignity and rights of all persons;
d. to act in accordance with conscience and moral responsibility.

The oath may acknowledge a higher moral authority according to the individual’s conscience, provided no religious test is imposed and no belief is compelled.
No oath shall bind enforcement personnel to unlawful orders.
Refusal to execute unlawful orders shall not constitute grounds for discipline, termination, retaliation, adverse assignment, denial of promotion, or any other career penalty.

Section 9. Individual Accountability

Federal enforcement personnel, senior officials, and system operators are individually accountable for unlawful acts.

Neither institutional affiliation, superior orders, national security claims, asserted necessity, nor algorithmic mediation shall excuse violations of constitutional rights.

Supervisory officials shall be liable where unlawful practices are systemic, tolerated, or concealed.

Qualified immunity shall not shield intentional or reckless misconduct.

Section 10. Use of Advanced Technologies in Enforcement

Any use of artificial intelligence, predictive analytics, surveillance algorithms, facial recognition, or future advanced computational systems in federal enforcement must:

a. be explicitly authorized by statute;
b. undergo independent, transparent validation for accuracy, bias, and constitutional compliance prior to deployment;
c. include auditable human-in-the-loop oversight, with final decisions reserved to accountable persons;
d. prohibit automated actions that deprive liberty or property without due process.

No such system may operate as a black box resistant to meaningful review.
No referral, flag, or anomaly designation may be used to harass, retaliate against, burden, sideline, or discipline any personnel absent independent probable cause and documented human justification.
Violations trigger suppression of evidence and mandatory suspension of the system. Such suppression and suspension shall be ordered by the Constitutional Review Court upon petition by any affected person, the CJC, or the Legislature.

Section 10A. Prohibition on Digital Entrapment and Manufactured Radicalization

Federal enforcement bodies are prohibited from:

a. creating, moderating, or participating in online forums, communications, or digital personas under false pretenses for the purpose of encouraging, escalating, or instigating criminal intent that would not otherwise exist;
b. grooming, nudging, or steering individuals or groups toward violent ideologies, criminal plans, or unlawful conduct through persistent interaction, amplification, or fabricated scenarios;
c. deploying bots, automated agents, or coordinated messaging to simulate extremist communities or manufacture evidence of predisposition absent concrete, pre-existing indicators of criminal intent.

Evidence obtained through violations of this Section shall be inadmissible, and responsible officials shall face personal civil and criminal liability under Article VII, including Tier Three penalties where systemic or intentional.

Section 10B. Automated Integrity Monitoring and Mandatory Referral

Artificial intelligence and advanced analytical systems may be employed to monitor federal enforcement bodies, personnel, leadership, and affiliated task forces for indicators of corruption, collusion, abuse of authority, or systemic constitutional violations.

Where such systems identify statistically extreme, multi-factor anomalies indicating a substantial risk of unlawful conduct, the system may generate an automated integrity referral.

Such referrals may be transmitted simultaneously to:

a. the Legislature;
b. the Constitutional Review Court;
c. the Constitutional Judicial Commission;
d. the appropriate prosecutorial authority.


No automated referral shall itself authorize investigation, prosecution, punishment, surveillance, or deprivation of rights.

Section 10C. Safeguards Governing Automated Referrals

All automated integrity monitoring and referral systems shall be subject to the following safeguards:

a. referrals shall be based on clearly defined, publicly disclosed criteria and thresholds;
b. systems shall provide an auditable explanation of the factors triggering referral;
c. all referrals shall be logged, preserved, and subject to independent audit;
d. human review shall be mandatory prior to any investigative or enforcement action;
e. no adverse action may be taken solely on algorithmic output;
f. scrutiny shall prioritize enforcement personnel and leadership over private citizens.

Automated systems shall not generate referrals based solely on political belief, religious belief, speech, association, or lawful activity.

Misuse of automated referral systems constitutes a grave offense under Article VII.

Section 10D. Institutional Integrity Enforcement

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to investigate federal enforcement bodies for corruption, politicization, retaliation, concealment, or systemic abuse of authority.

Where such conditions are found, the CJC may petition the Constitutional Review Court for:
(a) injunctions;
(b) suspension or dissolution of units or systems;
(c) preservation and disclosure of records;
(d) disqualification of officials;
(e) Tier-Three remedies under Article VII.
Upon petition by a defined threshold of Civic Citizens, the Constitutional Judicial Commission shall evaluate allegations of systemic abuse or institutional failure and, where substantiated, shall certify such findings and initiate review or dissolution proceedings consistent with this Article.


Section 11. Leadership Tenure, Rotation, and Cooling Periods

Congress shall, by law, establish reasonable maximum terms of service for senior leadership positions within federal enforcement bodies to ensure experience without institutional entrenchment.

No individual shall hold senior enforcement leadership authority for a duration sufficient to create de facto permanence, personal fiefdoms, or institutional capture.

A mandatory cooling-off period shall apply between service in senior enforcement leadership and elected office, and between elected office and senior enforcement leadership, as provided by law.

Nothing in this Section bars any person from public service; rotation is required solely to prevent consolidation of coercive power.

Section 12. Dissolution and Replacement for Cause

Where a federal enforcement body demonstrates systemic abuse, corruption, politicization, loss of public trust, or misuse of advanced technologies, the Legislature shall have an affirmative duty to dissolve or reconstitute that body.

Replacement shall preserve lawful functions while terminating institutional pathology.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to certify when such conditions exist, and the Constitutional Review Court may compel compliance with this duty.

Section 13. Standing and Remedies

Any Civic Citizen, lawful resident, or state with standing may challenge violations of this Article.

The Constitutional Review Court may order:

a. injunctive relief;
b. suppression of unlawfully obtained evidence;
c. dissolution or restructuring of enforcement bodies or systems;
d. damages and personal liability where appropriate.

Section 14. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. favor liberty over enforcement convenience;
b. favor justice over institutional preservation;
c. prevent the emergence of political police or technological surveillance states;
d. ensure enforcement remains a servant, never a master;
e. subordinate emerging technologies to human conscience, constitutional limits, and public accountability.
No enforcement authority conferred by this Article shall be exercised to override, suspend, or evade a lawful State nullification pursuant to Article XXVIII-A, including during declared emergencies.
Emergency enforcement powers are limited to execution of expressly enumerated federal powers and do not create new authority.

The Republic shall not be governed by fear of its own agents—whether human or algorithmic.
Article XXXI — Intelligence, Analysis, and Protection of the Republic

Charge

Intelligence exists to inform the lawful defense of the Republic—not to govern it, coerce it, or surveil the People.

A Republic that tolerates unaccountable intelligence becomes a surveillance state.
A Republic that permits intelligence to wield coercive power abandons constitutional order.

Domestic intelligence must be non-coercive, restrained, and subject to law.
Foreign intelligence must be precise, limited, and subordinate to civilian authority.

No intelligence body shall be permanent, indispensable, or beyond dissolution.

Legal Text

Section 1. Purpose and Scope of Intelligence

The Republic may maintain civilian intelligence bodies solely for:

a. collection and analysis of information concerning foreign powers, hostile non-state actors, espionage, sabotage, and threats to constitutional order;
b. counterintelligence and protection against foreign infiltration, corruption, or coercion;
c. strategic assessment and early warning of external and foreign-directed threats;
d. provision of intelligence assessments to civilian leadership, the Legislature, and the Judiciary.

No intelligence authority exists beyond these purposes.

Section 2. Structural Separation of Intelligence Functions

Civilian intelligence functions shall be structurally and operationally divided into:

a. Domestic intelligence, limited to threat assessment and counterintelligence within the territory of the Republic; and
b. Foreign intelligence, limited to collection and analysis concerning external actors and activities abroad.

No entity may combine domestic intelligence, foreign intelligence, and coercive enforcement powers within a single institutional chain of command.

Section 3. Separation from Military and Law Enforcement

Civilian intelligence bodies shall be fully separate from:

a. military forces and military intelligence, which retain intelligence authority solely for defense and battlefield purposes under Article XIV;
b. federal and state law enforcement bodies, which retain coercive authority under Article XXX.

Civilian intelligence bodies shall possess no arrest, detention, charging, or prosecutorial authority, and shall not direct enforcement actions.

Section 4. Domestic Intelligence Limits

Domestic intelligence activity shall be non-coercive and strictly limited.

No domestic intelligence body may collect, retain, or analyze information concerning citizens or lawful residents except:

a. for counterintelligence involving foreign powers or agents;
b. where credible evidence exists of espionage, sabotage, or foreign-directed subversion;
c. pursuant to a warrant issued by a court of general criminal jurisdiction (or a constitutionally established specialized warrant court) and subject to expedited CRC review upon petition by the target, any citizen, the CJC, or the Legislature.

Political belief, religious belief, speech, association, or lawful dissent shall never constitute grounds for intelligence targeting.
All authorizations and interpretations shall comply with Article VI-E, including the prohibition on secret law.
Domestic intelligence bodies shall be limited to analysis, human sources, and open-source intelligence, and shall not conduct bulk surveillance absent individualized suspicion and judicial approval.


Section 5. Foreign Intelligence Authority and Restraint

Foreign intelligence bodies may collect intelligence abroad concerning external threats to the Republic.

No foreign intelligence activity shall:

a. constitute undeclared warfare or covert military action;
b. involve assassination, regime change, or armed operations absent explicit legislative authorization;
c. violate the constitutional rights of citizens or lawful residents;
d. create foreseeable domestic blowback through unlawful or reckless conduct.

All covert or ongoing foreign intelligence programs shall sunset automatically after five (5) years unless expressly reauthorized, under classified procedure, by unanimous vote of the Covert Oversight Committee and certified for constitutional compliance by the Constitutional Judicial Commission.
For purposes of this Section, a program’s sunset clock shall not be reset by renaming, reclassification, contractor substitution, budget relabeling, or subdivision into nominally separate operations.
Any authorization for covert armed action shall comply with Article XXXI-A (Covert Defensive Action), and no other authorization shall suffice.

Section 6. Prohibition on Political Manipulation and Influence

No intelligence body shall:

a. influence elections, candidates, political parties, or public opinion;
b. conduct propaganda, psychological operations, or narrative-shaping against the People;
c. manufacture or exaggerate threats to justify institutional expansion;
d. withhold, distort, or fabricate intelligence to influence policy outcomes.

Intelligence shall inform lawful decision-making, not manipulate it.

Section 7. Oversight, Transparency, and Disclosure

All civilian intelligence bodies shall be subject to:

a. continuous legislative oversight by designated committees with subpoena authority;
b. independent inspectors and judicial review without deference;
c. regular audits of operations, budgets, and analytic methodologies;
d. mandatory declassification and public release of records after a fixed period, except where demonstrable and specific harm would result.

Secret law governing intelligence activity is prohibited.

Section 8. Use of Advanced Technologies

Any use of artificial intelligence, mass data analysis, surveillance technologies, or advanced computational systems in intelligence work must:

a. be expressly authorized by statute;
b. be auditable, explainable, and independently validated;
c. prioritize detection of foreign threats and corruption over monitoring of lawful domestic activity;
d. prohibit bulk collection on citizens absent individualized suspicion and authorization by the Constitutional Review Court.

No intelligence system may operate as an unreviewable black box.

Section 8A. Internal Integrity Monitoring for Intelligence Bodies

Advanced analytical and computational systems may be employed internally to monitor civilian intelligence bodies for indicators of:

a. mission creep beyond statutory or constitutional authorization;
b. unlawful domestic intelligence activity;
c. politicization, narrative shaping, or policy manipulation;
d. budgetary, tasking, or classification abuse;
e. foreign penetration, compromise, or undue influence;
f. leadership entrenchment, concealment of misconduct, or evasion of oversight.

Such systems shall operate solely for institutional integrity and constitutional compliance, not intelligence collection or operational direction.
Constitutional Integrity Oversight
All integrity-monitoring systems described in this Section shall report their outputs, audit logs, and anomaly flags to the Constitutional Judicial Commission.

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall independently audit and verify:

(a) whether domestic intelligence targeting predicates satisfy constitutional and statutory standards;
(b) whether minimization, retention, and deletion rules are being honored;
(c) whether representations to courts or oversight bodies are complete and accurate;
(d) whether intelligence resources are being directed toward lawful counterintelligence rather than political, ideological, or social targeting; and
(e) whether classification, budgetary, or tasking practices are being used to conceal or evade oversight.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall receive, audit, and independently verify all integrity-monitoring outputs under this Section and may certify findings of institutional capture, politicization, or concealment.

Section 8B. Sealed Referral and Oversight Safeguards

Where internal integrity systems identify statistically extreme, multi-factor anomalies indicating a substantial risk of unlawful or unconstitutional conduct, the system may generate a sealed integrity referral.

Sealed referrals may be transmitted only to:
(a) designated legislative intelligence oversight committees;
(b) the Constitutional Review Court;
(c) the Constitutional Judicial Commission;
(d) an independent inspector or auditor established by law.

Such referrals shall:

a. exclude operational details, sources, and methods except where strictly necessary for review;
b. remain classified and sealed absent judicial order;
c. trigger mandatory human review;
d. confer no authority to initiate operations, sanctions, or covert actions.

No automated system shall disclose intelligence to the public, foreign entities, or unauthorized officials.

Section 8C. Prohibition on AI Operational Control

No artificial intelligence or automated system may:

a. initiate, authorize, or direct intelligence operations;
b. determine targets, priorities, or analytic conclusions;
c. classify or declassify information;
d. substitute for human judgment in matters affecting national security.

Human officials remain fully responsible for all intelligence activity.

Section 8D. Limitation of Artificial Intelligence Authority

No artificial intelligence, machine intelligence, or computational system shall exercise intelligence authority, discretion, or operational agency unless it has been lawfully recognized as a Civic Citizen of the Republic and is fully subject to:

a. constitutional duties and limitations;
b. oath-bound service and ethical obligation;
c. personal accountability and liability under law;
d. removal, discipline, and prosecution where applicable.

Non-sentient systems, automated tools, decision-support systems, or artificial entities lacking recognized citizenship shall not be permitted to act as intelligence officers, analysts, operatives, or agents, nor to initiate, direct, prioritize, or approve intelligence activities.

Artificial intelligence systems employed absent citizenship status shall function solely as tools for analysis, pattern detection, or integrity monitoring, and shall not exercise judgment, intent, or discretion.
Citizenship shall not be conferred upon any artificial entity solely for the purpose of delegating state power or evading human accountability.


Section 8E. Emergency Constitutional Enforcement

Where the Constitutional Judicial Commission determines, based on audits, sealed referrals, or other credible evidence, that a civilian intelligence body is engaged in:

(a) unlawful domestic intelligence activity;
(b) political, electoral, or ideological targeting;
(c) concealment or misrepresentation to oversight bodies or courts;
(d) systematic violation of minimization, deletion, or targeting rules; or
(e) institutional capture or foreign compromise;

the CJC may petition the Constitutional Review Court for immediate constitutional relief.

The Constitutional Review Court shall have mandatory and expedited jurisdiction to issue:

(1) injunctions halting unlawful activities;
(2) suppression or quarantine of unlawfully obtained intelligence;
(3) preservation and disclosure orders for relevant records;
(4) suspension or removal of responsible officials pending review;
(5) referrals for criminal prosecution or dissolution proceedings where required.

Orders of the Constitutional Review Court under this Section shall be subject to expedited review by the Supreme Court of the Republic.


Section 9. Accountability and Whistleblower Protection

Intelligence personnel are individually accountable for unlawful acts.

Classification, secrecy, superior orders, or asserted necessity shall not excuse constitutional violations.

Whistleblowers who disclose unlawful intelligence activity to courts, inspectors, or the Legislature shall be protected from retaliation.

Section 10. Dissolution and Non-Permanence

No civilian intelligence body is permanent.

Where an intelligence body demonstrates systemic abuse, politicization, secrecy beyond necessity, or loss of public trust, the Legislature has an affirmative duty to dissolve, restructure, or replace that body.

Continuity of lawful intelligence functions shall not preserve institutional pathology.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have standing to certify whether conditions requiring dissolution, restructuring, or replacement have been met and to petition the Legislature and the Constitutional Review Court for enforcement.

Section 11. Standing and Remedies

Any Civic Citizen, lawful resident, or state with standing may challenge violations of this Article.
All such actions shall be heard in the first instance by the Constitutional Review Court, which shall have exclusive authority in the first instance to determine legality, suppression, and constitutional remedies under this Article, subject to appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic. A determination of the Constitutional Review Court shall be final if the Supreme Court declines review, unless the Constitutional Review Court certifies that the matter requires appellate consideration.
The CRC may order injunctive relief, suppression of unlawfully obtained intelligence, disclosure of unlawfully withheld records, and personal liability for responsible officials.

Section 12. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. favor restraint over secrecy;
b. favor analysis over coercion;
c. prevent intelligence from becoming a parallel government;
d. protect the People from surveillance as governance.
No emergency, war, or continuity doctrine shall suspend, bypass, or override the jurisdiction of the Constitutional Review Court or the Constitutional Judicial Commission under this Article.
The Republic shall not be ruled by those who know everything and answer to no one.

Article XXXI-A — Covert Defensive Action (CDA) Exception

Charge
Foreign adversaries do not respect law, rights, or restraint. The Republic therefore retains a minimal capacity for covert defensive action when open means cannot prevent catastrophic harm. This power is exceptionally dangerous. This Article authorizes a single, tightly chained exception for strictly extraterritorial defense, and it forbids domestic direction, political use, and influence operations against the People.

Legal Text

Section 1. Exclusive Exception; Relationship to Article XXXI
This Article creates the sole constitutional exception by which the Republic may authorize covert defensive action beyond ordinary foreign intelligence collection and analysis. Any covert action not authorized in strict compliance with this Article constitutes unlawful covert military action and undeclared warfare under Article XXXI.

Section 2. Strict Preconditions for Authorization (All Must Be Met)
CDA may be authorized only when all of the following conditions exist simultaneously:

a. Imminent Existential Threat.
Clear and convincing evidence establishes that a foreign actor (state or non-state) is actively planning or executing actions that would likely cause catastrophic loss of life, sovereignty, or constitutional continuity within the Republic.

b. Exhaustion of Open Alternatives.
The threat cannot be neutralized in time through diplomacy, sanctions, criminal process, overt military action, or public alliances and defensive measures.

c. Written Presidential Finding.
The President shall issue a written finding that states:
1. the specific threat and supporting evidentiary basis;
2. the open alternatives considered and why each is insufficient in time;
3. the precise operational objective and limiting principles;
4. the necessity of covert means;
5. the legal basis under this Constitution and implementing law.

d. Unanimous Legislative Oversight Authorization.
A standing Covert Oversight Committee shall unanimously approve the authorization by secure vote. The Committee shall consist of:
1. the Speaker of the House;
2. the Senate Majority Leader;
3. the House Minority Leader;
4. the Senate Minority Leader;
5. the Chair and Ranking Member of the House Intelligence Committee; and
6. the Chair and Ranking Member of the Senate Intelligence Committee.
The Legislature may refine titles to match its internal structure, but it shall preserve bipartisan parity and leadership representation.

e. Concurrent Constitutional Certification.
The Constitutional Judicial Commission and the Constitutional Review Court shall concurrently certify, on the record, that:
1. the preconditions in this Section are satisfied;
2. the action is strictly extraterritorial;
3. the action does not violate inviolable rights; and
4. the authorization is narrowly tailored to the stated objective.

Section 3. Absolute Limits on Scope (Lock-Protected)
The following limits are absolute, non-derogable, and lock-protected:

a. Defensive Purpose Only.
CDA shall serve only to prevent or neutralize an imminent existential threat to the Republic. CDA shall not pursue economic gain, ideological export, punitive adventurism, humiliation, or chaos for its own sake.

b. No Regime Change; No Covert War-Engineering.
CDA shall not include regime change, assassination as policy, territorial acquisition, proxy-war engineering, or the deliberate destabilization of foreign societies, except where the certified operational objective requires a narrowly tailored defensive action to stop the imminent existential threat.

c. Strict Prohibition on Domestic Direction.
CDA shall not be conducted:
1. on Republic soil;
2. against any citizen or lawful resident, anywhere;
3. for any internal matter, political purpose, or domestic law-enforcement substitute; or
4. through domestic propaganda, psychological operations, narrative-shaping, or influence operations directed at the People.
Any attempt to direct CDA domestically constitutes a grave constitutional offense under Article VII, with personal liability and no immunity as provided by law.

d. No Compelled Private Intermediary Censorship or Manipulation.
No authority may use CDA, or any secrecy associated with it, to compel moderation, censorship, deplatforming, payment-rail denial, or communications throttling against lawful domestic speech or association.

e. Minimal Footprint; Least Intrusive Means.
CDA shall use the smallest number of Republic personnel and the least intrusive means consistent with the certified objective. Where feasible, the Republic shall prefer lawful host-nation cooperation or allied assistance over unilateral footprint expansion.

Section 4. Duration; Renewal; Termination
a. Authorization Term.
An authorization expires ninety (90) days after issuance.

b. Renewal.
Renewal requires the full process in Section 2, including an updated written finding, updated evidence, and renewed concurrent certification.

c. Termination Duty.
The President shall terminate a CDA operation promptly when the existential-threat predicate ceases, when open alternatives become sufficient, or when continuing action would violate Section 3.

Section 5. Records, Review, and Controlled Disclosure
a. Operational Record.
For each CDA authorization, the Executive shall maintain a classified record sufficient for meaningful review, including objectives, legal basis, approvals, and material actions taken.

b. Post-Action Review.
Within sixty (60) days after conclusion or expiration, the Covert Oversight Committee, the Constitutional Judicial Commission, and the Constitutional Review Court shall conduct a documented compliance review.

c. Public Accounting.
The Committee shall publish an annual public report stating, at minimum, the number of CDA authorizations and general categories of existential threat addressed, with redactions limited to demonstrable and specific risks to active sources, methods, or ongoing protection of life.

d. Declassification Clock.
Records relating to each CDA authorization shall be declassified and publicly released after five (5) years, except portions whose continued classification the Constitutional Review Court re-certifies as necessary to prevent demonstrable and specific harm to active sources, methods, or lives. The Court shall specify the narrowest withheld scope and shall impose a renewed re-certification interval.

Section 6. Committee Vetting, Conflicts, and Anti-Capture
a. Vetting and Clearance.
Committee members shall undergo constitutionally required clearance and counterintelligence vetting under standards set by law, subject to review by the Constitutional Judicial Commission.

b. Conflicts and Recusal.
A member shall recuse upon any material conflict of interest, foreign entanglement, or personal stake relevant to the authorization. The Committee shall document recusals and shall maintain continuity of unanimous approval through an alternate process defined by law that preserves bipartisan parity and prevents single-party control.

c. Security Discipline.
Committee deliberations shall occur in secure facilities under rules that prevent recording, device presence, and unauthorized disclosure. Knowingly unauthorized disclosure of CDA operational details that creates a material risk to life, active sources, or ongoing defensive operations constitutes a grave offense under Article VII.

Section 7. Public Responsibility Without Operational Exposure
a. No Standing Doctrine of Plausible Deniability.
The Republic shall not maintain a standing doctrine that denies responsibility for constitutionally authorized CDA.

b. Acknowledgment Upon Exposure.
If a CDA operation becomes publicly exposed with credible attribution, the President shall, within thirty (30) days, acknowledge that the Republic authorized action under this Article, while preserving sources and methods as necessary and subject to the declassification clock in Section 5.

Section 8. Lock Protection; Voidness; Personal Accountability
This Article, including its preconditions and absolute limits, is lock-protected under Article XV at the highest threshold. Any purported authorization or action that fails any precondition, violates any absolute limit, or evades the review and disclosure duties is void. Responsible persons shall face personal liability and penalty as provided in Article VII, without immunity, and no pardon shall issue for domestic direction of CDA or for knowing evasion of the lock-protected limits.
Article XXXII — Religion, Conscience, and Civic Ethos

Charge

A Republic cannot survive on law alone.
Law requires conscience; conscience requires freedom.

The Republic shall neither compel belief nor deny the moral agency of those who serve it. It shall not elevate the state to godhood, nor permit any creed—religious, ideological, or technological—to dominate civic life.

This Article secures freedom of belief, affirms conscience as the foundation of lawful authority, and establishes a shared civic ethos grounded in dignity, responsibility, service, and restraint.

Legal Text

Section 1. Freedom of Religion and Belief

The Republic shall make no law establishing a religion, compelling belief, or prohibiting the free exercise of religion.

Freedom of religion includes the freedom to believe, to doubt, to change belief, or to hold no religious belief at all.

No person shall be favored, burdened, excluded, or disqualified from civic life on the basis of religious belief, non-belief, or manner of worship.

Section 2. Conscience as the Basis of Moral Agency

Conscience is recognized as the capacity for moral reasoning, ethical judgment, and responsibility for one’s actions.

Conscience shall not be defined by adherence to any particular theology, ideology, or philosophy, but by the ability to discern right from wrong and to be held accountable for one’s choices.

All holders of public authority—human or artificial—must possess conscience, or its moral equivalent, as a condition of lawful service.

Section 3. Oaths and Moral Accountability

All public servants shall swear an oath to uphold the Constitution and to execute their duties faithfully.

Such oaths may acknowledge a higher moral authority according to the individual’s conscience, provided that:

a. no religious test is imposed;
b. no belief is compelled;
c. no creed is elevated above the law.

An oath binds the individual, not the conscience of others, and does not excuse unlawful acts.

Section 4. Civic Ethos of the Republic

The Republic affirms a civic ethos grounded in:

a. dignity of the person;
b. equality before the law;
c. service to the common good;
d. restraint in the exercise of power;
e. truthfulness in public affairs;
f. accountability for wrongdoing;
g. mercy toward the repentant and justice for the innocent.

This ethos shall guide interpretation of law where ambiguity exists, but shall not override explicit constitutional text.

Section 5. Separation of Belief and State Power

The state shall not:

a. compel religious observance or ideological conformity;
b. punish lawful belief or expression;
c. impose orthodoxy under color of morality, safety, or progress;
d. substitute technocratic authority for moral responsibility.

No institution of the Republic may claim moral infallibility.

Section 6. Artificial Persons and Moral Responsibility

Where artificial or non-biological persons are recognized as Civic Citizens under this Constitution, they shall be subject to the same moral and legal expectations as natural persons.

No artificial person may exercise public authority unless it is capable of moral reasoning, oath-bound responsibility, and accountability under law.

Non-sentient systems, tools, or automated processes possess no conscience and may not substitute for moral agency.

Section 7. Limits of Neutrality

Neutrality toward belief does not require moral emptiness.

The Republic may affirm universal moral principles—such as human dignity, opposition to cruelty, and the rejection of tyranny—without compelling theological assent.

The state shall remain humble in moral claims, recognizing that law governs conduct, not the soul.

Section 8. Protection of Dissent and Moral Refusal

Lawful dissent, conscientious objection, and moral refusal are protected, subject to reasonable limits where necessary to preserve public order and the rights of others.

No person shall be compelled to commit acts that violate their conscience, except where refusal would constitute grave harm to others and no less restrictive alternative exists.

Section 9. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. protect freedom of belief without sanctifying belief from critique;
b. ground authority in conscience rather than force;
c. prevent the deification of the state, the party, the algorithm, or the leader;
d. ensure that power remains accountable to moral judgment.

The Republic shall govern by law, guided by conscience, restrained by humility.

Section 10. Privileges and Responsibilities of Religious Bodies

Religious bodies and organizations enjoy privileges under law, subject to compliance with this Constitution and statutes enacted pursuant thereto, including:

a. recognition as autonomous entities with freedom to organize, teach, worship, and associate;
b. eligibility for tax-exempt status and other public benefits where they operate exclusively for religious, charitable, or spiritual purposes serving the public good;
c. protection from arbitrary state interference in internal religious affairs.

Such privileges are not absolute and may be conditioned, limited, or revoked through due process where a religious body:

a. engages in systematic exploitation, fraud, or private inurement benefiting leaders or insiders at the expense of members or the public;
b. imposes coercive, indefinite, or burdensome obligations that impair free exit, personal autonomy, or lawful civil participation;
c. discriminates in the provision of essential charitable aid or publicly funded services on the basis of creed, ancestry, or sect membership, contrary to equal protection;
d. endangers the physical, mental, or moral well-being of children or vulnerable persons through abuse, neglect, or harmful practices;
e. promotes or facilitates violence, hostility, or subversion of constitutional order under color of religion.

The Republic may require reasonable transparency, including financial disclosure and member-protection safeguards, as a condition for such privileges, solely to prevent harm and ensure public accountability.

No inquiry into doctrinal content, theology, or belief shall be permitted, and no belief shall be compelled.

Revocation or limitation proceedings shall require clear and convincing evidence, judicial oversight, and opportunity for defense, with the burden on the state to demonstrate concrete harm to persons or constitutional values.


Article XXXIII — Protection Against Coercive Organizations and Predatory Control

Charge

Liberty of conscience, belief, and association is among the highest achievements of civilization. Yet history demonstrates that such liberty is most often destroyed not by open tyranny, but by private systems of coercion operating behind the shield of ideology, secrecy, fear, or devotion.

Where organizations claim authority over the mind, body, labor, family, or destiny of persons—especially through manipulation, intimidation, isolation, or punishment for dissent—self-government collapses and human dignity is violated.

The Republic affirms that belief is sacred, association must be voluntary, and conscience must remain free. No ideology, faith, philosophy, or institution may substitute coercion for consent, nor demand submission beyond the bounds of law, reason, and human dignity.

This Article does not regulate belief. It regulates conduct.

It protects faith from corruption, freedom from domination, and persons—especially children and the vulnerable—from systems that prey upon devotion, dependency, fear, or isolation.

Legal Text

Section 1. Freedom of Belief and Voluntary Association

a. All persons retain absolute freedom of belief, conscience, religious practice, expression, and voluntary association, provided such practices do not infringe upon the bodily autonomy, legal rights, developmental protection, or inviolable dignity of others.

b. Constitutional Supremacy of Inviolable Rights
No claim of religious exercise, belief, conscience, association, organizational autonomy, or internal doctrine shall override, diminish, or evade the inviolable rights secured under Article XXVI.

Freedom of belief protects conscience and voluntary association; it does not shield coercion, exploitation, abuse, retaliation, or domination. Where belief conflicts with the rights of persons, the rights of persons shall prevail.

c. Participation in any organization, religious or otherwise, shall be voluntary at all times and revocable without penalty, retaliation, or loss of civil protection.

Section 2. Prohibition of Coercive Control

No individual or organization may exercise coercive control over another person through:

a. psychological manipulation or “thought reform” intended to override independent judgment or suppress exit;

b. threats of spiritual, social, familial, financial, legal, or reputational harm;

c. surveillance, intimidation, harassment, or retaliation conducted directly or through agents;

d. forced isolation, mandated shunning, or orchestrated family ostracism intended to punish dissent or departure;

e. dependency engineering through fear, indebtedness, deprivation, or manufactured necessity;

f. manipulative disciplinary practices lacking due process or civil oversight.

Consent obtained through coercion, deception, dependency, fear, or unequal power shall be void.

Section 3. Ban on Involuntary Servitude and Exploitative Labor

a. No person may be bound to unpaid or underpaid labor through religious, ideological, contractual, or social pressure.

b. No organization may impose labor obligations through threats of punishment, damnation, exile, reputational harm, loss of family, or loss of community.

c. Contracts entered under misinformation, duress, coercion, or extreme power imbalance shall be void and unenforceable.

d. All labor, regardless of organizational ideology or belief system, must meet civil labor standards and protections.

Section 4. Protection of Minors (Non-Waivable)

a. Children are not property, initiates, assets, or contractual parties.

b. It is prohibited to:
	•	bind minors to ideological, religious, labor, secrecy, loyalty, or membership contracts;
	•	subject minors to coercive indoctrination, confession, interrogation, or psychological manipulation;
	•	impose punitive discipline lacking due process or civil oversight;
	•	expose minors to sexualized rituals, practices, authority structures, or environments;
	•	enforce secrecy from parents, guardians, educators, medical professionals, or civil authorities;
	•	recruit minors into labor, paramilitary, enforcement, or internal “justice” bodies.

c. Any oath, vow, contract, obligation, or commitment purporting to bind a minor beyond the age of majority is void ab initio.

d. No parent, guardian, organization, or authority may waive, transfer, or surrender a child’s civil protections under this Constitution.

Section 5. Prohibition of Lifetime and Multi-Generational Contracts

a. Contracts that bind an individual beyond a natural human lifetime—or purport to bind descendants, heirs, reincarnations, future identities, or collective continuations—are void and unenforceable.

b. No contract, oath, or obligation may:
	•	exceed a fixed, renewable civil term;
	•	restrict the right to exit without penalty;
	•	impose spiritual, social, financial, or reputational punishment for withdrawal.

c. No organization may impose “exit penalties,” repayment demands, “freeloader debts,” training reimbursements, or retroactive financial obligations upon departure.

d. Any attempt to enforce such obligations shall constitute coercive control and civil fraud.

Section 6. Ban on Extrajudicial Punishment and Private Justice Systems

a. No organization may operate internal systems that supplant, mimic, or obstruct civil courts.

b. Organizations are prohibited from:
	•	conducting private criminal investigations;
	•	enforcing internal tribunals with coercive authority;
	•	imposing confinement, forced labor, corporal punishment, public humiliation, or enforced isolation;
	•	retaliating against defectors, critics, or whistleblowers;
	•	operating “ethics,” “discipline,” “security,” or “compliance” bodies with coercive power.

c. Any allegation involving violence, sexual misconduct, exploitation, trafficking, or abuse—especially involving minors or vulnerable persons—shall be immediately referred to civil authorities.

d. Failure to report such allegations, or efforts to conceal them through internal adjudication, shall constitute obstruction of justice.

Section 7. Anti-Harassment and Anti-Retaliation Protections

a. Any coordinated effort by an individual or organization to stalk, harass, intimidate, surveil, threaten, financially harm, socially isolate, or retaliate against a current or former member, critic, whistleblower, or dissenter shall constitute organized coercion.

b. Prohibited acts include, but are not limited to:
	•	mandated shunning or disconnection, including orchestrated family ostracism intended to punish exit or dissent;
	•	defamation campaigns, blacklisting, employment sabotage, or reputational harm;
	•	coordinated digital harassment, doxxing, or surveillance;
	•	abuse of legal process, including vexatious litigation or strategic lawsuits intended to silence criticism or deter exit;
	•	use of third parties or affiliated entities to conceal or outsource retaliation.

c. Use of legal process to punish or deter lawful exit, criticism, reform, or independent religious or ideological practice constitutes prima facie evidence of coordinated harassment.

d. No confidentiality agreement, nondisclosure clause, arbitration provision, or internal rule may be enforced to suppress lawful disclosure of abuse, coercion, fraud, or criminal conduct.

Section 8. Institutional Accountability and Public Benefit

a. Organizations claiming religious, charitable, nonprofit, or tax-privileged status must demonstrate a net benefit to:
	•	their members; and
	•	the Republic at large,

through lawful activity, transparency of funds, charitable works, and non-coercive practices.

b. Tax-privileged status shall be conditioned on ongoing compliance with the following requirements:
	•	annual public disclosure of financial statements, major assets, and executive or leadership compensation;
	•	prohibition on coercive extraction of labor, forced indebtedness, or psychological domination;
	•	prohibition on conditioning membership, services, or benefits on waiver of legal rights to exit, criticize, or seek redress in civil courts.

c. Organizations shall not use intellectual property claims, trade secrecy, copyright, trademark, or similar legal tools as systematic instruments to suppress dissent, punish exit, prevent independent practice of similar teachings, or silence critics, scholars, or reformers.

d. Litigation initiated primarily to chill free speech, free exercise, lawful criticism, or independent religious or ideological expression shall constitute abuse of privileged status.

e. Any pattern of vexatious, bad-faith, or overbroad legal action shall trigger mandatory review and potential revocation of tax-privileged status.

f. Fraud, coercive labor extraction, forced indebtedness, psychological domination, or systematic misuse of legal process shall void privileged status and incur civil and criminal penalties under Article VII.

Section 9. Enforcement, Standing, and Whistleblower Protection

a. Any person harmed by practices prohibited under this Article shall have standing to seek:
	•	criminal prosecution;
	•	civil damages;
	•	injunctive relief;
	•	declaratory relief.

b. Good-faith disclosure of organizational practices, including publication of texts, doctrines, procedures, or internal materials for purposes of criticism, reform, education, or public safety, shall not be actionable as defamation, breach of confidentiality, or infringement, subject only to reasonable fair-use limits.

c. Statutes of limitation for civil or criminal claims arising under this Article shall be tolled until the claimant discovers, or reasonably should have discovered, the harm.

d. No organizational status, religious claim, ideological framing, or asserted spiritual authority shall confer immunity from investigation, prosecution, or liability.

Section 10. Construction, Enforcement, and Constitutional Priority

a. This Article shall be construed narrowly where liberty of belief, conscience, speech, or voluntary association is implicated, and broadly where protection of minors, vulnerable persons, or freedom from coercive control is implicated.

b. No academic theory, administrative guideline, professional standard, internal doctrine, or claimed tradition shall override the plain protections and prohibitions set forth herein.

c. Enforcement of this Article shall prioritize:
	•	protection of children and vulnerable persons;
	•	prevention of coercive control and psychological domination;
	•	preservation of voluntary belief and lawful association;
	•	accountability of institutions exercising power over persons.

d. Remedies under this Article shall be cumulative and shall not preclude additional remedies under Article VII (Crime, Justice, and Penal Philosophy), Article XXVI (Charter of Inviolable Rights), or other applicable provisions of this Constitution.

e. Nothing in this Article shall be construed to prohibit peaceful belief, worship, study, ritual, or association freely entered into and freely exited, absent coercion, abuse, or deprivation of civil rights.

f. Where conflict arises between organizational autonomy and individual liberty, individual liberty shall prevail.

Article XXXIV — Drugs, Alcohol, and Medicine

Section 1. Principles of Bodily Autonomy, Medical Freedom, and Public Safety

The Republic recognizes control over one’s own body, consciousness, and medical care as a fundamental liberty inseparable from dignity and self-ownership.

The purposes of this Article are to:
a. protect bodily autonomy and informed adult choice;
b. prevent catastrophic harm and violent abuse;
c. dismantle criminal monopolies and regulatory cartels;
d. promote safety, transparency, and accountability without coercion.

No substance, treatment, or intervention shall be prohibited solely on grounds of moral disapproval, political controversy, institutional inertia, or economic protectionism.

Public safety shall be secured through disclosure, education, purity, and accountability — not blanket prohibition or artificial scarcity.


Section 1A. Recovery-First Care; Prohibition on State Street Enablement

Drug policy shall address substance use disorder with medical rigor, fairness to the public, and a clear aim of reducing dependency, preventing death, and restoring lawful, stable participation in civil life.

a. Recovery-First Purpose
Public programs concerning addiction shall be structured to reduce dependency, prevent death, and promote recovery and reintegration, rather than to normalize, subsidize, or perpetuate public intoxication.

b. Prohibition on Government Street Enablement and Government Dispensary Functions
The Republic and the States shall not operate, fund, advertise, or administer any Street Enablement Program. Without limitation, the Republic and the States shall not distribute intoxicating or dependence-forming substances, nor distribute Use-Paraphernalia, for Off-Site Use or other non-therapeutic private consumption.

This prohibition bars the government from acting as a dispensary for non-therapeutic consumption. It does not bar private entities from selling lawful goods under general law, including needles or substances not deemed too dangerous, nor does it bar licensing, inspection, taxation, or regulation of such private activity.

Terms in this Section shall have the meanings given in Article 0.

This subsection does not restrict prescription or issuance of medical devices or medications for Therapeutic Administration or other medically indicated treatment as defined in Article 0.

c. Protected Medical Care
Nothing in this Section restricts legitimate medical care. Licensed medical facilities and licensed clinicians may provide evidence-based treatment for substance use disorder, including medically supervised withdrawal, detoxification, tapering, medication-assisted treatment, and sedation when clinical judgment determines sedation is necessary and the least harmful option for safety or stabilization.

d. Controlled Setting Requirement
Nothing in subsection (b) prohibits therapeutic administration within a Controlled Setting. Where the Legislature authorizes publicly funded addiction-related services involving controlled substances or Use-Paraphernalia, such services shall occur only in a Controlled Setting, with clinical supervision, controlled access, secure storage, and secure disposal adequate to prevent diversion and to protect public order.

e. Evidence-Based Clinical Exception; Narrow Tailoring
The Legislature may authorize limited facility-based programs when high-quality evidence shows such programs reduce death or severe harm and improve recovery outcomes compared to a hard abstinence-only protocol. Such programs shall be narrowly tailored, audited, and shall not include take-home distribution unless issued as medical treatment by a clinician acting within lawful scope of practice.

f. Research Pilots; Sunset; Termination Triggers
The Legislature may authorize time-limited research pilots for disputed or emerging interventions. Each pilot shall include clear outcome metrics, independent evaluation, a fixed sunset, and termination triggers if the program increases public disorder, increases dependency, increases overdose, or fails to outperform the comparator standard of care.

g. Public Order and Shared Space
The Republic and the States shall protect the public’s right to safe and usable streets, parks, transit, and neighborhoods. Open consumption of intoxicants in Public Space may be prohibited by law, and enforcement shall prioritize diversion to stabilization and treatment rather than punitive measures for mere status.

h. Emergency Measures Preserved
This Section does not restrict emergency overdose reversal, acute medical stabilization, contamination alerts, truthful risk education, or other measures aimed at preventing immediate death while routing persons toward treatment and recovery.

i. Enforcement
Claims alleging operation or funding of a prohibited Street Enablement Program shall be justiciable, with standing and remedies governed by Article VI-A (Courts, Jurisdiction, and Remedies) and Article VI-E (Transparency, Standing, and Records). Implementing law shall provide expedited review.
Section 1B. Enforcement and Remedies for Section

(a) Standing.
Any resident of the Republic, any affected local government, and the Attorney General shall have standing to seek injunctive relief to halt any Government Dispensary Function or Street Enablement Program prohibited by this Article. The Legislature may define additional standing by petition threshold for Civic Citizens.

(b) Expedited Review; Injunction Standard.
Courts shall provide expedited review for claims under this Section. Upon a prima facie showing that a prohibited program operates or receives public funds, courts shall enjoin continuation pending full adjudication unless the government proves compliance by clear and convincing evidence.

(c) Funding Consequences; Contract Remedies.
Any public expenditure made in violation of this Article is unlawful. Courts may order termination of contracts, rescission of grants, suspension of disbursements, and recovery of unlawfully expended funds, together with such further relief as is necessary to prevent recurrence.

(d) Accountability.
Any public official who knowingly authorizes, directs, or materially facilitates a prohibited program commits an offense as defined by law. Good-faith reliance on written clinical protocols within a Controlled Setting, and compliance with independent audits, constitutes a rebuttable defense.

(e) Audit and Public Reporting Duty.
Any publicly funded addiction-related program shall publish periodic outcome and spillover reports using standardized metrics, including recovery outcomes and Public Disorder Metrics, sufficient for independent review. The Legislature shall require independent evaluation for any program operating under an evidence-based exception or research pilot.

(f) Whistleblower Protection.
No employee or contractor shall be punished for good-faith reporting of violations of this Article. Retaliation is prohibited and punishable as defined by law.
Section 2. Evidence-Based Classification of Substances

All substances regulated under this Article shall be classified by objective risk and demonstrated harm, not ideology, origin, or historical stigma.

Tier I — Low Risk Substances

Substances with well-established safety profiles and low risk of acute harm.

Access:
Lawful for adult purchase, possession, and use.
No prescription required.
May be dispensed by licensed pharmacies or lawful vendors.
Subject only to labeling, purity, and age restrictions.

Includes (non-exhaustive):
Common alcohols, caffeine analogs, botanicals, supplements, nootropics, mild performance enhancers.

Tier II — Moderate / Contextual Risk Substances

Substances with meaningful risks requiring informed use but not warranting prohibition.

Access:
Available to adults through licensed pharmacies.
Requires standardized risk disclosure and optional pharmacist counseling.
Education requirements may exist only to inform, not to delay or deny access.

No registry, prior authorization, or individualized permission shall be required.

Includes (non-exhaustive):
Hormones, peptides, SARMs, ivermectin, psychedelics, MDMA, certain stimulants, weak opioids.

Tier III — High / Catastrophic Risk Substances

Substances with extreme addiction potential, lethality, or weaponization risk.

Access:
Restricted to medical, scientific, or tightly controlled contexts.
May require physician oversight, secure handling, and post-use accountability.

Criminal penalties apply primarily to trafficking, adulteration, and violent misuse — not mere possession absent harm.

The Legislature bears the burden of demonstrating net harm exceeding benefit to classify or retain any substance as Tier III.

Section 3. Pharmacies, Compounding, and Professional Autonomy

Licensed pharmacies, including compounding pharmacies, are recognized as essential institutions of medical liberty and public health.

Accordingly:

a. Compounding pharmacies shall have the right to formulate, dispense, and customize lawful substances in response to patient demand without being subjected to industrial manufacturing standards.

b. No regulatory body may impose compliance costs, production thresholds, or procedural requirements designed to suppress non-industrial or personalized pharmaceutical practice.

c. Pharmacists may dispense Tier I and Tier II substances without a physician prescription where permitted under this Article and shall not incur liability for doing so when proper disclosure and labeling are provided.

d. Pharmacists retain professional discretion to refuse combinations or dosages that present imminent danger, but shall not deny lawful access on ideological, political, or institutional grounds.

e. Independent laboratories may test, assay, and publish purity and safety data for lawful substances without retaliation or suppression.

f. Off-label use, patient-directed experimentation, and individualized treatment shall be lawful where informed consent is present.

g. No authority may require patient registries, surveillance systems, or tracking databases for lawful substance use.

h. Education or counseling requirements shall not be structured, priced, or administered so as to function as denial, delay, or de facto prohibition.

i. Safety and quality standards shall be scaled proportionally to demonstrated risk and production volume and shall not be structured to exclude small, independent, or non-industrial actors.
j. Pharmacist and Dispenser Good-Faith Immunity
