Access shall be limited by age, credential, purpose, and supervision, and shall use the least restrictive controls consistent with victim protection and public safety.

When such material no longer retains evidentiary, investigative, or scientific value, the law may authorize destruction only by court order after notice, public logging, and certification that destruction will not impair any pending investigation, appeal, or bona fide research need. Destruction under this Section shall never serve ideological convenience, reputational protection, or political interest.

Section 8. Construction

This Article shall be interpreted liberally to favor disclosure, transparency, independent verification, and public accountability.

It shall be read in harmony with Article XXVI (Charter of Inviolable Rights) and enforced as a structural safeguard against secrecy as a mode of governance.

Section 9. Lock Designation

Pursuant to Article XV, the following principles of this Article are designated for lock protection:
	•	the presumption of openness;
	•	the burden on the State to justify secrecy by clear and convincing evidence;
	•	the prohibition on retroactive classification or destruction to evade accountability;
	•	the right of standing to enforce access and challenge obstruction.


Article Iv — The Legislative Branch

Charge

This Article establishes the composition, powers, procedures, limits, and accountability of the Legislative Branch of the Republic.

It defines how laws are proposed, debated, enacted, amended, and repealed, and it sets binding rules to prevent concentration of power, factional capture, secrecy, or circumvention of constitutional authority.

The Legislature exists to exercise lawmaking authority on behalf of the People subject to the supremacy of this Constitution, the rights secured in Article II, and the constraints imposed throughout this Charter.
Section 1. Vesting of Legislative Power

(a) Bicameral Legislature

The legislative power of the Republic is vested in a bicameral Legislature consisting of:
	•	the People’s House; and
	•	the Senate of the States.

No law shall be enacted except by passage through this Legislature or by lawful popular process as provided in this Article.

(b) Subordination to the Constitution and the People

All legislative authority is subordinate to:
	•	this Constitution;
	•	judicial review;
	•	executive veto as provided elsewhere; and
	•	the reserved sovereign powers of the People.

(c) Scope of Legislative Power

The Legislature shall enact laws only within the powers granted by this Constitution.

No statute shall be enacted for private benefit, factional advantage, or personal enrichment.

All legislation shall be enacted through public process, recorded votes, and procedures ensuring transparency, notice, and accountability.

(d) Hybrid Non-Delegation Doctrine

The Legislature may employ departments and experts to assist in administering the laws, but it may not delegate:
	•	the power to make binding rules of general applicability;
	•	the power to impose penalties of general applicability; or
	•	the power to define the scope, meaning, or application of rights.

No regulation, directive, or rule shall carry the force of law unless:
	•	the Legislature has authorized its subject matter;
	•	the Legislature has established clear boundaries within which it may be written; and
	•	the Legislature has approved the final rule, or permitted it to take effect under procedures established by statute that preserve legislative supremacy and judicial review.

(e) Prohibition on Administrative Lawmaking

Agencies may propose regulations, but may not create new obligations, redefine terms, expand authority, or manipulate constitutional meaning beyond limits set by Congress and the Constitution. Attempts to do so constitute constitutional overreach and are void.  Interpretive guidance, rulemaking, advisory opinions, or enforcement standards that effectively create binding obligations or expand statutory scope shall constitute unlawful lawmaking and are void.
(f) Emergency Legislation

In times of war or disaster, Congress may legislate with expedition but shall not abandon constitutional boundaries. Emergency statutes shall contain strict sunset provisions that expire when the emergency expires, and remain subject to judicial review. No emergency grants Congress powers not rooted in this Constitution.

(g) Supermajorities

All constitutional supermajority thresholds in this Article shall be sixty percent (60%) unless another Article expressly provides otherwise.

(h) Rule of Construction

This Section shall be construed to:
1. preserve the exclusive authority of the Legislature to make law;
2. prevent the exercise of legislative power by administrative or private bodies; and
3. enforce strict compliance with the non-delegation and approval requirements set forth herein.
Section 2. The People’s House

(a) Nature and Purpose

The People’s House serves as the primary drafting and deliberative body of the Republic. It exists to:
	•	translate public needs into law;
	•	refine proposals through debate;
	•	ensure constitutional compliance; and
	•	represent population-based civic interests.

(b) Composition and Electorate

Members of the People’s House shall be elected directly by Civic Citizens from population-based districts of approximately equal size, apportioned as provided herein.

(c) Apportionment Base

Apportionment shall be recalculated every ten years. Representation and districting shall count only:
	•	Civic Citizens; and
	•	the minor children of Civic Citizens, each counted as one full unit for apportionment.

Non-civic lawful residents, migrants, refugees, foreign nationals, and unlawful entrants shall not be counted for apportionment or districting.

(d) Non-Integer Apportionment and Minimum Representation

Non-integer apportionment outcomes shall be handled according to established proportional methods used at the time of adoption, as refined by statute. Each State shall receive not less than one seat.

(e) Membership and Odd-Number Requirement

The total number of seats in the People’s House shall always be an odd number. If apportionment yields an even number, one additional seat shall be added by law to preserve an odd total, apportioned under neutral rules consistent with this Constitution.

A default fixed membership of 331 Members may be established by statute as a stable baseline, provided that:
	•	the odd-number rule is preserved;
	•	each State retains a minimum of one seat;
	•	apportionment remains decennial; and
	•	any change to the fixed membership baseline requires a two-thirds (2/3) vote of each House.

(f) Legislative Functions

The People’s House may:
	•	introduce legislation;
	•	amend proposed laws;
	•	initiate appropriations;
	•	conduct investigations;
	•	draft articles of impeachment; and
	•	refer matters to popular vote where authorized.

The House shall not:
	•	exercise executive authority;
	•	appoint executive officers;
	•	command military or police forces; or
	•	insulate legislation from popular review.

(g) Qualifications

To stand for election, a candidate shall:
	•	be a Civic Citizen;
	•	have completed honorable service as required by the citizenship provisions of this Constitution;
	•	possess a record free from corruption, treachery, or grave moral offense;
	•	demonstrate knowledge of the Constitution; and
	•	reside within the district represented at the time of election.

(h) Term Length, Limits, Vacate-Rule, and Total Service Cap
	•	A full term in the People’s House is seven (7) years.
	•	No person may hold a seat in the People’s House for more than twenty-one (21) years total across the entire Legislature, as provided herein.
	•	A person may serve non-consecutive House terms and may seek election in a different district, provided that the Member vacates any House seat for one full term before holding any House seat again.
	•	The twenty-one-year cap is the controlling churn limit across both chambers.

(i) Staggered Elections and Transitional Alignment

Elections to the People’s House shall occur every two (2) years, with seats divided into election classes to ensure continuity and prevent total replacement in a single moment except by lawful recall. Initial transitional alignment and class assignments shall be established by statute.

(j) Election Integrity

Elections to the People’s House shall be free, fair, transparent, auditable, and uniform across the Republic. Foreign influence and partisan manipulation of district lines are prohibited.

(k) Vacancies and Interim Service
	•	States shall determine the process for filling vacancies in House seats and for maintaining the staggering structure, consistent with this Constitution and subject to judicial review for abuse.
	•	Where a special election would break staggering laws or destabilize the election-class system, appointment alone shall stand until the next lawful election window for that seat.
	•	States may appoint an initial representative to fill the interim two-year slot (or other transitional interval) until a regular election can occur consistent with staggering.
	•	Any appointment of less than half a term shall not count toward the twenty-one-year cap.

(l) Ethics and Conduct

Members shall act with humility and integrity. Bribery, foreign enrichment, insider trading, undisclosed compensation, self-dealing, and service to foreign interests are grave offenses, punishable by expulsion and permanent disqualification from office.

(m) Mandatory Direct Voting and Bill Familiarity
	•	Every Member must vote personally and directly. No Member may assign, delegate, or transfer voting power to any surrogate, proxy, or party officer.
	•	Every Member voting on a bill must be sufficiently familiar with the bill to answer questions in committee regarding its purpose, scope, costs, enforcement mechanism, and constitutional authority.
	•	Any systematic violation of this duty constitutes dereliction of office and may be grounds for censure, committee removal, or expulsion under law.

(n) Caucus Limits

Legislative caucuses are permitted only as temporary single-issue bodies.
	•	A caucus must state one issue in its charter.
	•	A caucus dissolves automatically upon resolution of the issue by enactment, defeat, expiration, or withdrawal.
	•	No caucus may persist as a permanent faction, mega-party, or shadow leadership structure.
	•	Parties may exist as election associations, but Congress shall not be governed through permanent caucus-machinery that bypasses transparency and individual accountability.

(o) Interpretation

The People’s House embodies the direct civic will of the Republic, derived from those who have earned citizenship and from the children who are being raised to bear its duties.
(p) Anti-Evasion of Legislative Structure
No chamber, caucus, committee, conference, leadership body, or procedural rule may be structured, renamed, or operated so as to evade, dilute, or reconstitute powers prohibited by this Article.

Internal rules of procedure are subject to constitutional review for compliance with this Article.

Section 3. The Senate of the States

(a) Nature

The Senate is the chamber of State representation within the national Legislature.

It exists to represent States as political units within the federal system and to exercise the powers assigned to it by this Constitution.

(b) Two Senators for Every State

Each State shall have two Senators as follows:
	•	one Senator appointed by the Governor of the State; and
	•	one Senator selected by the State Legislature.

Each Senator possesses one vote. No State may be deprived of representation.

(c) Third Senator Rule for the Most Populous States; Adjustable by Supermajority
	•	The ten most populous States, as determined by the same decennial apportionment used for the People’s House, shall each receive one additional Senator selected by a State Security Consortium.
	•	Congress may expand or contract the number of States eligible for a third Senator only by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of each House.
	•	No change may bypass the constitutional requirement that the Senate and the People’s House remain odd-numbered bodies.

(d) Odd-Number Senate Rule: Additional Senator to the 11th Most Populous State

To render tie votes extraordinarily rare, and to preserve an odd-numbered Senate, when the number of States is even, the eleventh (11th) most populous State shall receive one additional Senator.
	•	This additional Senator shall be selected by sortition from among qualified Civic Citizens of that State under procedures established by law and subject to judicial review.
	•	This Senator serves the same term length, ethics rules, and constitutional duties as all Senators.
	•	This provision is not an at-large seat and shall be tied strictly to the 11th most populous State at each decennial recalculation.

(e) State Security Consortium

The State Security Consortium shall consist of senior representatives chosen internally from:
	•	the State National Guard or military reserve;
	•	State and municipal law enforcement leadership; and
	•	fire, emergency medical, and disaster-response command.

Selection procedures shall:
	•	be transparent;
	•	exclude partisan officeholders;
	•	prohibit federal interference; and
	•	remain subject to judicial review.

(f) Term Length, Limits, Vacancies, and Total Service Cap
	•	A full term in the Senate is seven (7) years.
	•	No person may serve more than two (2) full Senate terms, subject always to the twenty-one-year total cap across the Legislature.
	•	States shall determine the process for filling Senate vacancies, including transitional appointments, consistent with this Constitution and judicial review for abuse.
	•	Any appointment of less than half a term shall not count toward the twenty-one-year cap.

(g) Qualifications

To serve in the Senate, a person shall:
	•	be a Civic Citizen;
	•	have completed honorable service as required by the citizenship provisions of this Constitution;
	•	possess a record free from corruption, treachery, or grave moral offense;
	•	demonstrate wisdom, prudence, and knowledge of constitutional governance; and
	•	maintain residency in the State represented.

(h) Duties and Limitations

The Senate shall:
	•	review, amend, approve, or reject legislation passed by the People’s House;
	•	provide advice and consent on judges and senior officers as defined elsewhere;
	•	ratify or reject treaties and international agreements;
	•	serve as a stabilizing force against tyranny of the majority; and
	•	conduct trials on Articles of Impeachment brought by the People’s House.

The Senate shall not originate legislation except where expressly permitted by this Constitution.

(i) Presiding Officer

The Vice President of the Republic shall serve as President of the Senate and shall cast a vote only in the case of a tie, consistent with the Executive Article. The Senate shall otherwise govern its debate and procedure independently.

(j) Ethics and Conduct

Senators shall maintain the highest standards of integrity and shall not accept bribes, gifts, foreign payments, or advantages for themselves or their families. Corruption is a grave offense and results in expulsion and permanent disqualification.
(k) Eligibility
Eligibility criteria and selection mechanisms under this Section shall be fixed by constitutional rule and may not be altered to advantage any faction, party, or officeholder.
(l) Rule of Construction

This Section shall be construed to:
1. preserve equal State representation as defined herein;
2. enforce the selection, term, and qualification requirements set forth in this Section; and
3. prevent any chamber, State, or officer from altering Senate composition or powers except by constitutional amendment.

Section 4. Legislative Process

(a) Passage of Laws

A bill becomes law only if:
	•	passed by a majority of the People’s House;
	•	passed by a majority of the Senate; and
	•	signed by the President or enacted over veto as provided elsewhere.

(b) Single-Subject Requirement

Every bill shall address only one subject clearly expressed in its title. No bill may contain riders, unrelated provisions, hidden appropriations, or ideological hostage-taking. Budget bills may not be used to enact criminal prohibitions, social policy, or regulatory changes unrelated to revenue and expenditure.

(c) Mandatory Public Notice

No bill may be voted upon unless its full text has been publicly posted for at least seventy-two hours, and every amendment has likewise been posted. Emergency bypass of this posting rule requires a two-thirds vote of each House and written public justification.

(d) Purity of Appropriations

Appropriations shall be single-purpose and confined strictly to the object stated. Hidden appropriations, omnibus packages, and backdoor funding are forbidden.

(e) Mandatory Budget and Essential Pay

Congress shall enact a full and transparent budget annually and may not adjourn for a new session until this duty is fulfilled. Under no circumstances may Congress permit:
	•	the military to go unpaid;
	•	essential personnel to go unpaid; or
	•	national defense to be impaired by failure to enact required appropriations.
Failure to provide these funds constitutes a violation of constitutional duty.
(f) Failure to Act
Failure to enact appropriations as required constitutes actionable constitutional violation subject to remedies under Section 11.

Section 5. Popular Legislative Power

(a) Popular Initiative

The People retain the sovereign right to introduce legislation directly.
	•	Initiation Threshold
A proposed statute shall be docketed upon verified petition signatures from not less than twenty percent (20%) of Civic Citizens nationwide. No geographic minimum shall be required for federal initiatives.
	•	Verification
Signature verification shall include:
	•	a non-invasive biometric identifier approved by statute and consistent with Article II (Informational Self-Determination and Bodily Autonomy); and
	•	a second verification method, such as a license or national digital identification.

Digital media may be used for collection and verification under secure national standards established by law.
	•	Time Window
A petition shall have a defined collection window of one (1) year. A failed petition may be attempted again without limit.
	•	Drafting and Review
Congress shall draft the initiative without adding, deleting, or altering any operative provision, definition, threshold, penalty, or enforcement mechanism except to convert the text into formal statutory language.
	•	Vote and Ballot Method
Initiatives reaching threshold shall be placed on a national ballot and shall pass only by sixty percent (60%) approval of Civic Citizens voting, by paper ballot.
	•	No Turnout Floor and National Voting Access
No turnout floor shall be required. A national day off shall be provided for non-essential labor to ensure voting access, with special provisions for essential employees.
	•	Duration and Renewal
Any initiative enacted by popular vote becomes federal law for ten (10) years. Renewal requires a majority (50%+1) approval by national ballot. Upon renewal, the law becomes permanent statutory law unless and until repealed by the Legislature or the People under this Article. Any effort to convert such a measure into a constitutional amendment must proceed through the amendment article provided elsewhere in this Constitution.

(b) Popular Veto of Legislative Acts

The People retain the sovereign right to veto legislation enacted by Congress.
	•	Petition
Upon verified petition by not less than ten percent (10%) of Civic Citizens within a statutory time period after enactment, the law shall be suspended and submitted to a national ballot.
	•	Vote
The law is void if rejected by sixty percent (60%) of Civic Citizens voting.
	•	Repeat Attempts
The People may attempt veto petitions again without limit, subject only to neutral procedural rules set by law.

(c) Popular Override of Legislative or Executive Blockage

A proposed law rejected by Congress or vetoed by the President may be enacted by the People by:
	•	Sixty percent (60%) national approval by paper ballot; and
	•	full constitutional review by the Supreme Court.

No turnout floor shall exist. Congress shall draft faithfully and may not sabotage the measure by delay, distortion, or insertion. The enacted measure shall follow the ten-year duration and renewal rules of subsection (a)(7).

(d) Limits on Popular Processes

Popular processes may not:
	•	violate enumerated rights;
	•	abolish separation of powers;
	•	establish caste or servitude;
	•	suspend judicial independence;
	•	entrench incumbents or eliminate future elections; or
	•	target individuals or groups by name.

(e) Judicial Safeguards

Courts shall certify procedural validity and constitutional compliance. Courts shall not review political merit or popularity.

Section 6. Transparency and Deliberation

(a) Public Proceedings and Archives

All legislative debates, votes, hearings, committee proceedings, and records shall be public and permanently archived.

(b) Closed Sessions: Narrow National Security Exception Only

Closed sessions may occur only for national security matters whose disclosure would pose a demonstrable and immediate risk to the safety of the nation. Closed sessions require written justification and remain subject to judicial review.

(c) Mandatory Declassification After Twenty-Five Years

All closed-session records shall be disclosed after twenty-five (25) years, unless a court finds that a specific continuing threat still looms. Continued sealing shall be time-limited, narrowly tailored, and periodically re-justified.

(d) Judicially Approved Withholding and the Censorship Test for Government Documents

Any censorship, redaction, withholding, or classification of legislative documents requires judicial approval under a strict test requiring clear and convincing evidence that disclosure would cause direct, immediate, and grave national harm. Withholding must be narrowly tailored, time-limited, and subject to appeal. This provision applies only to government documents and does not restrict private speech.

(e) No Omnibus Deception

No bill may contain unrelated provisions. Each law shall address a single subject.

(f) Real-Time Publication

Congress shall publish in real time:
	•	roll-call votes;
	•	bill texts and amendments;
	•	appropriations and contracts;
	•	committee summaries; and
	•	calendars and schedules.

(g) Whistleblower Protection

Whistleblowers who lawfully disclose corruption, abuse of classification, bribery, or grave public danger shall be protected. Retaliation is a high crime. 
Retaliation against a protected whistleblower constitutes a grave constitutional violation enforceable under this Constitution.

Section 7. Ethics, Corruption, or Discipline

(a) No Self-Dealing

Members shall not trade on insider knowledge, receive undisclosed compensation, serve foreign interests, or benefit personally from legislation.

(b) Prohibition on Lifetime or Inherited Office

No office under this Constitution shall be held for life, inherited, or converted into a permanent entitlement.
(c) Equality of Government Benefits

No law may grant legislators, officers, or their families benefits, exemptions, or protections not equally available to all persons under the same legal conditions. No officer or representative may exempt themselves or their children from conscription, service burdens, or wartime obligations borne by the People.

(d) Discipline for Corruption

Conviction of corruption, bribery, covert foreign enrichment, or grave abuse results in removal, permanent disqualification, and criminal prosecution.

Section 8. Recall, Removal, and Public Oversight
This Section is subject to the scope limitations, continuity requirements, and reconstitution obligations set forth in Article XVI-B.

(a) Recall of Individual Members

Members may be recalled by the People of their district or State under procedures established by State law and consistent with this Constitution and judicial review for abuse.

(b) National Recall of Congress

The People retain the ultimate authority to recall a Congress that has betrayed constitutional duties. 
National recall shall operate only as provided in this Section and shall not alter the regular election cycles, the bicameral structure of Congress, or the constitutional allocation of powers.
	•	Timing Rule
A national recall may occur at any time beginning two (2) years after a national legislative election.
	•	Petition Threshold
A national recall petition requires verified signatures from not less than ten percent (10%) of Civic Citizens nationwide.
	•	Recall Vote
A recall is enacted upon sixty percent (60%) approval by Civic Citizens voting.
	•	Effect
A successful national recall shall:
	•	vacate all seats in one chamber of Congress at a time, as specified in the recall petition;
	•	trigger immediate special elections for vacated House seats or lawful reselection or reappointment of Senators, as applicable;
	•	preserve constitutional continuity by preventing simultaneous dissolution of both chambers; and
	•	require reconstitution of legislative functions without interruption.

Where recall would otherwise eliminate an entire election class in the People’s House, each Governor shall appoint one interim Representative from their State to occupy the next expiring two-year class until the next regular election cycle, in order to preserve staggering and continuity.

No single recall petition or vote may dissolve both chambers of Congress simultaneously.
Implementation must occur within ninety days of certification.
	•	Non-Interference
Congress may enact neutral administrative procedures but may not obstruct, delay, penalize petitioners, or raise thresholds. Any interference constitutes constitutional malfeasance.

(c) Ethics Tribunal and Audits

An independent Congressional Ethics Tribunal shall investigate corruption, bribery, foreign influence, conflicts of interest, abuse of office, manipulation of procedure, and violations of transparency rules, and shall possess subpoena power. Congress shall undergo annual independent audits, with reports published in full.

(d) Independent Prosecution

Crimes committed by Members shall be prosecuted by independent prosecutors under constitutional procedures. No immunity exists for crimes under color of office.

(e) Public Performance Index

A public database shall record attendance, voting records, committee participation, sponsorship of bills, ethical findings, and financial disclosures.

Section 9. Lobbying Courts and Advocacy Rules

(a) Establishment of Lobbying Courts

Independent Lobbying Courts are established as the transparent venue for organized petitions for legislative favor, including requests for:
	•	new laws;
	•	amendments;
	•	regulatory changes;
	•	appropriations;
	•	tax modifications;
	•	trade exceptions; or
	•	any other legislative favor.
Lobbying Courts are transparency and disclosure forums, not criminal or civil courts, and exercise no adjudicative or punitive authority.
Participation does not restrict speech, petition, or advocacy, but conditions legislative access on public disclosure.
(b) Public Record

Proceedings shall be recorded, transcribed, and published within seven days. National security sealing is permitted only for matters that directly threaten the safety of the nation and must be judicially approved and time-limited.

(c) Filing Limits and Equal Access

Each organized petitioner shall be limited to one filing per week and two hours of hearing time, subject to neutral rules. The Courts shall maintain free access for individuals, civic groups, small businesses, and public-interest advocates.

(d) Small and Medium Business Advocate

A designated advocate office shall exist to assist small and medium businesses and other small organizations in navigating the Courts and presenting petitions fairly.

(e) Prohibition on Covert Influence

Outside of duly convened Lobbying Court proceedings, it is unlawful for Members, staffers, executive officers, or agency officials to accept secret payments, meet privately for legislative commitments, or conduct covert negotiations for legislative favors. Violations constitute corruption and grounds for removal and prosecution.

(f) Constituent Communications Preserved

Nothing in this Section prohibits ordinary constituent communication, including calls, letters, meetings in public venues, public forums, and public testimony, for expressing views or urging support or opposition, including lawful threats of recall. Organized requests for special legislative favors remain subject to the Lobbying Courts and transparency rules.

(g) Disclosure Requirements

Petitioners shall disclose funding sources, foreign ties, decision-makers, and beneficiaries. Shell structures to obscure influence are forbidden.

(h) Rule of Construction

This Section shall be construed to require public disclosure, recorded proceedings, and equal access for all petitioners seeking legislative favor, and to prohibit undisclosed, private, or covert legislative influence.
All popular remedies exercised under this Article are subject to the limitations and continuity requirements of Article XVI-B.

Section 10. Congressional Officers and Neutral Governance

(a) Non-Member Speaker of the People’s House

The People’s House shall elect a Speaker who is not a sitting Member of Congress. The Speaker shall be:
	•	a former President of the Republic or a Justice of the Supreme Court, as qualified by law;
	•	a neutral presiding authority;
	•	a non-voting officer; and
	•	responsible for maintaining order and constitutional procedure.

(b) Qualifications Reaffirmed

No person may serve as Speaker unless that person is:
	•	a former President of the Republic or a Justice of the Supreme Court (as specified herein);
	•	a Civic Citizen in good standing; and
	•	free from corruption, treachery, or grave moral offense.

(c) Term of the Speaker

The Speaker shall serve a term of two (2) years, synchronized to the House election cycle, and may be re-elected without limit, provided the Speaker remains qualified and is not a sitting Member of Congress.

(d) Election Timing

The People’s House shall elect the Speaker:
	•	at the first sitting of each newly seated People’s House following the regular House election cycle;
	•	within seven (7) days of a vacancy caused by removal, resignation, death, incapacity, or disqualification; and
	•	upon lawful restoration of Congress after dissolution, recall, or catastrophe.

(e) Election Procedure
	•	Election shall occur by open recorded vote of the People’s House.
	•	A candidate must receive a majority of seated Members to be elected.
	•	If no candidate receives a majority on the first ballot, additional ballots shall be held until a majority is achieved, and no ballot may be conducted by secret vote.
	•	The House may establish neutral procedural rules to manage ballots, provided those rules do not permit partisan officers or caucuses to control the outcome.

(f) Limits on the Speaker

The Speaker may not:
	•	whip votes;
	•	direct legislative outcomes;
	•	bury bills properly introduced;
	•	enforce partisan discipline; or
	•	participate in closed-door legislative bargaining.

The Speaker’s sole voting capacity, if any, shall be limited to administrative matters that do not affect passage or defeat of legislation, and shall be defined narrowly by law.

(g) Interim Presiding Officer

During a vacancy or temporary incapacity of the Speaker, the House Clerk shall preside for ministerial purposes only, including the administration of Speaker elections, and shall possess no authority to schedule, block, or influence legislation.

(h) Removal

The House may remove the Speaker at any time by majority vote. The Speaker may also be removed for corruption or constitutional violation under procedures established by law and judicial review.

(i) Rule of Construction

This Section shall be construed to enforce the neutrality, non-partisanship, and procedural limits of the Speaker as set forth herein.

Section 11. Judicial Remedies for Legislative Failure

(a) Standard of Proof

Judicial enforcement under this Section requires clear and convincing evidence.

(b) Justiciable Duties

The Supreme Court may declare Congress in contempt of the Constitution and order Congress to convene and vote where Congress:
	•	fails to pass a lawful budget;
	•	allows unconstitutional war-making or unconstitutional emergency extensions to persist;
	•	refuses to perform mandatory constitutional duties; or
	•	obstructs constitutionally required transparency.

Judges may review the constitutionality of budgets and may approve or deny judicially requested censorship, redaction, or withholding of government documents under the censorship test described herein. Courts may not control policy discretion, substitute political judgment, or dictate legislative outcomes.

(c) Justiciability Override

Compliance with the duties imposed by this Article constitutes a constitutional obligation, not a political question.

Courts of the Republic shall have jurisdiction to compel compliance with procedural duties herein and may not decline review on grounds of discretion, internal legislative governance, or political question doctrine.

Each chamber retains plenary constitutional authority to structure its officers, and such authority is not limited by historical practice or membership status.

(d) Rule of Construction

This Section shall be construed to authorize judicial enforcement of mandatory constitutional duties set forth in this Article, and to prohibit courts from issuing orders that determine the substantive content of legislation.

Section 12. Non-Delegation and Administrative Restraint

(a) Legislative power shall not be delegated to administrative or executive bodies except for narrowly defined, temporally bounded, and ministerial functions governed by an intelligible principle set forth by statute.

(b) No agency or administrative body may promulgate rules of general applicability carrying the force of law absent explicit and express legislative authorization.

(c) Delegations of authority involving major questions of political, economic, social, or civil consequence—including those with vast economic impact, novel regulatory frameworks, or effects upon fundamental rights—are presumed invalid unless unmistakably authorized by statute.

(d) All delegations of rulemaking authority with legal force shall sunset automatically after five years unless affirmatively reauthorized by law.

(e) Broad, open-ended, implied, or self-extending delegations are void.

Section 13. Government Self-Binding and Equal Application of Law

(a) All laws of general application enacted pursuant to this Constitution shall bind public officials, legislators, judges, executive officers, and governmental entities equally with the public.

(b) No officeholder, agency, or branch of government shall exempt itself from compliance with laws of general application.

(c) Any statute or regulation conferring exemption, immunity, privilege, or special advantage upon public officials or their immediate associates is void.

(d) Changes to compensation, benefits, immunities, or privileges applicable to officeholders shall not take effect until after an intervening election or term of office, as applicable.

(e) Violations of this Section constitute breaches of public trust and may give rise to removal, impeachment, or other lawful sanction.


Section 14. Rule of Construction

This Article shall be construed to:
(a) preserve the bicameral structure and separation of powers established herein;
(b) enforce the procedural, transparency, non-delegation, and anti-capture requirements of this Article;
(c) prevent evasion of legislative limits through procedural manipulation, emergency powers, or administrative proxy; and
(d) ensure that lawmaking authority remains accountable to the People under this Constitution.
Section 15. Article IV Lock Designation and Anti-Evasion Clause

Pursuant to Article XV (Amendments, Lock Clauses, and Anti-Emergency Drift), Article IV — The Legislature is hereby designated as LOCK-PROTECTED.

This designation reflects the deliberate judgment of the People that the legislative power is the most capture-prone authority in any republic and therefore must be constrained by explicit structure, enforceable duty, and judicially reviewable limits.

Section A. Scope of Lock

This Lock applies to the entirety of Article IV, including but not limited to:
	•	the composition, organization, and authority of the Legislature;
	•	limits on delegation, administrative rulemaking, and interpretive authority;
	•	legislative procedures, notice requirements, budgetary duties, and voting obligations;
	•	transparency, declassification, and lobbying disclosure mechanisms;
	•	popular legislative powers, recall provisions, and judicial remedies for legislative failure.

No provision of Article IV shall be repealed, suspended, weakened, narrowed, expanded by implication, or rendered ineffectual except in strict conformity with this Lock Declaration.

Section B. Prohibited Forms of Alteration

The following are expressly prohibited with respect to Article IV:
	•	reclassification of constitutional legislative duties as discretionary, internal, advisory, or non-justiciable;
	•	circumvention of structural limits through internal rules, caucuses, conferences, informal coordination bodies, or renamed procedures;
	•	delegation of lawmaking authority to administrative bodies through interpretation, guidance, enforcement standards, or rulemaking in substance if not in name;
	•	suspension or evasion of legislative obligations by emergency declaration, necessity claims, or institutional convenience;
	•	judicial reinterpretation that restores doctrines of deference, political question abstention, or implied legislative immunity barred by this Constitution.

Any attempt to effect such alteration by statute, regulation, executive action, judicial doctrine, or intergovernmental agreement is void ab initio.

Section C. Permitted Amendments (Narrow Exception)

Amendment to Article IV may occur only for the purpose of:
	•	clarifying internal consistency, definitions, or cross-article coordination without reducing substantive limits or duties;
	•	strengthening transparency, accountability, or enforcement mechanisms;
	•	addressing newly discovered methods of legislative evasion, capture, or procedural laundering.

No amendment may:
	•	expand legislative discretion beyond constitutional bounds;
	•	restore administrative lawmaking authority;
	•	weaken judicial remedies for legislative failure;
	•	diminish popular override or recall mechanisms;
	•	reduce notice, voting, or budgetary obligations.

Section D. Amendment Threshold

Any amendment to Article IV shall require all of the following:
	•	approval by a supermajority of both chambers of the Legislature, as defined in Article XV;
	•	certification by the Supreme Court of the Republic that the amendment does not restore prohibited doctrines, expand legislative immunity, or dilute enforceable duties;
	•	independent review by the Constitutional Judicial Commission (CJC) affirming absence of self-dealing, institutional capture, or procedural manipulation;
	•	ratification by the People, under procedures no less rigorous than those required for original constitutional adoption.

Failure to satisfy any requirement shall invalidate the amendment in its entirety.

Section E. Anti-Backsliding Rule

No amendment, statute, regulation, or judicial interpretation adopted after ratification of this Lock shall be construed to:
	•	convert enforceable legislative duties into discretionary acts;
	•	insulate legislative procedures from constitutional review;
	•	reintroduce administrative lawmaking through indirection;
	•	weaken popular oversight, recall, or transparency mechanisms.

Where conflict exists, Article IV shall control.

Section F. Judicial and Legislative Duty

All courts and legislative bodies of the Republic are bound to:
	•	enforce Article IV as written;
	•	compel compliance with its procedural duties where violated;
	•	resolve ambiguities against expansion of legislative power and in favor of accountability.

Failure by any court, legislator, or legislative officer to honor this Lock constitutes constitutional misconduct.

Section G. Declaration of Legislative Intent

This Lock affirms that legislative power exists to deliberate, decide, and be accountable — not to evade responsibility, delegate authority, or govern by omission.

The People therefore place Article IV beyond erosion by faction, inertia, emergency, or self-interest.


Article XL — Energy, Abundance, and National Resilience

Charge — Article XL: Energy, Abundance, and National Resilience

The modern energy system is a grotesque monument to state capture, cronyism, and deliberate scarcity—a sclerotic regime that feeds on subsidies, smothers innovation with red tape, and condemns the People to high prices, fragility, and dependence. What should be abundant and inexpensive has been rendered artificial and costly by the very governments that claim to protect the public interest.

As Thomas Sowell observed, “The first lesson of economics is scarcity: there is never enough of anything to satisfy all those who want it. The first lesson of politics is to disregard the first lesson of economics.” Modern energy policy exemplifies this error. Real scarcity is ignored while artificial scarcity is imposed—through subsidies that pick winners, regulations that strangle competitors, and emergency powers that entrench failure. Energy poverty is repackaged as virtue; dependence is sold as security.

Ron Paul stated the principle plainly: “The government shouldn’t be in the business of subsidizing any form of energy.” Yet today, vast public resources flow to favored interests—legacy producers, ideological programs, and politically connected intermediaries—while genuine innovators are buried beneath permitting delays, mandates, and compliance mazes. This is not a free market. It is mercantilism under a moral pretext: socialism for the connected, austerity for the public.

Engineers of abundance remind us that reality, not bureaucracy, produces power. As Elon Musk has remarked, the greatest energy source already exists at planetary scale, and progress comes from harnessing what works—not from chasing prestige projects, subsidized illusions, or administratively designed outcomes. Abundance is achieved by aligning with physics, economics, and evidence—not by decree.

Javier Milei has warned of the tools by which states come to dominate society: “With tools such as printing money, debt, subsidies, price controls, and regulations to correct so-called market failures, they can control the lives and fates of millions of individuals.” Energy policy has become one of the most potent of these instruments—used to redistribute wealth upward, enforce dependence downward, and cloak control in the language of necessity.

This Republic rejects the empire of enforced scarcity. It rejects subsidies, mandates, regulatory cartels, and emergency pretexts that convert the lifeblood of civilization into a lever of coercion. Energy abundance is not a luxury; it is the natural outcome of liberty, innovation, competition, and evidence. Anything less is a betrayal of the People and a surrender to administrative rule.

Accordingly, this Article stands as a bulwark: private initiative first; technology neutrality absolute; subsidies forbidden; regulatory obstruction dismantled; and civilization-scale breakthroughs encouraged through voluntary incentives alone. Let markets, not mandarins, deliver the power that sustains freedom. No more excuses. No more chains.

Energy abundance—or decline.


Section 1. Principle of Energy Abundance
 🔒
The Republic recognizes access to reliable, affordable, and sufficient energy as a foundational condition of economic vitality, public welfare, and national security.

Public policy shall favor energy abundance over enforced scarcity, except where temporary restraint is demonstrably necessary to prevent material harm, catastrophic failure, or system collapse.

Energy scarcity imposed by design, ideology, administrative convenience, or regulatory obstruction is forbidden.

Section 2. Primacy of Private Initiative
The production, innovation, ownership, and distribution of energy shall, as a default rule, be open to private individuals, cooperatives, and enterprises operating lawfully within the Republic.

Private energy generation—including decentralized, off-grid, experimental, and self-provisioned systems—is presumptively lawful.

The State shall not monopolize energy production, control pricing or allocation, suppress private innovation, or restrict lawful energy development absent clear and convincing evidence of material harm or systemic risk.

Section 3. Technology Neutrality and Deregulatory Mandate
 🔒
Energy policy shall be:

a. technology-neutral;
b. grounded in empirical evidence, reproducible analysis, and transparent risk assessment;
c. open to continuous innovation, improvement, and replacement.

No energy source—solar, nuclear, fossil, geothermal, synthetic, or novel—shall be prohibited, penalized, subsidized, or favored by ideology, asserted consensus, or political narrative.

Regulatory barriers that materially obstruct private energy development, deployment, or modernization shall be removed unless the State demonstrates, by clear and convincing evidence, that such barriers are necessary to prevent concrete harm.

Section 4. Limited Public Works Authority (Exceptional and Temporary)

Where private provision is demonstrably incapable of meeting essential national needs due to scale, security, or catastrophic vulnerability—and where deregulation alone is insufficient—the Republic may act directly as a measure of last resort.

Any public construction or operation of energy infrastructure shall require:

a. express statutory authorization;
b. written findings of demonstrated necessity;
c. full transparency and audit;
d. automatic sunset not exceeding five (5) years, absent supermajority renewal.

Public energy works shall not crowd out private enterprise, entrench obsolete systems, or persist once private provision becomes feasible.

Section 5. Corps of Engineers and Critical Infrastructure

Congress may authorize the Corps of Engineers or successor public works bodies to design or construct energy infrastructure only where:

a. national defense, disaster resilience, or grid survival so require;
b. failure to act would impose unacceptable risk to life or sovereignty;
c. private actors cannot reasonably perform the work in time or at scale.

Such authority shall be strictly limited, temporary, and shall not include pricing control, permanent operation, or market exclusion.

Section 6. Environmental and Human Balance

Energy development shall be governed consistently with:

a. Article IX (Land, Homesteading, and Agricultural Duty);
b. Article XXXVII (Environmental and Ecological Stewardship);
c. Article VIII (Economic Structure and Stewardship).

Environmental protection shall be evidence-based and proportional, and shall not serve as a pretext for energy deprivation, permanent austerity, or indirect control of the population.

Section 7. Austerity and Emergency Limitations
 🔒

Energy rationing, compulsory reduction, or enforced austerity may occur only where:

a. material scarcity or imminent system collapse is demonstrated by clear and convincing evidence;
b. measures are temporary, narrowly tailored, and judicially reviewable;
c. no less restrictive alternative can reasonably achieve the same protection.

Permanent emergency framing of energy governance is prohibited.

Section 8. Breakthrough Energy: Incentives, Disclosure, and Sunset

Where a method of energy generation is demonstrated to be civilization-scale in impact—capable of materially eliminating energy scarcity through abundance—the Republic shall encourage its disclosure and deployment through voluntary incentives rather than compulsion.

Congress may provide for statutory frameworks that:

a. offer substantial prizes, bounties, or guaranteed public procurement contracts for disclosure and deployment;
b. encourage voluntary licensing on fair and reasonable terms;
c. protect inventors against suppression, sabotage, or foreign capture.

Any such framework shall be evidence-based, non-punitive, and non-coercive, and may include:

d. optional shortened periods of exclusive rights;
e. optional post-recoupment licensing incentives, triggered only after demonstrable recovery of development costs and reasonable profit;
f. eventual public-domain release after defined temporal or economic thresholds, where continued exclusivity no longer serves innovation or public benefit.

No individual or entity shall be compelled to deploy, license, or surrender energy technology absent voluntary agreement or judicial finding of fraud, suppression, or unlawful restraint of trade.

Section 9. Anti-Subsidy and Anti-Cronyism Rule
 🔒

No subsidies, tax preferences, loan guarantees, or preferential financing shall be granted to any energy source or producer.

Public funds may be used only for neutral prizes, open procurement, or temporary public works authorized under Sections 4 or 5.

Cronyism, capture, and artificial market distortion are forbidden.

Section 10. Construction

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. favor abundance, resilience, and innovation over scarcity and stagnation;
b. preserve maximum private liberty consistent with national survival;
c. reject ideological or technocratic capture of energy policy;
d. bind the State to the same standards of evidence, proportionality, and restraint imposed upon the People;
e. permit any person or enterprise with standing to challenge regulatory obstruction, unreasonable delay, or denial of lawful energy development as a form of artificial scarcity, subject to evidentiary standards and judicial review consistent with this Constitution.

Pursuant to Article XV, the following provisions of Article XL — Energy, Abundance, and National Resilience are hereby designated Lock-Protected Provisions. These provisions may not be amended, repealed, suspended, or reinterpreted except by the supermajority and procedural safeguards specified in Article XV.

🔒 
Article XL — Lock-Protected Provisions
	•	Section 1 — Principle of Energy Abundance 🔒
Rationale:
To permanently prohibit enforced energy scarcity, austerity by design, ideological deprivation, and regulatory obstruction of energy essential to liberty, prosperity, and national survival.
	•	Section 3 — Technology Neutrality and Deregulatory Mandate 🔒
Rationale:
To constitutionally forbid ideological favoritism, narrative-based energy policy, and regulatory suppression of lawful private energy development absent clear and convincing evidence of concrete harm.
	•	Section 7 — Austerity and Emergency Limitations 🔒
Rationale:
To prevent energy emergencies from becoming permanent governance regimes or instruments of coercive control.
	•	Section 9 — Anti-Subsidy and Anti-Cronyism Rule 🔒
Rationale:
To permanently bar subsidies, tax preferences, loan guarantees, preferential financing, and captured energy markets regardless of technology, political fashion, or asserted necessity.

All other provisions of Article XL remain amendable under ordinary constitutional procedures and are expressly excluded from lock protection.


Article XLI — Patents, Knowledge, and the Public Commons

Charge

The modern intellectual property regime has become a bloated instrument of rent-seeking and stagnation—patent thickets that entrench incumbents, evergreening that delays competition, and endless litigation that rewards lawyers over inventors. What began as a tool to reward disclosure and risk has too often morphed into permanent monopolies that bury knowledge, raise prices, and slow progress.

Yet the core idea—temporary, disclosure-based privileges to encourage creation and investment—has merit. As Ayn Rand argued, the law may recognize the contribution of the mind by granting a limited window to recoup costs and profit from original effort, provided the knowledge is fully disclosed for others to build upon.

Thomas Sowell reminds us that politics disregards scarcity—and when it comes to non-scarce ideas, politicians and cronies have imposed artificial scarcity to favor the connected. Elon Musk exposed the system’s flaws by open-sourcing Tesla’s patents, demonstrating that innovation often thrives on speed, talent, and openness rather than government-granted monopolies. Even critics such as Stephan Kinsella, who reject intellectual property outright, highlight how the present system distorts markets and punishes peaceful imitation. Javier Milei’s attack on state-granted privileges echoes the same truth: artificial barriers that entrench power must fall.

This Republic rejects perpetual enclosure and suppression. Intellectual property is a limited tool—not a natural right, not eternal, and not a license to hoard. It exists to incentivize disclosure and reward risk, then yields to the public commons. Creators shall receive real, time-bound protection; the People shall inherit the knowledge that advances civilization.

Innovation belongs to those who create and share, not those who litigate and lobby. The future is built on open progress—guarded incentives, not ironclad monopolies.

Section 1. Principle of Instrumental Intellectual Property

Intellectual property, including patents and related exclusive rights, is not a natural right inherent to persons or entities.

Such rights exist solely as temporary legal privileges, granted by the Republic for the limited purpose of encouraging disclosure, innovation, investment, and the advancement of knowledge for the eventual benefit of the People.

No grant of intellectual property shall be construed as perpetual, absolute, or immune from limitation, convergence, or termination in the public interest, as governed by this Constitution.

Section 2. Disclosure as the Condition of Protection

Exclusive intellectual property protection shall be conditioned upon full, truthful, and sufficient public disclosure of the protected invention, method, or process.

No person or entity may simultaneously claim exclusive rights while withholding, obscuring, fragmenting, or strategically concealing essential information necessary for understanding, replication, evaluation, or future improvement of the protected subject matter.

All disclosures required under this Article are incorporated within and subject to the archival, access, preservation, and anti-suppression duties established in Article X (Knowledge, Technology, and the Digital Commons).

Failure to disclose as required shall render any claimed exclusivity voidable or unenforceable, subject to judicial determination.

Section 3. Duration, Recoupment, and Convergence

Exclusive intellectual property protections shall be limited in duration and structured to permit reasonable opportunity for recoupment of development costs and profit, without enabling permanent control, hoarding, or suppression of knowledge.

Congress may establish statutory frameworks that:

a. define finite periods of exclusivity proportionate to the nature, risk, and cost of development;
b. recognize earlier convergence where public funding, civilization-scale impact, or rapid cost recovery is demonstrated;
c. provide for voluntary licensing incentives following recoupment of reasonable investment and profit;
d. ensure that, upon expiration or termination, protected knowledge transitions into the public commons.

All intellectual property granted under this Article remains subject to the mandatory convergence, preservation, and public-access provisions of Article X, including acceleration or termination upon abandonment, dissolution, suppression, or abuse.

No alteration of exclusivity shall apply retroactively to vested grants absent just compensation or voluntary assent.

Section 4. Archival Preservation and Knowledge Continuity

All inventions, processes, methods, schematics, source materials, and supporting documentation disclosed pursuant to this Article shall be preserved in a secure, durable, and publicly accountable archival system, as governed by Article X (Knowledge, Technology, and the Digital Commons).

Such preservation shall ensure:

a. long-term integrity, accessibility, and readability;
b. protection against loss, destruction, manipulation, or strategic disappearance;
c. continuity of knowledge across generations, institutions, and technological transitions.

No grant of intellectual property shall exempt the holder from archival obligations imposed by Article X.

Section 5. Suppression, Shelving, and Abuse of Privilege

Intellectual property privileges shall not be used to suppress, bury, delay, or strategically withhold knowledge whose disclosure would materially advance scientific understanding, public welfare, or civilizational capacity.

Abuse of privilege includes, but is not limited to:

a. acquisition of exclusive rights for the primary purpose of non-use or delay;
b. defensive patenting intended to prevent deployment or competition without bona fide development;
c. fragmentation of disclosures to obscure functional understanding;
d. contractual or licensing schemes designed to evade convergence to the public commons.

Findings of suppression or abuse under this Article shall require clear and convincing evidence and may result in limitation, termination, or acceleration of convergence, consistent with Article X enforcement standards and subject to judicial review.

Any person or enterprise with standing may seek judicial relief against suppression, shelving, or abuse of intellectual property privileges, subject to evidentiary standards consistent with this Constitution.

Section 6. Patent Office Stewardship and Anti-Capture Constraints

The Patent Office or successor authority shall function solely as a registrar, archivist, and steward of disclosure, and not as a gatekeeper of innovation, industrial policy actor, or market participant.

Its duties shall be limited to:

a. registering disclosures and claims of exclusivity;
b. ensuring compliance with disclosure and archival requirements;
c. recording statutory triggers for expiration, convergence, or termination.

The Patent Office shall be subject to strict transparency, conflict-of-interest, and anti-capture rules, consistent with Articles X and XI, and shall not exercise discretionary authority to favor, suppress, delay, or condition innovation beyond mechanical compliance with law.

Section 7. Public Funding, Research, and Accelerated Convergence

Where research, development, or innovation is funded in whole or in part by public resources, any resulting intellectual property shall be subject to accelerated convergence to the public commons.

Congress may provide by law that publicly funded or publicly commissioned innovations:

a. receive reduced periods of exclusivity;
b. require broader disclosure obligations at earlier stages;
c. transition to the public commons upon recoupment of reasonable private investment, where applicable.

Public funding shall not be used to create permanent monopolies, proprietary choke points, or exclusive control over knowledge whose development was materially supported by the People.

No alteration of exclusivity arising under this Section shall apply retroactively to vested grants absent just compensation or voluntary assent.

Section 8. Public Records, Access, and Auditability

All intellectual property disclosures, registrations, archival materials, and convergence determinations under this Article shall constitute public records, subject to access, inspection, and audit consistent with Article XXXIX (Records Access) and Article X (Knowledge, Technology, and the Digital Commons).

Limitations on access may be permitted only where narrowly necessary to protect:

a. legitimate national security interests;
b. personal privacy unrelated to the protected subject matter;
c. temporary competitive confidentiality expressly authorized by law.

Such limitations shall be construed narrowly and shall not be used to conceal suppression, abuse, capture, or evasion of convergence.

Section 9. Construction

This Article shall be interpreted to:

a. favor disclosure, competition, and innovation over secrecy and rent-seeking;
b. ensure that intellectual property serves the public good rather than private enclosure;
c. prevent permanent monopolization or suppression of civilization-advancing knowledge;
d. preserve incentives for creation while guaranteeing eventual convergence to the public commons;
e. permit private parties with standing to enforce the prohibitions of this Article through judicial process;
f. operate in harmony with Articles X, XI, and XXXIX, which govern knowledge stewardship, anti-capture safeguards, and public records.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to require the continuation of any intellectual property regime beyond such time as the People, through their representatives, determine that such privileges are no longer necessary to incentivize innovation.

Article XLI — Lock-Protected Provisions

(Pursuant to Article XV)

Pursuant to Article XV (Amendment and Lock Clauses), the following provisions of Article XLI — Patents, Knowledge, and the Public Commons are hereby designated Lock-Protected Provisions. These provisions may not be amended, repealed, suspended, or reinterpreted except by the supermajority procedures and safeguards specified in Article XV.

🔒 
Section 1 — Principle of Instrumental Intellectual Property

Lock Scope: Entire Section.

Rationale:
To permanently affirm that intellectual property is a temporary legal privilege granted for public benefit, not a natural, inherent, or perpetual right, and to foreclose constitutional reinterpretation treating ideas, discoveries, or methods as homesteadable property.

🔒 
Section 2 — Disclosure as the Condition of Protection

Lock Scope: Entire Section.

Rationale:
To constitutionally require full, truthful, and sufficient disclosure as the price of exclusivity, preventing secrecy, fragmentation, concealment, or strategic obscuring of knowledge under color of monopoly.

🔒 
Principle of Inevitable Convergence to the Public Commons

Lock Scope:
The governing principle derived from Sections 3, 5, and 7, that all intellectual property protections are temporary and must ultimately terminate or converge into the public commons.

Rationale:
To permanently prohibit eternal enclosure of civilization-advancing knowledge and to ensure that intellectual property privileges serve innovation only for a limited time before yielding to public access and use.

🔒 
Section 5 — Prohibition on Suppression, Shelving, and Abuse of Privilege

Lock Scope: Entire Section.

Rationale:
To permanently forbid the use of intellectual property privileges to suppress, bury, delay, shelve, or strategically withhold knowledge for anti-competitive, coercive, or rent-seeking purposes, subject to evidentiary standards and judicial review.

🔒 
Right of Standing for Enforcement

Lock Scope:
The provisions establishing standing for private parties to seek judicial relief against suppression, shelving, abuse, or evasion of convergence, as set forth in Sections 5 and 9.

Rationale:
To guarantee enforceability through judicial process and prevent institutional capture, agency paralysis, or selective non-enforcement of constitutional knowledge protections.

🔒 
Non-Entrenchment of Intellectual Property Regimes

Lock Scope:
The final sentence of Section 9, providing that no intellectual property regime is constitutionally required to persist indefinitely.

Rationale:
To clarify that this Constitution does not mandate the permanent existence of any patent or intellectual property system and preserves the authority of the People, through their representatives, to abolish or replace such regimes where incentives are no longer necessary.


Article XLII — Freedom of Communication

Charge
The modern censorship regime is tyranny in digital form: surveillance that chills speech, compelled platform control that launders censorship through intermediaries, and pretextual regulation—invoking safety, democracy, or stability—to govern discourse rather than conduct.

When the State claims authority over truth, liberty collapses. Mass surveillance breeds self-censorship; compelled moderation converts private platforms into instruments of control; and “misinformation” becomes a weapon to silence dissent instead of confront error.

Free societies depend on the ability of individuals to speak, listen, assemble, and associate without permission. Encrypted and anonymous communication is not a threat to self-government; it is a prerequisite for it.

This Republic rejects prior restraint, compelled mediation, mass surveillance, and encryption sabotage. Criminal acts may be punished, but communication itself shall not be pre-emptively governed, filtered, or coerced. Let the People speak, listen, organize, and decide—freely and without fear.

Section 1. Broad Protection of Communication

No law shall abridge the freedom of speech, expression, press, assembly, petition, or any form of communication, including electronic, encrypted, anonymous, or broadcast forms, whether public or private.

These protections apply regardless of medium, technology, platform, or method of transmission, present or future.

Section 2. No Prior Restraint; No Compelled Mediation

Prior restraint on communication is prohibited.

No person, platform, network, or intermediary shall be compelled to censor, moderate, amplify, demote, label, or otherwise mediate content absent a specific judicial order addressing proven, particularized harm attributable to identified actors.

General mandates, algorithmic filtering, or blanket content controls are forbidden.

Section 3. Encryption, Anonymity, and Private Association

The right to private, encrypted communication and anonymous expression is inviolable.

No law shall require encryption backdoors, key escrow, mandatory identification to speak, real-name requirements, or systemic weakening of privacy or security for the general public.

The State shall not condition access to communication networks on identity disclosure or viewpoint compliance.

Section 4. Surveillance Limits

Mass, bulk, or warrantless surveillance of communications is prohibited.

Targeted surveillance may occur only pursuant to a judicial warrant based on probable cause of a specific crime, describing with particularity the person, scope, and duration. Surveillance based on thought, belief, association, or lawful expression is forbidden.

Section 5. Platform Neutrality and State Action

Private platforms may set their own terms and exercise editorial discretion.

However, when a platform functions as a common carrier, receives material government compulsion or direction, or acts in concert with the State, it shall not discriminate or impose restrictions based on viewpoint, lawful political content, or identity.

The State may not evade this Article by outsourcing censorship, moderation, or surveillance to private actors.

The State shall not grant, condition, revoke, or threaten immunity, liability protection, regulatory forbearance, funding, or preferential treatment based on a platform’s willingness to censor, surveil, or moderate lawful communication on behalf of the State.

Section 6. Narrow Carveouts for Criminal Harm (Strictly Limited)

Nothing in this Article prevents post-facto enforcement against criminal acts committed through communication, provided that all safeguards below are met:

(a) Imminent, Specific Harm

Intervention is permitted only to address direct incitement, true threats, or coordination of imminent lawless action toward identifiable victims, supported by clear and convincing evidence, and subject to judicial order or immediate judicial review.

(b) Crimes Against Children

Material constituting evidence of child exploitation may be investigated and prosecuted as criminal conduct, not as protected expression, without mandating general-purpose scanning, platform-wide monitoring, or the weakening of encryption, anonymity, or security for the general public. Enforcement shall proceed only through targeted warrants, individualized investigations, and judicially supervised process.

(c) Fraud, Coercion, and Criminal Conspiracy

Speech integral to fraud, extortion, trafficking, or criminal conspiracy may be prosecuted after the fact based on acts and intent, without prior restraint or generalized monitoring.

Section 7. Prohibited Pretexts

The following shall never justify restraint, surveillance, or compelled mediation of communication:
	•	Claims of “misinformation” or “disinformation” absent specific criminal acts;
	•	“Hate” or offensive expression absent direct, imminent threats;
	•	Public order, democratic stability, foreign influence, or ideological harm;
	•	Health, safety, or national security narratives lacking individualized warrants and evidence.
Section 7B. Prohibition on Speech-Crimes of Mere Dissent

(a) Core Rule.
No law shall criminalize, penalize, or create civil disability for speech or expressive conduct solely because it:
    1. criticizes, condemns, mocks, or satirizes the Republic, a State, any public institution, any public officer, any political party, or any public policy;
    2. disputes official narratives, official statistics, official communications, or claims of governmental legitimacy, competence, or morality; or
    3. expresses opposition to war, military action, foreign policy, policing, taxation, regulation, or any other exercise of public power.

(b) Forbidden Labels and Vagueness.
No person shall be prosecuted or punished under vague, elastic, or status-based speech categories, including “discrediting,” “fake news,” “harmful misinformation,” “anti-state propaganda,” “extremism,” “radicalization,” “hate,” or similar labels, unless the State proves each element of a defined criminal offense with particularity under subsection (c).

(c) Narrow Exception for Direct Criminal Instrumentality.
Speech may be restricted or punished only where the government proves, by clear and convincing evidence:
    1. specific intent (mens rea) to cause or materially facilitate a defined criminal act;
    2. a direct and proximate causal connection between the expression and that criminal act; and
    3. imminence and likelihood of the criminal act, not speculative or generalized risk.
Mere falsity, error, controversial opinion, moral offense, institutional embarrassment, or political inconvenience shall never suffice.

(d) Prior Restraint and Orders.
No injunction, censorship order, compelled deletion, compelled labeling, or compelled mediation may issue against lawful political communication. Any order targeting specific expression shall be narrowly tailored to prevent a proven, particularized criminal act, and shall state written findings on intent, imminence, and causation.

(e) Construction.
Ambiguities in speech-restricting laws shall be construed against the State. The burden rests on the State to prove the narrow exception; the presumption favors free expression.
This subsection does not bar prosecution of underlying crimes; it bars punishment based on label absent proof of defined criminal elements.

Section 7C. Prohibition on “Foreign Agent” and “Undesirable” Stigma Regimes

(a) Core Rule.
No person, association, publisher, platform, charity, newsroom, academic institution, or civic organization shall be designated, labeled, registered, or burdened as a “foreign agent,” “foreign-influenced,” “undesirable,” “enemy of the people,” or similar stigmatizing status by reason of foreign contact, foreign funding, cross-border affiliation, international speech, or political viewpoint.

(b) Due Process Threshold.
The State may impose narrowly tailored disclosure or registration duties only upon conviction (after trial and appeal) for a specific crime involving:
    1. espionage; or
    2. knowing direction or operational control by a foreign state in the commission of defined criminal acts.
Financial support, donations, grants, or association alone shall not satisfy this threshold absent proof of knowing criminal coordination.

(c) No Compelled Disclaimers; No Forced Self-Denunciation.
The State shall not compel any person or entity to append government-scripted labels, disclaimers, warnings, or “agent” markings to lawful speech, publications, websites, broadcasts, or communications. The State shall not require routine public self-identification that predictably chills lawful political participation.

(d) No Administrative Suppression by Designation.
No designation, listing, or administrative finding may be used to deny banking, payment rails, hosting, domain services, employment, licensing, education access, permits, or access to public venues for lawful speech and association, absent conviction for a defined crime and individualized judicial findings of necessity.

(e) Remedies and Oversight.
Any person subject to attempted designation or compelled labeling under this Section shall have immediate standing for expedited injunctive relief. Courts shall presume irreparable harm from compelled stigma or chilled political speech.

Section 8. Remedies and Standing

Any person or entity with standing may seek judicial relief for violations of this Article. Courts shall provide expedited review and effective remedies, including injunctive relief and suppression of unlawfully obtained evidence.

Section 9. Construction

This Article shall be interpreted to favor maximum freedom of communication, least-restrictive means, and individualized, judicially supervised enforcement. It shall be read in harmony with Article XXVI (Charter of Inviolable Rights) and shall not be suspended by emergency declaration, administrative necessity, or indirect coercion.

Section 10. Lock-Protected Provisions

Pursuant to Article XV (Amendment and Lock Clauses), the following provisions of Article XLII — Freedom of Communication are designated Lock-Protected Provisions. No law, regulation, emergency order, administrative act, or judicial reinterpretation shall amend, repeal, suspend, derogate from, or narrow these provisions except through the supermajority procedures and safeguards specified in Article XV.

1. Section 1 — Broad Protection of Communication
Lock Scope: Entire Section.
Rationale: To permanently secure the freedom of speech, expression, press, assembly, petition, and all forms of communication, including electronic, encrypted, anonymous, and broadcast forms, against abridgment by statute, regulation, technological control, or administrative practice.

2. Section 2 — No Prior Restraint; No Compelled Mediation
Lock Scope: Entire Section.
Rationale: To permanently prohibit prior restraint and compelled censorship, moderation, amplification, demotion, labeling, or mediation of lawful communication, except pursuant to specific judicial orders addressing proven, particularized criminal harm.

3. Section 3 — Encryption, Anonymity, and Private Association
Lock Scope: Entire Section.
Rationale: To permanently protect the right to private, encrypted, and anonymous communication and association, and to forbid encryption backdoors, key escrow, mandatory identification to speak, real-name requirements, or systemic weakening of privacy and security for the general public.

4. Section 7 — Prohibited Pretexts
Lock Scope: Entire Section.
Rationale: To permanently bar censorship, surveillance, compelled mediation, or indirect suppression justified by generalized or pretextual claims, including misinformation, hate, public order, democratic stability, foreign influence, health, or national security, absent individualized criminal acts supported by evidence and judicial process.

5. Section 7B — Prohibition on Speech-Crimes of Mere Dissent
Lock Scope: Entire Section.
Rationale: To permanently forbid criminalization, penalty, or civil disability for speech based solely on dissent, criticism, or dispute of official narratives, and to prevent vague speech-crime labels from substituting for defined criminal elements.

6. Section 7C — Prohibition on “Foreign Agent” and “Undesirable” Stigma Regimes
Lock Scope: Entire Section.
Rationale: To permanently forbid compelled stigma, registration, or administrative suppression of lawful speakers and organizations based on foreign contact, funding, or viewpoint, and to prevent designation-based denial of essential services absent conviction for defined crimes with full due process.
Article XLII-A — Communications Infrastructure and Civic Network Neutrality

Section 1. Purpose and Relationship to Article XLII

This Article governs the infrastructure, transmission, and technical conveyance of communications.
It exists to ensure that the freedom protected by Article XLII cannot be defeated through economic throttling, technical discrimination, or infrastructural capture.

Where conflict is alleged, Article XLII shall control as to expressive rights, and this Article shall control as to transport, access, and neutrality.

⸻

Section 2. Civic Communications Infrastructure

Communications infrastructure essential to civic participation—including wired, wireless, satellite, and successor technologies—shall be recognized as critical civic infrastructure, whether publicly or privately operated.

Such infrastructure shall be operated in a manner consistent with:
	1.	neutrality,
	2.	nondiscrimination,
	3.	transparency,
	4.	resilience,
	5.	universal access to the extent practicable.

Ownership structure shall not exempt compliance.

⸻

Section 3. Network Neutrality

No operator of communications infrastructure shall:
	1.	block, throttle, degrade, or prioritize lawful data traffic based on:
	•	content,
	•	source,
	•	destination,
	•	viewpoint,
	•	application type,
	•	or affiliation;
	2.	impose discriminatory pricing, latency, or access conditions that materially impair civic participation;
	3.	condition service quality on political, ideological, or commercial alignment.

Differential treatment is permitted only where:
	•	strictly necessary for network integrity,
	•	content-agnostic,
	•	narrowly tailored,
	•	and publicly disclosed.

⸻

Section 4. Measurement, Transparency, and Proof

Operators shall maintain objective, verifiable performance metrics, including latency, throughput, packet loss, and availability.

Where discrimination is alleged:
	1.	statistical disparity and technical evidence shall suffice to shift the burden of proof;
	2.	intent need not be shown where effect is substantial;
	3.	failure to disclose metrics creates a rebuttable presumption of violation.

⸻

Section 5. Economic Neutrality and Anti-Capture

No entity may:
	1.	use market dominance to impose de facto censorship through access degradation;
	2.	leverage infrastructure control to extract political, ideological, or behavioral concessions;
	3.	collude with public or private actors to suppress lawful communication indirectly.

Structural separation, common-carrier obligations, or access mandates may be imposed by law where necessary to prevent capture.

⸻

Section 6. Civic Access and Inclusion

The State shall ensure that communications infrastructure policy:
	1.	promotes universal civic access;
	2.	avoids exclusion by cost, geography, or artificial scarcity;
	3.	supports redundancy and decentralization;
	4.	preserves interoperability and open standards.
