All constitutional questions arising from preexisting law shall receive priority review, subject to the default-to-liberty, anti-paralysis, and time-limit rules of Article 0.
	•	Temporary Expansion of Review Capacity.
For the duration of the transition only, the CRC may be augmented by a Temporary Constitutional Review Panel (“Super CRC”), constituted solely for the purpose of expediting normalization of legacy law.
	•	Composition and Limits.
The Temporary Constitutional Review Panel shall:
	•	consist of additional judges or jurists meeting the qualifications for CRC service;
	•	operate under the same ethical, procedural, transparency, and conflict-of-interest rules as the CRC;
	•	possess no authority beyond constitutional conformity review; and
	•	dissolve automatically upon expiration of the transitional period.
	•	Authority and Effect.
Decisions of the Temporary Constitutional Review Panel shall have the same legal force as CRC decisions, subject to consolidation, rehearing, or reversal by the full CRC in accordance with this Constitution.
	•	No Emergency Bypass.
The existence of transitional backlog, institutional incompleteness, or administrative burden shall not justify bypassing CRC review, invoking emergency authority, or suspending constitutional safeguards.
	•	Sunset.
All temporary review authority under this Section shall expire automatically at the conclusion of the transitional period, and no such authority may be renewed except by constitutional amendment.
Section 9-A. Prioritization and Public Triage

During the transitional period, the CRC shall operate a published triage system for normalization of legacy laws, regulations, and governmental actions.

(a) Categories.
Reviews shall be classified and processed by urgency:
1. High Priority: matters affecting life, liberty, bodily autonomy, property, due process, speech, association, surveillance, emergency powers, or any LOCK-protected provision.
2. Medium Priority: structural, fiscal, institutional, or economic measures with substantial public impact.
3. Low Priority: administrative or procedural provisions with minimal rights impact.

(b) Transparency.
The CRC shall publish triage criteria, workload statistics, and progress reports at least annually, subject only to narrow operational redactions.

Section 9-B. Temporary Scaling and Delegation

(a) Super CRC Confirmation.
The Temporary Constitutional Review Panel (“Super CRC”) may be used to expedite normalization and shall dissolve automatically at the end of transition.

(b) Size Cap and Sunset.
The Super CRC shall not exceed double the ordinary CRC review capacity and shall sunset earlier if backlog falls below a statutory threshold.

(c) Delegation of Low-Priority Matters.
Low-priority legacy reviews may be delegated to State Supreme Courts under CRC-issued standards, with CRC oversight and final review available upon petition or contest.

Section 9-C. Optional AI-Assisted Triage

Audited artificial systems may be used only to assist screening, sorting, and conflict-flagging of legacy laws.
No artificial system may issue binding decisions, certify constitutionality, or substitute for human judicial judgment.
All dispositive actions shall be made by human judges or jurists subject to the ordinary rules of this Constitution.

Section 9-D. Timelines and Default Rule for Legacy Enforcement

(a) Review Deadlines.
Legacy matters shall be resolved within:
1. two (2) years for High Priority;
2. five (5) years for Medium Priority;
3. such longer period as law may allow for Low Priority, provided that no Low Priority provision may be used to burden LOCK-protected rights during delay.

(b) Default-to-Liberty for Legacy Law.
If a legacy law burdens a LOCK-protected right or core structural safeguard and is not certified for conformity within the applicable deadline, it becomes unenforceable upon expiration of that deadline until and unless the CRC certifies conformity.

(c) Evidence Capture Protected.
Nothing in this Section shall criminalize or suppress good-faith documentation of crime, abuse, or public corruption, including capture and submission of evidentiary material, subject to narrow victim-protection and access-control rules.

Section 10. Interpretation
This Article shall be interpreted narrowly.

Its sole purpose is to enable orderly transition into constitutional governance, not to authorize deviation from it.

Article VI — The Judiciary Branch

⸻

Charge:

The Judiciary exists to interpret and apply this Constitution and the laws enacted pursuant to it, to resolve cases and controversies according to law, and to safeguard the liberties, structure, and supremacy of the Constitution against all encroachment.

The Judiciary is an independent branch bound by this Constitution and by the duty to decide cases impartially and according to law.
⸻

Section 1. Vesting of Judicial Power

The judicial power of the Republic is vested in:
	1.	one Supreme Court;
	2.	such inferior courts as are established by this Constitution; and
	3.	such lower courts as may be established by law consistent with this Constitution.

Judicial power extends only to actual cases and controversies arising under this Constitution and the laws of the Republic.
⸻
Section 1A. Judicial Expansion and Geographic Reach

The Circuit Courts shall initially consist of nine (9) circuits.

Additional circuits may be established by law without fixed numerical cap, provided that any such expansion satisfies all of the following constitutional conditions:
	1.	Neutral Justification
Expansion shall be justified by objective criteria, including:
a. sustained population growth;
b. persistent and excessive caseload burdens;
c. permanent extraterritorial jurisdictions or overseas territories;
d. geographic scale such that reasonable access to appellate review would otherwise be impaired.
	2.	Prospective Application Only
No circuit may be created, altered, divided, or realigned:
a. to affect the outcome of any pending case;
b. to target identifiable litigants, issues, or jurisdictions;
c. to advantage or disadvantage any political party, faction, or branch.
	3.	Uniformity and Structural Integrity
Circuit boundaries shall be drawn to preserve:
a. geographic coherence;
b. administrative efficiency;
c. doctrinal consistency across circuits.
Congress shall not create circuits designed to isolate, evade, or entrench divergent legal doctrines.
	4.	Anti-Fragmentation Safeguards
Any expansion beyond nine (9) circuits shall include statutory mechanisms to:
a. promote harmonization of appellate doctrine;
b. reduce intercircuit conflict;
c. prevent de facto regional lawmaking.
	5.	Constitutional Review
Any law establishing or restructuring circuits shall be subject to mandatory review by the Constitutional Review Court for compliance with this Section.

Any circuit established in violation of this Section is void.

⸻

Section 2. Supremacy of the Constitution

This Constitution is the supreme law of the Republic.

All judicial officers are bound to uphold it, and any law, act, or governmental action repugnant to it is void.

Claims arising under Article XXVIII-A shall be justiciable as of right and shall not be dismissed as political questions, discretionary enforcement matters, or non-justiciable controversies.

⸻

Section 3. Independence and Separation

The Judiciary shall remain independent of the Legislative and Executive branches.

No court shall exercise legislative or executive authority, and no other branch shall direct judicial decision-making except as permitted by this Constitution.

⸻

Section 4. Limits on Judicial Authority

The Judiciary shall:
	1.	decide cases, not make law;
	2.	issue remedies tailored to the parties before it;
	3.	refrain from advisory opinions except where expressly authorized;
	4.	exercise restraint consistent with constitutional duty.

⸻

Section 5. Sources of Law

In interpreting this Constitution and the laws of the Republic, courts shall not treat foreign law, foreign judicial decisions, international tribunals, or transnational norms as binding authority.

Judicial interpretation shall give controlling weight to the text, structure, and original public meaning of this Constitution.

⸻

Section 6. Severability

If any provision of this Constitution or of any law is held invalid, the remaining provisions shall remain in force unless the invalid portion is inseparable from the remainder.

⸻
Section 7. Enforcement, Standing, and Civic Remedies

(a) Where this Constitution establishes a right, duty, prohibition, or limitation, standing to enforce such provision shall be construed broadly.

(b) Any person adversely affected by a constitutional violation shall have standing to seek declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, or other appropriate remedy, without the necessity of demonstrating special injury beyond the violation itself.

(c) Failure by public authorities to enforce constitutional duties constitutes a breach of public trust and shall be subject to judicial remedy.

(d) No constitutional provision shall be rendered unenforceable through denial of standing, remedies, or jurisdiction unless this Constitution expressly so provides.

(e) Questions of enforcement shall be presumed justiciable unless explicitly declared political and non-justiciable by this Constitution.

(f) Courts shall resolve challenges to State nullification on an expedited basis. Pending adjudication, the nullified federal action shall remain unenforceable within the State.
⸻
Section 8. Subarticles

The structure, operation, and limits of the Judiciary are further governed by the following Subarticles, which are integral parts of this Article:

Article VI-A — Courts, Jurisdiction, and Remedies
Article VI-B — Constitutional Review Court
Article VI-C — Appointment, Qualifications, and Independence
Article VI-D — Ethics, Discipline, and Removal
Article VI-E — Transparency, Standing, and Records
Article VI-F — Artificial Intelligence in the Judiciary
Article VI-G — Jury Doctrine
Article VI-H — Constitutional Deadlock and Popular Referendum
Article VI-I — Judicial Continuity and Emergency Function

⸻

Section 9. Emergency Hierarchy

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to authorize emergency judicial powers inconsistent with Article XV.

Judicial continuity provisions shall operate subject to Article XV, Article XXXVI, and Article XXXVIII, according to their respective constitutional hierarchy.

⸻

Section 10. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to preserve judicial independence, protect constitutional liberties, prevent consolidation of power, and ensure that justice is administered openly, lawfully, and without fear or favor.

The Constitutional Review Court adjudicates law and structure. The Constitutional Judicial Commission protects institutional integrity and anti-capture. The two shall never substitute for one another.

⸻

Article VI-A — Courts, Jurisdiction, and Remedies

(Authoritative, Integrated Version)

Section 1. Judicial Structure

The judicial system of the Republic consists of:
	1.	the Supreme Court of the Republic;
	2.	the Circuit Courts of the Republic; and
	3.	the District Courts of the Republic.

The Supreme Court and the Constitutional Review Court shall each consist of nine (9) judges.

The Circuit Courts shall initially consist of nine (9) circuits.

⸻

Section 1A. Judicial Expansion and Geographic Reach

Additional circuits may be established by law without fixed numerical cap, provided that any such expansion satisfies all of the following constitutional conditions:
	1.	Neutral Justification
Expansion shall be justified by objective criteria, including sustained population growth, persistent and excessive caseload burdens, permanent extraterritorial jurisdictions, or geographic scale impairing reasonable access to appellate review.
	2.	Prospective Application Only
No circuit may be created, altered, divided, or realigned to affect the outcome of any pending case or to advantage or disadvantage any political faction.
	3.	Uniformity and Structural Integrity
Circuit boundaries shall preserve geographic coherence, administrative efficiency, and doctrinal consistency.
	4.	Anti-Fragmentation Safeguards
Expansion beyond nine (9) circuits shall include statutory mechanisms to reduce intercircuit conflict and prevent regionalized lawmaking.
	5.	Constitutional Review
Any law restructuring circuits shall be subject to mandatory review by the Constitutional Review Court.

Any circuit established in violation of this Section is void.

⸻

Section 2. Supreme Court Jurisdiction

The Supreme Court shall have original jurisdiction only where expressly authorized by this Constitution and appellate jurisdiction as provided by law.

The Supreme Court shall decide only actual cases and controversies and shall not issue advisory opinions except where expressly permitted by this Constitution.

⸻

Section 3. Circuit and District Court Jurisdiction

Circuit Courts shall exercise appellate jurisdiction and such original jurisdiction as may be assigned by law consistent with this Constitution.

District Courts shall exercise original jurisdiction subject to appellate review.

No court shall extend its jurisdiction by implication, convenience, or necessity.

⸻

Section 4. Venue and Forum Integrity

Venue shall be proper only where a substantial nexus exists.

Forum shopping, judge shopping, and strategic venue manipulation are prohibited.

Courts shall dismiss or transfer actions brought in bad faith.

⸻

Section 5. Standing and Justiciability

Standing shall be liberally granted for claims alleging violation of this Constitution, provided a concrete or direct deprivation is shown.

Courts shall dismiss moot, nonjusticiable, or abusive actions and may impose sanctions for vexatious litigation.

⸻

Section 6. Scope of Remedies

Judicial remedies shall be limited to the parties before the court and narrowly tailored to redress the proven injury.

Courts shall not issue remedies that effectively legislate, administer, or regulate beyond the case at hand.

⸻

Section 7. Prohibition on Nationwide Injunctions

No court shall issue nationwide, universal, or non-party injunctions except where this Constitution expressly authorizes such relief.

Declaratory judgments shall not bind non-parties absent constitutional authorization.

⸻

Section 8. Temporal Limits on Relief

Injunctive or extraordinary relief shall include defined duration and shall expire automatically unless renewed upon fresh findings.

Permanent injunctions are disfavored.

⸻

Section 9. Appellate Review and Remedy Correction

Appellate courts shall correct jurisdictional or remedial excess without disturbing lawful findings unnecessary to correction.

⸻

Section 10. Prohibition on Judicial Lawmaking

Courts shall interpret and apply law; they shall not create, amend, suspend, replace, or rewrite statutes or constitutional provisions under the guise of interpretation or remedy.

Policy determinations remain the province of the Legislative Branch.

⸻

Section 10A. Bench Legislation as Constitutional Misconduct

Bench legislation—the creation, amendment, suspension, or effective replacement of law or constitutional meaning by judicial decree rather than interpretation—is a grave constitutional violation.

A pattern of bench legislation, or a willful act thereof, constitutes abuse of judicial office and a breach of the separation of powers.

No claim of necessity, efficiency, moral urgency, evolving standards, or perceived justice shall excuse bench legislation.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to preserve access to justice while preventing judicial usurpation of legislative authority and maintaining the constitutional separation of powers.
Article VI-B — Constitutional Review Court

Section 1. Establishment and Purpose

A Constitutional Review Court (CRC) is hereby established.

The purpose of the Constitutional Review Court is to provide disciplined, neutral, and authoritative review of constitutional questions, to ensure uniform interpretation of this Constitution, and to prevent constitutional drift, fragmentation, or abuse by any branch of government.

The Constitutional Review Court exists to safeguard constitutional structure, not to govern.

The Constitutional Review Court exercises judicial power and shall adjudicate cases within its jurisdiction and issue binding judgments on the merits, subject to the limits and review provisions of this Constitution.

⸻

Section 2. Composition

The Constitutional Review Court shall consist of nine (9) judges.

Judges of the Constitutional Review Court shall meet the same constitutional qualifications as judges of the Supreme Court, unless otherwise specified by this Constitution.

The Court shall sit en banc unless otherwise authorized by this Constitution.

⸻

Section 3. Jurisdiction

The Constitutional Review Court shall have jurisdiction limited to:
	1.	review of the constitutionality of statutes, executive actions, regulations, and governmental structures;
	2.	resolution of conflicts concerning the separation of powers;
	3.	review of laws or actions alleged to violate express constitutional prohibitions;
	4.	mandatory review of judicial restructuring, including circuit creation or realignment, as required by Article VI-A;
	5.	such other constitutional questions as this Constitution expressly assigns.

The Constitutional Review Court shall not exercise jurisdiction over:
	1.	criminal guilt or innocence;
	2.	civil liability between private parties;
	3.	fact-finding;
	4.	evidentiary determinations;
	5.	discretionary policy judgments.
All determinations of the Constitutional Review Court shall be binding and enforceable, and shall be final unless accepted for review by the Supreme Court of the Republic or certified by the Constitutional Review Court as requiring appellate consideration.

⸻

Section 4. Referral and Access

Cases may reach the Constitutional Review Court only by:
	1.	referral from the Supreme Court;
	2.	referral from a Circuit Court where a substantial constitutional question is dispositive;
	3.	direct referral required by this Constitution;
	4.	petition by a coordinate branch where separation-of-powers disputes are alleged, as authorized by law.

The Constitutional Review Court shall not accept original filings from private parties except where this Constitution expressly authorizes such access.

⸻

Section 5. Powers and Limits

The Constitutional Review Court may:
	1.	declare laws, actions, or structures constitutional or unconstitutional;
	2.	articulate binding constitutional interpretations;
	3.	remand matters to the referring court for disposition consistent with its ruling.

The Constitutional Review Court shall not:
	1.	issue nationwide, universal, or non-party injunctions;
	2.	prescribe remedies beyond constitutional invalidation;
	3.	retain ongoing supervisory authority over other courts or branches;
	4.	substitute its judgment for legislative or executive discretion where constitutional boundaries are not crossed.

⸻

Section 6. Effect of Decisions

Decisions of the Constitutional Review Court on constitutional questions shall be binding on all courts and branches of government.

Where a law or action is held unconstitutional, it shall be void to the extent of the constitutional defect.

Unless otherwise specified by this Constitution, the effects of such decisions shall be prospective, except where retroactivity is required to prevent manifest injustice.

⸻

Section 7. Relationship to the Supreme Court of the Republic

(a) Distinct Jurisdictional Roles
The Constitutional Review Court exercises original jurisdiction over constitutional compliance, validity, and legal effect of matters expressly assigned to it by this Constitution, including matters routed through the Constitutional Judicial Commission. The Supreme Court of the Republic serves as the court of last resort and retains ultimate appellate and precedential authority.

(b) Appellate Review
Final judgments and orders of the Constitutional Review Court are subject to appellate or discretionary review by the Supreme Court of the Republic as provided by this Constitution. The Supreme Court may affirm, reverse, remand, or modify such determinations, but shall not exercise original jurisdiction over matters assigned in the first instance to the Constitutional Review Court except where expressly authorized herein. A judgment of the Constitutional Review Court shall be final if the Supreme Court declines review.

Where the Supreme Court is evenly divided, the CRC judgment shall stand as binding disposition of the constitutional question presented, but shall not create Supreme Court precedent.

(c) No Advisory or Subordinate Function
The Constitutional Review Court does not act in an advisory capacity to the Supreme Court, nor does it issue opinions by referral for the purpose of assisting Supreme Court deliberation. Each court shall exercise its own constitutionally assigned jurisdiction independently and without subordination, subject only to the appellate authority of the Supreme Court as provided herein.

(d) Referral from Other Courts
Lower courts of the Republic shall refer questions of constitutional compliance, validity, or enforceability to the Constitutional Review Court where this Constitution so requires. Such referrals do not divest the Supreme Court of appellate jurisdiction over the resulting determination.

(e) Precedential Effect
Decisions of the Supreme Court of the Republic constitute binding constitutional precedent. Decisions of the Constitutional Review Court carry binding effect unless and until modified or reversed by the Supreme Court.

(f) Construction
This Section shall be construed to prevent jurisdictional overlap, advisory adjudication, or forum shopping, and to preserve a clear sequence of original constitutional adjudication followed by appellate review.

(g) Complexity Certification

The Constitutional Review Court may certify that a matter presents complexity, novelty, or institutional consequence requiring appellate consideration. Upon such certification, Supreme Court review shall be mandatory.


⸻

Section 8. Standing and Procedure

Standing before the Constitutional Review Court shall be limited to questions of constitutional compliance and shall not expand access beyond that permitted by Article VI-A.

Proceedings of the Constitutional Review Court shall be:
	1.	adversarial where appropriate;
	2.	public, except where limited secrecy is constitutionally justified;
	3.	recorded and permanently archived.

Procedural rules shall favor clarity, restraint, and timely resolution.

⸻

Section 9. Independence and Restraint

Judges of the Constitutional Review Court shall exercise their duties independently and without regard to political consequence.

The Court shall interpret this Constitution according to its text, structure, and original public meaning.

The Court shall refrain from constitutional revision by interpretation.

⸻

Section 9A. Institutional Integrity of the Constitutional Review Court
The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have independent and continuing authority to investigate, audit, and certify whether the Constitutional Review Court is subject to corruption, capture, coercion, improper influence, or structural impairment.

Where the CJC finds credible evidence of such impairment, it shall issue a public certification and refer the matter to the Judicial Review Board and to the Legislature for corrective action.

The CJC shall not review the substance of constitutional rulings, but shall safeguard the Court’s independence, honesty, and constitutional fitness.


⸻

Section 10. Emergency and Continuity Constraints

The Constitutional Review Court shall operate subject to Article XV.

No emergency, continuity, or necessity doctrine shall enlarge the jurisdiction or powers of the Constitutional Review Court beyond those enumerated in this Constitution.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to preserve constitutional supremacy while preventing judicial overreach, concentration of authority, or substitution of judicial will for democratic governance.

⸻

Article VI-C — Appointment, Qualifications, and Independence

Section 1. Judicial Offices Covered

This Subarticle governs the appointment, qualifications, tenure, and independence of judges of:
	1.	the Supreme Court of the Republic;
	2.	the Constitutional Review Court; and
	3.	the Circuit and District Courts of the Republic,

except where this Constitution expressly provides otherwise.

⸻

Section 2. Judicial Confirmation Council

A Judicial Confirmation Council (JCC) is hereby established.

The Judicial Confirmation Council shall consist of seven (7) members, selected as follows:
	1.	two members appointed by the President;
	2.	two members appointed by the People’s House;
	3.	two members appointed by the Senate; and
	4.	one member selected by majority vote of the sitting Supreme Court.

Members of the Judicial Confirmation Council shall serve staggered terms as provided by law and shall not hold judicial office while serving.

The Council exists to evaluate professional competence, ethical fitness, and constitutional understanding, not political ideology.

No function assigned to the CJC may be exercised by the CRC, and no function assigned to the CRC may be exercised by the CJC, except where this Constitution expressly provides joint certification.
⸻

Section 3. Nomination and Appointment Process

Judges of the Supreme Court, Constitutional Review Court, and Circuit Courts shall be appointed through the following process:
	1.	nomination by the President;
	2.	vetting and public evaluation by the Judicial Confirmation Council; and
	3.	confirmation by a majority vote of the Senate.

District Court judges shall be appointed as provided by law, subject to constitutional qualification standards and Senate confirmation unless otherwise authorized by this Constitution.

No judicial appointment shall take effect without Senate confirmation.

⸻

Section 4. Qualifications

All judges shall:
	1.	be Civic Citizens of the Republic;
	2.	possess substantial legal training and experience as defined by law;
	3.	demonstrate competence in constitutional interpretation;
	4.	possess a record of ethical conduct and professional integrity.

Judges shall not be selected or excluded on the basis of race, sex, religion, ideology, political affiliation, or factional loyalty.

⸻

Section 5. Disqualifications

No person shall be appointed or serve as a judge if that person:
	1.	holds office in the Legislative or Executive Branch;
	2.	has served as a registered lobbyist, senior political operative, or campaign manager within the preceding five (5) years;
	3.	holds substantial financial interests presenting unresolved conflicts of interest;
	4.	is bound by oath, pledge, or allegiance to a foreign power or transnational authority;
	5.	has engaged in conduct demonstrating contempt for constitutional limits.

⸻

Section 6. Term of Office, Mobility, and Service Limits

Judges of the Supreme Court, the Constitutional Review Court, the Circuit Courts, and the District Courts shall be subject to a cumulative lifetime limit of twenty-one (21) years of judicial service across all judicial benches of the Republic.

Service on any judicial bench shall count toward this cumulative limit, regardless of rank or court.

Upon completion of service on a particular court, a judge may be appointed to a different judicial court, provided that:
	1.	the judge does not exceed the cumulative lifetime service limit;
	2.	the judge does not return to the same court or substantially identical role;
	3.	the appointment does not constitute promotion to a court of equal or greater constitutional authority after completion of service on a higher court.

No judge may serve more than once on the Supreme Court or the Constitutional Review Court.

No judicial appointment may be structured to evade or extend the lifetime service limit imposed by this Section.

⸻

Section 7. Compensation and Non-Diminution

Judicial compensation shall be fixed by law and shall not be diminished during a judge’s term of office.

Judges shall not receive compensation, gifts, or benefits from any source other than lawful public compensation.

⸻

Section 8. Independence and Immunity

Judges shall be independent in the exercise of their judicial duties.

No judge shall be subject to discipline, removal, or retaliation for lawful judicial decisions or good-faith constitutional interpretation.

Judicial immunity shall not extend to corruption, criminal conduct, or willful violation of this Constitution.

⸻

Section 9. Prohibitions on Influence

No person or entity shall:
	1.	attempt to coerce or improperly influence a judge;
	2.	condition confirmation on ideological pledges or commitments;
	3.	require party affiliation, loyalty oaths, or doctrinal conformity.

Judges shall not engage in political fundraising, partisan advocacy, or public endorsement of candidates while in office.

⸻

Section 10. Cooling-Off and Post-Service Restrictions

Upon leaving judicial office, former judges shall be subject to cooling-off periods as provided by law.

No former judge may appear before the court on which they served for a period not less than five (5) years following separation.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to secure judicial independence, prevent ideological capture, preserve public confidence in the courts, and ensure that judges serve the Constitution rather than faction or power.

⸻

Article VI-D — Ethics, Discipline, and Removal

(Authoritative, Integrated Version)

Section 1. Judicial Duty and Ethical Obligation

Judicial office is a public trust.

Judges shall uphold the Constitution, apply the law faithfully, and conduct themselves with integrity, impartiality, and restraint.

⸻

Section 2. Code of Judicial Ethics

A uniform Code of Judicial Ethics shall govern conflicts of interest, disclosure, recusal, conduct, and post-service restrictions.

No ethical rule shall punish lawful judicial reasoning.

⸻

Section 3. Judicial Review Board

A Judicial Review Board (JRB) is hereby established as an independent body.

Members shall be appointed by the President, the Legislature, and the Judiciary in balanced proportions and shall not hold judicial office concurrently.

⸻

Section 4. Jurisdiction and Authority

The JRB may investigate credible allegations of misconduct, conduct hearings with due process, issue findings of fact, and recommend discipline or removal.

The JRB shall not discipline judges for the substance of lawful judicial decisions.

The Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have concurrent authority to refer evidence of corruption, capture, retaliation, or systemic misconduct to the Judicial Review Board.

The JRB shall not decline or dismiss a CJC referral without written findings subject to public disclosure.

⸻

Section 5. Grounds for Discipline

Judicial discipline may be imposed only for:
	1.	corruption or bribery;
	2.	willful violation of this Constitution;
	3.	criminal conduct;
	4.	persistent failure to perform judicial duties;
	5.	abuse of office;
	6.	knowing and material ethical violations;
	7.	willful or repeated bench legislation, as defined in Article VI-A.

Disagreement with legal reasoning alone shall not constitute grounds for discipline.

⸻

Section 6. Sanctions

Sanctions may include reprimand, suspension, reassignment, or removal.

Judicial officers who engage in willful or repeated bench legislation shall be presumed unfit for continued judicial service, absent clear and convincing evidence of isolated error promptly corrected upon review.

⸻

Section 7. Removal from Office

Removal requires a finding of cause by the Judicial Review Board and confirmation by a supermajority of the Senate, or such other process as this Constitution expressly authorizes.

⸻

Section 8. Interim Measures

Temporary suspension may occur where necessary to protect judicial integrity and shall not be punitive.

⸻

Section 9. Protection Against Retaliation

No judge shall be disciplined for lawful decisions, good-faith constitutional interpretation, or dissenting opinions.

Retaliatory discipline is void.

⸻

Section 10. Transparency and Records

Disciplinary findings and sanctions shall be public and preserved pursuant to Article VI-E and Article XXXIX.

⸻

Section 11. Emergency Constraint

No emergency or continuity doctrine shall suspend ethical accountability.

⸻

Section 12. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to ensure accountability without intimidation and independence without impunity.

⸻

Article VI-E — Transparency, Standing, and Records

Section 1. Presumption of Judicial Openness

Judicial proceedings, opinions, orders, filings, and records shall be presumed open to the public.

The Judiciary is bound by the same constitutional presumption of openness that governs all branches of the Republic under Article XXXIX.

Secrecy in judicial proceedings is the exception, not the rule, and shall be permitted only as expressly authorized by this Constitution.

⸻

Section 2. Public Proceedings and Opinions

All judicial proceedings shall be open to the public, except where limited closure is necessary to prevent substantial, specific, and foreseeable harm to a constitutionally protected interest.

All final opinions, judgments, and orders shall be published promptly and in full.

No court shall issue secret law, unpublished binding precedent, or concealed interpretations of this Constitution.

⸻

Section 3. Standing to Enforce Transparency

Any person shall have standing to challenge:
	1.	unlawful sealing or withholding of judicial records;
	2.	improper closure of judicial proceedings;
	3.	destruction, alteration, or concealment of judicial records;
	4.	violations of transparency obligations imposed by this Constitution.

Standing under this Section shall be construed liberally and independently of injury requirements applicable to other claims.

⸻

Section 4. Narrow and Time-Limited Sealing

Judicial records or proceedings may be sealed only upon a written finding, supported by clear and convincing evidence, that:
	1.	disclosure would cause substantial and specific harm to a constitutionally protected interest; and
	2.	no less restrictive alternative is available.

All sealing orders shall:
	1.	be narrowly tailored;
	2.	specify their scope and duration;
	3.	expire automatically unless renewed upon fresh findings meeting the same constitutional standard.

Indefinite or permanent sealing is prohibited.

⸻

Section 5. Record Preservation and Archiving

All judicial records, including filings, evidence admitted into the record, opinions, orders, transcripts, and metadata, shall be preserved as public records held in trust for the People.

Judicial records shall be archived in coordination with the Public Ministry of Records established under Article XXXIX.

No judicial officer or court shall maintain off-book, undisclosed, or inaccessible record systems.

⸻

Section 6. Prohibition on Destruction or Retroactive Secrecy

No judicial record shall be destroyed, altered, sealed, or retroactively classified for the purpose of evading accountability, review, or public access.

Destruction of judicial records may occur only pursuant to lawful retention schedules or judicial orders consistent with Article XXXIX.

Intentional destruction, concealment, or falsification of judicial records constitutes a grave constitutional violation.

⸻

Section 7. Transparency of Judicial Discipline

Proceedings, findings, and sanctions of the Judicial Review Board shall be public, except where limited confidentiality is necessary to protect complainants or due process.

Final disciplinary outcomes shall be published and permanently archived.

⸻

Section 8. Access, Costs, and Non-Obstruction

Access to judicial records shall be timely and meaningful.

Fees shall not be imposed except to recover reasonable and actual duplication costs and shall not be used to deter or delay access.

Administrative burden, embarrassment, reputational harm to officials, or institutional convenience shall not justify denial or delay.

⸻

Section 9. Relationship to Article XXXIX

This Subarticle shall be read in full harmony with Article XXXIX.

Where a conflict is alleged, the construction favoring greater transparency, access, and preservation shall control.

The Judiciary shall not claim exemption from Article XXXIX except where this Constitution expressly provides otherwise.

⸻

Section 10. Remedies and Accountability

Courts shall provide expedited review of transparency claims.

Judicial officers and court personnel who intentionally obstruct access, destroy records, or violate this Subarticle shall be subject to discipline, removal, and personal liability as provided by law.

No immunity shall attach to intentional violations of transparency obligations.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to ensure that the Judiciary does not govern in darkness, that constitutional adjudication remains publicly knowable, and that the memory of the Republic is preserved intact for present and future generations.

⸻

Article VI-F — Artificial Intelligence in the Judiciary

Section 1. Subordination of Artificial Intelligence to Judicial Authority

Artificial intelligence, algorithms, automation, and advanced computational systems used within the Judiciary shall be treated solely as tools.

No artificial system shall exercise judicial power, discretion, or authority.

All judicial responsibility shall remain vested in identifiable human judges, accountable under this Constitution.

⸻

Section 2. Permitted Advisory Uses

Artificial systems may be used only for advisory, clerical, or assistive functions, including:
	1.	research assistance;
	2.	document management and citation checking;
	3.	docket administration and scheduling;
	4.	pattern identification in non-dispositive data.

Advisory use shall not bind, substitute for, or preempt independent judicial judgment.

⸻

Section 3. Prohibited Uses

Artificial systems shall not be used to:
	1.	determine guilt or innocence;
	2.	assess credibility, demeanor, intent, or truthfulness;
	3.	impose or recommend criminal sentences;
	4.	calculate damages or liability in a binding manner;
	5.	weigh evidence or apply legal standards autonomously;
	6.	override or constrain jury authority;
	7.	generate binding judicial opinions or orders.

Any judgment or order materially influenced by prohibited use is void.

⸻

Section 4. Disclosure and Litigant Rights

Any use of artificial systems in a judicial proceeding shall be disclosed to the parties.

Litigants shall have the right to:
	1.	know whether artificial systems were used;
	2.	receive a general description of their function;
	3.	challenge improper or undisclosed use.

No party shall be compelled to accept algorithmic assessment as a substitute for human adjudication.

⸻

Section 5. Opt-Out and Human Review

Where artificial systems are used in advisory capacities affecting case processing, any party may request human-only review.

Judges shall independently evaluate all outputs and shall not defer to algorithmic recommendations.

⸻

Section 6. Auditability and Transparency

All artificial systems deployed within the Judiciary shall be:
	1.	auditable;
	2.	documented;
	3.	subject to inspection for constitutional compliance.

No proprietary, opaque, or undisclosed system essential to adjudication may be used.

Judicial reliance on uninspectable “black box” systems is prohibited.

⸻

Section 7. Judicial Artificial Intelligence Oversight Office

A Judicial Artificial Intelligence Review Office (CAIRO–Judicial) shall operate within the oversight framework established under Article XII.

The Office shall:
	1.	audit judicial AI systems for compliance;
	2.	investigate violations;
	3.	publish regular public reports;
	4.	refer misconduct for discipline under Article VI-D.

The Office shall possess no adjudicatory authority.

⸻

Section 8. Records and Preservation

All records relating to the procurement, deployment, training, configuration, and use of artificial systems in the Judiciary shall constitute public records.

Such records shall be preserved and made accessible pursuant to Article VI-E and Article XXXIX.

⸻

Section 9. Emergency Prohibition

No emergency, efficiency rationale, or workload justification shall authorize artificial systems to exercise prohibited judicial functions.

Emergency authorities under Article XV shall not override the protections of this Subarticle.

⸻

Section 10. Remedies and Accountability

Any person harmed by judicial use of artificial systems in violation of this Subarticle shall have standing to seek relief.

Judicial officers, administrators, or contractors who knowingly authorize prohibited use shall be subject to discipline, removal, and personal liability as provided by law.

No immunity shall shield intentional violations.

⸻

Section 11. Relationship to Article XII

This Subarticle is subordinate to and shall be construed in harmony with Article XII.

Where a conflict is alleged, the construction imposing greater human accountability, transparency, and restraint shall control.

The Judiciary shall not claim exemption from Article XII except where this Constitution expressly provides otherwise.

⸻

Section 12. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to ensure that justice remains a human moral act, that machines do not replace judgment in matters of liberty and rights, and that technology serves the courts without governing them.

⸻

Article VI-G — Jury Doctrine

Section 1. Constitutional Status of the Jury

The jury is a constitutional institution of the Republic and a direct instrument of popular sovereignty in the administration of justice.

In criminal cases, the jury stands as an independent check upon the State, empowered to protect liberty against unjust accusation, prosecution, or law.

⸻

Section 2. Authority Over Law and Fact

In criminal cases, the jury possesses the authority to judge both the facts and the application of the law to those facts.

No court shall instruct a jury that it is bound to convict upon a particular interpretation of the law.

No verdict of acquittal shall be set aside, reviewed, or questioned on the ground that the jury disagreed with the law, its application, or its justice.

⸻

Section 3. Prohibition on Coercion and Punishment

No juror shall be punished, sanctioned, investigated, fined, imprisoned, or otherwise penalized for:
	1.	the verdict rendered;
	2.	the reasoning employed in reaching a verdict;
	3.	refusal to convict in a criminal case.

Inquiry into jury deliberations for the purpose of punishing jurors or impeaching a verdict is prohibited.

⸻

Section 4. Limits on Judicial Control

Judges shall not:
	1.	direct a verdict of guilty;
	2.	override or vacate a verdict of acquittal;
	3.	coerce unanimity through threats, sanctions, or improper instructions;
	4.	impose instructions designed to nullify the jury’s constitutional authority.

Judicial instructions shall explain the law but shall not compel a particular outcome.

⸻

Section 5. Hung Juries and Mistrials

Where a jury cannot reach unanimity in a criminal case, the court may declare a mistrial.

No adverse inference shall be drawn against the accused from a hung jury.

Repeated prosecutions following mistrial shall be subject to judicial scrutiny to prevent harassment or coercive retrial.

⸻

Section 6. Civil Juries

In civil cases, the jury shall determine questions of fact.

No court shall override a civil jury’s factual findings except where constitutionally authorized.

The Legislature may regulate civil jury practice by law, provided that such regulation does not impair the essential function of the jury as a finder of fact.

⸻

Section 7. Jury Independence and Composition

Juries shall be drawn from the People and shall represent a fair cross-section of the community.

No jury shall be selected, excluded, or shaped to secure a particular verdict.

Jurors shall be free from intimidation, surveillance, or retaliation by the State or private parties.

⸻

Section 8. Relationship to Artificial Intelligence

No artificial intelligence, algorithmic system, or automated process shall be used to:
	1.	influence jury deliberations;
	2.	assess juror credibility or behavior;
	3.	recommend or predict jury outcomes;
	4.	substitute for jury judgment.

Any verdict influenced by prohibited use of artificial systems is void.

⸻

Section 9. Non-Waiver of Structural Protection

The jury’s constitutional role shall not be diminished by statute, procedure, efficiency concerns, or administrative convenience.

Any law, rule, or practice inconsistent with this Subarticle is void.

⸻

Section 10. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted liberally in favor of jury independence, acquittal authority, and protection of the accused.

Ambiguities shall be resolved to preserve the jury as a living institution of popular judgment rather than a mere procedural formality.

⸻

[LOCK DESIGNATION]

The following principles of this Subarticle are designated for lock protection and shall not be abridged by amendment except by explicit constitutional revision:
	1.	jury authority over law and fact in criminal cases;
	2.	prohibition on punishment or coercion of jurors;
	3.	finality of acquittals;
	4.	independence of jury deliberations.

⸻

Article VI-H — Constitutional Deadlock and Popular Referendum

Section 1. Purpose and Extraordinary Nature

This Subarticle establishes a limited mechanism for resolving genuine constitutional deadlock where the ordinary processes of adjudication cannot yield a determinate outcome.

The popular referendum authorized by this Subarticle is extraordinary, subsidiary to judicial review, and shall not be employed as a routine instrument of governance.

⸻

Section 2. Definition of Constitutional Deadlock

A constitutional deadlock exists only where all of the following conditions are met:
	1.	a substantial question of constitutional interpretation is dispositive of a matter of national scope;
	2.	the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Review Court have rendered final decisions that are irreconcilably divided or incapable of producing a binding constitutional rule;
	3.	no further judicial remedy or clarification is available within the Judiciary;
	4.	continued uncertainty materially impairs the operation of the Republic or the equal application of constitutional rights.

Mere disagreement, dissent, delay, or political controversy shall not constitute deadlock.
For purposes of this Section, “incapable of producing a binding constitutional rule” includes: an evenly divided court; lack of quorum; recusal or vacancy preventing formation of a controlling rule; or fractured opinions lacking any controlling rationale. A mere difference of reasoning does not constitute deadlock where a binding constitutional rule exists.

⸻

Section 3. Exhaustion of Judicial Remedies

No popular referendum may be initiated unless all judicial remedies have been fully exhausted.

Judicial exhaustion requires:
	1.	final disposition by the Supreme Court; and
	2.	final constitutional determination by the Constitutional Review Court under Article VI-B, Section 7, including Supreme Court opportunity for review and mandatory review where the CRC certifies appellate consideration is required, where jurisdiction exists.

Failure to pursue available judicial remedies bars invocation of this Subarticle.

Nothing in this Section prohibits resolution of a certified constitutional deadlock pursuant to Article VI-H; pending such resolution, the default-to-liberty rule governs.

⸻

Section 4. Certification of Deadlock

A declaration of constitutional deadlock shall require certification by:
(1)	 a supermajority of the Constitutional Review Court; and
(2) concurrence by a supermajority of the Supreme Court,
 that the criteria of Section 2 have been satisfied; and, 
(3) certification by the Constitutional Judicial Commission that no party, judge, or institution has engaged in coercion, capture, corruption, or strategic obstruction designed to manufacture or prolong the deadlock.

Absent such certification, no referendum may proceed.
“Supermajority” shall have the meaning given in Article 0 (Supermajority Rule) unless this Subarticle expressly provides otherwise.

⸻

Section 5. Scope and Form of Referendum

A referendum under this Subarticle shall be limited strictly to the constitutional question certified as deadlocked.

The question presented shall:
	1.	be stated neutrally and precisely;
	2.	present no more than two constitutionally permissible alternatives;
	3.	avoid partisan framing, legislative detail, or policy embellishment.

The referendum shall not amend this Constitution unless the amendment procedures of Article XV are separately satisfied.

⸻

Section 6. Effect of Referendum Outcome

The outcome of a referendum conducted pursuant to this Subarticle shall:

	1.	resolve the certified constitutional question;
	2.	bind all branches of government;
	3.	be applied prospectively unless otherwise required to prevent manifest injustice.

The referendum outcome shall not:
	1.	diminish enumerated rights;
	2.	suspend judicial review in future cases;
	3.	authorize retroactive punishment.

Threshold:
The certified constitutional question shall be resolved only upon a supermajority vote of participating Civic Citizens, as defined in Article 0, unless this Constitution expressly requires a higher threshold.

⸻

Section 7. Judicial Review of Process

Courts shall retain jurisdiction to review:
	1.	compliance with the requirements of this Subarticle;
	2.	the neutrality and clarity of the referendum question;
	3.	the integrity of the referendum process.

Courts shall not review the substantive choice made by the People where the process complies with this Constitution.

⸻

Section 8. Prohibitions and Safeguards

No referendum under this Subarticle may be used to:
	1.	target specific persons or groups;
	2.	override a final acquittal;
	3.	suspend due process;
	4.	evade constitutional rights;
	5.	resolve ordinary policy disputes.

Emergency, necessity, or expediency shall not justify deviation from these safeguards.

⸻

Section 9. Frequency and Non-Repetition

No substantially similar constitutional question may be submitted to referendum more than once within a defined period as provided by law, absent materially changed circumstances.

Rolling or repetitive referenda designed to exhaust or coerce the People are prohibited.

⸻

Section 10. Relationship to Other Articles

This Subarticle operates subject to Article XV.

Nothing herein shall be construed to diminish the authority of the Judiciary under Article VI, nor the rights secured by Article XXVI.

Election administration related to referenda shall comply with Article XVI.

⸻

Section 11. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted narrowly, to preserve judicial independence while recognizing that ultimate constitutional sovereignty resides in the People.

Where doubt exists, the construction that favors judicial resolution over popular referendum shall control.

⸻

[LOCK DESIGNATION]

The following principles of this Subarticle are designated for lock protection and shall not be abridged except by explicit constitutional revision:
	1.	exhaustion of judicial remedies as a prerequisite;
	2.	dual-court certification of deadlock;
	3.	narrow scope and neutral framing of referendum questions;
	4.	prohibition on rights diminution or retroactive punishment;
	5.	judicial review of process integrity.

⸻

Article VI-I — Judicial Continuity and Emergency Function

Section 1. Purpose and Scope

This Subarticle establishes limited measures to preserve the continuous operation of the Judiciary during declared emergencies, catastrophic disruption, or temporary incapacity.

Judicial continuity exists to maintain constitutional adjudication, not to expand judicial authority or suspend rights.

⸻

Section 2. Constitutional Hierarchy

All continuity measures under this Subarticle operate subject to Article XV.

Nothing in this Subarticle shall authorize powers inconsistent with Article XV, Article XXXVI, or Article XXXVIII, according to their respective constitutional hierarchy.

Where a conflict is alleged, the construction that most restricts emergency authority shall control.

⸻

Section 3. Preservation of Judicial Review

At all times, including during emergencies:
	1.	access to courts shall be preserved to the maximum extent practicable;
	2.	habeas corpus and core constitutional review shall not be suspended except as expressly permitted by this Constitution;
	3.	judicial independence and due process shall remain operative.

Emergency conditions shall not justify denial of judicial review.

⸻

Section 4. Temporary Operational Adjustments

During a declared emergency, courts may adopt temporary operational measures, including:
	1.	modified scheduling;
	2.	alternate locations;
	3.	remote proceedings where constitutionally permissible;
	4.	temporary reassignment of judges within existing courts.

Such measures shall be procedural only and shall not alter jurisdiction, remedies, or substantive rights.

⸻

Section 5. Prohibition on Emergency Courts and Extraordinary Tribunals

No emergency, provisional, or special tribunal shall be created outside the judicial structure established by this Constitution.

No court shall be vested with expanded jurisdiction, secrecy, or authority by virtue of an emergency.

Secret courts, secret law, or undisclosed adjudicatory bodies are prohibited.

⸻

Section 6. Non-Expansion and Anti-Laundering

Emergency or continuity measures shall not be used to:
	1.	expand judicial power;
	2.	consolidate authority;
	3.	bypass ordinary appointment, ethics, or removal requirements;
	4.	evade transparency or record-preservation obligations.

Any measure that persists beyond the termination of the emergency is void.


Section 7. Duration and Automatic Sunset

All continuity measures shall:
	1.	be expressly time-limited;
	2.	terminate automatically upon the expiration of the declared emergency;
	3.	be subject to periodic review where continued necessity is asserted.

Continuation without fresh authorization consistent with Article XV is prohibited.

Section 8. Transparency and Records

All actions taken pursuant to this Subarticle shall be documented and preserved as public records.

Emergency proceedings, orders, and administrative measures shall be disclosed promptly upon restoration of normal operations, subject only to narrow, time-limited protections consistent with Article VI-E and Article XXXIX.


Section 8A. Emergency Integrity Oversight

During any declared emergency, the Constitutional Judicial Commission shall have full authority to audit, inspect, and monitor all judicial continuity measures, emergency procedures, sealed proceedings, and continuity records.

Any concealment, obstruction, or abuse of emergency authority shall be immediately certified to the Constitutional Review Court and the Judicial Review Board.

Section 9. Accountability

Judicial officers and administrators who knowingly exceed the authority granted by this Subarticle shall be subject to discipline, removal, and liability as provided by this Constitution.

No immunity shall attach to intentional violations of continuity constraints.



Section 10. Interpretation

This Subarticle shall be interpreted to ensure that emergencies do not become a pretext for secrecy, exceptional justice, or permanent alteration of the judicial order.

The Judiciary shall remain a court of law, not a court of emergency.

⸻

Article VII — Crime, Justice, and Penal Philosophy

Charge
This Article establishes the constitutional framework governing criminal liability, adjudication, punishment, and penal restraint within the Republic. All provisions of this Article shall be construed to ensure legality, proportionality, due process, and restraint in the exercise of the State’s punitive power. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to authorize punishment, detention, or coercive sanction except as expressly provided by law and consistent with constitutional safeguards.

Section 1. Purpose of Criminal Law

a. Protection of the Innocent
The foremost purpose of criminal law is the protection of innocent persons from violence, coercion, exploitation, and fraud.

No legal theory, procedure, or ideology may supersede this duty.

b. Preservation of Public Order
Criminal law exists to preserve public order so that liberty may exist without fear.
Lawlessness is not freedom; it is the abdication of justice.

c. Accountability for Harm
Crime is defined by harm done, not merely by rule violation.
Where harm exists, accountability must follow.

d. Restoration Where Possible
Where crimes admit of repair, the justice system shall prioritize:
	•	restitution to victims;
	•	restoration of property and opportunity;
	•	repair of social trust.

Where harm is reparable, restitution to the injured party shall take precedence over punitive confinement, except where confinement is necessary for public safety.

e. Incapacitation Where Necessary
Where an offender poses a continuing danger, removal from society is justified to protect life and order.

The safety of the many outweighs the comfort of the irredeemable.

f. Moral Clarity
The law shall distinguish clearly between:
	•	accident and intent,
	•	weakness and malice,
	•	error and predation.

Justice fails when it refuses to name evil.

g. Rejection of Legal Formalism as Escape
No person guilty of heinous crimes—including murder, rape, sexual exploitation, trafficking, or severe violence—shall escape accountability solely due to procedural defects.

Procedural violations by officials shall be punished separately and severely,
but truthfully obtained evidence of grave crimes remains admissible.

Justice shall not sacrifice the innocent to preserve technical purity.

h. Equal Obligation Under Law
All persons—citizens and lawful residents alike—are equally bound by criminal law and equally entitled to its protections.

No caste, office, ideology, or status grants immunity from accountability.

i. Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to ensure that criminal law serves truth, safety, and justice—
not ideology, convenience, or abstraction.

As Scripture teaches:
“Justice, justice shall you pursue.”
Section 2. The Three Tiers of Justice

a. Principle of Differentiated Justice
Justice shall be administered according to the nature of the offender, the degree of harm caused, and the likelihood of rehabilitation.

The Republic rejects both indiscriminate punishment and indiscriminate leniency.

Accordingly, criminal justice shall be structured into three distinct tiers.

b. Tier One: Therapeutic Justice (Rehabilitation Without Incarceration)
Tier One applies to offenders whose conduct arises primarily from:
	•	substance addiction;
	•	mental illness;
	•	psychological impairment;
	•	developmental incapacity;
	•	situational crisis;

and who do not pose a continuing threat of violence or predation.

Measures under Tier One may include:
	•	mandatory treatment or detoxification;
	•	psychiatric or psychological care;
	•	supervised community programs;
	•	vocational training;
	•	restorative justice processes;
	•	monitored reintegration.

Tier One exists to heal, not to punish.

Failure to comply with Tier One requirements shall result in escalation to Tier Two.

c. Completion and Finality of Tier One Dispositions
Completion of all court-ordered requirements under Tier One constitutes full satisfaction of criminal liability for the offense.

No further punishment, disability, or collateral consequence may be imposed upon completion.

Time served is time served.

d. Sealing of Tier One Records
Records of Tier One offenses shall be:
	•	sealed from public access;
	•	unavailable to employers, landlords, insurers, or private parties;
	•	accessible only to courts and law enforcement for limited judicial purposes.

Tier One records may not be used to:
	•	deny employment;
	•	deny housing;
	•	deny education;
	•	impose civil penalties;
	•	justify enhanced sentencing for unrelated offenses.

e. Protection Against Recriminalization
No person who has successfully completed Tier One requirements shall be subjected to conditions or restrictions that:
	•	foreseeably push them toward recidivism;
	•	function as de facto punishment;
	•	undermine rehabilitation.

The Republic shall not sabotage its own justice.

f. Tier Two: Rehabilitative Incarceration
Tier Two applies to offenders who:
	•	commit serious crimes;
	•	demonstrate willful wrongdoing;
	•	require confinement for public safety;
but who retain a reasonable prospect of reform.

Confinement under Tier Two shall:
	•	be secure and disciplined;
	•	require labor, education, or training;
	•	prioritize restitution to victims;
	•	provide moral, psychological, and vocational rehabilitation;
	•	condition privileges and release upon demonstrated reform.

Comfort is not the aim; correction is.

g. Tier Three: Punitive Incapacitation
Tier Three applies exclusively to offenders who are:
	•	convicted of heinous crimes, including murder, rape, child sexual exploitation, trafficking, or acts of extreme violence;
	•	repeat violent offenders demonstrating incorrigibility;
	•	demonstrably unrepentant, predatory, or irreversibly dangerous.

Tier Three confinement shall:
	•	prioritize permanent protection of society;
	•	impose harsh and demanding conditions proportional to the offense;
	•	deny privileges unrelated to basic human survival;
	•	require compulsory labor where physically possible;
	•	exclude early release except under extraordinary judicial review.

This tier exists not to rehabilitate, but to restrain and punish.

Conditions shall be harsh but not cruel.

h. Prohibition on Tier Conflation
No authority may:
	•	treat Tier Three offenders as candidates for routine leniency;
	•	impose Tier Three conditions on Tier One offenders;
	•	collapse all offenders into a single penal model.

Justice requires distinction.

i. Review and Movement Between Tiers
Movement between tiers may occur only:
	•	by judicial review;
	•	upon clear evidence of change or deterioration;
	•	with victim input considered where applicable.

Escalation is permitted for noncompliance, deception, or new offenses.

De-escalation requires sustained proof of reform.

j. Moral Foundation
Mercy is owed to the repentant.
Correction is owed to the errant.
Severity is owed to the wicked.

The Republic shall not confuse these duties.

k. Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to preserve moral clarity, protect the innocent, and ensure that justice remains humane without becoming weak, and severe without becoming cruel.

As Scripture teaches:
“The rod and reproof give wisdom, but a child left to himself brings shame.”

Section 2A. Cross-Reference: Structural and Institutional Crimes

a. Constitutional Escalation
Any act declared a grave offense under:
	•	Corporate Legitimacy and Accountability;
	•	Knowledge, Technology, and the Digital Commons;
	•	Transparency, Anti-Capture, and Public Stewardship;

shall, when committed with intent, coordination, or systemic scale, qualify as a Tier Three crime under this Article.

b. Institutional Malice
Where harm arises not from isolated conduct but from organized systems, policies, technologies, or corporate structures, culpability shall extend to:
	•	architects of the system;
	•	beneficiaries of the harm;
	•	enforcers and facilitators;
	•	those who knowingly conceal, excuse, or profit from the offense.

c. No Shield of Abstraction
Corporate form, algorithmic mediation, financial instruments, bureaucratic distance, or institutional layering shall not mitigate criminal liability.

Structural harm is personal harm at scale.

Section 2B. Classification of Offenses
 Offenses shall be classified as: 
	•	Tier One (minor): Non-violent, low-harm conduct; punishments limited to fines, community service, or short-term restrictions. 

	•	Tier Two (serious): Conduct involving moderate violence, fraud, or harm; punishments may include incarceration up to 10 years, restitution, and supervised release. 


	•	Tier Three / Grave (heinous): As defined in Article 0; punishments may include lifetime confinement, mandatory labor under humane standards, permanent forfeiture of certain rights (subject to due process review), or, in extraordinary cases involving mass death or betrayal resulting in irreparable harm, capital punishment (subject to unanimous jury finding, multiple layers of review, and preference for lifetime incapacitation absent clear necessity).

	•	All classifications and punishments must be proportionate, evidence-based, and subject to appellate review.

Section 2C. Temporary Protective Measures for Imminent Threats
 Where clear and convincing evidence establishes an Imminent Threat of Grave Harm (as defined in Article 0), courts may issue temporary orders restricting access to firearms, liberty of movement, or other means of harm (e.g., extreme risk protection orders). Such orders shall: 

	•	Be strictly time-limited (initially not exceeding 14–30 days); 
	•	Require an adversarial hearing within 72 hours where feasible; 
	•	Include a clear pathway for immediate restoration upon cessation of the threat; 
	•	Be narrowly tailored and subject to expedited appeal; 
	•	Never become permanent absent full due process under Section 5 of Article II. These measures are civil in nature and do not constitute punishment.


Section 3. Standards of Guilt, Evidence, and Truth

a. Presumption of Innocence
Every accused person is presumed innocent until guilt is established through lawful adjudication.

This presumption protects the innocent; it shall not be weaponized to shield the guilty through deception, intimidation, or technical gamesmanship.

b. Burden of Proof
The burden of proof rests entirely upon the prosecuting authority.

Guilt must be established beyond a reasonable doubt for criminal conviction.

Reasonable doubt concerns truth and material facts, not speculative, manufactured, or ideological uncertainty.

c. Mens Rea (State of Mind)
Criminal liability shall account for intent and mental state.

The law shall distinguish among:
	•	intentional acts;
	•	knowing acts;
	•	reckless acts;
	•	negligent acts;
	•	accidental acts.

Punishment must be proportionate to both harm and intent.

d. Admissibility of Evidence
All evidence that is:
	•	materially relevant;
	•	reliable;
	•	probative of truth;

shall be admissible, regardless of how it was obtained, provided that its authenticity and accuracy are established.

Procedural violations in evidence collection shall not invalidate truthful proof of grave crimes.

e. Separate Accountability for Official Misconduct
Any official who unlawfully obtains evidence shall be:
	•	prosecuted independently;
	•	subject to severe penalties;
	•	barred from office where appropriate.

Justice shall punish wrongdoing without nullifying truth.

f. Exclusion of Fabricated or Coerced Evidence
Evidence shall be excluded if it is:
	•	fabricated;
	•	materially altered;
	•	knowingly falsified;
	•	proven to be unreliable;
	•	obtained through coercion rendering it untruthful.

Truth is not served by lies, even in pursuit of justice.

g. Corroboration for Extraordinary Claims
Extraordinary accusations shall require corroboration proportional to the severity of the charge.

No person shall be convicted solely on the basis of:
	•	uncorroborated hearsay;
	•	speculative inference;
	•	ideological presumption;
	•	collective guilt;
	•	demographic assumption.

Justice demands proof, not narratives.

h. Confessions and Admissions
Confessions are admissible only if:
	•	voluntarily given;
	•	corroborated by independent evidence;
	•	not induced by coercion, torture, or threat.

Truth extracted through cruelty is unreliable and forbidden.

i. Scientific and Technical Evidence
Scientific, forensic, or technical evidence must:
	•	meet established standards of reliability;
	•	be subject to independent verification;
	•	be transparent and reproducible;
	•	disclose error rates and limitations.

Pseudo-science and politicized expertise are inadmissible.

j. Truth-Seeking Authority of the Court
Judges possess affirmative authority to:
	•	question evidence;
	•	seek clarification;
	•	order independent testing;
	•	require additional proof;
	•	reject narratives unsupported by fact.

The court exists to discover truth, not to referee performances.

k. Jury Integrity
Juries shall be composed of impartial peers.

No juror may be selected or excluded on ideological, racial, religious, or political grounds.

Jury tampering, intimidation, or manipulation constitutes a grave offense.

l. Verdict Integrity
Verdicts must reflect:
	•	evidence presented;
	•	lawful instructions;
	•	rational deliberation.

Nullification motivated by ideology, intimidation, or coercion is forbidden.

m. Appeals
Appeals shall address:
	•	material errors of law;
	•	demonstrable factual error;
	•	newly discovered evidence;
	•	constitutional violations affecting outcome.

Appeals shall not be granted for harmless procedural defects that do not affect guilt.

n. Finality of Truth
Once guilt is lawfully established through fair process and reliable evidence, justice shall proceed without delay.

Endless litigation shall not be used to exhaust victims or society.

Overly litigious individuals or organizations that establish a pattern of abusing the courts for obstruction or ill-gotten gain may be compelled to bear full court costs and sanctions.

o. Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to elevate truth above technicality, justice above performance, and moral clarity above procedural cynicism.

As Scripture teaches:
“You shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free.”

Section 4. Rights of Victims

a. Recognition of Victims
Victims of crime are persons against whom harm has been committed.

The justice system exists foremost to acknowledge, protect, and restore them.

Victims are not witnesses for the state alone; they are parties with inherent standing.

b. Right to Dignity and Protection
Victims shall be treated with dignity, respect, and seriousness at all stages of the criminal process.

They shall be protected from:
	•	intimidation;
	•	retaliation;
	•	public shaming;
	•	coercion;
	•	unnecessary exposure of private details.

The Republic owes safety to those already harmed.

c. Right to Information
Victims have the right to timely and truthful information regarding:
	•	charges filed or declined;
	•	court proceedings and schedules;
	•	plea negotiations;
	•	sentencing recommendations;
	•	incarceration status;
	•	release, transfer, or escape of offenders.

No material decision affecting a victim shall occur in secrecy.

d. Right to Participation
Victims shall have the right to:
	•	be heard at bail, plea, sentencing, and parole proceedings;
	•	submit impact statements;
	•	present evidence relevant to harm suffered;
	•	object to unjust leniency.

Victim input shall be considered, though it shall not substitute for lawful judgment.

e. Right to Restitution
Victims are entitled to full restitution for:
	•	physical injury;
	•	psychological harm;
	•	lost income or opportunity;
	•	medical and therapeutic expenses;
	•	property loss or destruction.

Restitution shall take priority over fines payable to the state.

f. Priority of Victim Claims
Any assets seized from offenders shall first be applied to victim restitution before state claims, fees, or administrative costs.

The offender owes the victim before owing the treasury.

g. Protection Against Procedural Evasion
No plea agreement, diversion program, or sentence reduction may be granted in heinous or violent crimes without:
	•	judicial findings on the record;
	•	notice to the victim;
	•	opportunity for victim objection.

Victims shall not be silenced for convenience.

h. Special Protections for Vulnerable Victims
Victims who are minors, disabled persons, or victims of sexual or violent crimes shall receive:
	•	trauma-informed procedures;
	•	privacy protections;
	•	specialized advocates;
	•	shielded testimony where appropriate.

Protection shall not undermine truth-seeking.

i. Right to Timely Justice
Victims have the right to resolution without unreasonable delay.

Intentional delay tactics designed to exhaust or silence victims constitute abuse of process.

j. Right to Appeal Certain Decisions
Victims may seek review of:
	•	dismissal of charges;
	•	non-prosecution agreements;
	•	plea agreements in violent or predatory crimes;
	•	parole or early release decisions.

Such review shall be limited, expedited, and narrowly tailored.

k. State Duty of Care
The Republic shall provide victims with:
	•	access to counseling and medical care;
	•	legal assistance where necessary;
	•	relocation or protection services when threatened.

Justice does not end at conviction.

l. No Retaliatory Liability
Victims shall not be subject to civil or criminal liability for:
	•	reporting crimes in good faith;
	•	cooperating with lawful prosecution;
	•	providing testimony.

False reporting made with malicious intent remains punishable.

m. Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to restore balance between the rights of the accused and the rights of those harmed, recognizing that justice fails when victims are reduced to procedural afterthoughts.

As Scripture teaches:
“Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights of all who are destitute.”

Section 5. Sentencing Philosophy and Proportional Punishment

a. Purpose of Sentencing
Sentencing exists to:
	•	protect the innocent;
	•	restrain the dangerous;
	•	restore victims where possible;
	•	punish wrongdoing proportionately;
	•	reinforce moral order and public trust.

No sentence shall be imposed solely to satisfy ideology, public outrage, or bureaucratic convenience.

b. Proportionality
Punishment shall be proportional to:
	•	the severity of harm caused;
	•	the intent of the offender;
	•	the degree of culpability;
	•	the risk of future harm;
	•	the offender’s history.

Minor crimes shall not receive major punishments,
and major crimes shall not receive minor ones.

c. Alignment With the Three Tiers of Justice
All sentences shall explicitly correspond to one of the three tiers:
	•	Tier One: therapeutic and restorative measures;
	•	Tier Two: rehabilitative incarceration with restitution and labor;
	•	Tier Three: punitive incapacitation for heinous or incorrigible offenders.

Courts shall state on the record the tier applied and the justification for placement.

d. Individualized Sentencing
Sentencing shall be individualized, accounting for:
	•	facts of the offense;
	•	offender history;
	•	victim impact;
	•	prospects for rehabilitation;
	•	public safety needs.

Mandatory sentencing schemes that eliminate judicial judgment are disfavored,
except for heinous crimes where minimum incapacitation is required.

e. Severity for Heinous Crimes
Crimes involving:
	•	murder;
	•	rape;
	•	sexual exploitation of children;
	•	human trafficking;
	•	extreme or repeated violence;

shall receive sentences prioritizing incapacitation over rehabilitation.

Leniency in such cases requires extraordinary justification and explicit findings.

f. Rehabilitation as a Conditional Privilege
Rehabilitation is not an entitlement.

It is earned through:
	•	demonstrated accountability;
	•	compliance with programs;
	•	measurable behavioral change;
	•	sustained good conduct.

Failure to engage in rehabilitation shall result in escalation of confinement conditions or tier placement.

g. Restitution as a Core Component
Where feasible, sentencing shall include mandatory restitution.

Labor, wages, and assets of the offender may be applied toward restitution.

Restitution obligations survive release.

h. Truthful Sentencing
Sentences shall be imposed honestly and transparently.

Artificially inflated maximums paired with routine early release are forbidden.

If a sentence is imposed, it shall be meant.

i. Parole and Early Release
Parole or early release may be granted only when:
	•	public safety is not compromised;
	•	restitution obligations are substantially met;
	•	the offender demonstrates sustained reform.

Parole is prohibited for Tier Three offenders except under extraordinary judicial review.

j. Review and Adjustment
Sentences may be reviewed periodically to:
	•	assess rehabilitation;
	•	correct demonstrable error;
	•	address new evidence;
	•	respond to changes in dangerousness.

Review shall not become a revolving door.

k. Equality Before Sentencing
Sentencing shall not vary based on:
	•	race;
	•	sex;
	•	wealth;
	•	political status;
	•	ideology;
	•	office or influence.

Justice is blind to status, not to facts.

l. Public Accountability
Sentencing data shall be published in anonymized form to ensure:
	•	consistency;
	•	proportionality;
	•	public confidence;
	•	detection of systemic abuse.

m. Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to ensure that punishment restores order without cruelty, protects society without indulgence, and reflects moral seriousness without vindictiveness.

n. Right to Trial and Limits on Coercive Plea Bargaining
Every accused person retains the right to a public trial for any criminal offense, except for minor civil infractions expressly designated by law.

No person shall be coerced into confessing guilt through:
	•	threat of disproportionate sentencing;
	•	stacking of charges to induce fear;
	•	denial of access to trial;
	•	use of pretrial detention as leverage.

Trials exist to discover truth, not to extort admissions.

o. Prohibition on Charge Manipulation
Prosecutors may not reduce, dismiss, or substitute charges in a manner that:
	•	conceals the true nature of the offense;
	•	misrepresents the harm committed;
	•	reclassifies violent or predatory crimes as minor offenses;
	•	permits offenders to evade proportional accountability.

Accordingly, reductions such as:
	•	rape pleaded down to assault;
	•	armed robbery pleaded down to petty theft;
	•	child sexual offenses pleaded down to non-sexual crimes;
	•	trafficking pleaded down to regulatory violations;

are forbidden.

Charges must reflect reality.

p. Narrow Scope of Permissible Plea Agreements
Plea agreements may be permitted only when:
	•	the underlying facts remain accurately charged;
	•	victim rights under Section 4 are preserved;
	•	sentencing remains within the appropriate tier;
	•	judicial findings justify the agreement on the record.

Plea agreements exist to conserve resources, not to distort justice.

q. Mandatory Judicial Review of Pleas
All plea agreements require:
	•	explicit judicial findings of factual sufficiency;
	•	confirmation that the defendant was not coerced;
	•	confirmation that the victim was notified and heard where applicable;
	•	confirmation that the plea does not undermine public safety.

Judges serve as guardians against prosecutorial abuse.

r. Right to Appeal
Every criminal conviction, whether by trial or plea, is subject to appeal on grounds including:
	•	material legal error;
	•	violation of constitutional rights;
	•	newly discovered evidence;
	•	demonstrable coercion or misconduct.

No conviction shall be insulated from review.

s. Interpretation
This subsection shall be interpreted to restore the trial as the central instrument of justice, restrain prosecutorial overreach, and prevent the use of fear as a substitute for proof.

As Scripture teaches:
“Justice is turned back, and righteousness stands far away.”

t. Inviolability of Constitutional Minimums and Tier Three Terms
