(c) Anti-Speculation Measures
The Republic may regulate or restrict large-scale acquisition of residential property by institutional investors, bulk ownership that inflates housing costs, vacancy hoarding, and speculative practices disconnected from improvement.

(d) Occupancy and Use
Buildings and developed land suitable for habitation or lawful enterprise shall not be left vacant for more than twelve (12) consecutive months without just cause. Just causes include active renovation, lawful transition of ownership, seasonal use, certified hardship, or safety remediation.

(e) Temporary Stewardship Transfer
Temporary stewardship transfer shall not convey title, equity, or permanent control. It shall exist solely to restore lawful use following authorization by the Constitutional Review Court, for a defined duration not exceeding five years, after which full possession shall revert to the owner, with just compensation where required.

(f) Prohibition on Artificial Scarcity
No owner or consortium may coordinate vacancy or land banking to manipulate rents or withhold entire districts from use. Such conduct constitutes market manipulation.

Section 6. Trade, Tariffs, and National Industry

(a) Fair Trade Principle
Trade shall increase prosperity and peace without hollowing domestic industry, enslaving labor abroad, or creating permanent dependency.

(b) Strategic Industries
Industries essential to national survival, security, or independence shall be protected and maintained domestically.

(c) Anti-Offshoring Abuse
No enterprise may offshore production solely to evade standards and then re-import goods while enjoying domestic legal privileges or public subsidy.

Section 7. Welfare, Assistance, and Anti-Dependence

(a) Purpose of Assistance
The Republic affirms a duty to aid the vulnerable while restoring dignity, stability, and productive participation.

(b) Reciprocity
Able-bodied adults receiving long-term assistance shall contribute through work, training, public service, rehabilitation, or caregiving where capacity exists.

(c) Protection of the Vulnerable
No work requirement shall apply to the severely disabled, the elderly, or primary caregivers where no alternative exists.

(d) Review and Sunset
All assistance programs shall include objectives, sunset provisions, periodic review, and public reporting.

(e) Interpretation
Mercy shall not become indulgence, nor support surrender.

Addendum — Definitions and Construction
	•	Rent-Seeking
Rent-seeking refers to the extraction of income, advantage, or control through legal privilege, monopoly power, artificial scarcity, financial manipulation, or regulatory capture without proportional productive contribution to goods or services.
	•	Parasitic Wealth Extraction
Parasitic wealth extraction refers to sustained economic gain derived primarily from exploiting dependency, asymmetry of power, or enforced scarcity rather than from productive enterprise or value creation.
	•	Productive Labor
Productive labor includes work that materially or socially contributes to goods, services, infrastructure, care, knowledge, safety, or the lawful functioning of society.
	•	Systemic Risk
Systemic risk refers to financial, industrial, or supply-chain conditions whose failure would threaten national stability, public welfare, or sovereign independence.
	•	Federal–State Boundary
In cases of conflict, federal authority under this Article shall extend only to preventing oligarchy, systemic risk, national dependency, or market manipulation, and shall not be construed to standardize local economic life beyond those guardrails.
Addendum: Illegitimate Use of Cultural Assets

Section A. Art and Antiquities as Instruments of Corruption

The use of art, antiquities, cultural artifacts, or historically significant objects as instruments for money laundering, concealment of criminal proceeds, sanctions evasion, tax evasion, or storage of opaque and unaccountable wealth constitutes parasitic wealth extraction and an economic crime against the Republic.

Such conduct extracts value without productive contribution, obscures honest scales, and corrodes the moral foundations of commerce.

Section B. No Cultural Exemption from Economic Justice

No claim of artistic merit, cultural prestige, collectible status, or heritage significance shall exempt any asset or transaction from lawful provenance, transparent ownership, and economic accountability under this Article.

Wealth that hides in shadows, trades on secrecy, or cloaks itself in false reverence is not stewardship, but deceit.

Section C. Construction

This addendum shall be construed to affirm that wealth exists to serve life and truth, not to evade justice; that honest measures delight the Lord; and that no market, however rarefied, may place itself above the moral law that binds all commerce within the Republic.
Article VIII-A — Supplemental Economic Doctrines and Safeguards

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Additive Effect

This Article supplements Article VIII — Economic Structure and Stewardship.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to repeal, narrow, suspend, condition, or reinterpret any provision, prohibition, cap, ratio, or safeguard established in Article VIII.

Silence in this Article shall not be construed as authorization to weaken, evade, or dilute Article VIII.

⸻

Section 2. Lawful Private and Alternative Exchange Systems

The People retain the right to engage in lawful private exchange systems, including but not limited to:
	1.	commodity-backed currencies;
	2.	mutual credit systems;
	3.	barter and local exchange networks;
	4.	cryptographic or digital exchange instruments.

Such systems shall be lawful provided that they do not:
	1.	claim legal tender status by coercion;
	2.	impersonate public currency;
	3.	evade lawful taxation;
	4.	function as instruments of fraud, coercion, or concealment.

Nothing in this Section shall be construed to diminish the Republic’s monetary sovereignty or to authorize a central banking cartel prohibited under Article VIII.

⸻

Section 3. Prohibition on Monetary Manipulation

No public authority shall engage in monetary manipulation, including but not limited to:
	1.	hidden debasement;
	2.	inflationary dilution for political ends;
	3.	opaque monetary expansion;
	4.	covert redistribution through currency distortion.

Monetary instruments shall not be used to conceal insolvency, evade fiscal discipline, or transfer wealth without transparent legislative authorization.

Violation of this Section constitutes economic misconduct against the People.

⸻

Section 4. Constitutional Debt Sustainability Doctrine

Public debt shall remain subordinate to productive capacity and generational equity.

In addition to the substantive restrictions imposed by Article VIII, no public borrowing may be incurred that:
	1.	exceeds sustainable ratios relative to national productive output, as defined by law using publicly disclosed methodologies;
	2.	binds future generations absent compelling necessity;
	3.	conceals long-term obligations through off-balance-sheet instruments.

Any override of statutory debt limits shall require heightened legislative thresholds and full public disclosure.

⸻

Section 5. Bad-Faith Offshoring and Re-Importation Prohibited

Offshoring of labor, production, or capital undertaken for the primary purpose of evading constitutional labor standards, environmental protections, safety requirements, or ethical obligations is prohibited.

Re-importation of goods or services produced through such bad-faith offshoring shall not receive legal protection, subsidy, or preferential treatment.

Corporate form, jurisdictional layering, or contractual indirection shall not shield such conduct from accountability.

⸻

Section 6. Protection of Ethical Domestic Enterprise

Enterprises that comply with constitutional labor, safety, environmental, and compensation standards shall not be disadvantaged in law or practice in favor of entities that externalize harm.

The economic structure of the Republic shall favor productive, ethical, and transparent enterprise over speculative, extractive, or deceptive models.

⸻

Section 7. Anti-Capture and Anti-Evasion Principle

No economic doctrine, regulatory structure, emergency justification, or efficiency rationale shall be used to evade or nullify the caps, ratios, prohibitions, or structural safeguards established in Article VIII.

Economic governance shall not be delegated, privatized, or obscured in a manner that defeats constitutional accountability.

Any mechanism that has the effect of systematically undermining Article VIII is void.

⸻

Section 8. Transparency of Economic Instruments

All public economic instruments, including debt instruments, guarantees, subsidies, and monetary mechanisms, shall be documented and preserved as public records.

Secrecy, complexity, or technical opacity shall not be used to conceal economic transfer, risk, or obligation from the People.

This Section operates in coordination with Article XXXIX.

⸻

Section 9. Structural Economic Harm as Public Injury

Where economic systems or policies reasonably foreseeable to produce widespread harm through concentration, distortion, or exploitation, such harm shall be treated as injury to the People collectively and to affected individuals individually.

Scale shall not diminish culpability or accountability.

⸻

Section 10. Interpretation

This Article shall be interpreted to reinforce, not weaken, the economic discipline, ethical stewardship, and anti-capture structure established by Article VIII.

Where doubt exists, the construction that preserves the greatest force of Article VIII shall control.

⸻Article VIII-B — Prohibition of Predatory Economic Practices

Section 1. Non-Derogation and Relationship to Article VIII

This Article supplements Article VIII — Economic Structure and Stewardship.

Nothing in this Article shall be construed to narrow, dilute, suspend, or reinterpret the principles, prohibitions, caps, ratios, or safeguards established in Article VIII or Article VIII-A.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most restrains exploitation and protects human dignity shall control.

⸻

Section 2. Purpose

This Article prohibits economic practices that extract value through deception, coercion, structural asymmetry, or psychological manipulation, even where nominal consent is claimed.

Economic freedom does not include the freedom to prey upon dependency, ignorance, or desperation.

⸻

Section 3. Predatory Practices Defined

Predatory economic practices include, but are not limited to:
	1.	Deceptive Omission — withholding material risks, costs, exit barriers, failure rates, or adverse outcomes reasonably necessary for informed consent;
	2.	Coercive Sales Architecture — high-pressure tactics, artificial scarcity, time-limited inducements, emotional leverage, or social pressure impairing free choice;
	3.	Recruitment-Driven Compensation — compensation derived primarily from recruiting participants rather than from bona fide goods or services sold to end users;
	4.	Asymmetric Entry and Exit — arrangements facilitating easy entry while imposing disproportionate penalties, forfeitures, lock-ins, or barriers to exit;
	5.	Psychological Exploitation as a Business Model — systematic reliance on cognitive, emotional, or informational asymmetry to induce transactions adverse to participants.
6.  Highly leveraged acquisitions — Highly leveraged acquisitions that encumber an operating enterprise with debt exceeding a constitutionally reasonable proportion of acquisition value, where such debt materially impairs productive operation, worker compensation, or long-term viability, shall be presumptively predatory.

⸻

Section 4. Invalidity of Consent

Consent obtained through predatory economic practices is invalid as a matter of law, notwithstanding the absence of an express false statement.

Waivers, acknowledgments, or disclaimers shall not cure predation.

This Section regulates conduct and transactional architecture, not protected expression.

⸻

Section 5. Prohibited Schemes

Schemes commonly characterized as confidence operations, pyramid schemes, multi-level marketing arrangements, or functionally equivalent structures are prohibited where they satisfy Section 3, regardless of nomenclature or formal design.

Substance shall control over form.

⸻

Section 6. Mandatory Cooling-Off Period for High-Risk Transactions

For any transaction designated by law as high-risk, including but not limited to:
	•	timeshare interests;
	•	investment contracts marketed to non-professionals;
	•	advance-fee services;
	•	long-term lock-in agreements;
	•	recruitment-based compensation schemes;

a mandatory cooling-off period shall apply.
	1.	The cooling-off period shall be no less than seven (7) days from execution or payment, whichever occurs first.
	2.	During this period, the purchaser or participant may rescind for any reason or no reason, without penalty, forfeiture, or adverse consequence.
	3.	Any attempt to waive, shorten, obscure, or condition the cooling-off period is void.

⸻

Section 7. Bright-Line Presumptions

Transactions subject to Section 6 are presumptively predatory where:
	1.	material risks, costs, or failure rates are not disclosed prominently and in plain language;
	2.	compensation is primarily derived from recruitment rather than end-user value; or
	3.	exit requires forfeiture, penalty, or continued payment disproportionate to any bona fide service rendered.

Such presumptions may be rebutted only by clear and convincing evidence.

⸻

Section 8. Enforcement and Remedies

Violations of this Article are actionable through:
	•	civil enforcement;
	•	injunctive relief;
	•	restitution and disgorgement;
	•	dissolution of offending entities;
	•	prohibition on reconstitution under successor names or structures;
	•	criminal referral where warranted.

Arbitration clauses, choice-of-law provisions, forum selection clauses, or class-action waivers shall not bar enforcement.
Where an enterprise enters insolvency within a defined period following extraordinary distributions to executives or controlling investors, such distributions shall be subject to mandatory clawback.

⸻

Section 9. Escalation and Severity

Where predatory economic practices are willful, systematic, concealed, or result in widespread harm, such conduct constitutes parasitic wealth extraction and qualifies as a grave offense under Article 0.

Such conduct is eligible for Tier-3 classification pursuant to Article VII.

No property right shall vest in proceeds derived from predatory conduct.

⸻

Section 10. Interpretation

This Article regulates conduct, not protected expression.

It shall be construed broadly to prevent evasion through rebranding, contractual form, technological mediation, jurisdictional fragmentation, or legal indirection.

Where doubt exists, the construction that most protects human dignity and economic freedom shall control.

⸻Article VIII-C — Systemic Confidence Exploitation 
	1.	The Republic recognizes systemic confidence exploitation as a distinct and grave form of economic predation.
	2.	Systemic confidence exploitation consists of repeated or patterned conduct designed to extract value through deception, emotional manipulation, false identity, manufactured trust, or asymmetric disclosure, particularly where such conduct targets vulnerability, dependency, or isolation.
	3.	Such conduct constitutes an attack on economic freedom, human dignity, and public trust, regardless of formal consent or contractual appearance.
	4.	The Republic affirms a compelling public interest in the proactive detection, investigation, and disruption of systemic confidence exploitation, including through pattern-based inquiry not dependent on individual victim reporting, subject to probable cause or equivalent constitutional standard.
	5.	No contractual waiver, arbitration clause, jurisdictional indirection, or organizational restructuring shall immunize systemic confidence exploitation from investigation or enforcement.
	6.	The identification, investigation, and adjudication of such conduct shall proceed only through lawful process and evidentiary standards, with constitutional compliance review by the Constitutional Review Court.
	7.	This Article is declaratory and reservational.
It authorizes no punishment beyond that provided by law, but denies any presumption of legitimacy to enterprises or actors whose business model relies on confidence exploitation.

⸻

Article VIII-D — Economic Constitutional Enforcement Directorate
 Charge
Economic liberty cannot be preserved where constitutional prohibitions exist only on paper.
Predatory extraction, systemic exploitation, and oligarchic consolidation succeed not because they are lawful, but because they are complex, concealed, and under-enforced. Where enforcement is episodic, under-resourced, or politically dependent, constitutional economic safeguards decay into symbolism.
This Article establishes a narrow, judicially subordinated Economic Constitutional Enforcement Directorate to investigate, document, and prosecute violations of Articles VIII, VIII-A, VIII-B, and VIII-C, while denying it all authority to regulate, legislate, punish, negotiate, or define economic policy.
⸻
Section 1. Establishment and Judicial Subordination (Lock-Protected)
There is hereby established the Economic Constitutional Enforcement Directorate (“the Directorate”) as an investigative and prosecutorial arm solely subordinated to the Constitutional Judicial Commission (CJC).
The Directorate shall not be part of the Executive Branch, shall possess no independent executive or regulatory authority, and may not be merged with, absorbed by, or subordinated to any executive agency, department, ministry, or office. Any attempt to do so is void ab initio.
⸻
Section 2. Strict Subject-Matter Jurisdiction (Lock-Protected)
The Directorate’s jurisdiction is limited exclusively to alleged violations of: • Article VIII — Economic Structure and Stewardship; • Article VIII-A — Supplemental Economic Doctrines and Safeguards; • Article VIII-B — Prohibition of Predatory Economic Practices; • Article VIII-C — Systemic Confidence Exploitation.
The Directorate shall prioritize systemic, patterned, or large-scale conduct reasonably foreseeable to produce widespread economic harm, institutional capture, or parasitic wealth extraction.
The Directorate possesses no authority over ordinary commercial disputes, contract interpretation absent constitutional violation, lawful business failure, labor relations not rising to constitutional violation, taxation, rate-setting, price controls, or any matter outside the enumerated Articles.
⸻
Section 3. Investigative Powers and Absolute Prohibitions (Lock-Protected)
(a) Permitted Powers
Subject to judicial warrant where required, the Directorate may: 1. conduct forensic accounting, financial analysis, and pattern-based investigations; 2. issue subpoenas for records, testimony, and data; 3. compel production of documents, transactional histories, and control relationships; 4. investigate successor entities, affiliates, shells, proxies, and control structures; 5. assemble evidentiary records for referral to prosecution.
(b) Absolute Prohibitions
The Directorate shall have no authority to: 1. issue regulations, guidance, interpretive rules, or policy directives; 2. define lawful or unlawful economic conduct beyond constitutional text; 3. impose fines, penalties, sanctions, or remedies; 4. negotiate settlements, grant immunity, safe harbors, or exemptions absent court approval; 5. suspend enforcement for policy, political, economic, or emergency reasons; 6. act as an independent prosecutor; all cases must be referred to the CJC or authorized courts.
Any such prohibited act is void and constitutes a grave constitutional offense.
⸻
Section 4. Initiation of Investigations
Investigations may be initiated only by: (a) referral from the Constitutional Judicial Commission or Constitutional Review Court; (b) sworn public complaints or whistleblower submissions meeting evidentiary thresholds; (c) legislative request for systemic review of a defined industry or pattern; (d) pattern-based indicators derived from lawful public-records analysis.
The Directorate shall not self-initiate investigations absent CJC authorization.
Investigations shall be declined where motivated by political animus, ideological bias, lawful wealth accumulation, unpopular speech, or sectoral dislike.
All initiations shall be documented and subject to judicial review, with redaction permitted only for active investigative necessity.
⸻
Section 5. Prosecution and Judicial Remedies
The Directorate may refer cases only to the Constitutional Review Court or courts of general jurisdiction for prosecution.
All remedies shall be imposed by courts only and may include: • injunctive relief; • restitution and disgorgement; • clawback of unconstitutional gains; • dissolution or restructuring of offending entities; • prohibition on successor reconstitution; • referral for criminal prosecution where warranted.
The Directorate shall not decline prosecution based on entity size, economic importance, employment impact, market position, or claimed indispensability.
“No entity is too big to comply.”
⸻
Section 6. Transparency and Public Accountability (Lock-Protected)
All non-classified records of the Directorate constitute public records under Article XXXIX.
The Directorate shall publish quarterly reports detailing: (a) investigations initiated and declined, with reasons; (b) referrals made and actions filed; (c) remedies sought and imposed; (d) systemic or pattern-level findings.
Annual audits conducted by the CJC shall be public.
Secrecy shall not be used to conceal favoritism, delay accountability, or suppress evidence of constitutional economic harm.
⸻
Section 7. Personnel Independence and Anti-Capture
Personnel shall be selected based on demonstrated competence in law, economics, accounting, forensic investigation, or data analysis.
No person may serve who: 1. has been employed by, lobbied for, or materially invested in a regulated entity within the preceding seven (7) years; 2. holds partisan office or party leadership; 3. seeks future employment or compensation from entities subject to investigation.
A post-service cooling-off period of five (5) years shall apply before accepting compensation from any entity investigated or prosecuted during tenure.
Violations constitute grave constitutional offenses.
⸻
Section 8. Standing, Review, and Discipline
Any person subject to investigation has standing to challenge jurisdictional overreach, procedural abuse, or constitutional violation before the Constitutional Review Court.
Broad citizen standing is granted to challenge Directorate misconduct, abuse of authority, or unlawful non-enforcement.
Willful abuse, selective enforcement, or collusion with private interests constitutes grave constitutional misconduct subject to removal, liability, and permanent disqualification from public office.
⸻
Section 9. Construction and Lock Protection
This Article shall be construed strictly to enable enforcement of existing constitutional economic safeguards without creating new regulatory authority, investigative sprawl, or policy power.
Ambiguities shall be resolved against expansion.
Judicial subordination, strict jurisdictional limits, prohibitions on rulemaking and punishment, transparency obligations, and anti-capture safeguards are structurally locked pursuant to Article XV and may not be repealed, suspended, diluted, or reinterpreted except through the highest procedural threshold defined therein. 
Article IX — Land, Homesteading, and Agricultural Duty

Charge
This Article establishes constitutional rules governing land ownership, use, stewardship, and agricultural policy within the Republic. All provisions of this Article shall be construed to promote productive use, environmental stewardship, long-term sustainability, and broad access to land for lawful residence and cultivation. Nothing in this Article shall be interpreted to authorize land restriction, forfeiture, or redistribution except as expressly provided by law and subject to constitutional safeguards.

Legal Text

Section 1. Stewardship of Land

(a) Duty of Stewardship
The land, waters, soil, and natural systems of the Republic are held in sacred trust for the People and for future generations.
All land within the Republic shall be held subject to a duty of stewardship. Ownership of land confers not only rights, but obligations to use, maintain, and preserve land in a manner consistent with the long-term welfare of the People, the environment, and future generations.
Land is not a purely speculative instrument, nor an object of neglect; it is a public trust held in private hands. For purposes of this Article, beneficial ownership, control, coordination, or common management shall be aggregated, regardless of legal form or number of entities involved.
For purposes of stewardship, responsible land use may include the maintenance of forest health, soil stability, watershed protection, and reasonable mitigation of known ecological or fire risks, consistent with evidence and due process.
Stewardship shall have the meaning given in Article 0: the fiduciary duty of officials, landholders, and institutions to preserve and enhance these resources for long-term welfare, subject to enforcement as a constitutional obligation.
Neglect, waste, soil depletion, or predatory exploitation that materially weakens the Republic or future generations constitutes a grave offense (cross-reference Article 0; Article VII Tier Three offenses; Article I §9).
Stewardship obligations apply equally to individuals, corporations, trusts, religious bodies, and any coordinated ownership structure.
(b) Definition of Stewardship
Stewardship shall require that land be:
	•	maintained in safe, habitable, or productive condition appropriate to its zoning and designation;
	•	protected against intentional degradation, abandonment, or waste;
	•	free from prolonged neglect that creates public harm, blight, environmental damage, or artificial scarcity;
	•	used in good faith for habitation, agriculture, commerce, conservation, or public benefit.

Nominal, sham, or token use designed solely to evade stewardship obligations shall not satisfy this duty.

(c) Prohibited Conduct
The following constitute violations of stewardship:
	•	prolonged abandonment without just cause;
	•	deliberate deterioration or stripping of land or structures;
	•	hoarding land or housing to manipulate scarcity or price;
	•	allowing land to become hazardous, unsanitary, or ecologically destructive;
	•	maintaining property solely as a financial instrument without meaningful use;
	•	using shell entities or layered ownership to evade accountability.

Such conduct is contrary to the common good and subject to sanction.

(d) Enforcement Authority
Stewardship shall be enforced through a mixed model:
	•	local authorities shall conduct inspections, issue notices of violation, and document conditions;
	•	state authorities shall oversee enforcement standards, ensure uniformity, and prevent abuse or favoritism;
	•	all compulsory actions shall be subject to judicial review.

No land may be seized, reassigned, or repurposed without due process of law. Courts shall evaluate substance over form and material outcomes over nominal compliance.

(e) Notice and Opportunity to Cure
Before any compulsory action is taken, the owner shall receive:
	•	written notice of specific violations;
	•	a reasonable opportunity to cure or remediate;
	•	access to an impartial hearing;
	•	the right to present evidence and contest findings.

Emergency action may be taken only where immediate danger to life, health, or the environment exists, and must be reviewed by a court without delay.

(f) Remedies
Upon judicial finding of sustained stewardship violation, remedies may include:
	•	fines proportionate to harm and duration;
	•	mandatory remediation or use requirements;
	•	temporary receivership;
	•	transfer to homesteading, public trust, or community use as defined by law;
	•	forfeiture only in cases of willful, repeated, and egregious violation.

Receivership, temporary stewardship, compulsory leasing, or provisional homesteading shall not convey title or permanent ownership. Transfer or forfeiture of title may occur only upon a judicial finding of willful, repeated, and egregious violation of stewardship duties, following notice, opportunity to cure, proportional review, and written findings of fact and law.
Standing shall be construed broadly to include affected landholders, neighboring communities, downstream users, and civic organizations.
Punishment shall be corrective first, punitive only when correction is refused.

(g) Protection Against Abuse
Stewardship laws shall not be used to:
	•	dispossess productive smallholders;
	•	target owners based on political, ideological, or cultural grounds;
	•	enable corruption, favoritism, or retaliatory enforcement;
	•	concentrate land ownership in the State or corporate monopolies.

All enforcement actions must be transparent, reviewable, and grounded in demonstrable harm.
(h) Public Grazing and Commons Use.
The people retain the right to graze livestock and working animals on public lands traditionally or reasonably suitable for such use, provided such grazing is conducted in a non-destructive, non-hazardous, and ecologically responsible manner.

Such use shall not be conditioned upon discretionary permits, exclusive leases, or administrative approval regimes that function as barriers to access, favor large or centralized operators, or suppress subsistence, small-scale, or traditional use.

The government bears the burden of demonstrating, by clear and site-specific evidence, that a particular grazing practice, as conducted, causes material harm to public safety or the environment that cannot be mitigated by reasonable, narrowly tailored conditions.

Grazing rights shall not be extinguished, suspended, or reduced by generalized policy, speculative modeling, or economic preference, and shall be construed as a lawful use of the public commons consistent with stewardship obligations.
(i) Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to ensure that land serves life, family, production, and continuity—not speculation, decay, or absentee domination.

As Scripture teaches: “Moreover, it is required in stewards that one be found faithful.”

Section 2. Homesteading Rights

(a) Purpose
The purpose of homesteading is to restore productive use of neglected land, expand access to housing and agriculture, strengthen families, and prevent permanent hoarding or decay. Homesteading is a civic instrument of renewal, not a loophole for speculation or seizure.

(b) Eligibility
Only Civic Citizens of the Republic may initiate a homesteading claim. “Civic Citizen” has the meaning set forth in Article III. Legal residents may participate only as dependents, partners, or laborers under a qualified Civic Citizen.

No corporation, trust, shell entity, or foreign-controlled body may initiate a homesteading claim.

(c) Eligible Land
Land eligible for homesteading shall be limited to parcels that meet all of the following conditions:
	•	demonstrably unused, abandoned, or neglected for a continuous period defined by law;
	•	not actively farmed, inhabited, or maintained in good faith;
	•	not subject to active remediation or lawful development;
	•	not held for essential public, military, ecological, or cultural purposes;
	•	not the primary residence of any lawful owner.

Farmland, housing stock, and mixed-use land may qualify only upon judicial certification of abandonment or non-productive hoarding.

(d) Petition and Review
Homesteading shall proceed only by formal petition filed with the appropriate local authority and reviewed by a Stewardship Court or designated judicial body.

(e) Provisional Stewardship Period
If approved, the petitioner shall be granted provisional stewardship for a fixed term not less than three years.

(f) Final Vesting
Upon successful completion of the provisional period and certification by the Stewardship Court, title shall vest fully in the homesteader, subject to continuing stewardship obligations.

(g) Civic Contribution
Responsible agricultural labor, soil stewardship, and family-scale food production may qualify as equivalent public service toward earning Civic Citizenship, subject to objective verification and the standards of Article III and Article XVIII.

Section 3. Anti-Speculative Ownership
(a) Purpose
The purpose of this Section is to prevent land and housing from being treated as purely speculative instruments divorced from use, stewardship, and human settlement.

(b) Definition of Speculative Ownership
Speculative ownership shall be defined as the acquisition or retention of land or housing primarily for price manipulation, artificial scarcity, passive appreciation without productive use, or rent extraction absent maintenance or improvement.

(c) Ownership Transparency
All land ownership shall be transparent. Beneficial ownership must be publicly disclosed. Anonymous or nominee ownership is prohibited. Failure to disclose constitutes grounds for forfeiture.
Any attempt to circumvent these limits through proxies, trusts, shell companies, or pretextual coercion (as defined in Article 0) is void ab initio.
(d) Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to ensure that land serves families, workers, farmers, and communities before financiers and absentee interests.

Section 4. Agricultural Protection

(a) Purpose
Agriculture is a matter of national survival, not merely commerce. The Republic affirms that food security and domestic agricultural independence are essential to sovereignty.

(b) Preservation of Farmland
Farmland shall be preserved primarily for food production. Conversion to non-agricultural use shall be restricted and subject to transparent approval.

(c) Foreign Ownership
Foreign governments, foreign-controlled entities, and large corporations (as defined in Article XVII) shall be strictly limited in their ownership or control of agricultural land, water rights, and primary natural resources.
Such ownership or control shall be:
1. capped at a maximum percentage of total arable land per entity, as determined by statute;
2. subject to revocation if it results in land-hoarding, monoculture that degrades soil health, environmental harm, suppression of family farming, or demographic engineering (cross-reference Article 0 definitions of Demographic Engineering and Corporation);
3. prohibited outright for entities whose beneficial ownership includes substantial foreign state or adversarial interests.
Any attempt to circumvent these limits through proxies, trusts, shell companies, or pretextual coercion (as defined in Article 0) is void ab initio.
(d) Interpretation
This Section shall be interpreted to preserve farming as a living vocation, not a financial abstraction.

Section 5. Food Integrity and Ecological Protection

(a) Prohibition of Food Cartels
Food cartels, price-fixing, and supply manipulation are prohibited.

(b) Prohibition of Poisonous Practices
It is unlawful to introduce substances into soil, air, or water that degrade long-term fertility or habitability.

(c) Evidentiary Standard
No plant or substance may be prohibited without clear and convincing scientific evidence of substantial harm, subject to transparent public review, adversarial testing, and periodic renewal. Criminal penalties arising from such prohibitions shall require proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

(d) Third-Tier Crimes
Knowingly poisoning land, water, air, or food systems constitutes a third-tier crime as defined in Article VII.

Section 6. Ecological Responsibility

(a) Duty of Care
All persons and entities have a duty to avoid reckless or irreversible ecological harm.

(b) Scientific Standard
Environmental restrictions shall be based on reproducible scientific evidence and periodic review.
(c) Scientific Uncertainty
Where scientific uncertainty exists, the presumption shall favor liberty, property rights, and productive use unless clear and convincing evidence demonstrates imminent and specific harm.
(d) Interpretation
Environmental protection shall serve life and stewardship, not ideology or control.

Section 7. Native and Ancestral Stewardship

(a) Purpose
The Republic recognizes Indigenous and ancestral ties to land while maintaining one Constitution and one rule of law.

(b) Status
Indigenous communities are local civic entities subject to this Constitution.

(c) Interpretation
Heritage shall be preserved without fragmenting sovereignty.

Section 8. Religious and Communal Stewardship of Land

(a) Equal Application of Law
Religious and communal land holdings are subject to the same law and stewardship obligations as all others.

(b) Prohibited Uses
Land may not be used under religious pretext to conceal abuse, trafficking, or coercion.

(c) Interpretation
Faith does not excuse atrocity.

Section 9. Voluntary Communities and Cooperative Living

(a) Right of Formation
Voluntary communities may form, subject to the Constitution and laws of the Republic.

(b) Prohibition of Coercion
No community may restrict lawful exit or impose coercion.

(c) Interpretation
Community is a liberty, not a license.

Section 10. Housing Stability Mandate

(a) Purpose
Habitable housing shall not be artificially withheld from use amid demonstrable need.

(b) Due Process
No housing may be seized or repurposed without notice, opportunity to cure, judicial findings, and proportional remedy.

(c) Interpretation
Housing shall serve human dignity and continuity.
Section 11. Anti-Predatory Recycling and Material Reuse

(a) Material Stewardship Principle
All physical goods, machinery, electronics, and industrial artifacts embody labor, knowledge, and public value. Destruction of functional or repairable goods for market control, profit maximization, or artificial scarcity is a form of economic and environmental harm.

⸻

(b) Reuse Before Recycle

No recycler, manufacturer, disposal contractor, or waste intermediary may shred, export, or materially destroy any functional or repairable device, tool, or machine unless:
	1.	it has been offered for reuse, repair, or resale;
	2.	it has been offered to public institutions, schools, or charitable technology programs; and
	3.	it has been offered to preservation, repair, or historical organizations.

Only goods that are unsafe, irreparably damaged, or beyond reasonable economic repair may be processed for raw material recovery.

⸻

(c) Prohibition on Market-Suppressive Destruction

Destruction of usable goods for the purpose of:

• eliminating secondary markets;
• forcing consumer repurchase;
• maintaining vendor lock-in;
• suppressing competition;
• or controlling access to technology

is prohibited and constitutes economic sabotage and environmental fraud.

⸻

(d) Electronics, Machinery, and Digital Infrastructure

All electronic, computing, networking, industrial, and scientific equipment is subject to this Section.

This includes computers, servers, phones, routers, vehicles, medical devices, laboratory instruments, and manufacturing systems.

⸻

(e) Enforcement and Integration

Violations are enforceable by:

• environmental authorities;
• inspectors general;
• the Digital Commons Enforcement Authority;
• and any citizen with standing.

Remedies include seizure, redistribution, public auction, restitution, loss of contracts, and criminal penalties where willful.

Section 12. Article IX — Definitions and Construction
	•	Beneficial ownership, control, coordination, or common management shall be aggregated, regardless of legal form or number of entities.
	•	Courts shall evaluate substance over form and material outcomes over nominal compliance.
	•	Organization includes corporations, nonprofits, trusts, foundations, religious entities, cooperatives, associations, and any coordinated body of persons acting in concert.
	•	Coercion includes psychological, economic, social, spiritual, or immigration-based pressure.
	•	No emergency declaration may override due process, stewardship requirements, or judicial review guaranteed herein.
	•	Foreign funding, direction, or coordination related to land, agriculture, ecology, or food systems must be publicly disclosed.
	•	Rules of constitutional interpretation applicable to this Article are governed by Article XIX.
	•	This Article supplements Article VIII. Where provisions overlap, the stricter stewardship, anti-monopoly, or anti-abuse rule shall govern unless explicitly stated otherwise.
Section 13. Lock Designation

Pursuant to Article XV, this Article is hereby designated as LOCK-PROTECTED. No amendment, statute, executive action, judicial doctrine, or emergency declaration may dilute, suspend, reinterpret, or circumvent the stewardship obligations, anti-speculation provisions, homesteading rights, agricultural protections, or evidentiary standards herein except through the highest procedural threshold and certification of non-diminishment.


Article IX-A — Indigenous and Tribal Corporate Land-Use Rights, Stewardship, and Non-Exclusion

Charge
This Article secures lawful Indigenous and tribal corporate land-use rights— including fishing, hunting, grazing, and farming— as instruments of heritage preservation, livelihood continuity, and local resilience, while enforcing one Constitution, one rule of law, and uniform civil rights for all lawful residents.
These protections shall not create caste, hereditary political privilege, dual citizenship, territorial apartheid, or exclusionary sovereignty. Rights herein operate through ordinary property, easement, stewardship, and environmental law, with strict due process and anti-capture safeguards.
(Cross-references: Article II; Article III; Article III-B; Article IX; Article 0; Article XV.)

Section 1. Definitions and Scope

(a) Tribal Corporate Entity.
“Tribal Corporate Entity” means an Indigenous nation, tribe, or recognized people organized as a corporate entity under national corporate law, as recognized and permitted under Article III-B.

(b) Covered Uses.
“Covered Uses” means: subsistence and customary fishing, hunting, grazing, farming, gathering, and related land-management practices, including seasonal and ceremonial uses where consistent with public safety and stewardship.

(c) Covered Lands.
“Covered Lands” means:
(1) Tribal corporate lands held in fee, corporate title, trust-converted title, or other lawful corporate ownership form recognized under Article III-B and national property law; and
(2) Designated co-managed public lands subject to Section 3 of this Article.

(d) No Political Authority by Land-Use Right.
No land-use right recognized herein confers political authority, suffrage, office eligibility, or Civic Standing. Political authority is governed exclusively by Article III.

(e) Uniform Civil Rights.
All lawful residents retain equal civil rights under Article II. Nothing herein shall diminish civil rights, equal protection, due process, or access to courts.

Section 2. Tribal Corporate Land-Use Rights on Tribal Corporate Lands

(a) Baseline Rights.
On tribal corporate lands, Tribal Corporate Entities and their lawful beneficiaries may:
(1) fish, hunt, graze, and farm for subsistence, commerce, cultural continuity, or stewardship purposes;
(2) regulate ordinary access as a property holder may, consistent with Article II and Section 6 of this Article; and
(3) implement internal land-use rules that are viewpoint-neutral, non-discriminatory as to civil rights, and consistent with this Constitution.

(b) Public Safety and General Law.
Covered Uses remain subject to general criminal law, public safety law, and conservation law applicable to all persons, provided such law is:
(1) generally applicable and non-discriminatory;
(2) based on clear, site-specific evidence where it restricts customary practice;
(3) narrowly tailored to prevent imminent and specific harm; and
(4) subject to judicial review with due process.

(c) Stewardship Obligations.
Tribal corporate lands are subject to the same duty of stewardship as all lands under Article IX, including prohibitions on neglect, waste, soil depletion, and predatory exploitation, and the same protections against abusive enforcement.
Stewardship enforcement must respect Article II due process and takings protections.

Section 3. Co-Managed Public Lands and Priority-Use Framework

(a) Designation by Law; No Blanket Carve-Outs.
Law may designate specific public lands, waters, or ranges as co-managed areas where covered Indigenous customary use historically occurred, provided designation:
(1) is site-specific and publicly mapped;
(2) includes written findings of historic nexus and practical necessity;
(3) preserves one Constitution and one judiciary; and
(4) does not create exclusive sovereign territory.

(b) Priority Use Without Exclusion.
Within designated co-managed areas, law may grant Tribal Corporate Entities and their lawful beneficiaries a priority-use framework for Covered Uses, meaning:
(1) priority seasonal windows;
(2) priority allotments within sustainable limits; and/or
(3) priority access to permits where a permit system is constitutionally valid.
Priority use shall not constitute blanket exclusion of other lawful residents unless exclusion is necessary to prevent imminent and specific harm and is ordered by a court using the least restrictive means.

(c) Non-Discrimination and Equal Baseline Access.
All lawful residents may access public lands under general law. Priority-use frameworks must:
(1) remain viewpoint-neutral and not function as demographic engineering;
(2) preserve baseline access for non-tribal persons subject to stewardship;
(3) prohibit exclusive monopolization of public resources; and
(4) remain reviewable and adjustable to avoid ecological harm.

(d) Conservation Standard.
No restriction on general public access, and no allocation of exclusive priority beyond narrow windows or allotments, shall occur absent clear and convincing evidence that the restriction is necessary to prevent imminent and specific harm that cannot be mitigated by narrower means.

Section 4. Grazing and Range Rights Integration

(a) Harmonization with Article IX.
Where Article IX recognizes public grazing and commons use, Tribal Corporate Entities may participate in that commons under the same anti-capture principles and stewardship standards, and may also receive limited priority-use within co-managed areas under Section 3.

(b) No Exclusive Leasing Regime.
No priority-use framework may be implemented through discretionary permits or exclusive leases that function as barriers to access, entrench incumbent power, or suppress small-scale subsistence use, whether tribal or non-tribal.

(c) Evidence-Based Limits.
Where grazing practice causes material harm, the government bears the burden of demonstrating, by clear and site-specific evidence, that harm cannot be mitigated by reasonable, narrowly tailored conditions.

Section 5. Farming, Gathering, and Stewardship Easements

(a) Productive Use Encouraged.
Tribal Corporate Entities may farm, gather, and cultivate in ways consistent with long-term soil and watershed health, consistent with Article IX stewardship standards.

(b) Stewardship Easements.
Law may recognize stewardship easements on tribal corporate lands and co-managed areas to protect archeological sites, sacred sites, watershed corridors, wildlife corridors, and soil health, provided easements:
(1) are specific and recorded;
(2) impose the least restrictive means;
(3) include notice and opportunity to contest; and
(4) allow reasonable traditional use consistent with protection.

(c) Reciprocal Access Corridors.
Where feasible and safe, law should favor reciprocal access corridors (trails, right-of-way, waterways passage) that preserve general movement and continuity without forcing entry into culturally sensitive sites.

Section 6. Non-Exclusion, Anti-Caste, and Civil Rights Safeguards

(a) No Racial or Blood-Quantum Caste.
No law, policy, or corporate rule may create a racially segregated paradise, caste hierarchy, or hereditary civil-rights class. Civil rights remain uniform under Article II.

(b) Access Control Limited to Property and Cultural Sensitivity.
Tribal Corporate Entities may restrict entry to tribal corporate lands for the same reasons other private owners may, including prevention of crime and protection of sensitive rituals, sacred sites, or internal corporate meetings, provided restrictions:
(1) do not deny emergency access, lawful warrants, or due process;
(2) do not operate as public-accommodation discrimination where public accommodation law constitutionally applies; and
(3) do not convert public lands into exclusionary territory.

(c) No Dual Citizenship; No Separate Sovereignty.
Nothing in this Article creates dual citizenship, independent criminal or civil jurisdiction, or exemption from constitutional law, consistent with Article III-B.

(d) No Political Exclusion.
No priority-use framework under this Article may be conditioned on political belief, party affiliation, ideology, compelled speech, or compelled cultural assent.

(e) No Independent Police Power.
Nothing in this Article or in any tribal corporate charter shall be construed to grant any independent police power, power of arrest, detention authority, or criminal jurisdiction to any tribal entity or tribal corporate entity.
Trespass and other violations shall be addressed through ordinary civil remedies and through the constitutional judiciary and Republic law enforcement under general law, with full due process.
Private security may observe, document, and request departure, and may use only the same narrowly limited defensive force available to any private person under general law.
(f) Local Law Enforcement Permitted; Uniform Judiciary Required.
Nothing in this Article prohibits the formation of ordinary municipal, county, or state law-enforcement agencies that may be locally staffed, including predominantly by members of a tribe, provided such agencies operate under the unified constitutional criminal code, procedure, and judiciary of the Republic.
No law-enforcement body may claim separate sovereign criminal jurisdiction or submit cases to a parallel court system.

Section 7. Recordation, Transparency, and Anti-Predation

(a) Recordation of Designations and Rights.
All co-managed designations, priority windows, allotments, stewardship easements, and access corridors must be publicly recorded and mapped, with narrowly tailored redaction only for protection of sensitive archeological and sacred site locations.

(b) Anti-Predatory Encumbrance.
No contract, lease, bond, derivative, concession, management agreement, or financial instrument may encumber tribal land-use rights or co-managed priority rights in a manner that transfers effective control to non-tribal parties, extracts profit streams without fair market compensation, or engineers default to seize assets. Such instruments are void.

(c) Beneficiary Protection.
Where revenues or resource benefits flow from covered uses, governance shall operate for the benefit of lawful beneficiaries, with judicially auditable records sufficient to detect private enrichment or diversion.

Section 8. Enforcement and Remedies

(a) Standing.
Standing shall be construed broadly to include Tribal Corporate Entities, lawful beneficiaries, neighboring communities, downstream users, and civic organizations where demonstrable harm exists, consistent with Article IX.

(b) Judicial Forum and Due Process.
All disputes under this Article are subject to the constitutional judiciary. No separate or parallel court system is created. Injunctions, damages, restitution, and takings remedies remain available under Article II.

(c) Strict Scrutiny of Discriminatory Targeting.
Discriminatory taxation, special fees, licensing schemes, zoning, or indirect economic strangulation targeting tribal corporate covered uses are prohibited and shall be treated as unconstitutional takings and equal-protection violations, requiring full restitution and damages.

Section 9. Construction

(a) Against Exclusionary Sovereignty.
Ambiguities shall be resolved against the creation of caste, territorial apartheid, dual citizenship, or exclusionary sovereignty.

(b) In Favor of Stewardship and Equal Civil Rights.
Ambiguities shall be resolved in favor of stewardship, ecological responsibility, and equal civil rights under Article II, while preserving the practical ability of Indigenous communities to maintain customary covered uses and cultural continuity.

Section 10. Lock Designation

Pursuant to Article XV, this Article is designated as LOCK-PROTECTED.
No amendment, statute, executive action, judicial doctrine, or emergency declaration may dilute, suspend, reinterpret, or circumvent the non-exclusion safeguards, stewardship requirements, or due-process protections herein except through the highest procedural threshold and certification of non-diminishment.
